column5: 500ml bottle at Biggar Corn Exchange. Nutty brown with a moderate white head. Toffee aroma, flavour is caramel with some grassy notes. Not complex but still decent

Bottle. Clear ruby body with a thick beige head. Steady carbonation. Good lacing. Aroma of liquorice, brown sugar and digestive. Flavour of coffee and nuts. Thin to medium body with a smooth texture. Soft fizz. Much better than previous reviews suggest. The older reviews are from years ago; is this a new recipe?
Bottle. Dark copper colour. Malty; light grainy malts, caramel, nuts. Fruity; slight fruits, raisins. Mild grassy hops. Light hoppy bitterness in the finish. Rather thin. (2008)

Bottle shared at the 2015 edition of the chriso Pre-GBBF tasting - London. Cheers! Pours clear golden-brown with a light, creamy tan head. The nose holds old grains and plastic. Light sweet flavour, with more notes of plastic, light toffee, grains. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sweet finish, with some toasted grains and brown sugar. Eh, not great.
Bottle at Chris and Ruth’s Shindig 2015. Clear deep amber/copper beer with a decent head. Malty vinous aroma, caramel, raisins, fig notes. Malty dusty caramel flavor, raisins, some figs.
Bottle from Booths, Media City. Copper-amber with a thin head. Bitter with a light bitterness, and a nice light caramel sweetness in both aroma and taste.
Bottle from coop. Dissipatng head. Dark golden brown colour. Sweet aroma. Dry going down.

500ml bottle from Co-Op on the Isle of Arran. Pours copper red with a bubbly head which calms down to a small, off white layer of froth. Smells quite earthy, malty and fruity. Tastes initially quite crisp, green apple with a toffee finish. Gets more complex as it goes down and I’m getting other fruits of the darker kind but a sort of caramel, apple dessert taste is never far away. I have to be honest, this started off a bit disappointing but by the bottom of the glass I’m desperate for more. Lovely.
"A bitter-sweet ale, an immediately satisfying after-taste". Dark brown colour, strong toast but pleasant malt & hop aroma, good roasty & heavy beer taste. Easy drinking for a dark beer.
500ml bottle, a dark gold with s slim light head, faintly sweet hoppy aroma, as for taste a sweet light fruity mild hops and undemanding bitter finish. Fair enough as a mainstream ale.

Highly enjoyable! This one is amber and pours a very small, short-lived head - perfect for the style. You get a pretty profound malty aroma with some caramel and vanilla, apples and pears, whiskey and just a minuscule hint of vinegar. On the tongue, I detect quite assertive bitterness - more than usual for the style and nearly as much as many ESBs can boast. This beer is juicey, quaffable, not too thin. A slightly floral finish even adds some complexity. My overall verdict: an excellent 'pub-style' pint, proving that standard bitters can be as good as many of their more alcoholic cousins.
Ausgeglichener Hopfen und Malzgeschmack, keine breite Geschmackspalette, klassisches Pale Ale Aroma. Trockenfrucht und leichte Säure. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma: Fruity and malty sweet with hay. Flavour: Fruity sweet with slight caramel and little fruity bitterness. Colour: Golden amber with a white head. From: Bottle @ Nemlig.com Sept. 2017.

Bottle from the Caley Picture House. Appearance - golden with a nice fluffy head. Nose - lemon and malted barley. A bit shandy-like. Taste - more lemon barley water, but astringent malt this time. Palate - light bodied and dry astringent middle and finish. Overall - ok on the nose but a bit hard going on the taste.

Bottle. As "Marks & Spencer Organic Ale". Light golden in colour. Hoppy; very earthy hops, peppery. Fruity; tangy, orange and grapefruit citrus. Sweet malty; caramel and toffee. Well balanced; bitter earthy hops over sweet malts. Smooth bitter finish. Not bad. Drinkable. (2008)
Bottle at the 1780. Pours clear pale amber, nose is cereal, floral, sweet toffee, taste is dry, sweet, cereal, little sickly.

500ml room temperature bottle poured into tulip glass. Light amber colour. Small lasting head and lacing. Packs a bit of a punch and doesn’t hide it’s 6%ABV. Alcohol is very noticeable but not in an off putting way.
"Golden colour, clean full malt flavour and crisp hop aftertaste". Aroma slightly smelly socks. Taste citrus, refreshing but also dry and bit off.

500ml bottle shared at home. Pours hazy, cloudy even, yellow with a thin white head. Biscuit and flowery aromas, honey. Tastes boozier than many beers stronger than this. Light body and thin texture. no noticeable hop bitterness. OK, but a bit boring.
Bottle from Aldi a clear deep golden colour ale with a some honey carmel and malt overly sweet making and flowery spoiling it a bit
500ml bottle from Tesco, Ayr - clear golden straw, medium white head, sweet malty aroma, caramel, honey, fruity, floral, sweet, oily texture
Honey nute in taste, bitter palate. White foam, medium thick, stays for 3 minutes. Dark-golden colour. Not a bad beer.

Aroma: Honey and unripe tropical fruit notes. Subtle hint of sauvignon blanc. Appearance: Clear golden body with a huge white head that slowly fades. Light carbonation. Nice sticky lacing. Taste: The fruity flavours are verging on sour. Quite tangy. Noticeable boozy taste for its 6% ABV. Palate: Medium body with a dry, mouth-puckering mouthfeel. Gentle carbonation fizz. Overall: Average at best. No uniqueness of flavour. In a word: dull.
Bottle@home (0,5l) Broker white head, shrinking but stays. Color copper. Aroma malt, hops, floral. Taste hops, malt, some bitter, CO2. Palate silken, some bitter, lasting. Overall worth trying
From old tasting notes. Bright yellow gold color with a creamy beige head. Soft fruity ale-like nose. Moderately hoppy flavor is balanced by a pleasant sweet maltiness.

Geary’s American Ale pour to a beautiful, bright, pale golden color with a nice white head, and a good bit of carbonation. The nose is very fragrant with zesty/cirtic hop aromas, some nice pale malt aroma, and earthy aroma from the distinctive Ringwood yeast used in the brewing of Geary’s beers. The palate is firm with a good base of pale and biscuit malt flavors. This is coupled with a subtle back drop of buttery flavor, another by product of the Ringwood yeast strain. Geary’s American Ale finishes with a short, dry, mild hop bitterness that lingers. This is an outstanding golden ale, with a nice balance of hop and malt character. This beer is a natural with sea food, and makes the perfect foil for a boiled Maine lobster with drawn butter. This beer is hard to find outside of Maine, and New England, but is one well worth looking for. Love the patriotic lobster with the American flag on the label as well.
Nice citrussy floral aroma. Very thin palate and way too carbonated. Unpleasantly sour.
disapointed with this beer. strong citrus sweet aroma. Beer is hazy orange, little head. Initial sour taste on the palate, light watery no real body, little finish.

Aroma was overbearingly hoppy. I think they used a few too many aroma hops. This also loses some points for having chill haze (first I've ever seen in a commercial brew). It went uphill from there though, tasting quite nicely hopped (not overpowering), and finished well. Short lasting, hoppy aftertaste.

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: This is one of those IPA that is almost perfect. Well balanced hop & malt flavors, not really bitter at all. Pours a medium head and nice amber color. A citrus and floral hop flavor. Excellent beer.

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: Hate to say bad things but this one is terrible. Skunky earthy bitterness that leaves an awful taste

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: Can in Seattle. Darker brown-orange with some cloudiness, and a thin lingering cream head. Nose with hints of butterscotch and grain, hard to pick out the hops. Old school, quite antiquated body with fruity grain and modest coating bitterness. Orange notes in there, as well as earthy grass. Not terrible, but terribly boring.

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: Can from WW on 45. Hazy opaque orange, dull and brownish, oily-soapy beige head. Nose powerful orange and grapefruit, taste medium-bitter and similarly sweet, fullish body with spicy dough toward the end, some booze creeping in, briefly floral, bit sticky with some mild malt depth, bright citrus and juice top. Like it more and more with every sip! Tasty, juicy, approachable, repeatable. [2018.05.28: 3.5]

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: With A on the patio on Christmas Day, pours a dark rusty copper pour with an ephemeral beige head. Nose is hoppy citrus with pine and refin. Taste is hoppy, with softer citrus and pine. Drinkabke. Finishes on dry , crisp moderately long citrus mild hoppy notes Quaff Score 7 / 10

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: The ad is on the money! Perfectly communicated. So good. I could flow for days on this brewski. Just nice. The malt & hops mix pleasant on stomach. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle at Imazato. Dark amber, cloudy, with lace. Nose of caramel, pine, resin, some citrus. Bready, toasty malt flavor, some caramel, lots fo pine. Old school. Ok..

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: 12oz bottle (courtesy of Headbanger) poured into a Shaker at 40°. Color is a hazy gold with good carbonation and a rocky white head. Aroma is hoppy with a back note of malt. It has a medium body with a crisp mouth feel. Flavor is malt, a slight fruitiness, then a nice bitter kick. After taste is more bitterness and hop spice that gives white pepper. Overall it’s a good IPA, well balanced and tasty, but nothing special.

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: 12 oz bottle. Scent is of olives, yet not unappealing. Definitely a heavy caramel hit followed by earthy citrus and lingering bitterness. I’m finding this one enjoyable but just a bit above average.

column1: Fish Tale Organic India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle from World Beer Market (Sake no Taniguchi). Sweet malty caramel nose, light citrus. Clear gold/copper color, frothy head which descends into lines of thin cirrus clouds. Hard hit of caramel at first, then a soft saggy pillow of bittering. The malt seems musty and earthy. Medium-heavy body. Perfunctory nose. Big malty flavors but, as above, not completely pleasant.

Seems more like a pale ale to me than an amber, but could just be a lighter-hoppy amber. Smooth feel, pretty crisp, decent flavor....not bad for my first sample from Fish Tale. Something light for my warm-up drink before my drive to Superbowl Party! Would pair good with different kinds of food too. Good beer that I would get again, figuring I only sampled one to try. If you like beer (pale ales or IPAs) don't even bother reading the bad ratings, as there is nothing wrong with this one.... Water, barley, and hops.....that's it....how bad can it be?
Total Wine Fairfax bottle: pours dark amber with a white head. Aroma is light caramel and toast. Taste is lightly bitter, sort of sweet and rather malty. Meh.

Fish Tale Organic Amber Ale 5% Keeping on from the Naparbier ZZ Amber this is a slightly darker red with a thicker beige head of foam that has substantially more staying power. The aroma is less hoppy and more earthy caramel. Medium bodied and a touch raspy in terms of carbonation. The taste is malt-forward with caramel, cocoa, tobacco leaf and some sweet citrus thrown in for good measure. It kind of reminds me of an English Ale though I suspect this bottle may be roughly a year old... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Total Wine, Gainesville. Pours amber with a small soft off-white head. Aroma of caramel, soap, light fruit. Flavor is fruity caramel, sugar, grass. More sugar than anything else. Nothing to seek out here.

Lovely amber hue, ok head. Gentle hop aroma melds well with medium crystal malts. The body is also well balanced between easy hoppyness, and slightly sweet crystal malts with a touch of chewyness. This one has a good body too it and I think the sum amounts to more than the parts. A really solid amber.
A quality amber. Nice dry start with a lightly sweet finish. Not too hoppy with light malt. Bottle.

Pours a slightly hazy sparkling amber-orange with a small off-white head. Very sweet aroma of fruit and sugar. Taste is also quite sweet and sugary with some caramel malt, grain, breadiness and very mild hops. Thin bodied.

12 oz. brown bottle into a halice A: Very hazy murky dirty tawny pond water color. Small 1/4" haed quickly rose and fell leaving spotty lacing down the glass. S: Malty smell with earthy hops blending nicely with toffee. Slightly nutty. T: Caramel malt flavor with toasty bread and a thin sweetness. I do still get and like the earthy hallertau flavor. Tastes kind of watery overall. Not very complex but the beer is very cold. The slight nuttiness from the nose opens up a bit as it warms.Also a faint piney note but too little too late flavorwise to save this from mediocrity. M: Thin feel and slightly lacking in carbonation, however the sweet note lingers a bit. O: Really wanted to get into this since it’s certified organic, but nothing wows me here. Reminds me a bit of Bell’s Amber but not as good. The watery feel is a bit of a turnoff.
Bottle - slight malt flavor with no bitterness. Carmel flavor. Typical Amber style beer.

On tap at Fish Tale Brewpub, pours a filthy orange amber with a small white head. Aroma is nearly non-existent, with light bready notes and very subtle hops. Flavour is along the same lines, with dry bready malts and light hops. Boring incarnate - competent but nothing to this.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: On tap - pretty decent beer overall. nothing to exciting but could have a few.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Unique pale ale. The salmon name doesn't fit. Guess I want a smoked salmon aroma lol. Malty, & a lingering mild sweetness. Lemony non sour, apricotish. Pleasant slight hop flow mix. Probably too sweet for me, but much respect to this brewski! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Popped open the bottle from Total Wine, South Richmond and it appeared to be smoking. Obviously it wasn’t, but it was interesting nonetheless. Pours amber with a soft beige head. Aroma is floral hops, citrus, light soap. Flavor is floral hops, citrus, a bit of white bread, some minor grass, barley. Tingly on the tongue. Average at best. Boring at worst.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Mmmm, this is good and refreshing. It’s opaque copper and has a pure frothy head. Itsmells cool and flavorful, crisp malt, forward bite and balanced medium malt flavor with a light sweet finish. I think it’s the best organic I’ve had but I’ll have to check the ratings to be aure.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Orange peel nose, a little toe jam. Cloudy orange, thin yellow head, nice lace. Orange peel, mild DMS. Lilly finish. Light body, moderate carbonation.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Bottle from Total Wine in Gainesville, VA Aroma: bread, floral, citrus, Appearance: clear golden with a white head Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, Palate: medium body, sticky, average carbonation, bitter finish Tasty

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Has a pleasant citrus hop aroma. Taste is a tad citrus hops with a biscuit malt presence. Tingly slight bitter aftertaste. Not shabby.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Bottle from Wegmans. Pours hazy dark straw with off-white head. Nose is piney hopcitrus, malt. Tastes hoppy, citric, with caramel malt notes, smooth mouthfeel, and a decent finish.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Poured from the 12oz bottle into a shaker glass. Bright amber color with a thin cream colored head. Aroma is sweet and grainy with some citrusy hops. Flavor is mildly sweet and bready with some light floral and citrusy hop notes. Medium bodied. Nothing special but a decent pale and very drinkable.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Wild Salmon Pale Ale
column5: Appearance: pours with a small beige head that dissipates quickly, the beer is a bronze color, hazy Aroma: caramel, faint Taste: moderate bitterness, minimal pale malt background, Palate: lively carbonation, light mouthfeel, slight bitter aftertaste Overall: has a hallow feel to it that I’m not too fond of, not bad though, drinks like a light beer with a bit more flavor ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
smooth,full,creamy and flavorful. beery and luscious. sweet and with good cocoa,a touch of vanilla and a bit of roast. full flavorful malt presence and light scratchy flavorful hop. nice.
Very dark pour. Lightly roasted with good chocolate notes and some earth. Medium bodied. Dry finish. Some bitterness throughout. Nice porter.

Dark cola-colored beer with a thin foamy beige head that disappears quickly. Nose of light balsamic, semi-sweet cocoa, and Dr. Pepper. Flavor is slightly dryer than the aroma with unsweetened coffee, dark chocolate, a bit of smoke, and leather finished with a slightly tangy bitterness. Pretty good, if a little chalky.
12oz bottle pours a cola brown with some fluffy, white head. Nose has chocolate, molasses, smoke. Flavor is the same, cold smoke, bread, meaty, rye. Watery finish. Didn't hate it.
Black color small white head. Aroma is smokey, roasted w/ some chocolate. Flavor is roasted coffee w/ some chocolate and caramel help to lend a bit of depth.

On tap at Baileys. Pours a dark brown color with a medium off-white head. The aroma is big lactose, chocolate and ash. The flavor is more sweet and dark chocolates, some ash, big lactose sugars, a bit of metallic coffee. Very good.

Draught at the brewpub in Everett Dark brown color, almost black. Round mouthfeel, but the aroma and flavor is a bit on the roasty side for a Porter, although it has some chocolate; ordinary bitterness. Balanced and flawless.

Draft at Olympia brewpub last month. Pours dark, opaque with creamy head. Sweet chocolate nose. Taste: chocolate, roast, cola. Moderately sweet, finish is light roast bitterness. On the sweet side for a porter. Light+ body, oily texture.
On tap at the brewpub. Dark brown pour with a kaki head. Dark Roasted malt aromas, taste follows suit with a mild bitter chocolate finish. Some expresso low lights. Average body and mouthfeel.
Dark Brown colour With a beige head. Aroma is licorice, coffee, malt, hop, chocolate. Flavour is licorice, coffee, roasted malt, hop, chocolate. Medium body. Nice beer.
on tap-pours a white head and amber color. Aroma is citrus/cascade hops, secondary medium malt. Taste is nice, mild citrus /cascade hops with a bite, secondary medium malt. OK effervescence.

Seventh stop during the ABA Beer Tour ’07 in Olympia, Washington. Sampled on tap at the Fish Brewing brewpub. Pours a hazy medium amber brew with a very light white head that dissipates to a bubbly ring. Aroma of pine and grassy hops with some roasted nut scents and caramel malt. Taste is medium bodied, lightly carbonated with a bitter caramel flavor. FInish is a lingering bitter aftertaste with some caramel malt flavor. A little heavy on the bitterness for a Pale Ale, but a terrific brew.
[Tap - Fish Bowl] A great Pale ale with a ton of hops are you sure this is not an IPA? Wow what a great ale. This is not for the novice beer drinker. A great beer.

This was a great little pale, very light bodied, with some nutty maltiness, intermingled with some citrus hop flavor. Very well balanced, one of the btter APAs, I have tried in awhile, a refreshing surprise.

Tap. Hazy, light amber in color with a decent white head. Good lacing. Light citrus aroma with a sweet malt presence. Decent body. Malt and hop balance nicely with hop bitterness taking the lead in the finish. Decent.

(Draft: Fishbowl Brewpub in Olympia, WA) Hoppy, citrusy nose is pretty assertive for an amber ale, but welcome to the Pacific Northwest, I guess. The hoppiness has considerable presence in the flavor as well, easily balancing out the sweet, caramely, lightly roasty malts. Solid, medium body, well-carbonated, with a long-lasting finish. Clear, coppery body, but the off-white head is very small, fading to a miniscule rim before you know it, though a few strands of lace are left on the glass. Still just an amber ale, but quite flavorful and well-balanced for the style, and it doesn’t taste like cheap, sweet beer. Decent.

(draft) Clear amber body with beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, light caramel. Taste is mild sweet, grapefruit, and more grapefruit. Medium body, some chewiness. Possibly the hoppiest APA I’ve ever had (not that that’s a bad thing).
Ruby, mahogany color with white head & a bit of lacing. The aroma is fruity with light PNW hops. Flavor has some crystal malt & sweetness but rounds out to the hops & some tart 2-row. Finishes hoppy.
Cloudy brown,lasting beige head. Good fresh hop nose. Hop flavor with medium strength lasting hop finish
Drinkable, with a nice malt nose and a bit of hops. A step up from their "Lite" styles, but just barely.
Pours a reddish brown. Sweet caramel/roasty aroma. Roast malt/chocolate flavor with a touch of fruit and great hops.

Bottle from backlog notes. Pours dark brown in color with some reddish highlights and large tan head. The aroma and flavor had caramel, toasted grainy malts, nuts, and dark chocolate, almonds, dark fruits, red grapes, a splash of vanilla, good mouthfeel, alcohol is slightly warming. This was a very solid doppelbock and one that I should revisit again.

650ml bottle pours a reddish brown color with a 2 finger light beige head that leaves some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is chocolate and citrus with some floral notes and some woody notes as well. Taste is chocolately malty and dark fruity sweetness with some light roasted bitterness and mild hop bitterness in the finish. Flavors are very well balanced and carbonation is adequate with a medium body. One of my favorite doppelbocks, right up there with Celebrator.

Pours reddish brown with a frothy tan head. Nose is caramel malt, chocolate, dark fruits (raisin, plum, dates), slight cherry, and hints of slight hops. The taste is very similar but seems muddled. Great mouthfeel, slightly watery though. Great doppelbock.

Great colour, deep reddish brown. Thick beige head. Fantastic aroma, deep and malty. Caramel, Chocolate, Dark fruit. Smells great. Fantastic flavour. This is a great beer. Smooth and malty. Very complex. much of the aroma comes through in the palate. It is a little hot, the alcohol does come through. All in all I think this is a fantastic beer. A great dopplebock

Quite a nice, sweet, dark aroma, very thick. A bit of head on pour, lacing sticks around. Fairly dark. Thick, sweet, creamy, a bit of smokiness in there. Thick, complex and quite tasty. Its much thicker and flavourful that I thought it would be. I would benefit from bottle conditioning.

Bottle. Huge thanks to hobbersr for the share! Pours reddish-brown, with a very thin tan head, not persistent, poor lacing. Nose is rich, malty, and roasty, with the notes from the Merlot barrel really coming through; tight berries and acid play on top of the roast. Flavor is acid and berries, perfectly balanced by the roast and malt sweetness. This beer is drier than most Doppelbocks, but deliciously so! This has to be an older bottle, maybe 2 or 3 years old.

Fish Brewing Company--Detonator Doppelbock Reel Lager--Reel Ales Series--2008 Release--22 oz. Bottle--10.00% ABV--44 IBU’s. (4.5 / 5.0) Doppelbock--Thin lacy off white head. Clear dark bronze black color. Mild hop toffee toasted mild malt fruit chocolate smoke front. Creamy smooth rich toffee mellow sweet crusty malty toasted body. Smooth cloying burnt malt mild hop spice not hot dry end. Big Easy Doppel! Sampled 1/3/2009. $9.99 Each. Fish Brewing Company--Detonator Doppelbock Lager--Oak Aged--2004 Release--12 oz. Bottle--8.00% ABV--25 IBU’s? (4.5 / 5.0) Doppelbock--Aged in Oak. Mild lacy head. Clear dark red bronze black color. Mild hop rich malty front. Very smooth rich semi sweet toasted creamy light chocolate oak nut body. Clean mild hop and hot EtOH end. Sampled 6/29/2004.

Bottle pours very very dark brown/black with very little light passing through. A smell head of foam slowly fades away to a rich malty sweet nose of chocolate, biscuit, and wood. Medium rich body. Flavors follow the nose and and layer of complexity gives way to a nice dry finish. I read the description and really didn’t get any merlot notes in the nose or taste. The malty overtones must have been too much for it. Its a solid beer.

22 oz bottle purchased at Malt and Vine in Redmond, Washington. Pour is deep dark brown with a one inch tan head. Thick lacing left behind on the glass. Aroma of grassy tobacco and sweet dark fruit and roastiness. The wood is present, though subdued. Nice integrated nose. Taste is the roasty dark fruit sweetness right away, turning to the grassy hay tobacco in the finish. Palate is light medium, highish carb - making this quite easy drinking (perhaps too easy - shocked to see this is 10% per the label!). Alcohol mildly present after it had warmed. Well made and tasty, nice stuff.

Fish Brewing Company--Trout Stout--2001 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) Stout--Clear rich black red color. Medium tan head and lace. Mild roasted front. Slightly creamy smooth semi sweet roasted cherry caramel body. Drinkable balanced richness. Smooth lingering roasted end. Mild hops. Sampled 8/3/2001. Fish Brewing Company--Trout Stout Seasonal Ale. 2002 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Stout--Thick dark black color. Mild dark espresso light lace head. Roasted mild chocolate espresso floral hop front. Creamy crusty smooth rich roasted mild sweet cocoa fruit body. Tangy mild earthy hop end. Mild. Sampled 1/7/2003.

On Tap at the Fishbowl. Deep black with a thin coa coa colored head. Big aweet chocolate aroma. Sweet rosted flavoe...thin and lacking much backbone. Leathery coffee trailer. Lightlyhopped. Kindofalightweight,but sessionable.

Bottle. (Remembered from past tastings) A friend of mine brought this to me from the brewery originally started by his brother. Yes I am biased here. I don’t remember much other than both my friend and his brother were first rate home brewers and I liked everything they brewed so gotta score this respectfully. I’m happy to see that so many years later this brewery lives on.

Draft at the brewpub. Black. Very light rim of burnt tan. Nice roasty coffeeish nose. Medium body, a little watery in spots. Nice coffee and roast come through in a big way on the mid-palate; there’s a pronounced bite to this one. Lightly coffee-sour and peppery hop finish.

Pint - Fish Brew Pub - Olympia, WA Aroma – Nice dark malt aroma with lots of coffee and light chocolate. Appearance – Dark Black color, light head and clear well if you had a miners hat it would be clear. Dark as Hell… Flavor – Rich dark malt flavors, great coffee in the mix and a light bitter chocolate. Palate – Great Mouthfeel, good stout thick texture love the dry finish. Overall – This beer will put hair on your toe nails. The deep rich flavors are a beer lovers dream. Great flavors the coffee is rich and deep I loved it.

on tap-pours a thin tan head and black color. Aroma is coffee, dark malt-licorice, oatmeal. A bit astringent. Taste is coffee, dark malt-licorice, oatmeal, a bit astringent from the hops. Not my style but nice. OK carbonation.

Name: Trout Stout Date: 10/12/1996 Mode: Firkin Source: Brewfest, Newport, OR black, scant frothy head, slight roasted aroma, smooth roasted flavor with a touch of chocolate in a otherwise dry finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Score: **+/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
On Tap (cask) at Fishbowl Brewpub Olympia WA, pours out a nice black topped with a tan head. Some nice mix of malt and sweet with a little smoke.

Pours a very liduidy luscious dark brownish black and a smooth dark brown head. The nose is all chocolate, with just a hint of smokiness and espresso. Roasty maltiness, with a lot of milk chocolate and cocoa, welll balanced acidity, with a nice bit of hoppiness in the finish.
Very dark colour with very dark head. Rich, chocolatey aroma. Thick body with chocolate, slight metal, slight roast. Smooth and rich.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: Draught @ the brewpub. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a malty hoppy caramel aroma. Sweetish slightly toasted malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a malty hoppy caramel finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: I tend to like malty beers, so this one was right down my alley. .Tried while on a business trip to Olympia. I got to try 3-4 beers and their perry, but would like to sample a few more.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Slightly hazy burnished medium copper with slim tan rim. Very mild toasty nose. Medium body, carb’s almost lively. Toast, biscuit, and a little bit of herbal resin on the mid-palate. Brief toasty finish.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: on tap-pours an off white head and amber color. Aroma is mild medium malt. Taste is mild medium malt-caramel, secondary hops with some bite. Kind of light body.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: On tap at the Fishbowl Pub. Medium-dark clear amber color. Nice head gives off a very pleasant sweet, grass nose. I love the malt profile, but this might have benefited from just a skosh more hops. I thought it had been a while since I’d last seen 50 Fathoms, and I guess I was right. A pleasure to sample it again.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: Bright amber. Aroma is caramelly, earthy, grassy, slightly toasty. Buttery, footy taste leads to a pleasing hop signature. I can see where they’re trying to go with this big English yeast character but it’s not a place I want to go.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: Tap - Fish Brew Pub Funny I just had this last night on tap so it must have came out of retirement. A great ESB. Full of flavor. Bitter and very full of Hops. This was a great beer. Orange in color and a great haed. The malts where flavorful and the hops where stong. Great Beer.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: Cask: Golden hazy aurburn color with a nice thick bubbly head that looks very cask and a nice sheet of lacing down the glass. The aroma is hoppy and mild; fruity and floral. The flavor is mildly bitter with a slightly acidic and bitter mouthfeel. The malts are fairly dominate but the low gravity really lets the hop bitterness creep through. Smooth barely carbonated finish, very easy drinking, not bad.

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: Cask : Cloudy brown,off white head. Fruit nose, fruity malt taste. Lasting mild hop finish. Underhopped for the style

column1: Fish Tale 50 Fathoms Extra Special Bitter
column5: A decent beer, that has a good hop bite and generous malts, Fresh and crisp.

Bottle. (Remembered from past tastings) A friend of mine brought this to me from the brewery originally started by his brother. Yes I am biased here. I don’t remember much other than both my friend and his brother were first rate home brewers and I liked everything they brewed so gotta score this respectfully. I’m happy to see that so many years later this brewery lives on.

Cask pour @ the brewery. Clear amber with a frothy head. Nice floral hoppy aroma. Medium body with a very smooth mouthfeel. Very perfumy, pungent floral hop flavors with a lightly sweet caramel malt. A great cask brew.
Light malt nose with light balanced malt/hop flavor. an easy drinking beer which is more of an entry level beer.Nothing unpleasant, just nothing special.
So So beer, not hearty enough for me, I like'em strong and hop laden. This beer while drinkable is for the "Lite" lovers.

Bottle. (Remembered from past tastings) A friend of mine brought this to me from the brewery originally started by his brother. Yes I am biased here. I don’t remember much other than both my friend and his brother were first rate home brewers and I liked everything they brewed so gotta score this respectfully. I’m happy to see that so many years later this brewery lives on.

Draught @ the brewpub. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma with some nutty hints. Roasted malty caramel and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty caramel finish with some hints of chocolate.
on tap-pours a light tan head and mahogany color. Aroma is medium/dark malt-caramel, medium fruit, some nutty. Taste is medium/dark malt-caramel, medium fruit, some nutty. Mild carbonation.
Tap - Brewery Dark Brown in color with a thin head. Has a deep rich malt flavor with a nice chocolate nutty finish. This was a decent brew.
The return of a long-dead Fish brew, sampled at the Fishbowl. Chestnut colour. Slightly hazy. The aroma is very hazelnutty. Toast, light chocolate. Good body and sugars. Fairly well-made brown.
Brown in color with a light tan head. Light toasted malt nose. Malt flavor with a few hops. Nothing special.
Adequate brown ale with some nice malts and a bit of hops, not a big hit with me.

What results from all of this is a hearty festival ale with a lightly sweet malt flavor balanced by the subtle spicy quality of Ultra hops. Ist das eine wunderbier? Ja, das ist ein wunderbier! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

"Man, I’ve tried more new marzens this year than I thought was going to be possible, but I’ve yet to find one that really stood out (save for the german classics I’ve had in year’s past, and outliers like Bells and Great Lakes that I couldn’t get this year). Still no Surly Fest. :( Anywho, dark orange pour. Mild earthy hops, a little bready (toast) and a good amount of caramel. A little simple and not wuite as robust as I’d hoped. Another ok beer."

On tap 5 oz. sample at Judges' Bench in Ellicott City, MD. Clear, bright golden medium amber with a small off-white head and sparse lacing. Aroma of heavy malt, spice, brown bread, caramel and light hops. Taste of heavy malt, spice, brown bread, caramel, pepper and light hops. Medium body and medium/low carbonization. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cloudy gold with lasting head. Malt nose, medium malt taste. Laced with faint hops. Good lace
I'm quite fond of Marzens as a style. Rich and robust, large malt front and a good bit of hops at the finish, full bodied and meant for serious beer drinkers.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: Quite strong and with character but still a little thin. AMberish and with nice barley aroma.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: 12 ounce bottle from Uptown. Pours a golden hue with a large white head. A big malty light citrus nose. Sweet base, some oxidation (this must be from winter 2016). some spicy hops, honey. Very smooth. Flavorful.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: Winter Beer Fest 2016, Seattle. Thick creamy head, mostly clear orange-gold. Deep, wet fruity hop. Resin hops. Cool balanced alc. Well put together. Ginger candy. Nice.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: 12 oz bottle, big surprise no date, being a winter beer, it isn’t fresh that’s for sure- Pours hazy orange with a medium creamy white head. Aroma is dirty malt, biscuity, lemon, moderately sweet. The taste is a balanced IPA, grassy, sweet with an underlying bitterness, less lemon but there still. Not bad, although i’m sure it would have been better 3 or more months ago.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: Nice oatmeal stout. Black with a light tan head. The aroma is roast malt and a hint of chocolate. The flavor is roast malt. Very creamy and easy going down.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: a double IPA; amber color; nice, earthy, floral hop aroma; great hoppy flavor;citrusy hops with tropical fruit notes; medium bodied caramel malt base

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: Fish Tale’s Winterfish from Ezo Beer is a 7.5% IPA which is a distinctly US West Coast take on a Winter/Christmas beer. It pours a beautiful orange Amber with a filmy beige head and a tropical fruit hop bouquet - I get mango, papaya and guava. Not evoking winter but it does make me think oishisou. Medium bodied this is quite bitter pine resin, some fruits and malt sweetness. Nice.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: Draft - Light citrus and a bit of pith. Clear gold with a decent white head. Pithy citrus hops, light caramel sweetness and a dry finish.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: On tap at Fish Tale, pours a clear orange with a small white head. Aroma brings out light piney and resinous hops, not much else. Flavour is well-balanced, with piney and resinous hops, some fruitiness and dry caramel malts to back. Good balance and depth. Nice beer.

column1: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale
column5: 12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, December month notched with no year for dating. Pours moderately hazy/cloudy bright orange color with a 1 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of grapefruit, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, floral, grass, caramel, honey, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance of citrus/pine hops and moderate dark/bready malt sweetness; with solid strength. Taste of grapefruit, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, floral, grass, caramel, honey, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Fair amount of pine/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, lemon/orange zest, pine, caramel, honey, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice balance and robustness of citrus/pine hops and moderate dark/bready malt sweetness; with a good malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth, fairly sticky, and lightly creamy mouthfeel that is good. Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is a nice IPA. All around good balance of citrus/pine hops and moderate dark/bready malt sweetness; and very smooth to drink. It is at least a year old in age, but still a nicely enjoyable offering as it stands now.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: A: Murky dark red/brown coloured N: Grapes, figs, toffee T: Grapes, toffee, vinous, zest O: Past its prime and very vinous. Fun!

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: Bottle courtesy of hackobock. Pours hazy reddish brown with a small tan head that leaves some spotty trace on the glass while dissiapting, Smell is malty and fruity with dark bread, caramel, vanilla fudge, moist wood, dark grapes, raisins, prunes, leather, hay, oxidized red wine and hints of alcohol. Taste is slightly sweet, tiny bitter, slightly sour, malty and fruity. Mouthfeel is round, slightly dry, slightly tart, tiny boozy and medium to full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, sour and malty. Oxidized and way past its prime but still a very fun beer to try.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: May 28, 2016. Bottled November 2002, received in a trade, thanks! Cloudy amber with a small tan head. Aroma is sweet toffee, figs, some grape skins, some oxidized notes of sherry, cardboard. Taste is light to medium sweet, very light tartness, some vinous notes with a slight oxidized finish with grapes, sherry. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Held up alright, quite vinous.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: Bottle at Wailin Whales in Linus apartment 160528. Hazy amber beer with a decent beige head. Malty fruity aroma, caramel, toffee, grapes, raisins, woody notes. Fruity woody flavor, grapes, citrus, woody notes, some warming alcohol. Quite ok.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: Pours a dark golden brown with fluffy head. Aromas of dark malts, hops, and light bourbon. Flavors of sweet malts, hops, and nice bourbon notes.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: Bottle. Pours reddish amber white head. Nose/taste of merlot, oak, grape syrup, caramel, toffee and oak. Medium-full body.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: Bottle. Ruby brown pour with tan head. Some bourbon, oak, and sweet malt. Dark sweet malts, spice, barrel and dark tones.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: Bottle shared at Borefts beer festival day 1 26/09/2014. Thanks to fonefan for shared this one. Hazed dark orange coloured pour with a sticky off white head. Aroma is mint, caramel, toffee malts. Some age on the nose as well. Flavour is composed of caramel and toffee malts, mint and some hot alcohol. Palate is sweet and full bodied. Held up pretty well.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: 26th September 2014 Borefts VI. Bottle. Thanks to Fonefan for this blast from the past. Very hazy deep amber beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is light and smooth. Modest fine carbonation. Smooth malts, sweet tangy fruits, Sweet cognac. Dried fruits. Very mild spice. Light semi dry finish. Nice, has lasted well.

column1: Fish Tale Leviathan Barleywine - Barrel Aged
column5: Bottle shared at BBF 6, 26/09/14. Murky chestnut brown meets dark orange with a moderate off white covering. Nose is dark fruit rinds, spice, fruit cake, brown sugars, light roast. Taste comprises sweetish licks, toffee, toasted brown sugar, fruit loaf, spice. Medium + body, fine carboantion, lightly warming booze in the close. Ok barley wine but far from the great the rating on this one suggest it is!
Tap at Cap Tap. Pours translucent gold with a white head. Apricot aroma. Med minus body. Flavor is definitely apricot. Otherwise not too exciting. Nice for a fruity wheat beer.
On tap at the brewery. STRONG apricot smell and taste makes this beer refreshing.

Serving type: growler - Aroma - Smelled or wheat, slight citrus and apricot. A-Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a white head that did not last long and very little lacing. T/P - Taste of standard American wheat beer with an after taste of apricot. Very light carbonation. This beer is very crisp and light. O- This I very drinkable. I could easily drink a whole growler of this, especially on a hot summer day.
Not much of an aroma. Pyramid apricot ale has a better apricot taste but this one is good on a hot day Revere Stryker dog!

Pours cloudy golden orange, strong apricot aroma, very nice. Crisp and refreshing with strong wheat, and apricot flavor. Not a bad beer, they served these at the ski resort I worked at for 8 years and it was my customary "after a long day" beer thanks to its crisp refreshing nature.

Tap @Brewpub. Pours hazy light golden with a small white head and good lacing. This beer smells like slightly artificial apricot, perhaps a touch of wheat, but not much room for anything else. Flavor is about the same, medium sweet and no bitterness to be found. Light bodied. I can see this as a gateway beer for the Zima crowd, but not much going for it otherwise.

4oz sampler - Part of a 7-beer sampler tray. Easily the worst beer of the sampler tray. It tasted and smelled like some fruity hand soap, with an awful twang in the finish. It looked like something that would be found in the sink of some greasy spoon. Stay far, far away from this garbage.

a straight lite fruity beer here. very aromatic and refreshing. would make a good summer brew, but bear valley just had snow, so it’s a little out of season in october. similar but thinner than pyramid.
~Pours a light gold with small creamy white head. ~Strong apricot scent with wheat. ~Wheaty apricot flavor. ~Light crisp feel. Sweet finish. ~The apricot was a nice touch to this wheat brew.

Bottle from World Maket Microbrew pack. Nose smells like fresh apricots like are on the tree in my back yard right now; gold with a huge white head which laces they glass as it slowly recedes; flavor of apricot cobbler with some caramel malt.
On tap at the brewery. Typical Pale... nothing to write home about. wouldn’t revisit.
12oz Flasche "Yosemite Falls Pale Ale". Klares bräunliches Bier, wenig Schaum. Schöne karamelige Hoofennote. Fruchtig hopfiger Geschmack.

On tap at the Iron Door Saloon in Groveland. Dark orange color with white head. Aroma is green-earthy, some citrus. Taste is surprising, herbal-green, some citrus again, but very different. Something does not quite fit together here. Okay though.
Bottle. Huge foamy head....bad bottle?? Somewhat metallic in taste and smell. Copper appearance. Not too good, but will try again in case I got a stale one.

Bottle. It has a wonderful hop aroma with some nut underneath. Nice looking light brown color. Medium body and long walnut skin finish. Its a little weird that it smells like an IPA and tastes like a brown ale but it’s not off putting. Its actually very enjoyable.

A decent pale ale. Pours a nice amber color with not much head. Smells a little fruity and hoppy. Taste starts fruity and finishes hoppy. Not bad. Had in the bottle in Murphy's. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Snowshoe Brewing Company has made a decent beer in Thompson Pale Ale. Good nose, strong up front with a clean finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone4S

Bottle and Tap. Pours clear amber with a small white head that dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is faint spruce, pine and caramel. Citrus notes apparent on tap only. Flavor is the same (much fresher and more citrusy on tap). Light sweetness, light bitterness. Medium body.
Pours a nice orangish copper with a minimal head. This beer has a nice citrusy hop flavor with a bit of earthyness and a touch of malts, it also has a slight spice to it. Decent beer.

Really nice. Clean earthy aroma and some citrus. Appearance is golden amber with a thin legs and light head. Taste is clean malty cereal, bubbly, light sweet caramel. Palate is barely saturated with hop and grain. Overall easy to drink light to med body smooth light mouthfeel
Schönes Braun, kein Schaum. Aroma nussig, malzig. Im Trunk malzig süß, etwas wässrig. Hinten leicht bitter. Könnte mehr Bumps haben.
on tap at the brewery. burnt caramel smell and a decent appearance. smooth taste and not too boozy.

On tap at Tap House Pizza in Lodi Pours clear dark brown with a small beige head, some lacing. Aroma of toasted malts, caramel and hazelnuts. Flavors of toasted malts, caramel, nutty and citrus A good brown ale

14 ounce sample on tap at The Burger Saloon in Woodland, CA. The aroma has lightly sweet cocoa hints with very mild roasted malts. Light grassiness is also present. Mostly transparent mahogany body with a medium, strong, light tan head. Starts with some sweet cocoa flavors before an acetic, vinegary infected flavor takes over in the middle. Finishes very roasted. The infection is problematic.

Serving type: bottle Apearance- A amber dark brown with a quick disappearing tan head, and some sticky lacing. Aroma- Roasted malt, sweet caramel smell that is almost overpowering and coffee T/P- Taste is like the smell roasted malt chocolate and coffee. The coffee defiantly comes out in the taste. Overall- This is not bad; there are defiantly better browns out there. It is not well balances the coffee is a bit strong. If it was a little better balanced it would be outstanding as it is it is good and drinkable, but not out standing.

Pour had no head on a dark brown body. The aroma was mild brown sugar. Fine but not much there. The taste had a mild sweet malt balanced out with mild bitter. Crisp with low to moderate carbonation. It is a pretty mellow beer, which made it an easy drinker.

Had this beer several times...just getting around to rating it. Poured out of a growler filled at the brew pub. Pours a dark rich, coffee brown. Light off white head. Aroma is roasted barley. Taste is caramel, coffee and slight booze on the aftertaste. Good beer!

Bottle from Raley’s in Vacaville, CA. Pours a dark brown with a hint of red. Roasty malt flavor with a hint of carmel. The palate was little of on this one and fell apart on the tongue. A little thin bodied for my taste. Average brew.
Bottle. Pours clear deep chestnut with a large fizzy tan head and clumpy lacing. Aroma is caramel, toffee, roasted malts. Flavor is about the same with notes of tobacco and coffee. Medium body.

A dark brown colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of caramel, some fruits and malts. The taste of some sweet caramel, fruits and a little bitter. The aftertaste of sweet caramel with notes of bitter.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: @ zeitgeist 16-3-5: en lite maltig öl med sota toner av karamell och röda bär.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: On tap at Zeitgeist. Amber with a white head. Sweet with Strawberry jam, malt and caramel. Medium body and with a low bitterness.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: A dark dark amber-copper beer with a minimal off white head. Flavor is heavy on wheat and grass. A fair amount of bitterness, some undertones of toasted malts.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: On tap at Jupiter in Berkeley, lots of caramel here, reads scotch. Dark amber color.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: Sample at the Brewpub The amber ale poured clear dark amber with a white head and lacing. The aroma was of caramel and toasted malts. The ale was balance between a sweetness and floral hops. The ale had medium body with average carbonation. The finish was clean with smooth tones of caramel malts.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: Crimson pour with a small eggshell head. Caramel, toffee, brown sugar and a touch of citrusy hops. Pretty run of the mill amber. Nothing offensive but won’t get another.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: Off the tap with one finger of head on a cloudy, dark straw colored body. The aroma is citrusy and honey, pretty nice. The taste is mildly sweet with a hop spicy middle. It’s smooth with moderate carbonation. Here’s a good beer with some unique flavors and still an everyday drinker.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: Amber beer that drips of caramel and cocoa which is a strange target for this style.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: Bottle; poured a clear orange/copper type color with not much head. Aroma of caramel, toasted bread, and fruit. Mouthfeel was a bit fizzy, but not too bad. Alot of caramel and toast, some fruit. Not amazing, but solid.

column1: El Toro Poppy Jasper Amber Ale
column5: Amber in color with a white head. Toasted malt, bread, toffee, and caramel. Light floral hop qualities, some hints of pine, and a little citrus peel. The flavor is very sweet and malt forward. Lots of toffee, caramel, and bread. Floral hops, light pine bitterness, and some citrus peel. A little too sweet for me.

Draft @ SF Beer Week Opening Gala 2017. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grassy hoppy aroma. Fruity malty weak grassy hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty weak citrus hoppy finish.

Draft at the Brewpub The ale poured a clear golden color with a white head and lacing. Aroma of toffee and yeast. The medium body ale had average carbontion. The flavor of toffee and some citrus and bread. The finish was smooth with some lingering bitterness.

Clear golden pour with a white head. Floral hops, grainy sweetness, bread, and a hint of biscuit. There’s a lot of yeast, some lemon zest, and grass. The taste is a bit tart and lemony. Lots of grain, grass, and a moderate sweetness. Some light floral hop notes and yeast with a tangy finish.
Apricot colored pour, white head. GABF sample. Aroma of yeast, light hops, caramel, crackers, floral. Flavor is medium sweet and lightly hoppyy

Tap. Pours clear golden amber with a very small white head and minimal lacing. Aroma is weakly fruity with malt and floral notes. Flavor is medium sweet, light caramel, fruity, a bit of yeast. Finish is light bitter. Pleasant enough, but kind of bland.

Pours orange with a creamy white head. The aroma is surprisingly sweet with butterscotch and yeast. The flavor is the same with a little dough and a slight hint of hops in the finish. Rather interesting.

Poured a hazy gold color with a small white head. Light buttered toast aroma. Semi-sweet butter scotch flavor. Not as strong and repulsive as the beer prior to this and hopefully not just from a poorly rinsed glass.

Bottle, Brew 1259. Poured lighter golden orange with a short cap of white head. The aroma picked up toasted bready malts topped by a lovely pinch of lemon zest.. great balance of sweet and tangy. The flavor found fruity notes, honey, and sourdough bread at the core with earthy, floral, and lemony bitterness around.. bright and tasty.. well-balanced. Lighter-bodied with a feel that was a touch scratchy and delightfully tart.. felt good. This would make a great session beer.

12oz bottle. Murky orange-brown. Mild, dry, soapy aroma. Sandy and toasty, with some light sweet malt and non-aggressive hops. There is some English flavor in there, fruity with a touch of that fining taste, though I would doubt they are used. Pretty good actually, I really enjoyed the medium bodied mouthfeel, not thin and watery some other examples.

Bottle. Pours a hazy light orange color with a thick white meringue-like head. Mild wet grain and slight yeasty aroma. Taste is slightly sweet with a light earthy hop influence. Would be a nice brew to drink next to the grill.

On tap @ El Toro Brewpub [batch # 500 8-30-99] poured a cloudy copper with a minimal amber head. Aromas of carmel, toffee, sherry and light fruitiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, sherry, fruitiness, light toffee and a hint of earthiness with a smooth lingering bitter finish.
Hazy yellow gold. Sweet bready aroma. Flavor is the same with a crisp bitter finish.

Not a live review per se but a call back to the many times I've downed some cans of this over the years. Not seen very often on tap around my parts, but have imbibed many cans. All in all, it is a pretty inoffensive lager, but has a citrusy, alcoholic bite that is missing from most mass-produced canned lager. Nowadays I avoid like the plague, though.

On keg at The Hoop and Grapes, City of London, UK. It pours clear yellow, with a small white head. Aroma is artificial orange and malts at most. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, carbonation is average. Not liked it...

Keg tap at the new Brewhouse & Kitchen in Bedford. Yellow and clear. Film of white head. Light smell of water and porridge. Bitter corny taste. Nicely carbonated palate, I’ll give it that. I’ve had worse but fuckin hell this is average.

Draught in Rochester ; Nothing too wrong or right with this , a ’mid-card’ pale lager ... On the sweeter side of things in style context ,i like swill lager to be more bitter as the redemption for being shitty. Notes of grain, hay, cut grass, sugar , apple ester , light caramel, metal .
Keg at Lab, Leeds. Pours pale gold, white head, high carbonation. Corn aromas, light sweet taste. Astringent finish. Ok

From tap @ Savannah Café Bar, Haywards Heath. Clear pale golden color, small white head. Smell and taste malts, bitter, corn, straw. Low body, average carbonation. The only thing I loved while ticking this beer was the view of the waitress’ bosom. That was lovely, hmmm.
Half flying horse Wye. Pretty standard lager, crisp but Uncomplex malts with watery body
Keg at top secret comedy club. Pale yellow colour with small fleeting white head. Grainy stale aroma. Lager aroma. Grainy metallic flavour. Dull pale lager.
On tap in Hawkinge, Kent @The White Horse Inn. Mild, fruity taste of sweet citrus fruits and forrest. Quite sparkly and easy to drink.
On tap in Hawkinge, Kent. What a waste of time. Watery so-called beer with no aroma. Looks simple and tastes like nothing. Bad. Very bad.

I found this on the sweeter side as well, which is fine because I am not too fond of ESBs. Appearance is a cloudy medium brown...a little darker than apple cider but not as cloudy. Fruity aroma, like banana with that hard to describe European yeasty smell. Reminded me sort of like a Belgian. Tastes of caramal malts with toffee...fruits, hmmm..., I'm going with blackberry, banana, possibly hints of grape or cherry? Still had a medium amount of bitterness, but I wouldn't say "extra". Good balance of malts and hops on this one. I would buy again, but a little pricey. Will look out for it though if ever traveling, especially overseas.
"not a bad little bitter. a little sweet...light fruit and tofee, and a very delicate hop aroma and flavor with a hint of bittersweet in the finish. not the first thing I’d grab, but not bad either."

The pour was a cloudy deep reddish brown with a 1.5-finger off-white head that dissipated quickly. The aroma was toffee with a hint of holiday fruitcake. The flavor was toasty, nutty and a good dose of caramel malts. Slight hints of figs and ripe cherries just before the hops become noticeable. Herbal, resiny hops, but not a lot of bitterness. Overall, fairly well balanced. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and carbonation is medium, as well.

Cloudy dark ruby amber with a persistent light head and streaks of lace. Malt and strong dark fruit (almost cough syrup); light bittering, no solid trace of hops. Somewhat heavy and filling. Overal good for a change.
Gift from SJ. I liked this brew. A nice blend of roast, fruit and caramel malt. A mild hint of sugar, toffee in the dry finish. Well done.

Aroma is malts, fruit and slightly funky. The flavor is malts, a mixture of several fruits, raspberry, grape, apple, etc. This was more complex, a bit all over the place compared to other ESBs; it was decent as a whole didn’t seem to have a cohesive flavor, with some of the flavors kind of colliding and not balancing each other.

Pours a gorgeous mahogany, topped with a fluffy white head which leaves beautiful lacing down the glass. The aroma is rich fruit, like whisky soaked currants waiting to be folded into christmas pudding. Taste is loads of toffee, cut through with a sharp bitterness with leaves a long dry finish that simply delights. Medium to full body, well integrated alcohol. Lovely beer.

bottled. pours a murky brown with a medium head. it smells of chocolate and caramel. it has medium sweetness, with very little hoppy bitterness. overall a very well balanced beer with good flavor and finish.
A brown pour with white head and lace. Aroma of dried fruit and caramel malt dominate. Semi sweet caramel malt and just a hint of abv. Medium bodied but just a tad fizzy. Very decent beer.

Appearance: Pours a clouded body the color of fine, aged leather. Modest-sized head of large, dissipating suds. Smell: Cut hardwood planks layered with sweet-scented caramel and toffee and a good whiff of holidaytime fruitcake splashed here and there with bottled bitters. Taste: Lightly toasty, nutty, even woody maltiness with a big boost of candyish toffee sweetness. Noted fruity esters tasting of figs and tart cherries. Herbaceous, resiny hops with more than enough bitterness to ride out until the dry, mineral-hinted, earthy finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Low carbonation. Drinkability: A good, decent Welsh ESB and a pleasant early-evening brew, though there are a few others I’d sooner reach out my grubby hands for.

Pours a clear golden honey color with a thick white head. Aroma is dry dusty straw. Flavor has sweet cereal, straw and corn. Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is sweet and corny/cerealy/syrupy. Not good.

Botella de 33 cl desde Grecia via beni. Tomada en julio de 2007. ( fecha de cons pref para 12-2007) suave con 5 vol y sin ningún problema para beber, de las comerciales. Sin mucho o casi nada que resaltar.

Bottle: Pours clear, dark gold/scotch with a thin, soapy head. Scent is sweet corn, caramel... Grain, honey taste....bready.... Stale sugar, malt....Not terrible, but on the edge of unpleasant..... Still, a fairly strong body for a pale lager.

Serving: Bottle from State Line Liquors. It pours a clear gold color with a small white head. The nose has a good dose of grain sweetness, but not much else. The flavor is mild with light malt sweetness, a touch of grain, and honey. Not much in the way of bitterness, but easy to drink with no offensive notes. Certainly better than Aris, the only other Greek beer I’ve had.

Drank rite from the brown bottle but I can see its just a pale lager appearance. Somewhat metallic aroma. Seems a little uncivilized at first for a pale lager. Yes, some bitter shit in there and I’m thinking this approaches the taste of a domestic cheap ice beer. Good co2 sizzle makes this at least avereage. Fairly watery in construct. Goes down pretty easy, but there still is this background mild nag. Not bad over all but a little less smooth than anticipated.
Bottle at the hungry Greek next to my place, drank from bottle, aromas of rice, and dust. Flavors are the same, light overall, not the best beer out there, but wouldn’t order again.

Bottle with Maggi and Geoff at the Greek restaurant in ybor the night before Hunahpu 2013. Pours a clear, light golden body with fizzy carbonated bubbles and short, frothy white head. Aroma is sweet grain, light fruity malts, very faint skunk and rice. Mouthfeel is light, carbonated and somewhat crisp. Similar characteristics in the flavor, very plain but not offensive in any way. A drinkable pale lager if no other options are available.

Bottle as shown. Pours a clear pale gold with small white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is a sweet corn malt and honey. Thin mouthfeel with a skunky corn malt and metallic finish. Not much going on with this one.
Light straw color; Light to medium body; Aroma of malt, grain, & some fruit; Flavor of slight sweet malt, grain, and some hops; Fairly bland and watery; Not too bad.
From Can. Golden bubbly with a decent head, aroma of wort, herbs, sugar, flavor of malt, caramel, toasted bread, butter cookies and a touch of herbs, light bodied, decent

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: From old tasting notes. Hazy gold color. Big bubbly white head. Perfumy citrus malt aroma. Sweet tangy malt flavor is fruity and crisp. Brief sour finish.

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: weak aromas of hay, grass, and tin can. the taste is reminiscent of a cross between a lager and a golden ale. got a little bit of barnyard funk. unfortunately not much in the hops department. ice cold on a hot humid summer day is the way to go here.

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: 12-ounce bottles in a glass. A little boring, but that’s standard with Pale Ales. Not bad, especially for the price, but I would pick the Private Reserve from the same company before this one.

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: Pours a clear golden color with a bubbly white head that dissipated quickly. The aroma is sweet malts, sugar, white bread, and some mild hops. The taste is lightly toasted barley, white bread, cereal, and mild hops to help balance. The mouthfeel is light and the drinkability is super high. I really enjoyed this beer.

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: Couldn’t tell the difference between this and a lager. Not sure what makes it an APA. Not much aroma and taste, kind of bland.

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: Gaga Lok and this is just another yellow piss beer from the PacNW. Tastes like it should basically.

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: "cleaner than many pales, but that is because it’s a thoroughly weak interpretation of the style. standard macro attempt at a microbrew style. boring."

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a hazy burnt orange color with yellow tints around the edges of the glass. The head was about a film of a white cap. There was barely any lacing. The smell had a light spice somewhat like black pepper but not off putting, just different. There’s a light caramel malt gently coming in as it warmed. The taste was mainly malty sweet with the spice to come back secondly. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. There’s a quick spicy aftertaste and finish. Overall, APA, uh....sure, it’s a different one alright but nothing bad.

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: Bottle at The Burrito House (PDX). Sugary sweet malt nose. Pale straw color. Sweet, cookieish maltiness, very light citrus hop, light cake frosting finish. Thin. Claims to be brewed with Cascade hops, but they are not detectable. This was the only beer on the menu that I hadn’t tried before, and so I gave it a go. Pretty "crafty" stuff.

column1: Henry Weinhard's Blue Boar Pale Ale
column5: Bottle. Nose is noticeably hoppy, but the hops smell more like pepper than one of the traditional hop flavors. Taste isn’t all that bitter, but there’s a little bite to it, along with a faint hint of citrus. Not a lot of substance to the flavor, but drinkable.

Light yellow color, slightly cloudy. Large head. Light hops and malts. Mild taste, somewhat lemony, not a lot of flavor. Finish is mild and lemony. Aftertaste is somewhat bitter. Not a very good example of a Belgian white.

Bottle from Tesco’s Extra. Clear chestnut brown with a large off white head. Nose is toasted malt, plum, earthy hop, floral, apple, fruity, toasty malts. Taste is fruity, plum, apple, earthy hop, toasted grains, touch of ripe fruit, very slight banana fruit, bitter green leaf, tangy hop. Very good.
Danke an minutemat. Dunkler, weich herber Beginn. Mild aber angenehm hopfig, frisch, ein wenig röstig. Frisch, steigend würzig, malzig herber Abgang. 10/8/9/8/9/9
A mix of amber and dark malts in the taste. Fruity with a good hop complement.

So much flavour that it becomes a fully immersive experience, covering all bases with no stone unturned; like when you go to the doctor with a head cold and they decide to check your prostate while you’re there

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - amber with a red edge. Thin but attractive head. Nose - toffee and red fruit. Taste - strawberry and burnt toffee. Crunchy burnt bread. Palate - medium bodied, rich and creamy in texture. Dry crunchy finish. Overall - good.

Bottle shared with Ashton McCobb. Pours clear dark amber with a short-lived thin white head. Aromas of toffee and a light metallic note. Taste is light sweet, candied peel and toffee. Metallic finish.
Appearance: clear copper, no head Aroma: sweet malt, toffee with notes of roast malts Palate: low carbonation, smooth Taste: caramel, sweet followed by bitter after palate

Noch ein Bier aus der Bier-Index-Verkostungsbox von 2013 Dieses Bier war etwas schwer einzuteilen. Auf der einen Seite nette hopfige Aromen, dann ein tiefer, malziger Körper und dann noch ein paar fruchtige Aromen. Und zum drüberstreuen etwas Röstmalz-Geschmack. Alles ganz gut geformte Geschmäcker, aber dadurch wirkte das Bier sehr überladen und übertrieben. Hier wäre weniger wohl wirklich mehr gewesen.

9Feb2019 Sweet grain and cereal malts, caramel, biscuit, dark fruits. Slightly hazy brown, medium, creamy, off-white head. Light sweet. More bread, sweet grain malts, caramel, light biscuit, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Alright. Bottle from Ocado.
Nice amber color with a well balanced and smooth flavor. Would order again.

column1: Karl Strauss Brig Brew Golden Ale
column5: Draft at Brigantine Shelter Island. Pours clear gold with a fizzy white head. Tastes like corn, doughy malt, and mild citrus. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like corn, doughy malt, and faint citrus.

column1: Karl Strauss Brig Brew Golden Ale
column5: Draft at Brigantine La Mesa. Deep yellow pour with a foamy head. Aromas are malty and bready. Flavors were more pale malt with some golden ale bitterness. Just eh

column1: Karl Strauss Brig Brew Golden Ale
column5: From the tap at Brigatine Seafood poured golden with a good amount of head. Light sweet malty flavor with a lingering finish.

column1: Karl Strauss Brig Brew Golden Ale
column5: Nose is mildly biscuity and smells of crisp hops. Pours more light orange than gold with a soapy head. Flavor is initially hoppy, a citrus lemon kind of thing followed by bready malt. That is it. A mild hoppiness and coaty mouthfeel lingers for a bit, but it is still pretty light bodied. Pretty average really.

column1: Karl Strauss Brig Brew Golden Ale
column5: Very light nose of pale malt. Some lightly roasted malt sweetness, with caramel and toffee notes, but pretty tame really. Very spritzy carbonation tricks you into thinking a bit more is going on here than there really is. A very, very light ale.
Excellent wheat beer. Clean, sharp acidity characteristic of the type, and none of the burnt taste that mediocre ones have.

Bottle - Cloudy golden amber, high carbonation giving large white head, but dissipates to thin line. Strong yeasty aroma. Good mouthfeel. Strong initial orange tasting - decent finish.Easy drinking hefe.
"how is this a big ass beer? don’t ask me. a little bitter for a wheat, which isn’t a great flavor, but at least it makes it stand out a little from all the others that all taste the same."

Pours from a large swing-top bottle hazy golden with a pretty white head. and a floral citrus aroma. It looks nice, but the flavor is disappointing. Kind of a thin skunky hay taste with a dusty finish.
~Pours a cloudy gold with white head. ~Aroma of banana, clove and yeast. ~Sweet banana clove flavor. ~Medium fizzy, frothy feel. Bittersweet finish. ~Enjoyable Hefe. Above average.

22 oz. bottle - wow, poor ratings be damned but this was a great brew; pours bright gold and very cloudy; light carbonation and thin white head; strong and smooth aromas of lemons, wheat and yeast; wonderful texture and full bodied flavor; lots of sweetness; yummy

This is from a 12 oz bottle purchased from Corti Bros in Sacramento, CA. Poured a cloudy pale orange with almost no head. Nose is sour and kind of like a horse blanket. Not much mouthfeel. But it is the flavor that stops you in your tracks. It is awful. I am not sue what is in this but it is about as awful tasting a beer as I have seen in a long time. Both my brother and I were in complete agreement...this is a drainpour if you ever saw one. Gag.

Hmm... I did not think this was that bad really. For what it was. Poured a hazy orange brown with almost no head. Aroma of wheat, oranges, and light yeast. The flavor was much the same. Nice light orange accompanied by a little sweet fruit and a generic cereal wheat. Kind of thin, medium carbonation. It could have been a lot worse.

12 ounce bottle purchased from Corti Brothers in Sacramento, CA. Aroma is a bit sour, metallic, and musty. Kind of strange for a hefe. Moderately hazy golden-orange body with a medium, fluffy, manilla head. Fair lacing. Thin, lightly sweet, grainy start. There is some mild lemon citrus flavors towards the end. This is very undercarbonated, cardboardy, and very underattenuated. It’s really quite boring. Very rarely will I encourage a person to throw fruit in their weissbiers, but this is a beer in which I would totally approve of that practice with.

The aroma is not banana. It is more like citrus hop (or feline ....). Hazy golden color with a white head that filmed, leaving lace tatters. Very thin in body, light, almost creamy, carbonation. The flavor is indeed something glandular, with some clove and mephistolphian accompanyments. The finish is something metallic, with some citric aspects. The finish is astringently dry, and the mouth is not left in a happy condition. Strange stuff. PIne accents appear upon continued assumption (hence the earlier reference to cat ...?). Overall it is not really disgusting, it is just unexpected. So it is what it is. The mouth adjusts somewhat with the passage of time, hence the rating in excess of the average, I suppose.
One and done about sums it up. The name peaked my curiosity so I bought the 32oz bottle w/ the flip cap. The marketing is much better than the beer.

Bottle: Whoa, look at those ratings!!! I’m going to be blowing this one away with a good review here. I got my bottle through the beer of the month club and found it to be a nice made hefe, not exceptional, but certainly not bad. Misty yellow, orange, thin head, nice lacing. Nose of sweet malt and honey, clean tart and citric esters (orange, clove). The flavor is a bit musky, some sweet honey and sulpher notes. Not bad, needs more hops. Finishes a bit tangy and musky.

Can, from Trader Joe's (6/15/19). Pours clear golden with small foamy white head, faint malt aroma, high carbonation, mildly bitter malt taste with grassy hops, thin body, abrupt finish. Good generic Pilsner.
Can from Trader Joe's in Campbell, CA. Aroma is wet grains, wet cardboard, American breakfast cereal, slightly farty with a touch of honey. Taste is rain-soaked cardboard. Strangely heavy.
Watch our video review of this exact product here: https://youtu.be/EWJgMb8YDZc - THIS IS “BEER BRO’S” - Bro’s reviewing Beer! Search "BEER BRO's" or "Vegas Soup TV" on YouTube
I get this stuff at Trader Joe's sometimes. It's like 6.99 for 6 16 ounce cans or something, so it's a decent deal. But I prefer to get the other cheap beers over this one normally
.5l can pours clear amber with a thin anemic white head. Smells of straw, bread, banana. Taste adds a little floral note, straw bitterness, lemon rind. Crisp, light. Nothing amazing here.

500ml can on 1st Mar 2019. Laguna Hills. California, bought in a local Trader Joe's. Clear and clean golden body, snow white head. Grainy, malty nose and taste, not much hop action. OK for a cheap Pilsener.

1 pt.0.9oz from Trader Joes in Short Pump, VA the pils poured a clear amber color with a white head and limited lacing. The head had some lasting power. The aroma of crystal malts greets you. The pils has a light body with average carbonation. An easy beer to drink but light on the hops. The taste has more sweetness than desired. The finish was clean.

Passed up a few local ticks at a work dinner so for punishment bought this brew from Trader Joe’s that was next door. Dark gold. Nose is stale hops. Tastes of grains, old lemon, hay. Kinda weird tasting. I don’t like Trader Joe’s and I don’t like this beer.

I knew exactly what I was getting with this beer: something that I could chug down ice cold following a hot bike ride. It certainly worked fine for that purpose but it admittedly is not something I'd want to drink at any other point. It's thin, fizzy, and tastes like corn water. I happily didn't get a can that had the offensive metallic taste, but it definitely wasn't anything remarkable.

$1.17 pint can, Trader Joe's. Pours clear gold with a white head. Aroma of corn chips, corn. Flavor is watered down corn chips, hose water, light grass, paper. It's not as bad as I imagined, but not good.

330ml bottle pours a pale golden color with a small white head that leaves a few specks of lacing on the glass. Aroma is light grains and hops. Taste is light malt sweetness and light hop bitterness. Light body and light carbonation. A decent brew for the style, but still nothing special.
Hmmm, just as I expected. Gold pour. White head. Skunky aroma with pale malt and hop profile. Flavor is much the same. I dont even think this would go well with much of anything.

Pours golden to light amber with white head that quickly dissipates. Nose has a suggestion of honey, and is otherwise faint. Palate has honeyed malt taste, light hops, and a short finish. Slight herbal/vegetal like quality. Very easy drinking, better than domestic adjunct lagers.

Had this beer a couple years ago, so I’m going off memory. It was an unusual find, so I had to try it. It was a little on the malty side, but almost like a German beer in flavor. Some corn and grassy hops, but light with enough flavor to be refreshing.

330 mL. Found this at European Street Cafe in Jacksonville, FL. Pours a clear golden with a decent white head that dwindles down quickly. Aromas of sweet corn, fresh grass, and cereal. No lacing. Tastes like sweet corn bread. Clean, bland finish. This is a decent pale lager that I am not going to complain about. Fun to drink, not offensive, and hey! it’s Greek.

11 oz. bottle. Pours a clear gold with a moderate white head that faded to a sloppy, uneven white film after the first sip and left zero lace. Aroma of stale air, like being in an old attic, along with some malt and a bit of corn syrup sweetness. Thankfully, there was no staleness in the flavor, which was basically some mild sweet malt. No bitterness to speak of at the finish. Fairly smooth on the palate. This beer probably would have faired better with me if not for the off-putting aroma.

Bottle. Pours a gold with an initial 2 finger snow white head that faded fast into a soap scum topper. Nose is sweet malt and grassy hops. Taste is pretty the same. Lighter mouth feel. Meh, not any worse than a lot of Latin beers.
mmm, so i’m rating pale lagers again--oh, boy: this one has that familiar egg whiteness to it that never fairs well with my palate; somewhat oily, some spice actually, but not great; meh.

Not all that interesting...this is a basic lager, slightly better than a typical American lager. There was some residual sweetness to this beer, which gave it most of its flavor and very low hopiness if any. Not bad for a session lager but nothing interesting at all with this beer.

Brewed in Greece !! Pours a golden yellow color with a quickly dissipating white head. Aroma of corn, malts, and a hint of citrus. The taste is of sweet corn but not much else. The mouthfeel is very watery that ends with a slightly dry finish. This pale lager is boring, but the label is kind of cool.

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: Backdraft Brown is soda-like in color and head. The color is like Dr. Pepper: a dark copper brown, with dark orange highlights when held to the light. The head is a light tan, fizzy, that dissipates quickly and leaves a thin layer across the top of the beer. Smell is smoky, of dark roasted malts as well as some fruity yeast. Flavor is smoky as well, with just a suggestion of bitterness at the end. A thin and watery mouthfeel really detracts from the experience. Somewhat harsh carbonation. I had great expectations from the smell and flavor notes on the first sip, but the taste doesn’t follow through.

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: It had a tan head of average size that fades quickly leaving only a little lacing. The body has a dark brown color with some nice ruby red highlights.
