The aroma has a big sweet, malty, bready character. The base flavor is malty and bready with some hints of darker roasted malt and modest, slightly citrusy hops. The hops add a good balance to the mostly malty character and finish with the beer with a pleasant soft bitterness. Its texture is smooth, slightly slick and medium bodied with light to average carbonation.

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: Easily one of the most watery browns I’ve ever had. It pours decent and has an ok aroma of chocolate malt but the flavor just isn’t cutting it. There are some very subtle roasty notes up front but it finishes very bland. Just too plain to even be a decent brown. Quite disappointing!

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: From notes. 12oz bottle poured into a shaker. Aroma of banana and roasty malt. Not a whole lot going on here. Drinkable but don’t seek it out.

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: Brown, as you might expect. Splotchy white head. Smells like brown sugar and a bit of coffee. Flavor is brown sugar on toast. Dryish finish.

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: Roasted peanuts, sweet and salty aroma. Flavors of caramel, toasted bread, cherries and a hint of vanilla. Wet paper and watery finish. Plays it safe and doesnt really grab an interest.

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: Reviewed from notes. Served in a pint glass. Color is a moderately-dark brown with a tan head that persists for a bit before falling. Nose is quite plain with a bit of caramel and bread. The taste is bready with some light sweetness. Decent body with normal carbonation levels. Really just don’t have too much to say about this one. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 11-14-2010

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: Too watery for the style, a slightly malty and pretty watery flavor does not do this style justice, there are way too many other examples in this style that do that.

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: 12 oz bottle. Poured brown with a small head. Aroma was nice: malt, sweet, maybe some mild fruit. Taste really falls short: water, muddled malts, faint nut. Thinnish body. No real depth there. Overall: the nose was nice but the taste was very detached and lost.

column1: Hook and Ladder Backdraft Brown Ale
column5: Brown w/ off-white head. Big sweet malt and toffee aroma. Taste: Some toasty malt, caramel, chocolate and a little nutty. Not as sweet as the aroma hints at. Smooth and drinkable. Very nice brown.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: From old tasting notes. Hazy orange gold color. Thick creamy beige head. Earthy malt aroma. Creamy fruit malt flavor. Nicely balanced hop finish.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Golden orange pour with a white head. Nose is on the sweet side for a pale ale. Bread and grain aromas, some perfume, floral hops, grass, and light citrus peel. Flavor is a bit grassy, light bitterness, and sweet grain and malt. Some bread, water, floral hops, and very mild citrus peel. Pretty pedestrian pale ale.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: This a decent but not an outstanding pale ale. Very light in color it just doesn’t have all that much hops. A very easy finish. Certainly could be a bit happier.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Draught at the brwepub. Clear golden, no head. Sweaty citrus aroma. Mid sweet with clean mouthfeel and medium body. The harsh malt hardness is covered up to some extent by gooseberrry and citrus. Resiny bitter finish. A mediocre beer with lovely hop polish.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Bottle courtesy of cakanator. Pours a cloudy amber with a minimal off-white head. The nose is malt and light citrus. The taste is malt, lemon peel and light earthy hops in the finish. This one has some age on it as well I suspect. Light-to-medium bodied. Not very good.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: 12oz bottle-pours a thin off white head and gold color with floaties in the bottle that become lots of very small floaties after poured. Aroma is mild lemon/pine, some malt. Taste is lemon/pine, some malt. Dry finish.. nice beer even without taking into account possible aging. Thanks jwc215 for sharing this.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: mildly hoppy, copper coloured body. grapefruit, and other decidious fruit. kind of earthy actually. small finger sized head. definately liked this one.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Had this beer on 3/31/1998. Color is a bright golden with a slight haze in it. Carbonation is very good with a nice head. Aroma is a lightly sweet malt scent. Taste is a light body beer with a good bitter finish. It starts off with a light crisp body that goes down cool. The finish is fair, it’s a bitterness that gently builds with a slight tone of sweet malt. It’s main down fall is there is no hop flavor and there is a touch of skunk in it, but its very faint

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: I poured this beer ice cold just to try the first one, not to rate it and it poured w/ an awesome head and good lacing w/decent color for the style. But thats where the positive aspects of this beer end. palate was like iron, texture was as weak as a bud light! the head disa peared in seconds, very little-no scratch that it did have an aroma but not consistant again w/ the style. Wont buy again!

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Cloudy orangish red. Sweet caramel aroma. Toffee caramel taste. Medium/light body. Sweet. No carbonation.

Botella de 37,5 cl. Fecha de embotellado 12/2016. Color amarillo turbio sin espuma y carbonatación nula. Aroma a fresa, cítricos y manzana. Sabor a manzana, vinagre, cítricos y por supuesto fresa. Cuerpo ligero, poco ácida y agria, fácil de beber, muy suave, le falta potencia, lambic correcta y poco más.
Semi hazy golden liquid, no head. Aroma is sour, apple, strawberry. Medium body, no carbonation. Taste is sour, strawberry.
Bottle. Very fruity, identifiably strawberry, slightly tart, refreshing, effervescent beer. Very nice. (2008)

355ml bottle poured red in color with a film of pinkish head and very little lacing. Aroma is all strawberry. Taste is strawberry sweetness with some tartness in the finish. Light bodied with light carbonation. Just too darn fruity to appreciate.

Red ruby pour. Pretty simple. Straw berry aroma. Strawbeery / alcohol taste with a tart sweet finish. The fruit didn’t taste too artificial (Which I like that it didn’t) Niot favorite of styles, but not bad.
8th July 2006 Warning! Early amateur rating! Sweet but also tart strawberry. Not as fruity as a Fruli but a still a nice beer!
Pours dark golden with a thin wispy off-white head. Notes of strawberry, melon, cherry, soft wheat, light tartness. Medium bodied with lively carbonation.
I was too kind to this one. Pours reddish. Clear. Nose and taste of freshly picked strawberry and juice. Rated 6/7/02
Red amber with a dense head. Aroma of berries and straw. Sweet flavours with a bit of sourness and floral notes in the backgorund.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11. light amber with a white head. nose is strawberry and not much else. decent on the palate with flavors of strawberries and sugar but still very tolerable to drink.

( 12oz bottle from Lone Star Beverages in Carrollton, TX) Pours clear pink orange with nice frothy bubbles. Nose of strawberry juice, tart fruit and cherries. Taste of sugar, real strawberries, artificial sweetener with a lightly tart finish. This was better than I expected it to be.
Artificial-tasting strawberry shortcake sweetness and a strange bitter - two things that are not good seperately, put them together and it doesn’t get better.
On draft at the brewery in Denver. Pours a clear mahogany with an ecru head. Aroma is nutty with sweet caramel flavors.
A special blend of British Caramel malts brings this brew its texture and brilliant copper color with a distinctive rich malt finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From old tasting notes. Bright orange red color. Bubbly beige head. Spicy malt nose. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor is clean and crisp. Floral hop finish. Good flavor and balance.

Bottle poured a clear reddish amber with a lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of caramel, earthiness and light fruitiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of caramel, earthiness and a hint of fruitiness with a smooth lingering earthy finish.
Bottle: Pours clear copper with a huge beige head. Toffee, woody aroma. Slightly lactic and creamy caramel malt flavor. Simple, but good.

APPEARANCE- Reddish amber with a luxiourios, perfectly white head. NOSE- malty, no discernable hops. Like a red should smell. FLAVOR- same maltiness, but it’s pleasantly ’plain’. NOTES- Pretty straight forward ale. No hops pop out at you, though they may be in there. Really solid for what I think a red should be.
Received through a sampler. Pours dark amber, creaming head. Notes of toffee, sweet, malt. Overall a forgettable beer.

Pours deep amber brown color with a short lived cream head. Caramel, toffee, biscuit and sweet malt aroma and flavors. Medium light body and moderate carbonation. Sweet malt and caramel finish. Extracty.
A perfectly decent amber ale, maltier than most that are out there. A good regularly drinkable red. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Light toffee malt and straw aroma. Copper with moderate light tan head. Lightly sweet toffee and moderately bitter weedy quinine flavor. Decent body. A bit harsh.
From old tasting notes. Hazy bronze gold color. Creamy beige head. Soft toasted malt nose. Zesty malt flavor lacks depth. Mild grassy hop finish.

Bottle poured a clear gold with a small lasting white head. Aromas of bread and a hint of spicy hops. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of bread, light spicy hops and a hint of earthiness with a crisp dry finish.
Sampled at Boulder Craft Beer Festival. Golden appearance with a white head. Aroma of toasted grain and light hops. Similar flavor, malty and smooth with mild bitterness and a light dry finish. OK.

APPEARANCE- light color with reddish hue. White solid head, little lacing. On point for a pale ale. NOSE- slight bit of earthy hop is evident. FLAVOR- kind of bland. A little hop flavor, and it tastes like a lot of other ales.
Bottle. Semi sweet nose. Almost like a lager. Very little hops. Taste follows. Uneven. To sweet. Meh.
12 ounce bottle. Malty fruity mess. Not much going on here. I think that about sums it up.
Bottle: Clear, honey-gold with a small off-white head. Orange, grain malt aroma. Taste is light orange-peel, barley malt. Grassy hops.... Not much going on in this one.
A perfectly serviceable pale ale. Nothing special about it, but it's pretty textbook. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a golden color with a white head. Caramel, biscuit, floral hop, honey and pine aroma and flavors. Medium light body and average carbonation. Biscuit and floral finish. Not bad but pretty bland.
Bottle. Orange juice, biscuit malt, and light orange peel aroma. Golden yellow with moderate head. Sweet orange, light malt, and mildly bitter orange peel flavor. Light body. Okay but pretty boring.

Aroma - chocolate, roast, and even some smoke. Appearance - the body is black. Head is beige, and around 1", and settles relatively quickly. Taste - has roast, some sweetness, and a little bit of smoke. Palate - medium body, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a slight bit of roast.

Can. Nose is sweet, chocolate and roast, very light fruit. Pours pitch with a fluffy and sudsy tan head. Watery light body sweet and strongly fruity with no roast or chocolate, but there is a thin layer of brownish malt there, and some alcohol showing (too much for this sizer, really). Relatively soft (carbonation burned itself out quickly) with some nice black roast, but missing the middle roast textures and basically any coffee or chocolate in the mouth. No offensive by any means, just a soon-forgotten 90’s brewpub revival. [2015.12.25: 2.7]

Can from Crossroads. Pours a strange cola cola color with a small off white to almost tan head. Aroma is of some mild roast, light chocolate, some sweet syrup notes. Taste is much the same, chocolate, mild roast coffee, some syrup, mild sweetness with a little touch of bitterness. Body is not creamy as advertised.
Very nice stout. Can that’s in been in my fridge for a long time. Rich, oats, espresso, light fruit, subtle vanilla, very tasty and well done.

12oz can from Crossroads. Pours black with a small foamy tan head. Aroma of black malts, dark chocolate, hints of coffee, earth, and smoke. Taste of dark chocolate, black coffee, smoke, and earthy hop bitterness in the finish. Decent

12oz can from Spirits Xroads. Poured a deep black body with a smallertight foamy light tan head. Aroma is pretty good, notes of darker chocolate, oaats, dark toast, soy sauce, black olives and a touch of coffee. Medium body, super soft carbonation that is almost nonexisistant and a quicker fading aftertaste. Flavor is not as good as the aroma, notes of bitter dark chocolate, dark toast, cola, chocolate syrup and some soy sauce. Not bad but nothing to seek out.

12 Oz can. Pours black with a frothy tan head. Nice malt Aromas of coffee, chocolate, molasses and roasted malt. Medium sweet with complex, dark malt flavors: coffee, toffee, chocolate. Finishes with a long, bitter roasted malt and herby hop. Full body with a creamy mouthfeel and mild carbonation. Overall, yum! Great malt character, good texture. What a stout should be.
Decent brew. Pours deep brown with a small tan head. Aroma is light party/smoke. Finishes with light smokey notes.

Can; dark black pour with a light brown head. Aroma of oats, roasted malt, leather, with touch of milky sweetness. Very nice mouthfeel; rich, creamy but light. Some oats, some sweetness, touch of fruits, and mild roasted and caramel. Could really drink a lot of this. Nice beer.
Pours almost black. Coffee and chocolate aroma and flavors. Not a big fan of stouts, but this one is pretty good.
From old tasting notes. Amber red liquid supports a creamy beige head. Sweet spicy toasted malt aroma. Crisp, complex, dryish malt flavor. Big hoppy finish. Long clinging mouthfeel in aftertaste..

Frederick Brewing Company--Blue Ridge Brewing--Blue Ridge BMNT Amber Lager--2002 Release--12 oz. Bottle. 5.40% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.25 / 5.0) Amber Lager--Malt of the Earth Selction--Clear thin rich pretty amber color. Light head and lace. Light toasted floral mild malt fruit hop front. Tangy toasted smooth roasted caramel fruit body. Creamy sweet buttery mild hop end. Sampled 2/27/2003.

Amber pour with odd fruity aroma. I think something was wrong with this...it reminded of the Penn Weizen I had a ways back. Sour, citrus like bitter lemon mixed with sugar. Overcarbonated and thin. I couldn’t finish it. I even let it warm way up...no improvement. Yuck.

Not a bad vienna, though my hometown Penn Pilsner has this beat. Aroma was very weak which is disappointing as it would have scored higher. Pour was a nice medium amber with no head. Taste was a little thick...but had heavy roasted and caramel malt flavor. Nice carbonation and a a thin film seems to go down the throat with the swallow. Odd. Decent beer.

Bottle courtesy of slob. Pours amber/copper with a creamy white head. Smells of citrus, tea, earth and grapes. Tastes of sweet malt, tea, spices and touches of pepper. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is sweet. Decent.

Had this beer on 9/14/1999. Aroma is a lightly roasted malt scent. Color is an amber. Taste seems light for an amber. Starting with a medium body that goes down with a roasted flavor. Finish is this roasted malt flavor with a light hop bitterness. Its a good Amber.
An orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is quite light, what is there is sweet malty with hints of oranges. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel, leading to a dry metallic end.

Bottle. Sweetish caramel and toast malt fragrance. Amber pour with a rocky eggshell head. Crisp caramel and toast taste in a biscuity malty body with a little funky kick. Medium body with an only slightly dry caramelly aftertaste. Smooths out. Pleasant and quaffable.

12 oz bottle thanks to my Secret Santa. Soft brown hazy pour with amber leanings. Wispy head. Lightly sweet malt aroma that is a bit nutty. Lightly malty taste with hints of nuttiness and a mild sharpness at that finish. Fair. Body is medium.

I tried this hometown beer poured from the bottle, and was quite pleased. The beer had a malty, caramel aroma and came out a rich, but light, amber color. It had a mixture of flavors with a medium body and carbonation. Overall, I got more than I expected out of this beer.

Massey and I bought this beer 13 or 14 years ago at Shopper’s Paradise on mega-clearance because we were having a party. The Browns had long since returned to disgrace the gridiron. Don’t remember much about the beer, but we found some sweet-ass shirts in the closet the next day and watched the Masters. Tiger Woods probably won and probably celebrated with a limo full of Perkins waitresses. Notes of value and irresponsibility. Mouthfeel like a bastard.

I can’t believe this was in my friends fridge since ’99, we had to drink this hardcore Cleveland Browns fans beer. Golden pour, still a slight head. Taste like any other crappy pale lager, slight malts with corn and all that other crap mixed in and with a semi sweet probably oxidized taste, and no hops. After 7 years and being in a fridge this beer held up, I just wish it were a good beer to begin with.
Nice golden colored beer with good head. Nice malty aroma. Full malty taste. very good finish. Full Mouthfeel.
Hoppy, fresh aroma. Nice head, golden color. Moderate carbonation. Tasted hops and a bit of a worty flavor. Had a chalky sweet after that reminded me of Smarties.

A gift for me from my dad in '99. Tasted like the "Baqllpark Brew" Crooked River used to make for Jacob's field, only had a salty taste, why? Because I was crying tears of joy when I drank it. Not a remarkable brew, but the label is proudly on my wall.
Very enjoyable light golden ale with no adjuncts at all. This all malt brew is full of flavor and is still light enough to share with your less experienced beer drinking friends. Very enjoyable beer.
Fair malts and hops, clean golden color that pours to a bright white head. Clean and crisp, kept one bottle for a collectors item.
Pretty much no smell...and pretty much no taste lol very watery with some beer and light pilsner flavor...smooth but nothing to rate...had with Megan at polliwogs for duke-pitt game 2019

5/2/17. 12oz bottle from Five Points. Golden pour with a small white head. Plain bready aroma, pizza dough, a whiff of grass. Bready flavor, sweet pizza dough... maybe a slight bite of citrus if I really search, but really just doughy maltiness. Eh.

Bottle. Very light yellow, crystal clear and fizzy. Sweet, bready aroma. Drinks with a very starchy character, corn and even a hint of salt. Very reminiscent of some European patio beers I enjoyed back in the day. For the lighter beer lovers. (#6479, 12/27/2016)
Draft. Crystal clear golden color, medium white head. Straw aroma. Taste is lightly peppery straw.

Pours a clear golden with a fat, white head. Green grape and green banana peel nose. Most of the flavors approximate the nose, only in a more prominent fashion. A bit of a spicy Belgian note toward the finish.

Not Thomas Creek’s most exemplary brew, a rather basic pilsner with a light bready malt flavor, hint of noble hops with a grassy-lemon finish. Appearance was a fresh yellow golden color with pleasant lacing and some light white head, aroma of the same flavors described above. Light-bodied, just a good mild example of the style!
Sample at Örebro Öl & Whisky 2015. Malty smell with pale bread. Similar taste. Crisp. Light bitterness. Clean.

Bottled (backlog, Bishops Arms Vasagatan, Stockholm). Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is bready and biscuity malts with some slight grassy, herbal and mild floral notes. Wellbalanced and clean pils.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. Aroma- Has a soft aroma with grass and malt the primary driver. Appearance- A pale clear yellow color with a very small white head Taste- Has a very slight flavor, not bad but lacks character Palate- A light bodied medium carbonated pilsner Overall- Not a bad beer to drink when needing to be refreshed, very much in line with a BMC brand to me.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured hazy, golden, some white head and a bit of lacing on the glass. Aroma of grain and malts combined with some hints of hops. Taste is sweet, lots of grain notes, some malts and a slightly bitter finish. Drinkable but not memorable.
Draft. Amber color poured with a thin white head. The aroma is malty caramel with a light hoppy earthiness to it. It is a little thick on the tongue. Good.

Amber ale is one of my favorite beer styles. Malty and nutty aroma with deep copper color. This beer has a heavier body, malty with moderate hops and crispness, with a little sweetness and nutty flavor to finish. I don't like it as much as their Red Ale offering (which has a lighter body).

Have enjoyed this fresh on tap in downtown Greenville and also from the bottle at home in Columbia, and from both sources this is an exceptionally full-bodied and flavorful classic amber ale. Pours a transparent but dark mahogany wood color with a healthy amount of foam and an aroma of unsweet caramel. Rich toffee and caramel in the flavor but with less sugary sweetness, not much hoppy contrast. Takes a more malt-centric approach to this style and tends toward the burnt end of the caramelization spectrum. Personally, I prefer the less overt sweetness of this flavor profile much more than Thomas Creek's River Falls Red Ale, which I used to get this beer confused with.
Pours a clear dark amber with light head. Has a strong caramel malt aroma. A mix of flavors including caramel, roasted malts, grains, and some fruits. A lingering caramel malt aftertaste.
Light malty smell, little sweet off the bat...turns a touch bitter, a bit toasty over time...decent but a little too watery
Pours reddish-brown like coke with a thin off-white head. Medium bodied. Moderate carbonation. A little sweet. Dusty, astringent finish. Not bad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Old rating. Decidedly average and boring amber with all that entails…color, malty body, some sweetness, medium body.

Bottle shared by Dr Silverworm. Poured clear brown hue with medium frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium aroma of toasted malt. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium flavor of sweet malt with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Smooth drinkable brew.

12oz bottle, purchased on 2/23/15 from Habersham in Savannah. Shared with tmoney99. Bottle is labeled 6.8%. Mostly clear amber-brown color, with some dark particles in the body. Little ring of bubbly off-white head, few bits of lace. Toasty malt, and some caramel. Touch of dark fruit. Mildly spicy and earthy. Moderate bitter, light to moderate sweet. Medium to bigger body. Lighter, slightly rough carbonation. Mild slick finish. Surprisingly, one of the better Thomas Creek beers I picked up (I was beginning to get more and more nervous every time I popped a bottle open). Good bigger bitterness on this, good bigger flavor. A solid, darker, earthier hoppier amber ale.
Tap takeover at Matthews Beer Temple. Very average amber ale. Well balanced but not memorable at all. Pass.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Bottle; Pour is murky gold with a modest white head in this glass ; some spotty lacing here. The nose is overly sweet, there is some cream...... the flavor profile is bittering initially, some cream... there just isn’t much here. This is a mediocre one, for sure.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: a light clear peach with a bright white head, nice ring, but that’s about it... the aroma is very sweet, generic cream and sugar, a hint of skunk and alcohol... the taste is chemical alcohol and a hint of stall chalk... skip this mess.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Wisconsin Whitetail Cream Ale--1999 12 oz. Bottle. 4.20% ABV. (3.0 / 5.0) Golden Ale. Malt of the Earth Selection August, 1999. Clear thin light amber color. Light hop floral front that extends to and permeates malt body. Light texture with creamy feel. Hints of fruit. Clean floral spice end. Sampled 8/29/1999.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Hazy orange body with a thin white head. The aroma is light but pleasant. Mild citrus, nuts, and bread. The palate is a bit thin with some chalky residue...interesting. Completely unoffensive flavor. Overall pretty sweet...sweet citrus and malt. There’s really no hop balance. Not a bad brew. Reminds me a bit of Spotted Cow, just not quite as satisfying.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: I am always skeptical of anything that claims to be Irish and is not either from Ireland or a stout. These beers are typically bland amber-colored lagers and ales and not much worth trying. This is actually not a bland amber-colored brew though in so far as it’s actually golden in color. Aside from that, it does nothing to quell my skepticism. It is cloudy w/ a small white head. Nose is grainy and lightly fruity and possibly a bit nutty. Lightly sweet with earthy bitterness. Comes off as almost flat but there are still a few prickles of carbonation. There is nothing foul or off about this beer but there is nothing really to like about it either. It is neither particularly flavorful nor particularly drinkable.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Bottle thanks to 17thfloor. Semi hazy light amber with small to medium, creamy off-white head. Aroma is sweet citrus and caramel with a little grain and cardboard. Flavor is sweet grapfruit like malt, yeast, caramel, chalky, some bitterness. Medium body with large bubbled carbonation. Haven’t had a chalky beer in quite a while, ah the memories.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: hazy orange, small off-white head, some lacing. caramel nose, grapefruit/citric and malt notes also. malty sweet flavor, creamy caramel, touch of hoppy bitterness. medium bodied, bitter finish. inoffensive to most beer drinkers, exciting to few. too mild/simple/blah. thanks to cornfield for providing the bottle.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: 12oz bottle 2/6/09 (Binny’s Naperville)-Pours a hazy yellowish/golden with a small tight white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and a bit of dough. Taste of malt, hops, caramel, and dough. This medium bodied brew is not nearly as bad as people are rating it IMO. Nice brew.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: 12oz bottle. Pours murky orange with a foamy off-white head. Heavily carbonated. Aroma is of malt, caramel, yeast, and wheat. Taste is of dirty malt, earthy hops, caramel, yeast, and wheat. It’s not bad at all, just very earthy. If you enjoy eating bags of dirt and licking sidewalks, you will enjoy this beer.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: I liked this a bit more than the rest of the earlier reviewers. Attractive hazy golden pour. The nose is mainly caramel malt sweetness and bread dough. The flavor is a moderately creamy texture melange of dough, caramel/toffee malt, light earthy hop bitterness. Very drinkable. Thanks Cornfield!

2009 Bottle - Pours deep orange with a large off white head...aroma is candy malt, some light grain...flavour is dry, metallic and a bit ascorbic, grainy bitterness, roasted metal...ain’t nobody gonna miss Lang Creek...
Bottle from Hamilton, MT. Dark amber in color. Bready malt aroma with a few hops. Flavor is malty with some traces of hops.

Dark amber pour with a gigantic off white head. Like a big storm cloud brewing in my glass. Smells of sweet toffee and honey. Light bodied with a chewy texture on the palate. Finishes with a slightly malty tang. Good flavor and very drinkable. A decent session amber.

This beer pours an amberish red color with a frothy slightly off white head with good lacing. From aesthetics alone I was pretty damn pleased with this beer. The aroma is pretty prominent for something i had low hopes for. Caramel and hops are in there with a chocolate or molasses undertone. The flavor is very dessert like and almost leads me to think this would be a nice dessert beer.
Light copper amber, moderate off-white head. Aroma of toast, caramel, dry leaves. Earthy crystal malt profile, nice little amber.

Received single 12-oz bottle via trade with 5000. Pours a semi-clear copper amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that dissipates to a film top and decent off-white ring. Aroma of caramel malt, flowery hops, some white pepper, apples and a touch of brown sugar. Taste is slightly biscuit caramel malt, some dry hop character with toasted bread, and a touch of citrus zest. Finish is semi-dry a little roasted nuts and chocolate aftertaste that even has a lingering dark iced tea finish. An interesting amber ale.

baked bread aroma, also ripe orange. rich amber color with orange tint. respectable head fell to a whisper that hung around a while. creamy side to its depth of roasted character. there’s a metallic edge that hurts it overall but only a bit.
Pours reddish brown with a thin white head. Smells of sweet malt, citrus, roses, sugar. Tastes earthy with some citrussy notes and a slightly peppery finish.
Amer color with decent head. Nice fruity maltiness in aroma and flavor with notes of nuttiness, dough, candi, and chocolate and a tad of damp sock.

12oz Bottle - Gravity Room - Olympia, WA. Aroma – A nice mild amber aroma with a subtle amount of hops Appearance – Amber in color, clear with a thick head. Flavor – A great amber malt flavor with some hops. Needed a tad more flavor for my liking. Palate – Was dry and good to the finish just an avergae amber Overall –A decent beer for those who like average. This could have been great with more spicy mals and a tad more hops.

Bottle. Poured with a very spare, white head that was greatly diminishing. Body was slightly hazy and a dark yellow color. Aroma was of light malt and some breadiness. Light to medium-bodied on the palate, mostly thin-textured, with average carbonation. Flavor was lightly sweet with a short duration... went down very easy, but didn’t taste like anything special. A very easy blonde to drink... maybe too easy. Nothing that sets it apart from any others of its kind.
Bottle: Golden color pour with little head. Hoppy, spicy, citrusy aroma. Sweet, hoppy, grassy finish.
Bottle courtesy of kyzr. Pours a hazy gold with a white head. Smells of citrus, dry malt, floral hints. Tastes perfumy with a tarte, dry malty finish.
Bottle from Hamilton, MT. Golden/brownish in color. Slightly sweet aroma with some tartness. Some fruitiness in the nose. Fairly dry bready malt flavor. Not much in the way of hops.
Light golden color with a fairly fluffy white head. Low aroma, very yeasty. Mild carbonation with slight apple notes and a tiny hop hit near the finish. Rather boring.
Hazy deep golden, almost no aroma, a vague sweetness. Sweet biscuity flavour bordering on caramel, faint fruit hop or yeast note, very low bitterness. This just didn’t do it for me.

Received single 12-oz bottle via trade with 5000. Pours a semi-clear golden pale amber brew with a thin, creamy off-white head that slowly dissipates to a film top and white ring with some spotty lacing. Aroma of golden and caramel malts, citrus hops, some fruity apples, and a touch of corn grits. Taste is light bodied, some grit grain, floral hops and some caramel. Finish remains a little gritty but a good balance of dry and sweet aftertaste that quickly becomes crisp, clean cut. A pretty decent summer beer.

12oz Bottle - Gravity Room - Olympia, WA Aroma – Light malt aroma with some hops in the nose Appearance – A light golden color, clear and a light head. Flavor – This was a easy drinking light blonde ale with some nice subtle hops in the flavor Palate – Easy to drink, crisp, cold and well balanced beer. Overall –This was a nice beer nothing too specal about it just an average beer in the end.

Bottle: Lightly hazy blonde color with a nice puffy white head and a full sheet of lacing. The nose is very musky with wheat husk, light floral hops. The flavor is full of stale malt and a bit of sweetness. Funky.

Bottle: Clear yellow pour with lots of bubbles and a huge white head. Somewhat sticky lacing. Nose is mild with florals and grassiness. Some maltiness. The taste is true to style with light florals, wheat, and malts. Simple and basic, but not bad at all.

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is rye and caramel. Thin body, licorice, rye, light bitterness, good.

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: Rating #2021- 2015.09.27 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 4, Beer 121 - Draught at Taproom Clear amber pour with a bubbly white head, little retention.Aroma is stagnant grassy, vegetabley malts with a skunky hoppy note. Buttery farts on tap. An ungodly mess

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear amber with a medium sized white head. Sweet malt on the nose, toast, soft citrus, sticky and sweet. Medium bodied, light and softly fruity. Light citrus, a touch of malt. Sweet and fruity. Gentle floral malt into the finish.

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: Draft pour pint at the Duvall taproom. Copper amber pour with a lot of fizz head and lacing. Rich caramel malt aroma. Flavor is malty, expected average sweetness, and a simple hop addition late. Easy to drink. Tasty alt.

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: On June 24, 2015. At Jolly Roger Taproom (Maritime Pacific) in Seattle, Washington. Listed as 5.5% ABV and 30 IBU. Hazy brown color, off-white head with lacing. Fruity, malty taste. Malty aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness to medium low. Malty, fruity, toasty scent.

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours a cloudy darker reddish amber color with a smallish off-white head on there. Nose has a nice mix of caramel and nuttiness to it, with just a bit of bread coming through. Taste is lightly sweet and a bit doughy, but fairly refreshing and easy to drink. Not a bad brew.

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: Sampler, lots of lacing, burnt orange red color. Aroma is a bit spicy, burnt caramel, moderate strength. Flavor is much lighter but flavorful crisp woodsy feel. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: Amber pour with creamy off white head and lace. Aroma is very caramel malt forward. Flavor is sweet caramel malt with an ok floral bitter. Medium body with good carbonation. Lingering sweet at the finish.

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: Pours a finger of head on a hazy red body. The aroma is lemon, orange and grain. The taste has moderate lemon bitterness, earthy fruit and mild honey sweet ending. The texture is soft with moderate carbonation. A fine beer, nothing special but tasty with an alt style to it.

column1: Maritime Pacific Flagship Red Alt Ale
column5: Amber colour, quite clear with a white foamy head. Roasty flavour of caramel and nuts in sync with a strong hop presence and a woody aroma. Medium bodied and a little watery for my taste.

20 z. at Columbia City Ale House. This is a fairly clear amber with a tall head. It seems more like a British pale ale to me with some stonefruity yeast character, but maybe that's just the hop choice. It's certainly malty enough to be English style. Lots of biscuit is present with a firm hop bitterness. The finish is kind of toffee sweet to balance.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy yellow gold with small frothy white head. The aroma is citrus and grass. Medium body, skunk, earth, light finish, decent.
Stop #8. Draft pour at brewery. Dry hoped. Slight cloudy pour. Thin lacy head. Small hop aroma, little sweet flavor hoppy and sweet, little bitter on the finish. Nice dry hop.

Rating #2024- 2015.09.27 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 4, Beer 126 - Draught at Taproom. Golden pour with a bubbly, lasting white foam. Aroma is citrusy, grapefruit notes, mild grassiness, mild floral, piney scent.Taste is a blast of grapefruity hop character whose bitterness evolves to define this beer, a bold bitterness following a crisp, floral,resinous, citrusy sweetness. A rose amongst cigarette butts.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with a thin white head. Soft floral hops, a touch of malt and honey. Medium bodied, soft citrus, a touch of malt, grapefruit. Slow grapefruit, lingering malt. Not a ton going on. Gentle bitterness, soft floral with a touch of grapefruit.

On tap @ Ballard Beer Company. Listed as Dead Wreckoning here. Pours clear bright orange with thin white head. Aroma is thin caramel malt, oaky and dry on the finish. Taste is clean malty light caramel malt, oaky and dry and somewhat flat on the finish. Decent beer, flavorful for a pale.

Draught at Emmett Watson’s, 11/4/15. Good clarity throughout this copper-brass colored beer, with ample carbonation creating a medium-sized white head that shows moderate retention. Soft, but quite fragrant hops in the nose add a dusty, lightly dried floral aroma with just a hint of lemon. Bits of caramel and honey play about but it never seems biscuity or toasty, which is nice (I think). No alcohol, nor flaw. Moderate carbonation and a soft, lightly malty texture go down very easily in this hoppy, but not overly bitter pale ale. Floral notes, vanilla, light baked bread and a lightly dextrinous chewiness to the texture, on the finish. Very reserved, and while it’s brewed admirably, I can’t help wanting just a little more brightness and punch to it. The delicate flavors seem to fade in to the more domineering malts while a lightly piney note appears on the finish, rather out-of-place for the rest of the beer.

On tap at Maritime Pacific, pours a hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out dry hopping upfront along with biscuity malt. Flavour is pleasant, with notes of floral dry hopping and biscuity malt. Well-balanced and clean. Very drinkable.

On June 24, 2015. At Jolly Roger Taproom (Maritime Pacific) in Seattle, Washington. As "Islander Dry-Hopped PAle Ale" listed as 5.8% ABV and 40 IBU. Hazy golden color, white head. Herbal, bitter, hoppy taste. Herbal aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Hoppy, herbal scent.

Tap at the brewery with commonshawn, rosskyle, and wildcard. Pint glass. Golden in color with a hint of orange. Minimal froth. Aroma has plenty of pine and floral characteristics. Vibrant and refreshing on the nose. Mouthfeel is oily and resiny. Taste is mostly bright, citrus with pine cones kind of running the show. Not necessarily overly bitter but definitely hop resiny. Not really unique or impressive. Harmless.
Draft - Light fruity notes and a bit of apple. Clear gold with a decent white head. Fruity esters, stone fruit, light grass and a Belgian sweet finish. Nice.

Serving: from bottle--purchased at Northwest Sausage & Deli. Aroma: moderate orange and wheat. Appearance: small, white initial head with fully diminishing longevity. Clear, dark-yellow body. Taste: lightly sour initial flavor and lightly sour, clove finish with short duration. Palate: light body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Overall: excellent. I’ll drink this again whenever I see it.

Draught at WA Brewers Festival, 2014. Pours a slightly hazy light brown color. Nose is very light, and I almost can’t get anything off it. Taste is slightly sweet and slightly floral, but I find that there’s very little to this beer. Meh.
Enjoyed at kellys cafe in gig harbor washington in bottle. Nothing special. Just a very plain light golden belgian ale.

Bottle. Clear golden color with lasting white head, no lacing. Herbal, earthy, light fruit aromas. Medium bodied with average co2. Earthy, dusty, bready pale malt flavors with a light fruit sweetness___ nicely drying bitter finish---not bad

floral, earthy, bubblegum aromas crystal clear golden color constant bed of foam with some decent lacing. Has a light body with a bit of sweetness and soft bitterness some creaminess. This bottle had a bit of age on it I seem to remember liking this beet on tap better, decent summer quenched.

Crisp, slightly copper tinted golden coloured body with a thin, half a centimetre tall just off-white head. Aroma of very pale malt, a hint of grassy and herbal notes and a tiny bit of sweetness and alcohol. Light-bodied; Sharp metallic and earthy malt notes with a little sweetness and a hint of fruits with some grassy flavours finishing it off. Aftertaste shows a mostly malt flavour with hints of alcohol, sugar, grass and a little rice. Overall, not such a great beer, but somewhat refreshing. I didn’t get any of the yeast notes nor of the hoppiness. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Belmont Station in Portland, Oregon on 12-April-2013 for US$0.99 sampled at home in Washington on 18-June-2013.

355ml bottle pours a hazy pale golden color with a huge white head that retains quite well and leaves some decent lacing on the glass. Aroma is caramel and light fruits with some yeast. Taste is light malty sweet with some light fruits and mild hop bitterness with a yeasty finish. Light bodied and generously carbonated. A decent Belgian blonde ale, but a little on the thin side.
Bottle with Carla. Pours lightly hazy gold with white foam. Smells sweet with hints of belgian yeast. Tastes lightly wheaty and strongly of authentic Belgian yeasts.

Pours a light orange into Delirium Tremens Tulip. Three fingers of white head.. Light, crisp smell. Light fruits. Not a true Belgium smell. Maybe a bit bland. Sweet taste, but not much of it. Really light bodied. If you want a cheap Belgium knock off, this isn’t that close. Nothing special.

Pours a very dark ruby-brown, almost black, with a medium size tan head. Mild aromas of roasted malt with some chocolate and hints of coffee and hops. Tastes of malt but with a bitter finish. Medium bodied.
Draft - Raisin, dark fruit and cocoa. Deep brown with a decent white head. Lots of raisin, dark sugars and Roasty malts. Lots of raisin.
What a great beer!! Wonderful body and roasted malt character!!! Finish is smooth.

Nice deep dark brownish coloured body with a large, fast-dying light brown coloured head with larger bubbles and a glow of cola colours when held up to a light. Aroma of alcohol, raisins, pit fruits, chocolate, yeast and a bit of prunes - strong, but more of a porter or sweet stout than of an imperial stout. Medium-bodied; Strong alcohol and vanilla flavours with hints of oak and coffee, but a lot of earthy and mushroomy flavours with touches of chocolate and prunes. Aftertaste is fairly one dimensional and not too pungent - malty and chocolate flavours come out the strongest with a touch of alcohol on the finish. Overall, a decent baltic porter or stout, but not cutting it for the style. That said, it’s still a drinkable beer - just don’t expect it to be quite the imperial stout that you imagine, especially at 7,5% abv. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Belmont Station in Portland, Oregon on 12-April-2013 for US$2,59 sampled at home in Washington on 01-November-2014, about a year and half after purchasing it, which perhaps mellowed it out a bit, but this one wasn’t strong anyways.
Rating from my backlog. The look is reddish brown in color with a tan head. The smell is roast, malts, coffee, chocolate. The taste is chocolate, coffee, cat food, and ok.

Bottle 2013-Chocolate, roast, coffee, bread, dark fruit in the aroma. Pours black with a mocha colored head. Roast, chocolate, coffee, fruit, balancing bitterness great mouthfeel @7.5% which seems pretty low for an imperial stout, but doesn’t lack in flavor

Thanks to 5000 for sending this bottle. Black with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate, sweet and roasted malt. Flavor is roasted malt and chocolate with some light coffee notes. High, prickly carbonation and medium mouthfeel.

A deep dark imperial stout with a thin brown head. In aroma, nice sweet chocolate with resinous hops, licorice, molasses, a bit of funk, very nice and complex. In mouth, very sweet chocolate with vinous notes, ashes, floral hops, treacle, veering into old ale territory.

Bottle at the Pre-Christmas CBC - Clerkenwell Tasting, London. Thanks to Colin for this beer. Pours rich brown with a fine beige cream head. Sugary dark malt nose, some alcohol, burnt toast and dark cocoa. Medium sweet flavor with light roast, dusty cocoa, smooth dark malts. Medium bodied with fine, creamy carbonation. Light dry finish with mellow roasted malts, light earthy bitterness, some marshmallow, burnt wood, baking cocoa. Very smooth and pleasant impy stout, though not particularly complex.

Bottle at pre Xmas tasting (Belmont Station, Portland OR) - 21/12/12. Murky light black with a thin tan head that immediately dissipates to the edge. Nose is dark malts, molasses, touch of smoked gammon, light chocolate. Taste follows, touch of wood, leather, liqourice, chocolate. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry in the finish. Ok - lower end of the Imperial Stout market!

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Saxer Brewing Company--Portland Brewing Company--Henry Saxer Public Lager--2001 12 oz. Bottle. 4.70% ABV. 20 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Clear rich golden color. Creamy white head. Medium lace. Malty mild Saaz hop floral front. Smooth creamy malty buttery body is complex, tasty and lightly caramel sweet. Crisp mild malt hop end. Sampled 9/25/2001.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Medium Gold Color, large creamy head. Light hops, subtle malting. A nice mild lager, subtle flavor. Good malt to hop balance. Refreshing. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly malty, no bitterness.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Amber coloured. Crystal malty accented. Balanced & refreshing. ............

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Color- orange, light but dark for a lager. Head- Thick, slightly rocky. Aroma- clean and filling. Yeast is from Weihenstephan. Nice mouthfeel, light hoppiness, good efervescent.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: A very drinkable beer, clean and freash as lagers should be. I think a great session beer. Nice hop and malt nose, the mouth feel is clean and thirst quenching.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Saxer Brewing Company--Portland Brewing Company--Henry Saxer Dark Lager--2001 12 oz. Bottle. 4.50% ABV. 21 IBU’s. (3.75 / 5.0) Clear rich dark bronze red color. Big tan head leaves rich lace. Mild toasted cherry front. Smooth light tasty semi sweet toasted cherry caramel body. Smooth end hints at biscuit spice notes. Sampled 9/24/2001.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: No. 500!! When poured into my glass, this beer had a small sized tan head that contained fine-large bubbles that was mostly lasting. The body of this beer was clear with carbonation observed and a reddish-brown hue. The nose was malty and fruity with a malt and caramel flavoring. The palate was smooth and medium bodied. This beer left a good amount of lacing on the sides of my glass.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: This brew poured a small head of fine to medium sized light brown colored mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a poor lacing and a softly carbonated transparent brown colored body. The aroma is a very nice caramel malt one and the mouthfeel is smooth with a touch of "Brown" feeling to it. The flavor is a medium strength roasted caramel malt one with a mild caramel overtone to it. It is a bit on the thin side and could use a bit more character to it, but still i liked it and would drink it again.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Clear amber brown with a thin light brown head and large bubbles. Malty nose with a nutty, raisen aroma. Flavor is of caramel, sopa pop, and sugar. This has an even nutty taste, though a bit thin.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Dark amber with a short-lived head. Low carbonation. Slight nuttiness in the aroma. Smooth and malty with some roasted and grainy malt flavors. Slightly grassy hop flavors contribute a little in the finish; hardly any bitterness. Slight sourness in the aftertaste. Not bad, but it doesn''t seem to have a lot of personality.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Medium brown color, large head. Medium hops and malts. Medium bodied, roasted malts, slightly sweet malts, good hop flavor. A simple beer, but very well done. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is malty, slight bitterness. The malts really come through on this beer.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: As with his Public lager, this dark style is quite drinkable. Good malt and hop balance that leaves your palate with a clean and refreshed feel, but still a quite flavor filled beer, not the least bit "Wimpy".

From old tasting notes. Copper colored with a fine creamy beige head. Soft fruity toasted malt aroma. Wonderfully complex caramel malt flavor with herbal hop overtones. Sweet malt/hop finish is long and flavorful. Very true to that ESB style.

Frederick Brewing Company--Blue Ridge ESB Red Ale--1999 Release--12 oz. Bottle--4.80% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) ESB--Pretty clear bright light copper red color. Earth floral hop aroma backed by malty biscuity lightly roasted body. Hop spice touch in flavorful finish. Balanced with rich flavor despite light body. Sampled 6/29/1999. Frederick Brewing Company--Blue Ridge Brewing Company--Blue Ridge ESB Red Ale--2001 Release--12 oz. Bottle--5.40% ABV--35 IBU’s. (3.5 / 5.0 ) ESB--Clear thin copper red color. Creamy white head with light lace. Mild earthy floral hop front. Light textured ESB body with mild toasted bisquit fruit notes. Dry sweet. Mild hop ESB end. Sampled 6/24/2001.

Sept. 2006 - Another good effort from the Blue Ridge folks. Pour was amber colored with decent head and some lacing. The aroma was citrusy. The flavor was caramel, bready sweet with a citrusy hop bite. Well balanced. Good bee

Found this offering at a wedding last night. Pours amber/red (go figure) with a nice thick head that takes a little time to die down. Smells predominantly of hops with a little fruit and malt. Starts out tasting of a little malt and fruity followed by a kick of hops. Finishes dry and bitter. Mouthfeel is very smooth with some nice body and carbonation. A seviceable brew, especially for a wedding. Worth a try.
Had this beer on 9/14/1999. Aroma is malty. Color deep amber. Taste tangy, crisp and bitter. Starting with a light body that goes down with a crisp malt flavor . Finish is a sharp bitterness.

Name: Blue Ridge ESB Real Ale Date: 01/01/1994 Mode: Draft Source: Capitol City, DC Good strong bitter. Makes a statement. Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Bottle. Aroma is caramel and biscuit, sweet and malty. Light flowery fruitiness. Pours a hazy, coppery amber with a short-lived tan head. Medium-light bitterness is slightly exceeded by a rounded sweetness. Mild fruitiness with light floral hops. Medium body with a smooth (almost creamy), lightly prickly mf that calls for attention. Dry, slightly hoppy aftertaste. Not bad at all!

A pretty good hometown beer, I sampled poured from the bottle. The color was a dark orange-reddish with a thin tan head. The beer tastes pretty bitter with a slight touch of malty sweetness; it is also mildly sour.The aroma is dominantly malty with a possible hint of fruityness. It had fizzy carbonation and a medium body with a slick texture. The most inventive and rewarding of the Blue Ridge beers I have sampled so far.

A pretty good ESB - I just had a keg of Stoudt’s Scarlet Lady ESB in my beer meister and I actually wish I had had this one instead. It has a nice reddish color and very good flavor. I don’t think ESB is one of my favorite styles anymore, but this one was rather drinkable, all the same.

From a 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with a short blurb on the left side of label and a unmarked best before date on the right side. Made a satisfactory appearance, poured an amber hued copper with a foamy, clingy white head that settled into a thin bubbly lacing, good carbonation. Had a piney, earthy, lemony grassy nose with a sweet grainy malt background. A smoothly bitter, crisp light bodied mouth feel, good drinkability. Tobacco and earthy grassiness with a touch of lemon, a gentle rolling hop bitterness, balanced by a sweet, toasted barley maltiness with a light butteriness creeping in and a sweet malty and tobacco grassy finish, very tasty. A decent ESB from Blue Ridge, a tad too light bodied for me, but very quaffable.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: From old tasting notes. Opaque brown color topped by a huge tan head. Smooth chocolatey malt aroma. Rich roasted malt flavor. More chocolate

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Date: 06/24/2006 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting Appearance: black, big tan head, Aroma: light roasted malt aroma with a hint of chocolate, Flavor: nice roasted flavor, some sweet chocolate, light bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **+/4

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Poured a clear very dark brown with a ruby hue and medium tan head. Sweet and roasty aroma. Chocolate with a hint of coffee and a light tartness. Flavor of tart and roasty malt. Light to medium body.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Bottle shared by goldtwins: Pours an opaque black with a forthy nicely-lacing tan head. Sweet caramel and chocolate malty aroma has some aged malty character and a hint of light fruit. Body starts lightly sweet and citric turning more tart and roasty toward the thinner, fruity finish. Good aroma, but the body is too tart, most likely due to age.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Thanks to goldtwins for this one. Pours dark brown/ruby with a huge tan head. Not much lacing, but the head stayed around forever. Aroma of malt, chocoff, cabernet, and fruit. The taste showed roasty malt, with fruitiness, some nuttiness, and some finishing kriekiness. Palate was lighter than most stouts. This one had some Newcastle brown alishness to it, and was nicely complex. Quaffable.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: this bear had a big head, the type the pours well over your glass and on to the table. As for the beer, tasted a lot of alcohol. There was some other flavors, but for a stout it was very light. Not the best i’ve had...

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Dark. Obnoxiously foamy, bubbled out of bottle. Nose roasty, a bit tangy. Flavor is a bit roasty, but overpowering molasses is the most noticeable taste. Overfoam makes it a bit flat. Not exciting.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: A very smooth malty stout, with lots of caramel roastedness. Pours a deep rich brown color with a nice frothy tan head. Nice and nutty, balanced and very smooth.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: I had to pour this one down the drain because it was so old. My uncle gave me one to try but the carbonation was overwhelming and would not settle. The taste was very acidic as well. I will have to try it again sometime.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Huge head. Dark brown appearance. Roasted malt aroma with hints of fruit. Smooth malty taste and finish.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: 2nd of flight of 4 @ beerculture, as simply "Saratoga Pilsner". amber color, clear as far as i could tell in low light, malty, bitter, creamy.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Draft at kashkqval. Pours a clear light tan color. Drinkable slightly hoppy and sessionable

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Growler filled at Shoreline Beverage. I had to double-check this since it been retired with no ratings for ten years. Pours a slightly hazed gold with a thin-moderate linen white head that is gone before the second sip and leaves no lace. Mild aroma of malt with a few notes of noble hops. The flavor is malt followed by some noble hops with some mild lingering bitterness. Crisp and dry at the finish. Medium bodied.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Slightly hazy orange/golden colour with a super thick soapy off-white head. Aroma slighly yeastie, slightly wheatie with a sweet pit fruit smell. Light-bodied; Subtle apricot/peach flavour with some maltiness and hardly any hops. Aftertaste clean, but shows some persistent sweetness. Actually, nice for the style-definately worth trying. I bought this twelve ounce bottle at Chevy Chase Wine & Liquor in Washington and sampled it on 30-November-2003.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Clear golden body topped by big white head. Aroma is strongly lemony tart/sweet and slightly floral. Flavor is too much lemon tartness, with nothing to balance. A little too carbonated.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: This slightly cloudy brew had a poor nose, fair taste and a terrible aftertaste. I was hardly able to finish the bottle.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: A good pilsner, malts and hops well balanced. Decent carbonation, very crisp and clean tasting.
a decent wheat ale. not very wheaty and has a nice sweet rasberry finish. slightly bitter. had a draft pourat mickey finns. looks golden yellow in color similar to cloudy urine.

On tap, poured into a sampler glass. It has a soapy, lemon cleanser aroma with other notes of pine, and herb. It pours a murky pale yellow with a medium fluffy white head. Not much of it retains (a medium light ring) with a runny lace. The taste is a light bitter with a medium light sweet and a touch of sour. It’s a water thin texture with a fuzzy, light carbonation. The body is light and finishes with a lemongrass and other spice touch. It’s clean, dry, and crisp with a light aftertaste.

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy pale gold with a white head that starts and remains at the edges. Aroma is full of wheat and earthy grains. Flavor is similar with earthy grains and wheat. Unremarkable.

Clearly an entry level beer, that is a knock off of Goose Islands 312. Pours from tap into a pint glass a pale yellow orange with 2 fingers of white head. Nose and taste is semi sweet no big flavors here, a bit watery and thin even for this style.
draft... MF’s poke at GI 312... light sweet honey water some decent taste, easy to drink, better than a lager but not much there
If you think GI 312 is bad try this, it is buttery Perrier. Enough with the dumb area code wheat ales.
Tap at mickey fins. Pours a light amber orange with a small white head. A weird burnt pear note, doughy wheat, anf tangerines. Some light yeast character. Medium carbonation. Not bad.

Clear golden with a frothy white head. Nice aroma is tart wheat and bready yeast. Medium bodied. Decent flavor is tart wheat with a pale malt and citrusy sweetness. Another nice hot weather beer from Finns.
Pour is clear golden with a thin white head...smell is lightly toasty and sweet...taste is the same....no spices really there...nice mouthfeel...

Sampler at the pub. Cloudy American Wheat appearance. Smells shows banana esters that are more at home in a hefeweizen than an American wheat. But slightly higher hop levels are appreciated. Some ale fruitiness further down. Finish has a bit of sweet roll dough to it.

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: (Thanks, Jim! "ozzy70") Can. A- Rye, malty, mild pine, prickly pear. A- Golden orange, hazy liquid, off white head. T- Rye, malty. P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, malty finish. O- I am familiar enough with the prickly pear flavor that I could pick up some aroma and a bit of flavor from it. Lots of caramel malt and some rye note.

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: Shared with Strykzone of Facebook Chat. Pours bright gold with a white head. Nose of cactus flowers. Med body. The flavor is floral and the finish is lightly bitter. Good.

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: Can from variety pack. Purchased in West Yellowstone. Poured hazed amber, white head. Aroma of grapefruit, pine. Taste was mild bittersweet, pine, caramel, fruity.

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: On tap. (5.9% ABV) Pours a clear gold-orange with a medium, creamy, long lasting, off-white head that leaves curtains of lace. Sweet aroma of biscuit malt, tangerine, orange and floral hops. Sweet flavour of biscuit malt, tangerine, orange peel, prickly pear and spicy hops in a dry, bitter finish. Medium body with an oily texture and average carbonation. Unique and enjoyable.

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: Can split at L6, from an IP trade with Stevoj, 17/01/19. Very lightly hazed golden orange with a decent off white covering. Nose is pale malts, citric pith, tangerine, grass. Taste comprises orange zest, hint of pear, grass, toasted grains, tangerine, airy malts. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with moderate hop bitterness. Passable pale ... slightly better than I'd expected to be fair.

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: Can shared at the Columbus tasting 17/01/2019. Thanks to Colin for this one. A clear golden orange coloured pour with a loose off white head. Aroma is semi sweet pear watermellon, biscuity grains, turkish delish. Flavour is composed of semi sweet, tea leaves, turkish delish, dry grains. Palate is semi sweet, low carboantion, ok.

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: Can shared in London - cheers to Cloin. Pours clear gold with A small, creamy white head. Medium sweet flavour, some pine, ripe citrus. Light bodied with fine to average carbonation. Finishes with more bready malts, pine needles, ripe lemon. Not bad.

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: 17Jan2019 Bitter grain and cereal malts, bitter citrus fruits, orange peel. Clear gold, small, creamy, white head. Bitter grain malts, bitter citrus and tropical fruits, orange peel, green mango, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Alright. Can shared at L6 tasting - thanks to Theydon_Bois!

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: Nice pale ale but nothing really notable about this one. A bit hoppy finish and actually kind of a funky, though not bad, aftertaste. Not a beer I would go out my way for...

column1: Lewis and Clark Prickly Pear Pale Ale
column5: Nice smooth beer similar to an IPA. Excellent feel to it. Pick it up if you get a chance.
Vegetal, sweet, bloody awful. I tried this on tap years ago and it is as bad as people say. It's also over carbonated.

Pours dark amber into a shaker. White head with little retention recedes to hug rim. Sweet malt aromas. Medium bodied with rotting vegetables and sweet malt extract upfront turning to rancid earth in the lasting finish.

Low alcohol lager. Can from local corner shop. Good appearance and a sweet malty taste, dominated by a cloying artificial taste. Some bitterness, but not enough to offset the rather metallic sweetness. Not great, but better than nothing if you are trying to avoid alcohol.
Bottle - poura gold with a white head. Aroma is sweet malt. Taate is sweet and metallic.
Terrible low alcohol beer. Overly malty sweet, gold and thin. Tried for the first time in 2009.

Bottle pours a clear golden copper with a one finger off-white head and light lacing. Aroma is molasses, bread, wet suede, and light raisin. Taste is primarily bread crust while the backing flavors promote sweetness. The aftertaste is molasses and is short lived.

Bottle from Merchants, oh boy. Aroma is bad, like sticks in a forest, caramel, figs maybe, it smells like a wet log with moss on it after a good rain, grains, just awful. Appearance is amber, clear, light tan head that is amazingly still around. Taste is just terrible, caramel, corn, water, fizz, fake sweetener rounding out with an astoundingly bitter hop presence. Mouthfeel is light body, it feels overly sweetened, light crisp carbonation, really dreadful fake sweet caramel corn water aftertaste. Overall, we do have a contender here for worst beer I have ever had. Even the other n/a offerings had something to offer, but this one is extremely off-putting.

my mother used to buy me this all the time when i was a kid, even though she probably shouldn't have! either way, i thought i was the bees knees, and i honestly recall enjoying the taste. anyway, i stumbled upon a bottle recently and couldn't finish it. down the sink it went. definitely avoid.
Aroma, appearance, and body weren’t bad, flavor had a sour aspect. Tried a second bottle, same thing.

It pours a nice deep gold colour and brings close to a 1 finger head of foam. The lacing is good; actually better than many a brew I’ve had before. The smell is all cereal grain. Corn Flakes, Post Toasties...I almost want to reach for some milk and a bowl. The taste follows the nose to a tee, maybe a slightly better perception to my palate than to my nose. Cereal grain with slight sweetness, no bitterness. Not at all surprising, considering the style, and not offensive in any way to my palate and, in fact, has a kind of appeal that is hard to explain. Hey, we are working here with the bare minimum in alcohol content. ’nuff said. Light bodied with medium carbonation. Drinkability? I bought a sixer and this bottle sure left the scene in a hurry. I’m not saying that I’d want to drink it every day but it does make for a good change of pace. I think this is a very good Malt beverage.

In the interest of fairness, I found this bottle in the back of my sister’s refrigerator. My brother-in-law said: "Oh, I didn’t know that was still in there. That’s been there for a long time." That said, the appearance is a hazy light gold with absolutely no head or lacing. The aroma is very sweet and floral,
…
Going off memory on this one.(Probally 2 years ago) I remember it being a golden our and not much body at all. Tasted light a watery beer. I am not sure if they still make this.

[bottle] Pours a pale gold color with a very thin and fizzy white head. Had your standard lager smell... a nice balance of hops and malt. Nothing to write home about but nothing to turn up your nose at either. Dry and crisp taste mainly of malt with a slight hoppy finish. A bit watery, but I guess it’s to be expected
…
For my money, the best stooge is still Shemp................................

I didn’t expect much from this beer, given the mediocre reviews of Panther’s other
…

Clipper City Porter--2000 12 oz. Bottle. 4.70% ABV. 25 IBU’s. (3.75 / 5.00) Clear copper brown color. Light toasted front emphasizes hops. Medium light thin body accents toasted earthy rich flavor. Chalky texture, mild sweetness. Ends lightly dry. Light laced. 4/18/2000
This here is big for me. It is a very light brown color. definitely the lightest brown I have ever aseen in a porter. Roasty and delicious. I did notice cocoa as the label suggests.
Top notch porter, love the big roasted malt nose and a decent subtle hop bite. Smooth, rich and creamy. Slightly dry at the finish.
Tap at New England Brewing Company, New Haven. Colour is slightly cloudy orange with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Fruits, grass, some sweetness, hops and malts.

On tap at the brewery: Pours golden with a foamy white head. Aroma of cereal malts, grass, herbal, light citrus. Taste more of the same, kind of a cross between a pils and an IPA. Very grassy, medium body, really tasty.

New England Bucket List Trip #182. Growler from the brewery. Pours a hazy golden with a medium sized creamy off-white head. Good head retention. Aroma of dank, herbal hops and grainy malt. The taste is noble, herbal hops, caramel malt. Medium bodied, well balanced.

Nebco crushing it per usual. Really nice noble hopped spicy ipa with floral, and grassy herbal hoppiness with a nice toasty and nutty malt background. Not your traditional IPA at all and thats why it rocks.
Rich and biscuity, toasty, rich grassy and herbal hops. Fantastic malt flavors and overly hopped

64 oz growler into a tulip. Pours a hazy golden amber with thick sudsy white foam that clings forever. Looks like most hoppy NEBCO offerings. Nose is really unique and amazing. That typical English hop quality of grass, earth, and floral notes. Beyond that is a huge sweetness of caramel that ends in an almost zesty way, like a lemon or lime. Faint oak and vanilla to round it out. Really great. The flavor doesn’t quite match up though. English hops; floral and grassy with a moderate bitterness. Caramel malts and some wood on the finish, Smooth and easy drinking. Medium bodied and creamy. A pretty unique offering that I wish wasn’t so rare. However it’s not NEBCO’s best.

A: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing S: Floral, Mild Citrus, Mild Oakey T: Floral, Citrus, Grainy M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Bitter, Mildly Drying Overall, very hoppy and grainy for ’american strong ale’...more like an IPA.

Growler in a tulip. Pours cloudy golden with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of a lot of floral hops, some pale and caramel hops, and some dough. Flavor the same, with a lot of hops for the hops used. Average texture. A good IPA.

Big thanks to woosterbill for this one. Reviewed from notes. Pours a nice, deep golden color with a good white head. Nose brings some really strong earthy, herbal, and lightly-citric hops. Really, really nice. Taste is along the same lines with a bit of earthy and floral characteristics plus a good deal of pine and some slight citrus. This is a cacophony of hops without any one type really dominating. Slight bready notes. Great bitterness levels and a bit dry. I was not at all impressed with Sea Hag, but this showed me that when they try, NEBC can really bring the hop attack. Serving type: growler Reviewed on: 10-29-2010

Had a pint of this at American Craft in Brookline to have with my meatloaf. This was listed as a "hoppy maibock"Nice amber and orange color with a thin head. Very fresh puney hop aroma with some citrus notes. Mild bitter flavor. Medium body. Paired well with the meatloaf that had smokey bacon in it.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: #10, 4/2015. Svìtle zlatá, èirá barva, stabilní pìna. Nevýrazná sladová vùnì. Nižší plnost, nasládlá chu s nepøíjemnou dochutí. Možná špatná várka èi špatnì skladováno.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: Hromadný zápis: Dopisuji piva v rozmezí dnù 1.5. - 23.6. V této dobì jsem si piva kupoval pøevážnì z opavské pivotéky. Jednalo se jak o spodní, tak i svrchnì kvašená piva, obèas i spontánní. Vše si navíc dokumentuji i v pivním deníku, a kvùli málu èasu nebudu tady znova každé hodnotit zvláš. Vìtšina piv byla chutná, nìkterá slabší, nìkterá pøímo vynikající. Všem pivovarùm dìkuji za jejich výtvory, které jsou pro mì cennými zkušenostmi v oblasti pivních degustací.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: 0,5l bottle. Szép tartós hab, erõs szénsavasság, keserû utóíz. Üdítõ hatású sör, bár nekem túl szénsavas. Nem az a könnyed fajta. Gondolom ennek is a csapolt verziója lehet a komolyabb.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: getrunken auf einer Polterer-Reise in Prag im Mai 2018 Das normale Helle von Herold ist ein wunderbarer Vertreter des klassischen tschechischen Lagerbiers. Es ist gut süffig und passt auch gut als Speisebegleitung.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: 0.5l bottle, from a Komarno supermarket.Hazy golden body, nice silky off-white head. Aroma is moderate, with a bit of yeasty sourness, not very pleasant. Later also some buttery aroma, maybe diacetyl. Body is typical Czech bittersweet, with slightly closer to the sweet end than what I would prefer and expect from a pilsner. Nevertheless, there is nice, spicy, floral bitterness. Palate is perfect, mild, silky carbonation and a very fresh character. Enjoyable, fresh and harmonic, with minor flaws.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: Bottle at Pivovarský Klub, pours a crystal clear copper with a small beige head. Aroma brings out light cereal grains, with a touch of crisp cracker. Flavour is crisp, with biscuity malt and very restrained grassy hops. Pretty unsophisticated and lacking depth. Not a superior Czech pils.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: Bottled. Clear yellow colour, medium white head. Bready aroma, some hay and cereals. Lightly sweet taste, grains, honey, spicy hop bitterness. Light body, soft carbonation, dry finish with low hop bitterness. Good.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: Prakticky tady pøidávám tento komentáø, jen aby tady nìco bylo, protože zpìtnì dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: I'm sorry but I don't remember the beer description. I've written down only the overall rating.

column1: Herold Czech Premium Lager / Svìtlý Bøeznický Ležák 12°
column5: Tap@Bar Fiserka, Prague. Pale yellow, smooth white head. Aroma spices, yeast. Taste mainly sweet, mildly spicy finish.

Bottled. Cloudy golden colour, large and stable frothy white head. Typical weizen aromas, banana, cloves, bread. Well rounded taste of bread, dough, banana, tropical fruits. Light to medium body, average carbonation, smooth mouthfeel, decent fruity finish. Nice beer, classic hefeweizen.
500ml bottle from Xinhuadu, Jimei. Pours hazy golden orange with a white head. Aroma of malt with berries. Sweetish taste and finish.

50 cl. flip-top bottle @ home, bought @ Edeka, Kleve. Hazy dark yellow with a big white head. Banana and cloves aroma. Sweet creamy taste with a nice gentle bitter finish. More than decent Weissbier specimen.

very sweet, very malty and wheaty aroma. very murky foggy look. very nice taste of wheat, tastes of malt and has this very nice fruity/yeasty type of tang to it. a little bit watery, but it makes it feel pretty refreshing. 500ml bottle.
W aromacie banan, lekko goŸdzik, s³odki, intensywny, przyjemny. Barwa ciemnoz³ota, mêtne, piana ³adna. W smaku pó³s³odkie, kwaskowe, wysoko wysycone. Przyjemny weizen.
500ml bottle. It is the better Kapuziner weizen. Hazy, yellow colour, hint of yeast and tropical fruit aromas describe it. Maybe tangerine.

Review based on the BJCP2015 guidelines (style 10A). Bottle 50 cl - Batch A1 05:54 (BBF 02.02.20). AROMA: medium clove-like aroma with slight notes of bubble-gum. medium-low background of sweet wheat. APPEARANCE: gold color and hazy. medium moussy creamy white head with good retention. TASTE: medium-low initial wheat flavor with slight sweetness. low clove and faint bubblegum. medium-low to low bitterness with a semi-dry and slightly wheaty finish. PALATE: medium body with medium carbonation. OVERALL: an ok weissbier a bit less intense on the palate.
Bevuta alla spina. Classico aroma da Weiss. Torbida con schiuma persistente. FgMr
Trópusi gyümölcsök intenzíven megjelennek benne leginkább mandarin enyhe banános beütés az aromáját tekintve illata pörkölt maláta stílusával rendelkezik a sör.
Velmi dobré sladové pivo, které je pocitovì opravdu silné a pšeniènì sladové, pøitom cítím ménì vùnì høebíèku èi banánu. Je to trošku jedinou chybou, ovšem dobré poctivé pivo.

4 finger off-white head. Bit of lacing. Semi-hazy, mid amber to murky orange coloured beer. Aroma of wet sourdough bread, citrus peels, grains, hints of sweet liquorice and raisins. Taste of grains, bit metallic, bit of corn sweetness and a general pilsner skunkiness. Mouthfeel is soft with a round body. Medium, long & skunky bitterness. Medium carbonation. Light, somewhat hollow feel. Oily after a while. Overall: Well this was a dissappointing. Expected a dope ass Märzen or something along those lines but it didn't differ that much from a run-of-the-mill lager. It didn't have the typical overcarbonated, watery type of feel so there's atleast that.
* Old rating, 50cl bottle, best before stamp: L 03.04/146. Frisch-raues Bier. Malzig, leicht süßlich. Unrund. Im Nachgeschmack herb, leicht malzig-süßlich. Ok.

Not sure if I bought this in Ontario or had this in Berlin on tap. If it weren’t for flashbacks I would have no memory at all but I do remember it being dry. A well made Maibock that deserves more ratings. Page 49 of MJ’s Great Beer Guide only 472 Classic Brews to go.
Clear orange. Sharp skunky aroma and flavour. I do not like maibocks in general, but this one was so bad i could hardly finish it.
Clear orange color, thick foam. Skunky sharp metal aroma, bit hops maybe. Sharp metallic flavor and iron palate. This one is just disgusting, i cannot understand those previous ratings...
Good maibock. Wish I lived in Germany so I could get this in those massive beer mugs. Creamy aroma with hoppy finish.

Clear, deep gold with a nice white head. Spritzy, effervescent, and crisp. Nice aroma. Dry finish with sharp, lasting flavors. Didn't like the slight metallic flavor. Loved the bold mouthfeel. Overall, very enjoyable.

Upon its separation from the 330ml brown bottle the beer sets in the glass a slightly bemused golden amber color, the head moderate in size and off white in color with the resultant lace a thin covering upon the glass. Nose is malt sweet, quite crisp and fresh; start is sweet with a decent malt presence, the top light to fair in feel. Finish is stinging in its acidity, the hops personable and the aftertaste desert dry, a drinkable beer.

Clear golden color with lacing off-white head. Aroma has yeast, fruits and some spices. Taste is malty sweet with long somewhat bitter and a bit sweet aftertaste. Flavors of citrus, yeast, coriander and grass.
Chiara dorata con schiuma bianca fine e persistente. Al naso sentori floreali
Spice stale ashtray aroma with stone fruit. Murky yellow colour good head and lacing. Malt fruit ashtray flavour. Flat palate.
