Excellent American version of a classic english bitter. Complex, malts and hops to the front, great head and lace. Quite drinkable.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: Rockies Brewing Company--Boulder Brewing--Fall Fest Amber Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (3.0 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Rich golden red color. Light fruit flavor in rich Oktoberfest style malt body. A little spicy and not grainy as the best Oktoberfests. More of a cross between an Oktoberfest and a Winter Ale. Sampled 11/27/1998.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: Had this beer on 9/30/1998. Color is a rich amber with good carbonation and head. Aroma has a nice hop scent with light malt back tones. Taste is crisp and nice. It starts with a light bubbly body that goes down crisp and refreshing. The finish is also crisp with a fresh feel, lightly bitter and a nice light hop flavor. Its a well balanced brew with a nice fresh taste. Also it fits what a good Fall brew should be and this one would be wonderful on a cool Fall afternoon.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: A yeasty murky amber brown concouction with a lot of dust on the bottle. Medium fizzly head, an indication it was on its way beyond shelflife. Lots of caramello, toffe and some forestry brushed pine notes. Could have been a lot more "seasonal." Let’s make a happy little tree.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: 12oz bottle pours amber with a short offwhite head. Aromas of caramel, and a bit of pine. Flavor is caramel, some toffee, and some citrus and pine notes as well. Medium bodied. Not much carbonation. Pretty average all around.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: The aroma has caramel malt and pine hops with some spice and fruit. The appearance is deep amber with a small head. The flavor is not the best. There are all the elements from the aroma plus some prunes, paper, and grass. The palate is typical for an amber ale but the aftertaste is acidic. Much like the last Boulder Beer I had, this one could be stale.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: Pours dark golden tending towards amber with a fully receding white head. Aroma of sweet caramel and flowery hops. Taste of sweet toffee, nutmeg, and toasted malts. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, slightly sticky. Very nice label, wish the beer was as impressive.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: Deep amber. Nose some piney hops, bit of caramel. Flavor is woody, some maltiness, bitter hops with pine and citrus at the end. Decent, but it needs more malt or more hops, just feels like it’s missing something.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: Bottle (12oz). Poured slightly cloudy umber with a small off-white diminishing head. Aroma is of sharp evergreen resiny hops, but not rich or full - there’s also a background of light roast caramel/cocoa malt and pine cones - really does put you in mind of a walk in a late fall northern forest, although it gets a little funky on warming. Taste is much milder, the hops are muted and the malt is pretty basic, not much roast or caramel character - mouthfeel is weak and mostly flat, a touch astringent. The aroma’s the best thing about this, and even that’s not memorable.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: [bottle - 12 oz] Slightly murky ruby pour with a soapy looking white head. Not much of it, but very nice color. Very light aroma, mostly caramel or toffee mixed with some apple cider aroma, cinnamon and grain. Apples begin the flavor with a malty and grainy middle and a dry and very flavorless finish. It claims dry hopped, but there weren’t many hops to be found. Some slight bitterness at the end of a few sips though.

column1: Boulder Beer Fall Fest Autumn Ale
column5: bottle-pours glowing bright orange with a small soapy off-white head. grainy, lightly carmel, doughy aroma with a note of soil. flavors are mostly toasted malts and earthy hop tones. some bitting astringency on the body which brought the score down. the body was full for the style however. dry hopped? where? there is no hop aroma here, just alot of hop bitterness that is quite metallic in nature. some light diacytl in there as the beer warmed.

This was a rather interesting beer. Reminded me of a lighter version of Lagunitas Censored Ale versus many of the "ambers" out there....or similar to some Scottish Ales. This was actually more of a darker cloudy brown/copper color that looked pretty much like apple cider. Flavors were mostly caramel malts but had some citrusy flavors similar a pale ale or IPA. Not as bitter as those, but had a decent hop tone at the end. Nothing really special here, but is a decent beer either way.
Had this from the can in Durango, CO. It tastes lighter and less hoppy than most IPA's. easy to drink. Lighter taste and alcohol content too. F Avey---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Amber with a light cream head. Nose is rich caramel, malts, dough and sweet. Chewy palate, sticky caramel, dough, toffee, light finish.

Draft pour pint at the famous Red Rocks amphitheater. So happy to be back here at very well could be the world’s greatest outdoor music venue. To have a beer half as spectacular would the best, but I’ll take what I can get. Pours a clear copper color with a ton of foam head. Gainy aroma. Flavor is a little dry, malty. Bitter finish. Glad to try, but nothing really special here.

I got this at an airport bar and regret not getting a Sam Adams seasonal. This is copper colored and clear with a mixed bubbled white head. This smells like Flintstones vitamins and tastes like dirt and grass. It is not all bad actually, that is just a funny way to describe it. Still, this is likely the last time I get this at an airport bar.
Pours copper with a thin white head. Aroma is floral with plum and raisin notes. Flavor is surprisingly yeasty with a bit of malt and some more fruit flavors. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Boulder Beer. Pours clear orange with white head. Aroma is spicy, pepper, a little roast, citrus. Taste is very rye, simple, medium bodied, low carbonation, bitter finish. Overall, not very impressive.

(labeled as singletrack rye pale ale - can) pours unclear pale golden with a small creamy off-white head, good retention and lacing. spicy soap - irish spring-like *TM, citrus, woodsy cvanilla, spicy and peppery pean maltiness - spicy biscuits; appreciable dose of toasted caramel, pepper and pine. light carbonation, light body - slightly watery; assertive if not slightly unbalanced peppery-spicy-piney finish. decently crafted rye pale ale.
Can at home. Pours amber with a thin off white head. Aroma is pine with some citrus. Medium hopped and some bitterness. Fairly plain. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz can picked up at Harmons in SLC Pours cloudy golden with a medium sized off-white head, good lacing. Aroma of oranges and sweet malts, bisquity. Flavors of toasted malts, mild caramel, bready with a mild citrus bitterness OK
12oz bottle(10/00)-A golden body with a small head and an aroma of nothing. Taste of nothing really resembling a german Hefe with sour notes. Was expecting more from this. Bad example of a hefe.

Had this beer on 11/8/1998. Color is a very light gold with good carbonation and light head. Aroma is very thin and light. Taste is like a sour Bud. It starts with a light body that goes down crisp. The finish is a sour malt taste with a light bitterness. It is just a poor showing of a Weiss style.
A good American styled Weiss beer, not up to the European varieties, but still quite good. hazy and a hint of wheat in the malt nose. Nice head and lace, a just a fair hop bite.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: The English Pale Ale is not often attempted in the States so kudos to them for giving it a shot. Its a tough thing to brew so lightly and all of the imperfections shine through. The hops don’t dominate in favor of sweet, bready malts. There is a little lemon zing, but its barely discernible.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: Copper in color. Not much noticeable aroma...definitely English-style. Smooth malt character but light. Leaves you thirsting for another sip. Notes: Brewery visit during GABF

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: Re-rating and upping the score. The hops profile in this is not the most pleasant - a little sour - but downing the rest of the six pack with various meals during the week (especially Sunday breakfast) helped me better appreciate the taste. Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Medium amber brew with thin white head. Aroma of sweet malts. Taste is just off the mark - very honey-like sweet at the start breaking into a nice hops bitterness that holds promise but descends into a sour grassey mess at the finish. that final sour hops slug is really rather unpleasant. Nice palate. Distinctive but I’ll pass on this in the future.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: Color of honey, aroma of cardboard. Flavor starts off with a nice, sweet, honey ting, little bit of caramel malt, and then dirty dishwater emerges. This is gross. Bottle from Midtown Wine & Spirits, Nashville.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: This poured a copper color with a minimal white head. The aroma contains some caramel, toffee, and floral notes. The flavor is rather malty with some caramel, toffee, and a hint of lemons. The finish is rather sweet. Here you have it folks, they did the EPA spot on but I dont care for the style too much.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: 12 ounce bottle. Pours a bright burnt orange. Head is minimal and unremarkable. Sweet nose of caramel malt and some hops. Sweet toffee taste with minimal bitterness in the finish. Grassy and earthy hops come through the more you drink the beer, but it’s the malts that are the real star. If it had more hops going on, this thing could be astronomical. As it is, it’s simply quite good. That’s not a bad thing.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: On tap @ brewery. Smelled like a copper penny. Pretty mild body with a bland and unimaginative taste. Crisp and dry finish, so its easy to drink but not very tasty.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: Clear orange, light off white ring. Aroma is light fruity malt, caramel, sweet, light metal, some hop bitter notes. Taste is more metallic malt sweetness, some apple, hops are fruity but nondescript, a bit watery.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: 12 oz. bottle. Pours an orange copper color with thin gray film. Aroma of english barley, butter, malts, cherry. Taste is sort of a mix of these flavors but more bland, with a rather uninspiring finish, slightly metallic. Medium bodied and slightly watery. Not horrible but for the same price you can just get better beers.

column1: Boulder Beer Pass Time Pale Ale
column5: Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Toffee like malty sweet aroma. The flavor has sweeter malts with some light earthy hops. Ok.

330ml bottle from Coco Supermarket, Seminyak, Bali (Rp 29,000): Dark brown to ruby red in colour with a bubbly, tan coloured head that sits about a centimetre tall before halving in size. Roasted malts & darker notes open the nose with sugars & caramel showing before a nutty aroma sees things out. Similarly the taste is dark with the same roasted malts & toasted flavours the nose hinted at, I got more of a nutty flavour here too with & earthy bitterness near the end. It's smooth & medium bodied beer with a semi-sweet, crisp & wet feel to it & the balance was better than expected too. This one was easy to drink, enjoyable & one of the better San Miguel beers I've had into the bargain.
Well better than the regular garbage I guess. Def has some body & flavour and there is distinct (albeit faint) Germanic vegemite stink.......ahla bock. Some thinness late. Fully priced at 135 baht.
The foamstabilitiy is medium. It smells malty, darkmalty, sweet. The taste is darkmalty, malty, a bit sweet, little bit hoppy. Pretty round and refreshing!
330ml Flasche. Klar und schwarz mit minimaler Schaumkrone. Malzig mit Röstaromen. Süßlicher Geschmack.
How do i rate a beer? Just bare with me newbie here. Peace! Taste is good. Little hang over next day after 10 bottles of it :-) 330 ml bottle

330 ml. bottle. Pours a medium thick, well retained beige head, without lacing, over a clear brown (SRM 20) body........nose is lightly roasted malts, with mild cocoa, slight caramel tones, no esters, no hops......taste is mildly sweet with caramel tones, light roasted malts with mild hints of cocoa, toasted bread, finishes dry with no ester or hop tones......mouth feel, light body, no alcohol, moderate carbonation. This is clean and more or less meets the general style of Dark Lagers, but is not particularly interesting because of simplicity. However it is drinkable. BJCP 7/2/11/4/6

Bottle 33cl. as San Miguel Negra @Frosty Beer, Tanjung Pandan, Belitung, poured into a shaker. Deep dark brown, tall frothy beige head, good retention and lacing; aroma sweet malts, licorice, molasses, sugar syrup; taste heavy sweet, malty, licorice, molasses; sticky texture;

Dark amber with off white head - Malt aroma with some roasted notes and some fruity notes as well - Malt body with caramel flavour with hints of roasted malt with some hops in the back - The caramel flavour goes into the finish - This was ok

Purchased at AAFES Class 6 at Joint Base Myer-Henderson Hall, VA 11.2 oz bottle. Really a big letdown. Watery and weak at the start; picked up a bit later but not enough oomph for me. Nose is sweet malty but too sweet for me. No trace of ANY hops to my nose or taste but they have to be in there somewhere. Definitely not sessionable. No date markings; how it got from Manila through Skaggs (US importer) and into AAFES and onto shelf in VA likely not efficient, effective or economical.

Pours dark amber with heavy head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is caramel exclusively. Taste is sweet toffee, moving to a light coffee flavor with a hint of cinnamon. Finish is smooth, but without note. Not as bad as I was expecting. A decent lager, if you are drinking a lot of them.

From old tasting notes. Deep reddish brown color. Massive rocky tan head. Sweet brown sugar malt nose.mtasty bittersweet dark malt flavor hints at chocolate, currants and coconut. Wonderfully complex and flavorful.
Bottle@tasting(2001), 50cl. Head: beige colored. Color: coca-cola. Aroma: malt, chocolate, licorice. Taste: chocolate, roasted malt. Palate: smooth, dry, some bitter, medium body. Overall: nice.
Bottle at Chriso’ Blue Mountains of Virginia tasting. Smells of a sugar lined cardboard box. Not a huge amount of body, very old, some roasted malt. Just not very good. Aroma is frankly revolting.

22nd May 2010. ChrisOs ’Blue Ridge Mountains Of Virginia’ tasting! (Early hours of the morning rating). Clear dark brown beer. Light creamy palate. Tired aged malt. A little chocolate. That’s it! Showing it’s age.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ chrisos Back In The UK Tasting. Unclear medium brown color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, oxidide, malty, light chocolate. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, fruity dried fruit. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100522]
bottle at Chris-O ... deep brown ... sweet blackcurrant and toffee roast malts ... light oxidation ... blackcurrant and chocolate roast ...

(Bottle) Pours dark brown with a light brown head. The aroma is of mild cocoa-like roast and a mild oxidation alongside light notes of fruits. Light acidic. The flavour is acidic and light fruity with some light cocoa notes. Bit sourish. Light bodied. This bottle was too old.
Hazy redish brown with a small off-white head. Roasted and fruity notes. Some malt taste combined with raisins. Medium body with a short, dry finish.
thicker then most porters i have had as of late really nice raosted malt nose and choc, this carries through to the flavor really nice well done

Date: 02/10/2000 Mode: Bottle Conditioned Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta brown, whispy tan head, sweet winy malt aroma, sweet malt flavor, wine like esters, slight hint of bitterness, good, but is it a porter? Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Very mild smell, light gold color, medium white head. Initial flavor is light malt, grain, slight peppery spice. Medium carbonation, very refreshing. I really enjoy Euro-pale lagers for some reason, this is my current fav. It's similar to Heineken but more interesting to me at least.
Overgezet van mn Untappd rating. Blik geprobeerd met LiekevdV. Het is een goudgeel bier met een wit schuim. De geur is moutig. De smaak is moutig en pils achtig. Niet veel bijzonders.

A melhor Draught Lager do mundo, segundo os juízes do Brewing Industry International Awards 2002. Puro malte, bem maltada, com leve amargor residual. Apresenta cor dourada brilhante, aroma vibrante e sabor refrescante, com inesperado final fresco. Bem equilibrada!

16.9 oz can from Trader Joes. I read the reviews before tried it and was pleasantly surprised once I did. This was a nice refreshing Lager, with a touch of sweetness and a nice little bitter note at the end.

Something about these european beers have been really working for me lately. sure there is no smell and I will admit the appearance is not all that appealing but its vaguely sweet and refreshing. nice light malt taste like all european beers. enjoying my imported pint.

Bottle. Pours a deep brune body with a tan head with great retention. Peat y dry and wooden toned body with a mild sweetness. A mild mineral tone with peat dryness and a moderate warming. A bit salt y sweet but quickly turns robust to a more roast y drying wooden tone mild palate and finishes dry and mineral like with a touch of smoke. Great stuff honestly, for me to rate a scotch ale a 4, now thats a killer scotch ale.

Bottle [341ml] shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & garthicus -- c/o HogTownHarry. Yeah, this sucker is old but I ain’t passing up rating it. Pours a clear pale gold with a spare diminishing white head. Poured more in the glass and now it’s a cloudy copper. Aroma of maple syrup, sugary malt, fruit and yeast. Slightly watery, light flavour of fruit, yeast and maple syrup -- somewhat oily mouthfeel. Average bodied. Another very old Unibroue beer that has held up quite well.

341ml bottle - shared with blankboy, garthicus and gregclow, via trade with JulienHuxley. Clear light gold with a smallish creamy-fizzy white head, some bubbles. Like the Sans Nom (both senior citizen bottles sample at the same time), it smells dry, fruity and a bit papery - not much alcohol presence in it, perhaps a tad herbal. There’s not much taste left at all - vague fruit sweetness, but mostly just dry, almost chalky oxidized grain - not nasty, but not all that pleasant either - mostly nothing. Light body, weak carbonation, slightly syrupy, and the papery dryness shifts to a mustiness in the finish - yeah, obviously way past its prime (but again, not vomit-inducing, not really even a drainpour). Thanks, Julien!!

Thanks to HogTownHarry. Appearance: cloudy yellow, a tiny white head. Aroma: perfume, caramel, honey and maple syrup. There’s a little spice and fruit hiding in there too. Flavour: light body with a little diluted honey, maple syrup, musky with a little sawdust.

Tart green apples and mild horsblanket nose . Mild balsamic and sourdough breead flavors. Orange and lemon zest soice with mild cloves and allspice. Nice yeasty mouthfeel. Tart acidic finish with some odd spice notes.

Wow. This was one beer that I have been wanting to try for quite sometime. Huge thanks to Todd for opening this one at Celebration November 2004. Light gold in colour. Aroma of cider, slightly sour, some light malt and some yeast. Flavour was pretty light with some cider vinegar, slightly sweet malt (cookie dough), still some citrus hops (lemon, orange). Still had medium carbonation after all these years, full mouthfeel. Finishes quick. Quit nice still, thanks again Todd.

Wow, I can’t believe I’m getting to rate this one. Cheers to Todd for starting the night off with this rarity - shared with muzzlehatch, tiggmtl, Rastacouere, radiomgb, DumDum and our host CapFlu. Bottle was found hiding on a shelf and was 1999 ’vintage.’ Somewhat cloudy pale straw yellow with a thin head that left us quickly and for good. Slightly sour cider aromas hit you immediately and then there is some cookie-dough and dry yeastiness too. An oily mouth-coating honey/fruit flavour - some citrus and some pear - leads to a quick finish. Stood up fairly well considering, but a treat no matter the outcome.

1999 bottle, shared with CapFlu, tiggmtl, Rastacouere, Beerhugger, Radiomgb, and DumDum in Ottawa. Hazy honey-dry apple cider color...bit cidery, and sour on the nose, lightly malty and yeasty flavor, with honey and a bit of pear, quite sweet. Full, slightly liquorish/oily mouthfeel. Amazingly good for its age...thanks again Todd!

Thanks Todd for sharing... Cidery, yeasty, dry, powdery, cookie-dough aroma that is slightly sour. Hazy,golden straw coloured body with thin, white, fully diminishing head. Yeasty cookie-dough, orange-lemon-citrus flavour. Mouthfeel is a touch oily. Medium bodied and very low carbonation. Though obviously past its prime, this was still a treat to have sampled. Bottle enjoyed with beerhugger, CapFlu, DumDum, muzzlehatch, radiomgb and Rastacouere.

12oz: Clear yellowish cider appearance, no head despite a surprising pop upon opening. Weird aroma, this old Unibroue yeast seemed to impart very cookie-ish overtones. It smells quite tart, dry, powdery with curacao suggestions. Past its prime ginger cookies flavour with notes of pears, coconut, repellently short finish, staling. Tart cookie dough finish. Medium bodied, very low carbonation. Yeah this was past its prime, but don’t pass the chance if you manage to find one, the difference between the older and newyer unibroue strain is worth an essay (which I don’t volunteer to write). Thanks Todd!

(Bottle) Sampled at Celebration November 2004. Pours a small white head with a golden body. The nose is somewhat musky, horseblanket with a milf flat apple sauce to it. The flavour lacks the renowned Unibroue yeastiness but it had pleasant hoppy notes. Amazing that there is this much left in the way of aroma and flavour after 5 years. Past its prime but still holding in there... Overall very nice.

Cask at Great Western, Wolverhampton I can’t believe I’ve not rated this before ! Nose is unremarkable – just some hints of porridge. Pours a rich ruby brown with a small cream head, and good lacing. Taste is a bittersweet conglomerate that is hard to define. More and more flavours come to the fore as it progresses through the mouth. Hazelnuts, liquorice, blackcurrant, raisins, figs, all with a full-bodied malty base to them. A wonderfully complex beer – the classic strong mild that all others (ought to) seek to emulate. It doesn’t get much better than this.

22/5/2019. Cask at The Dove Street Inn Spring Festival, Ipswich. Pours mid to dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of fruit, caramel, malt, dark fruits, berries and liquorice. Moderate sweetness and bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation. Sweet toffee to finish. Decent mild.

Cask @ GBBF 2017. Pours a dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma with weak hints of dark fruit. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with weak hints of dark fruit.
Cask at the Organ Grinder, Nottingham. Classic smooth dark mild with a hefty ABV
Cask old cock Otley. Ruby beer great beige head and lace. Aroma is malty vine fruits good sweetness. Subtle alcohol nice full body. Great mild.
Pours very dark with pretty much no head. Rich aroma of dark fruits and sweet malt, medium to strong sweet in flavour with medium bitterness to offset it. Very nice

Cask at Gloucester Beer Festival. Dark ruby brown, no head. Malty aroma, dried fruits. Taste is sweet, dried fruits, caramel, toffee, light roast, gentle bitterness. Light-medium body, very low carbonation.

On cask at The Wellington in Birmingham. Pours dark ruby brown with a lasting beige head. Aroma: sweet malts, dark fruits, dried fruits. Taste: moderate sweet, light bitter, with dark fruits, prunes, figs, caramel, toffee. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, sweetish nutty finish. Good stuff, it's seen as a classic for a reason

Cask at the Robin Hood Beer Festival 2017. Dark brown with reddish tint. Mildly sweet aroma of dark preserved fruit and sweet malts. Not too watery. Initial taste is sweetish, of red berries, mostly cherry, and dark chocolate. Bitter chocolate in the middle, leading to an even ,ore bitter finish. Aftertaste is fruity again, again mostly cherries. Not bad.
on cask at The Cask Bar Newcastle under lyme, very easy drinking, nice head, dark ruby body with a balanced to sweet finish.
At the brewery. Sample. It’s a lager! Metallic wheat in the middle. Pours clear yellow with no head. ---Rated via Beer Buddy
this one is just so so. i prefer a few other canadian lagers and pale lagers to this, but it’s not offensive...just standard in a light lager sort of way."
(Bottle) Pours a medium white head with a clear straw body. Malt aroma with a mild but sweet taste. Above average beer.
Nice, descent, malty, bit sweet lager.......................................
Nice easy taste for a cream ale. Not too harsh. Muskoka usually produces good beers and the cream ale is a solid choice.
Sipped from the can on the cottage's dock. Bready malt, touch sweet, barely bitter finish. Even in this ideal setting, this beer is just meh.
Amber, solid cream ale, there is a sweet toastiness that works well. Not overly complex but robust and satisfying.

Where Purchased: 473ml can part of winter mixer pack from LCBO #310. Consumed: from a draught glass. Aroma: Smells mildly hoppy and malty. Appearance : filtered med gold colour with thick head that lasts to the end with very sticky lacing. Taste: Good malts with some sweet and medium to hop taste. Palate : med to full body. Bitter aftertaste. Good carbonation for a cream ale. Overall: A little too hoppy for a cream ale. Bittersweet aftertaste. I was glad to try and probably will buy again. MB. The Beer "Bear"on.
Medium malt profile, a little astringency from the bitterness, not super balanced. Decent safe amber beer, nothing worth buying again. Can from YYZ

Thanks to Derek for bringing me this thoughtful gift. Pours a dark golden with a thin white head. The nose is pretty mild, with grass, caramel, honey, and bread. The taste brings light bitterness. Some sweetness comes through late in the sip. Its grassy with a lesser herbal tone, and has bread, caramel, and nuts. All around, the flavors are balanced fairly. Aftertaste is short and grassy. Medium bodied and smooth in texture. This one is drinkable at least, but won't be remembered.
Can (16 oz). Pours light golden amber gwith off-white head that dissipates quickly. Nose of hay, some cream, and a little grass. Light bread crust and hay upfront. Some cream in the long, dry finish.

Ar: Light corn; a bit of cracker and sulfur; fairly clean and low intensity on the nose. AP: Copper-orange and crystal-clear; large light beige head with good retention, leaves a wavy cap of smooth foam that pulls against the glass sides like wet dough as it drops. T: Lightly toasty; clean malt; a bit of red apple and pear; bitterness is medium-low; a touch of mossy hops; low sweetness; background black pepper; finish is more toasted malt. P: Medium body with high carbonation; medium-dry finish. O: An easy-drinking cream ale; a bit heavy on the toasted malt, but quite pleasant and smooth.

Can. Pours a hazy golden pale orange color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy weak creamy aroma. Fruity malty grainy creamy and slightly bitter flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy creamy finish.
Would rate this one slightly above the Lager. Not sure I get the full "cream ale" impact though.

Draft. Clear gold body, millimeter of white in top that instantaneous disperses. Aroma is mild grainy lemon. Taste is the same, bit of sweetness. Thin to medium body and moderate carbonation. Average lager.
Draft - Pale malts, light sweetness. Clear gold with a rich white head. Light pale malts and sweetness. Basic lager.
Fles 50cl thuis. Lekker wegdrinken, niet te zwaar. (2-2006).--------------.

From Mar 2006 Poured from 500ml brown bottle(room temp) a a medium gold with a large head of foam that dissipated slowly. The smell is a sweet and spicy mix of hops and malt that's not subtle at all and that is a good thing. The taste repeats the smell. Yummy sweet malty goodness up front with an ample background of lemony hops gives this ale such great balance and drinkablility that I find this one to be my favourite of the Wychwood brews! Bottom line: This is a great sessionable English Pale Ale that I have no qualms about visiting again and again.
Old rating. 500 ml bottle from Old Town. Toffee aromas with some bread. Taste is all toffee and malt. Lightly dry finish with some sweetness.
This beer has a great malty flavor. Nice earthy aroma. Not too hoppy. Has a good fruity taste.

"eh. decent enough, it’s true to the style as a classic english bitter, there’s just not much to grab one’s attention. well balanced but a bit thin, with a slightly bitter and spicy (and delicate) hop presence."
Botella de 50 cl en el lupulo en enero de 2010. Lote 9169 hasta 18-07-2010. Bastante ligera y algo especiada, sin mucho de interés. Regular.
16.9oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a medium brown with a small head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, and malt. Taste of the same with more malt. This medium bodied brew was OK.

column1: Heather Ales Alba Scots Pine Ale
column5: Bottle in Fort William, Scotland. Dark golden to amber pour, with a white head. Aroma is a bit sour candy-like; no spruce or pine at all. Taste same: sweet, fruity, sour candy. Soft carbo. Sorry, cannot take this seriously; this has nothing to do with pine and nothing with 'triple style'. (This brewery makes very specific beers, mostly fruit beers. Nice, but I still want to taste good beers).

column1: Heather Ales Alba Scots Pine Ale
column5: Aroma: sweet malt & citrus Appearance: red brown hazy with an off white head, sudsy lacing Flavour: super sweet with floral notes and noticeable pine Palate: finishes floral sweet

column1: Heather Ales Alba Scots Pine Ale
column5: Amber ale with white like head to it - piney, spice/fruit flavour. Average aroma great taste!

column1: Heather Ales Alba Scots Pine Ale
column5: 330ml bottle from Aldi. Clear amber with a big white head.. Sweet, piney aroma, flavour is sweet, sticky, floral, not too piney. Tasty

column1: Heather Ales Alba Scots Pine Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours clear amber. Aroma is spruce, floral, herbs. Body is medium, quite sweet and fruity, lowish spruce now. Pines though, and pine honey. Good, but not my favourite spruce/pine beer.

column1: Heather Ales Alba Scots Pine Ale
column5: 330ml bottle. Aldi. Pours dark copper/amber with an off white head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, Christmas cake, candied sugar ( almost like a Belgian yeast ) and some pine needle. Medium body, sweet and slight sticky ness. Taste is caramel, Christmas cake, brown sugar, pine, spruce and some orange peel. Nice warmth at the end with an almost licorice/ mint leave vibe. Really nice.
Aroma: metal, vegemite, carbon, light perfume and a touch of aniseed Appearance: black, tiny tan head, patchy lacing Flavour: blackberry, carbon, dark stone fruit Palate: thin finishes stewed fruit

Bottle. Pours dark brown. Aroma is elder berry and dark malts indeed, fruity sweetness. Body is medium, softly sour, pleasant gentle body, lowish carbonation. Balanced, more berries and roasted malts. Good.
AR: Stachelbeere, hefig, Kräuter, Zitrus AP: fast klares goldgelb TA: Stachelbeere, Kräuter, Zitrus, Zimt
Very dark color, hints of chocolate & cocoa, very rich flavors, semi-roasted finish

A world-class porter. Rich, slightly roasted, slight mocha flavors. A hint of mocha aroma, as well. Medium bodied. Very dark, almost black - showing a hint of dark red when tipped and held to a bright light.
On tap at a gig venue. Pours orange brown. Strawberry, cherry, booze, caramel. Medium body. Bit messy.
Thin head, no lacing, little aroma, sort of plain. Malty Marzen flavor, but not a whole lot to be remembered.
From tap at Brooklyn Brewery, New York. Brown-ish malt aroma with caramel, dark bread, notes of dried and stewed fruits, some toffee. Medium sweet, light to moderate bitterness.

12oz bottle poured into Dimpled Mug at 40°. Color is a bright clear amber with good carbonation and a thin tight off white head. Aroma is slightly sweet and malty. It has a lighter medium body with a crisp mouthfeel. Flavor comes in with crisp malt giving a bready note backed by spicy hops and nice bitterness. Aftertaste is clean letting the hop spice stand out. Overall it a very crisp clean and easy drinking Märzen, I would happily drink more.
Amber, traditional lager. Not bad. Doesn’t worth second try. Full of carbon dioxide.

Pour is a clear tan with a large white head. Aroma is typical caramel and toasted white bread. Flavor is about the same but very light and a bit watery. Typical oktoberfest but everything here is a bit on the light side. Like most from this brewer, decent but nothing that is going to set the world on fire.

Bottle poured a clear orange amber with a small lasting creamy amber head. Aromas of caramel, graininess and light toasted malt. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smooth dry finish. Flavors of caramel, earthiness and light graininess with a smooth dry lingering earthy caramel finish.
On bottle. Scent: Malty. Taste: Yeasty, round, banana. Texture: Sweet, medium low carbonation.
I remember this as being a really convincing white beer - very refreshing, very true to style, overall a great, great brew. Sadly, I've heard that they're closing this microbrewery down.
Bottle at the New Market in Amsterdam. Clear golden. Pretty much your standard pils. Slightly hoppy and light bodied.
Frisse smaak met passende hop en bitterheid. Perfect voor een warme zomerdag zonder een bijzonder memorabele indruk achter te laten.

Can in schieveningen Can't see it. Lagery pilsener malts, grains, cookies. Some leafy grassy notes. Taste has some juiciness, sweetish, thin bitter. Finish is malty, canny, a bit boozy. Strong carbonation medium body, quite average, not offensive.

Minimal off white head left a collar on a translucent dark golden still body. Faint malt & barley aroma. Medium bodied, soft on the tongue with a sharp back. Pale malt, pith, caramel, tang & Sweet citrus tastes. Pretty boring tbh.
Clear golden appearance with a frothy head. Citric hoppy smell, bitter taste with a medium body.
6L keg on perfect draft from Beerhawk. Clear golden appearance with thin white head. Aroma is malts and hops. Flavour is sweet, malt and hops.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: bottle into glass shared with pal josh, malty fruit, not bad, actually pretty decent for a super cheap beer from trader joes

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Minnesota Brewing Company--Three Monkey’s Brewing Company --Fat Weasel Lager--2000 Release--12 oz. Bottle--5.50% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) Pale Lager. Rich clear golden color. Light fruit front with malty lager aroma. Rich laced malty ale like body with light smooth lager flavor. Hints of buttery caramel malt. Ends smooth with minor spice. Sampled 5/31/2000.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Eww gross, completly bland and just blase. Its brewed for TJ, so what can you expect. There just isn’t much there.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Disappointing after their Ale. Slightly better than average lager flavor....

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Not bad...Not really good. The nose wasn't spectacular and the flavor left me wanting a tad more.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle. A golden yellow color with a dry crisp lager taste.................

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Certainly at a level above the Yellow fuzzies, perhaps a stepping stone into micros for the uncultured palates of the masses. It's not bad......for a lager.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Semi-healthy bronze appearance in this lager which exudes an aroma characterized by indiscernable spice notes. This is a medium to full bodied lager, again, with pungent spicy components that I fail to pinpoint. Still, no mystery that this lager is mediocre.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: I don't like lagers too much, so I won't comment....................

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Deep golden color and quick but full head with no lacing. A cute sweet nose and a modest balanced fuller light bodied beer. Way better than Gatorade on a hot day.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales - I thought, not another Amber ale, but this was different. An Amber type pour but with flower like aroma. Flavor of citrus and some sweet malt and a bitter ending.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft at JG Crummers. $3.50/pint. Pronounced hop character with a nice malty finish. Quite drinkable and enjoyable.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Semi-sweet aroma of honey, malt and some hops. Smooth and lightly sweet taste of malt mixed with honey and a touch of hops. Surprisingly bitter finish for a sweet smelling beer.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Clean honeyish aroma. Dry, and quite bitter. Definite honey flavor......

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales. Amber in color. Aroma of malts and hops. Flavor of malts, and little hops. No bite. Average.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On the malty side. Had it in growler that my Brother-in-law bought. Drinkable but unspectacular. At Beale St. recently, they don’t have the stout anymore but CB still produces this one.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft at the Beale Street Cafe. Poured orange with a thin beige head. Aroma is lightly fruity with some caramel, and almost sour. Watery body. Flavor is odd, slightly sour fruit and a light metallic note. Not that good.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (draft @ 2006 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY) Medium amber in color with a thick and puffy white head. Tasted and smells like all the other CB beers. Malt and hops mixed together, nothing standing out. Light bodied and lightly carbonated. Some hops but balanced with malts. Eh.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Appearance is ideal for the style. Malt balance is very good. Some raisin flavor present. Very quaffable session beer.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On Tap at Beale Street Cafe in Rochester. A nice malty amber with a balanced palate.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: had this at the Old Town coffee house, was great with the fried veggie basket

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Dry and pleasant tasting. No particular aroma. Good amber color. Competent but not exciting.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pretty straight forward stuff. Mild aroma and flavor with a coppery, metallic finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Murky gold color with a very thin head. Nice aroma of peppery hops and a touch of malt. Flavor is a good balance of hops, pepper and a smooth malty finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Hoppy aroma, light amber, good hops start, a fair malt backbone. Well carbonated, nice balance, good.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap, Buffalo Brewfest 04. Amber colour, nice hops in aroma. Flavour is more hops and decent carbonation. A classic American pale. I had better at the fest, but this left a good impression.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Slightly hazy golden color, thin white head. Maltier aroma, some traces of some spicy hops. Predominantly malty, spicy hops on the finish. Decent body for CB, lightly bitter finish. Decent but not great.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Dusty gold with a thin head. Very faint grassy aroma w. a little toasted malt. Malt continues into the flavor w. the hops, and a bit of a metallic tang.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: I have this a lot here because they have one of the best patio's and mexican food in buffalo. As for the beer Nice copper color. Good amount of hops blended well with a hint of spicyness.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Meager hop aroma, but very bitter. Has a weird spiciness. Not altogether pleasant.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft. Amber body, small white head, citric hoppy nose with bready malt notes. Very refreshing citric body with decent malt backbone.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap @ Ellicottville Beer Festival. Decent beer. Nice hop aroma & taste. Somewhat piney, some citrus & nice malt balance

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Nice hoppycitrius boquet, Amber color with a samll white head. Hoppy flaovr with malt present, medium to light mouth feel. REfreshing, dry finish. not too complex but very drinkable.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at Pizza Plant in Williamsville, NY. The beer is brewed specifically for the restaurant and it paired perfectly with the pizza/pub fare the place serves. When the beer was brought over to the table, it still had a small white head and the beers crisp smell was immediatly noticed. The ale had a very robust and full bodied taste, but it was still very drinkable. Their were light notes of citrus and some earthy woodsiness as well. However, these all took a back seat to the beers hoppy characteristics. Overall it was a very good beer and it was a perfect start to the night.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draught at The Pizza Plant, sampled from VeloVampire - Big hoppy nose, fruity and dry. The taste is a really nice hop blast, but far from overpowering. Grapefruity and piney off the top, then there’s an unusual earthy taste in the middle and towards the finish (not unpleasant). Fresh, well balanced hoppiness, and a little spicy. This actually reminded me somewhat of Mill Street’s Tankhouse Ale in Toronto.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the Pizza Plant - HELP!!!! The pods are coming......A super solid IPA with aroma of hops and some malt in there - the body is robust and the taste is much the same, hops and some strange earthiness, almost soil-like. Good though. Neat finish. Aw man, I loved my pod.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draught at 2006 Fall Festival of Ales. An occasional IPA is enough for my palate, and this one fits the bill. Not overpowering on the hops. The toastiness in the malts balances the palate well. Very solid example of the style.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Dark colour head,lace. Very very bitter, acidic more than citrus. Cannot score high in mouthfeel.Some hop aroma. Good carbonation. This can use more balance

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draught at Pizza Plant, Williamsport, NY. Pours a clear dark copper with a small off-white head. Big aroma of fresh hops with a touch of fruity malt. The flavour, as the aroma would lead you to believe, is quite hoppy but not excessively -- it’s really tasty, well balanced and fresh. Smooth and clean palate. I wouldn’t bother if you aren’t a fan of hoppy beers but I am and I really liked it.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Pizza Plant Inferno Pod Ale
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draught. Shared with blankboy at Pizza Plant, Williamsport, NY. Poured clear amber-red with a small off-white head. Aroma was initially quite mild, but opened a lot on warming - fresh medium hops, some very light hints of lightly roast malt and woodiness. Taste - *there* are the hops - lots of resiny, fresh hops, with spruce and hardwood notes (I only sampled this one, and burped hops for half an hour). Mouthfeel astringent and lively - quite complex for a hops-only brew. I quite liked it, but it’s a one-noter - but I was intrigued by the woody nature of the hops, unusual to me, definitely not just cascade hops - must be the hot pepper, which I didn’t actually taste.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Malty aroma and flavor, with a tiny hint of chocolate. Dark for an amber, but that''s okay with me!

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Great red color. Not a great hop flavor...................................

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales. Light brown in color. Light aroma of malt and hops. Hops are noticable in the flavor with the malt. ok

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Very malty, doughy nose. Just a hazy light brown appearance. Nice lacing. A bit malty in the palate, balanced well with some hops, finishes dry. Sampled from a growler.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Nothing on nose, nothing on first sip, but then there is a wallop of hops suddenly. Nice fun. Update 1 Feb 10 - Got a growler over the weekend, fresh out of the fermentor. Nice color, head and lace. Honey and malt on nose, honey, pecans and malt on palate. Really exceptional, the best I’ve had from CB.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Well done brown ale. No one is going to do cartwheels but the hops mix well with the malts in this one. I enjoyed it.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours a very dark brown with a thin tan head and a bit of lacing as it goes down. It has a nice nutty smell that mixes with the toasted malt. The taste is of the nuts upfront followed by an odd metallic and acidic flavor. I don’t know if the tap lines were dirty or what but there was a very odd finish to this brew. As this brew warmed, the odd skunky flavor increased and really drew my attention away from all of the nice things that were going on. This was definitely not the smooth nut brown that I would expect.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales. Poured a dark reddish brown. Thin off-white head. Smokey nuttiness in the aroma. Medium-bodied; Nutty flavor which fades to malt. Bitter aftertaste from the malt and nuts and hops.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Had on tap at The Old Toad. Smooth, roasty flavors. Color is a deep brown. Sweet, but not too thick. Overall a good session nut brown but lacking complexity.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Almost black. Roast malt aroma, with caramel, chocolae, nuts, and something like liquorice and/or tabacco. Very interestng nose. Nutty caramel flavor with decent fruitiness. Rich palate. Quite nice.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Hand derawn sample at Autumn Festival of Ales - French toast on front, hops on back. Novel, but I’m not sure when I’d want it. Breakfast, maybe.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap and The Old Toad in Rochester. Poured dark ruby brown with a beige head. Aroma is almost all caramel. Medium body. Very interesting flavor. Sweet caramel, graham cracker, kettle corn, roasted chestnut, earthy, woody. Pretty original I thought, and very enjoyable.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Ruby body with a white head. Butterscotch aroma, some light malts as well are evident. Thin body, somewhat watery. The taste isn’t bad but a bit bland for the style. Clean ending.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Amazingly, almost zero aroma from the tap pour. Taste is hazelnut, wood chips, pretty buttery, slightly bitter and sour.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Growler from the brewery. Pours chestnut brown with a one finger tan head. Aroma of sweet, smoked nuts and a mild hoppy spiciness. Flavor follows suit with smokey maltiness dominating, but a definite sprucey hops character is there, along with a mild earthy richness. Moderately thick mouth feel, smoothly carbonated.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Clear brown color with a very thin white head. Nutty and malty aroma with sweet and earthy notes. Creamy nut and malt flavor with a smooth finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Clear amber/orange color with a slight white head. Sweet and malty aroma with hints of berries and possibly some citrus. Initial flavor was a hoppy sensation with a nice transition to a smooth malt finish and a very slight bitter aftertaste.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Clear amber colour with a thin white head. Hoppy aroma with hints of berries. Medium to Light-bodied; Strong hop flavour fades to a bit of malt. Aftertaste has a very subtle hoppiness and some strong tea flavours. Decent bitter, but there are much better. I had this on draught at the Old Toad in Rochester, New York on 22-September-2003.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Cask. Warm, brownish orange color with some red hues. Nutty malt aroma. I enjoy the hops/malt balance with the even bitter finish. Has a dry nutty feel with a smooth velvety texture. Tastes like toffee and graham crackers. Served at the proper temperature and absolutely flat. A great beer. Could use some more body and a bit more complexity.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Very thin and slightly bitter. Extremely British tasting for being made in Upstate NY, i.e. not an abundance of flavor.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: It tastes and looks as a bitter should. Of course that is not always a good thing, but in this case it is.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bitterness and malt nicely balance, but lacks hops aroma and flavor. Nice on hand-pump.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Nicely smooth - and very bitter...too bitter. Not much body or malt presence. Doesn't seem to fit the Best Bitter category.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Nice dark color, not much of a head. Spicy aroma, palate of spice and malt. Not bad, not complex. With the name I was expecting a different style beer.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: A decent dunkel. I wish i knew more about it, such as alcohol %. Tasted and smelled like it had a high alcohol %. Deep amber/ruby color. Fairly sweet malt nose and taste. Pretty good.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Quite bitter (a little too bitter) but very clean and refreshing..........

Tap (TCBW2018) (4:2:4:2:8=2.0) Pale, brief head. Sweet macro-ish pale lager aroma. Grainy taste. Light palate, crisp carbonation. Totally macro, but clean. Relatively drinkable, but uninteresting to me.

Tap at MCBT. People were raving about these guys: Mahrs Bray Pils Matte copper with a perfumes aroma, medium bodied with lots of chewy malts, graham and honey. Nice crisp bitter herbal finish. Lovely crushable stuff.

At the source. Clear a bit pale golden, medium sized white head. Aroma is hayish, a bit floral blossom hoppiness. Flavor is malts, lightly bitter malts. Hard to describe better but distinctively different from the helles we had alongside. Interesting. 7-5-6-3-12.
Sampled at MBCC 2019. Low fluffy and quickly disappearing white head. Clear amber body. Sweet fruity honey aroma and flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short finish.
0,2 litre On tap at Gullkorn Hamar. Golden with white head. Malts, hops, yeast, grain, stale bitterness in The finnish.
Can at home from Sterk, Amsterdam 17th October 19. Pours a clear straw coloured beer. Aroma is light hay and straw. Taste is smooth, bitter, mellow, fresh grass and straw. Very drinkable lager.
330ml can. Clear golden, frothy white head. Aroma of malts, grass. Taste is malty, biscuity, toffee, grassy hops, bitter finish. Medium body and carbonation. Really nice balanced drinkable lager.
Marhs Brau Helles vollbier 4.9% Can at MBCT. It is a crystal clear gold color with a rich bready aroma. Honeyed malt flavor, crisp and spot on.

Can from Hop, Burns & Black. Crystal clear golden amber with a medium to large white foam head. Bubbles and clarity is amazing in this. Nose is dry, straw, fresh cereal wort, grass, hay, little metallic. Taste is clean, crisp, dry, grassy, hay, straw, fruity, prickly hop.
Draught at the Bierkeller. Clear golden. Bready malt, herbal hops. Semi dry, low to medium bitterness.
At the source. Clear golden color, white head. Smell and taste malts, lightly buttery, hayish, slight iron and nicely malt bitter. Medium body and carbonation. Decent. 6-5-6-4-11
Tap at gbbf 2019. Pours a clear gold colour with a tight white head, light hop aroma with some fruit, the taste is medium bitterness and fruity with a dry bitter finish.
Tap (TCBW2018) (4:3:4:3:8=2.2) Sweetish starchy lager aroma. Ditto taste. Is lager, I'm ungripped.

500 ml bottle. Unclear dark golden, foamy head. Bread, hay, straw, some lemon and marzipan. Light dry bitterness, malty sweetness. Medium bodied, oily texture, soft carbonated, dry finish. A different but very well made Helles.
Oh come on ice man it wasn't that bad.......................................

I never knew that the makers of steel reserve 211 made anything else, especially something i've had. Its been a little while, but since no one has rated it yet I'll give a general overview. This was not very good. They didn't get the whole black and tan mixture thing right. No wonder the monkey looks like that. The bottles were really weird too. It was too bitter for me and I'm damn glad i haven't seen it since.

Bottle from Merchants. Aroma is corn, earthy hops, some sweet grains, floral and dry. Appearance is a lighter golden, white head, slight haze. Taste is pleasant, light earthy hop, wheat, grains, floral, light grass, easy to drink, good. Mouthfeel is light body, light carbonation, light earthy hop and grainy aftertaste. Overall, this is about as solid as a Low Alcohol gets.

Das Sommer Pils (ehemals "Leicht" - Doppelt gelistet) der Mahrs Bräu aus Bamberg, Oberfranken. Die Brauerei hat für ihre Biere neue Etiketten herstellen lassen, hierbei leider auch einige Namen geändert, dass Bier bleibt natürlich gleich! Die Kronkorken sind geprägt und in Etikettenfarbe lackiert. Der neue Bierkastenpfand von 9 €uro ist denke ich auch einmalig. Das Etikett, Neu und Alt gefällt mir gut. Goldgelb im Glas, klar filtriert, die Schaumentwicklung ist anfangs sehr gut. Fruchtig frischer Antrunk, leichter maischiger Malzkörper trifft auf feine Citrusnoten. Der Hopfen im Abgang ist gut schmeckbar (Hallertauer Perle) und erzeugt eine harmonische Bittere. Eine richtig gute Alternative zum süssen Radler. Schmeckt gut. Bekannte Auszeichnungen: Australian International Beer Awards Gold 2016 / World Beer Cup Silber 2016.
Also das ist wirklich die allerbeste Alternative zum süssen Radler. Soviel Pilsgeschmack bei halben Umdrehungen gibts warscheinlich kein zweites Mal. Super würzig, schön hopfig wie ein Pilsner!
Light golden small head. Aroma is malt grain. Taste is the same sweet light bitter. Meh drinkable but not for mee

Bottle. Clear pale golden color with big white head. Aroma is sweetish crackers and noble hops. Taste is sweet grains, more noble hops, crisp. Medium carbonation. A good Leichtes, it?s not too sweet and has enough hops to make it thirst-quenching.

Bottle at home again style ticking has taken me to a world I’d rather not be. Dirty gold color, probably an old bottle. Nose is some lemon and cleaner. Tastes of 409, lemon, grains, floral, and stale hops. Watery but not terrible palate. Not very good

Bottle from Aldi drunk in a park in Bamberg. Very pale gold colour lasting white head Lots of carbonation in appearance. One of the better leichts ive had in that it isn’t terrible. Lots of light lemon flavour. Even some flowery hop presence especially on the finish. Some toast from the low abv. It’s fine.

Mahr’s Brau Leicht has a thick, spongy, frothy, white head, and a somewhat hazy, straw-gold appearance, with some ascending bubbles and very heavy lacing left behind on the glass. The aroma is of biscuit and bread dough, and the flavor is the same with a mild, rounding bitterness. Mouthfeel is almost medium, and Mahr’s Brau Leicht finishes crisp and refreshing. RJT

Yet another mistaken purchase, as I suspected that the ’leicht’ on the label meant light... but since I spent some months in Bamberg years ago and couldn’t remember this particular brewery, I gave it a shot. It is a pleasant, very light lager beer. I believe that this would compare quite well with other brews in this category, which damns with faint praise indeed.

Look; small head and very pale yellow body. Aroma; pale malts, lemon notes. Taste; pale malts, grass, lemon, leading to a somewhat dry lemongrass finish. Thin texture and normal carbonation. [50cl brown bottle 2.8%abv BB23-10-2015 T@Ferie2015]
Keg at The Resting Hare, Euston in 2016. Hazy yellow with a big white head. Aroma of cloves, banana and citrus peal. Very full bodied with soft fruit, straw and biscuity malt flavours.
Sampled at the Bierkeller. Cloudy golden. A bit dull, phenolic aroma. Semi dry, low bitterness.

resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, pale, golden, amber, orange, red, clear, hazy, cloudy, sparkling, rocky head, frothy, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, lightly sour, salty,

Keg @ Zly Casy. Pours thin and hazy, straw golden. Lasting white head. Good lacing. Huge banana aroma, peppery and a bit perfumed. Light almost watery, fairly dry mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Taste is peppery and fruity, cloves, coriander, banana and white bread. Dry finish.

Bevor es garnicht mehr erhältlich ist, schnell ins Glas damit - und dann gleich Gushing. In der Nase schöne Nelke. Im Trunk sehr cremig, frisch, süffig, leichte Süße, hinten feinbitter. Astreines Sommerweizen!

Orangefarben und hefetrüb im Glas mit mittlerer Schaumkrone. Zitronig frischer Antrunk, hefiger Körper mit guten Bananennoten, im Abgang wirds auch noch hopfig. Sehr erfrischendes Hefeweizen aus Oberfranken.
very light in body , bright yellow , very low in aroma , seems to be a "Leichte Weisse"

Pouts hazy yellow, big frothy head. Citrus plus plus aroma, hint of yeast and banana. Lovely tart lemony hit on first mouthful, balanced by some soft cinder toffee and banana in the back. Refreshing and tasty. Like.
At alte ringlein, Hazy golden yellow beer, small to medium head. Aroma is yeast, banana, wheat. Taste is the same, hint of sweetness. not bad.

Bottle shared. Very hazy dull golden with a very short lived head. Aroma of malt, grain a a little hay. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and light bitter. Above light bodied with moderate carbonation. [19-09-2016]
Direkt im Biergarten, sattes Gold, im Trunk zitronig, spritzig, nicht pappig. Bassd scho.
50cl bottle drunk on a very hot day. Thin white head. Clear pale golden pour. A bit too sweet.
0.5l bottle from Drikk Godt. Clear pale yellow color with white head and some lacing. Low carbonation. Not a good lemon drink, not a good beer.

Look; ultrapale straw yellow body. Aroma; some sweets, candiced lemon. Taste; lemon limonade, sweetness, leading to a sticky finish. Light texture and fresh carbonation. Some women love it, but I never wear dress. [Chilled to +2’c. 50cl brown bottle 2.6%abv BB26-10-2015 T@Ferie2015]
Klare blassgelbe Farbe, sehr wenig weißer Schaum. Geruch süß nach Zitronenlimonade. Geschmack fruchtig süß, viel Limo, überhaupt kein Geschmack von Bier.

Süßlicher Antrunk mit dumpfer Zitronigkeit. Nach kurzer Zeit wird der Süßstoff ersichtlich, das Getränk schmeckt fad, trocken auf der Zunge bleibt ein pelziges Gefühl, das sich zum Ende verschlimmert. 6/5/4/3/11/3
Clear yellow with small white head. Aroma is malt, fruit and lemon. Flavour malt, lemon, sugar, artificial, thin and sweet.

At Mahr’s. Very pale yellow pour. Intense lemony aroma, nice lemonade. Taste of lemonade, light mineral notes, very faint beer character. Lemony but not articficial which is pleasant, quite sweet though. Nice.
Gedronken bij mahr’s brau, gele kleur, witte schuimkraag, ruikt en smaakt naar citroen, lemon, 7up, sprite, geen alcholol.
50 cl @ the brewery. Pale yellow colour with a nice white head. Smells sprite, lemon. Tastes sprite.. Sneeuwwitje. Thin body, nice carbo.

"Mahrs Bräu Weißer Bock", Flasche (MHD: 03/20) von Ganicks Flaschbiershop, Berlin. - Nicht weiß sondern schwarzbraun, trüb; wenig Schaum, viel Bodensatz. - In der Nase konzentriertes Dunkelmalz, Maggi-artig, mit schmalspuriger, säuerlich-herber obergäriger Fruchtigkeit, Sauerkirsche, Lakritz, Anklänge an feuchtes Laub. - Antrunk streng dunkelmalzig und gut malzbitter mit Lakritz, Schokolade, Nelke und säuerlicher Frucht: unreife Aprikose, Bananenschale, Heidelbeere. Bizzelig rezent, ohne bocktypische Fülligkeit. Im Abgang ätherische Hopfenherbe. - Sehr eigenwilliger, ja exzentrischer Weizenbock, unrund und fast ruppig; die Einzelaromen sind nicht weichmalzig zusammengebunden. Überzeugt mich nicht. Vielleicht überlagert? (22.10.2019.)
Flaska. Dimmig mörkare brun öl med ett beige kvardröjande skum. Doft och smak rostad malt, karamell, jäst, skumbanan och en lätt kryddighet.
How: Draught. Where: MBCC 2019. Appearance: Brown colour with a tan head. Aroma: Malt, caramel, yeast, spices. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Malt, caramel, spices.
Dark brown. Medium sized, off-white head . Aroma of toasted malt, raisins and fruity esters. Moderate sweetness in taste. Liked this one.

Lightly sweet and very raisiny with a bit of dark fruit tartness. Pours pretty red tinged brown with a tight bubbled tan head. Mild carbonation makes for a smooth drinking experience. Decent but missing that German hoodoo that makes for a great lager.

Der weiße Bock präsentiert sich tiefschwarz im Glas. Elfenbeinfarbener Schaum zieht die Wandung hinunter und bestätigt das provozierende „mehr Alkohol“ vom Etikett. Ich rieche vor allem Sauerkirschen und einen Anflug von Rumtopf. Weich und voll fliest das Bier auf die Zunge, eine angenehme Malzsüße macht sich breit. Feines Prickeln sorgt dafür, dass diese nicht zu schwer wird. Ganz dezente Röstaromen übernehmen und dann mit angedeuteter Hopfenbittere den Trunk ausklingen zu lassen. Erst jetzt ahnt man wieder die Alkoholstärke dieses spannenden Bocks. Fruchtaromen begleiten die Pause bis zum nächsten Schluck. Ein Spitzenbier!
Pours hazy mahogany with a two finger, tan head. Aroma is banana, toffee and light roast. Taste is raisin and toffee, moving to banana and roast. Finish is roast and banana. A good weizenbock.

Decent but not next level for style. Some light roast. Banana and clove. Pours dark brown with good head and lacing. Some musk and a little tang in finish. Lacks body compared to best of style. Light tangy end. Tap at Churchkey.
MBCC. Hazy dark brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt, bread, yeast, wheat, dark fruit and caramel. Flavour is malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit, sweet and a little bitter.
[5/11/2019] Draught sample at Mikkeller Beer Celebration Copenhagen 2019. Red session. Brown. Caramel, fruity esters, some spiciness, bread, sweet. Nice.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales. I thought this was going to be big on the Wasabi, but I’m glad it was not. Some malt and plenty of hops detected in there also. Still would not drink much of this.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft at Cali Rollin - Take this beer out of the sushi bar and I wouldn’t even give it a second taste. It’s thoroughly unremarkable UNTIL you pair it with sushi rolls. It’s a nearly perfect match for any tuna, eel or mackerel roll. A fine example of matching beer with cusine.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2005 on tap at Cali Rollin’ Sushi Bar. Pours golden with medium carbonation. Aroma of barley and eastern spices. Goes amazing with great sushi as ClarkVV and Bucknaked both pointed out. Wasbi undertones are subtle with soy rounding out the circle of flavors. I would drink this beer without sushi but the entire sushi experience at the restaurant is what makes this brew so special. Also good for saki bombs while singing Tiny Dancer.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: At California Rollin in Rochester. I couldn’t really smell the wasabi, but I really did like the beer. Clean flavor with some hops. Very flat though, which was probably the restaurants fault. Overall I thought it went well with the food and was quite enjoyable.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Bitter aroma of hops and a little malt with a very slight spicy hint of wasabi. Bitter flavor with a smooth malt backbone and finish. Couldn’t really taste the wasabi. Very flat.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Tap: (Brewed by Custom Brewcrafters) This beer does go great with sushi, as ClarkVV already noted. Aroma: Bitter, hops, slight wasabi. Flavor: Bitter, crisp, sweet finish, very suble. Very crisp, enjoyable beer.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: A very good beer with sushi! Find this one at California rollin in Village Gate Square, Rochester. This beer has a pleasant bitter nose on it, with (suprise) wasabi notes. Very subtle though, not what I was expecting. Finishes like a wonderful APA should. A very meaty beer, with a clean flavor and even hopping.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Not a great weiss - no character, no estery notes. Mild flavor. Wasabe addition was undetectable. Too bad- I was hoping for something good and unique.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales - Good roasted malts and hop aroma. Very smooth taste. Flavor of roasted malt and hints of hops with a dry finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Sample at Autumn Festival of Ales - Hoppy nose, good clor, and that’s where it ended. Waxy, nasty flavor. Maybe it’s different with wings, but it’s nasty on its own.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pretty nice and a little more interesting than what I am used to from a brown ale. Clean stuff with a nice hop finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Good malty and hop aroma. Very smooth taste. Rather sweet with hints of hops and malt. Slightly dry finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Great malts. Medium hoppiness. A pleasant brew............................

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Sample at Autumn Festival of Ales - Hoppy nose, citrusy palate with a raisin background, some depth in flavor. Seemed a little feeble.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: This wasn’t really worthy of craft beer status. This was assembly-line amber. I am sure it was brewed to request by the folks at CBC but I was disappointed.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Golden amber color with a white head. Very balanced aroma of hops and malt with a touch of sweetness. Smooth malty flavor that is mixed well with peppery hops. Crisp and refreshing finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Very nice aroma, slightly sweet and malty with a hop undertone that balances perfectly. Great orangey color. Smooth and balanced flavor. Begins with a sweet malt taste and goes to a hoppy backbone with a slightly sweet yet bitter finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Outstanding aroma. Great malt/hop balance.................................

On NCL Norwegian Jewel Cruise over Xmas. Poured moderate carb and head w/ pretty ruby coat]... nice crisp acidic feel. with med body and sweeetness - Hopping is very English & restrained. I could drink boatloads but it sold out.
Bottle: Smooth overall taste with fresh after taste. Light head quickly disappeared. Disappointed in the light aroma and and weak hoppy taste.
A good English pale, a little lighter than American pales, quite drinkable and a decent balance of grains and hops. Likeable.
Resembles my favorite which is Heineken. For this reason, and the fact it is $10 a case cheaper, I will continue to enjoy it’s flavour and textures.
Easy drinking lager, best feature is the price, unbelievable how a fully imported beer is so cheap while locally made beers so expensive.
Zlatnozuta boja, bijela pjena srednje debljine, umjerno trajna. Slaba citrusno-metalna aroma. Slabe gorèine, veoma kratak, blago gorak finiš. Vodene teksture, srednje karbonizacije.
Piwo s³omkowe, idealnie klarowne z bia³¹ pian¹. W aromacie kukurydza i stech³a nuta. W smaku nijakie, wodniste. Goryczka niska, sporo nagazowanie.

500ml can. Clear golden with a thin ring of white foam. Flavors are bready cereals, banana, powdered sugar and sulphur with fruity and grassy notes. Medium body, moderate to good carbonation, oily texture.
A very average lager. It tastes okay and the fizz level is not bad. Was cheap to buy so I suppose that's a plus.
This beer tastes good but I am very disappointed that they use glucose in the fermentation process.I will not buy this beer again.
What can I say about this one, not good, but not bad eather. Easy drinking, that´s it basically.

Light fizz delivers negligible head to a standard lager coloured beer. Has that classical European malt twang, easy to drink. Not a beer connoisseurs drink, but can’t argue with value if you just want to sink a few with mates/sport/GoT/etc.
Nez faible de houblon et de céréales. Robe translucide d'un blond doré. Mousse laide et sans tenue. En bouche en sens les céréales et un petit ressenti métallique en fin de bouche.

Taster at Colorado Plus. Pours black, with a small to medium, bubbly, tan head. The nose is black coffee, anise, burnt toast, and maple. Dryish, with a burnt bitterness. Medium body, with a harsh, sticky palate. This is a solid stout, if a little aggressive.

On tap at Oasis poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, bakers cocoa and earthiness. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of roasted malt, bakers cocoa, earthiness and a hint of coffee with a smooth dry lingering earthy cocoa finish.
On draft at the brewery in Denver. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of leather and tobacco. Flavors are bitter roast.
On tap. Black color with a brown head. Malt aroma. Medium body. Chocolate malt flavor. Decent basic stout. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From old tasting notes. Opaque black color. Thick nice brown head. Lovely "Cocoa Puff" malt nose. Bittersweet roasted malt flavor is intense and full bodied.ma real mouthful. Rich chocolaty finish.

Oasis Brewing Company--Zoser Oatmeal Stout--1999 12 oz. Bottle. 6.00% ABV. (4.5 / 5.0) Stout--Deep dark black color. Thick dispersible pellicle. Big rich cherry chocolate front followed by rich creamy body. Sweetness and fruit linger till finish. Dry at end. Unexpectedly wonderful. Sampled 3/9/1999.

Had this beer on 4/1/2003. Aroma is mild with a rich roasted scent. Color is a solid amber black with good carbonation and a nice head. Taste is fresh and toasted. Starting with a full medium body that goes down crisp with a toasted flavor coming on. Finish follows by bring this toasted flavor full on and is then backed by an even bitterness that sharpens on the end.

Date: 05/27/2000 Mode: Bottle Source: Ohio black, big tan head, rich roasted oat aroma, rich creamy malt flavor, lots of chocolate, wonderful mouthfeel, hint of bitterness Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 17/20 Rating: 3.8/5.0 Score: ***+/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Well, not sure how many others enjoyed the Oasis as brewpub, but I did. Think it was a slew of elements, the first being that it was "discovered" upon the first trip to GABF and zip up to Boulder. The stout I felt was nice, but not exceptional - medium body, slightly sweet, but roasty and with coffee and other elements that satisfied.

Dark near-black opaque appearance, good head formation. Grainy, pastey oats, dry roasted malt aroma. Lively palate, sweet and fruity at first, touch of creaminess in the middle, dark chocolate with a heavily roasted and elevated alcohol finish. Hoppiness, bites in the finish. Quite a lot going on, probably more than technically should be in an oatmeal stout but pretty impressive.

Sampled at the Westword Feast. Clear copper colored appearance with a beige head. Aroma of toasted malt, mild earthiness and light hops. Similar flavor, adding mild sweetness and light bitterness. Medium body with a slight dry feel and a smooth finish. Solid.

Served on tap. Hazy amber color with a white head. Minimal grain malt aroma. Malt slightly bitter flavour. Medium chewy body. Decent beer. Good for crushing before a Man U match. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Oasis poured a clear reddish brown with a small lasting creamy amber head. Aromas of caramel, earthiness and a hint of fruitiness. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of caramel, earthiness and a hint of fruitiness with a smooth dry lingering earthy finish.

From old tasting notes. Deep reddish brown color. Bubbly beige head. Wonderful floral hop bouquet. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor with hints of honey and cinnamon. Wonderful complex hop bitterness pervades in the finish and leaves a lasting impression. Very flavorful and very drinkable.

Had in 3/28/2003. Aroma is full of a fresh hop scent. Color is a deep clear amber with good carbonation and a nice head. Taste sharp and bitter. Starting with a light medium body it goes doen with a sharp bite. Finish comes right on with a stong bitterness and fluffy smooth mouth feel then leves you with a lingering hop bitterness. although it is bitter and has a good hop aroma there is not much hop flavor .
Smells old and dusty. aroma of plums, molasses, toffee, triacle, like a barleywine but not as sweet. Ths is nuts. Syrupy and thin but a BIG bitter flavor.

Medium orange-amber hazy hue. Medium, creamy, light tan head. Massive treacle and toffee aroma. Some brown sugar, pungent earthy hops, prunes, lemons. Pretty nice if not a bit simple. Tastes much the same although the aroma is stronger. Moderately sweet, lightly bitter flavor. Lightly sweet, moderately bitter finish. Medium body, watery almost creamy texture, moderate carbonation.

A very interesting esb. Had a darkened orangish color to it with some serious brown tones. Had some serious bitterness to it in the aroma and in the body. Very decently malted with a nice hop undertone. A decent beer.

Appearance: clear bronze color, with a thick, fluffy, lacey, tan head. Nose is softly fruity, a touch citric, and over-all very nice. Taste: a load of hops boards the ’buds instantly, tasty hops, backed up with generous malt. Yum, I’m thinking, "Yum!", I’m saying, and, can I say it again? Yum, yummy, yum! Bitter hops come forward further on, adding to the taste sensation. Normally, I turn up my nose at ESBs, soured by so many bland versions, and this is one that isn’t. Rich, malty flavor lasts, and lasts, and lasts...tasty, toasty, and sweet. One to go to the head of the ESB class, I say.

nice caramel aroma. i thought i wiffed some odd berry, but who knows. really smooth, i think it’s really balanced too. at first i’m at battle with a creamy maltiness and a small of spike of hops even shows up, but it mellows quite swiftly--and i like this. that berry thing comes up later as well. this should be more assertive, though. i think this is not quite a bitter, but then again my favorite beers are absurdly bitter! i would drink this again. (mmm update: i read brooklynboy’s rating and yes, that berry is mostlike grapefruit--weird, egh? grapefruit and caramel? hmm)
From old tasting notes. Mahogany brown color. Bubbly beige head. Sweet toasted malt aroma. Subtle toasted malt flavor with hints of cocoa and caramel. Pleasant spicy hop finish. Nice brown ale.

Deep chestnut brown under a thin light ivory cap. Rich earthy nutty brown toasted malt aroma that’s pretty basic. Smooth brown malt semisweet flavor with a nice pseudo-chocolaty tone and dry toast malt finish. Meh. Average.

Bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of cocoa, caramel, earthiness and a hint of nuttiness. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of caramel, cocoa and earthiness with a smooth lingering caramel finish.

12 oz single bottle from Molly’s Spirits. Deep ruby/brown and clear appearance with a minimal tan head. Aroma of nutty malts, light caramel/toffee and chocolate. Similar flavor, adding moderate sweetness and minimal bitterness. Light to medium body with soft carbonation and a slight watery feel. Pretty generic brown ale overall, not bad though.

Bottle poured a clear brown hue w/ small white head. Faint nutty aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a light bitter finish. Taste is almonds skins. Medium bodied. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
