Had this beer on 3/28/2003. Aroma is a rich roasted malt scent. Color is a deep clear amber with good carbonation and nice head. Taste rich and toasted. Starting with a medium body that goes down with smooth feel and a roasted malt flavor coming on. Finish comes in with a sharpness which rolls into a rich tasted malt flavor and is backed by a mild bitterness. Overall I think this is one of the best Brown Ales I’ve ever had. It fits a English Style Dark Ale very well.

Fair enough not to offend, but nondescript enough as to remind me that I’m really not a fan of brown ales. If you love them you will probably enjoy, but not click your heels. If you feel like me, you won’t be disappointed in having tried, but will quickly move on ..

Dark brown body with some ruby highlights. The head is slightly yellow. The aroma is Cheerios and some light motor oil. The taste is rich with Cheerios and some caramel. There is a strange coppery finish with some light grass. A strange brown ale.

The Tut Brown pours out just right, a clear, caramel-y brown shade, adorned with a thick, creamy head. Aroma is mild, nutty, coppery, and slightly spicy. As for taste, we get richness right away, sweet, juicy malt, and just a drizzle of hops. Body is medium/light, and texture has something up front, a light hop bite, then fading. Finish is brief, but pleasant enough. Taste remains sweet and happy throughout, but toward the end this brew peters out and leaves my palate aching for more flavor, somewhere, anywhere. But if the old tastebuds weren’t in such a mood, this would be one fine session ale, for sure.

Not a good example of the style. Dark brown body under foamy beige head. The nose and the flavor had hints of nuttiness, some caramel, dough. Watery with medium carbonation. Bitterness. Just not very appealing.

Draft at source. Nose is floral and cream of wheat grainy smelling. This is not bursting with hop aroma as advertised. The Belgian pale ale with citra has way more hops. Taste is slightly less underwhelming but it isn’t bursting either. Slightly sweet. Meh.

This one is citruscy and soapy flavored. Easy to drunk and nice and hoppy. Pours light yellow with a thick white head. Had at Wild onion. Earlier Rating: 12/15/2012 Total Score: 3.4 One if the better pale ales I have tried. Really smooth and easy to drink. Really good even out of a can ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma pine, some citrus and a note of caramel..Orange amber color with a white head. Sweet malt up front...kind of off. Piney bitterness next. Finish is a bit unbalanced.with a weird after taste. Sub par.
From an old rating note (on tap in Charleston I think): Cloudy orange brown pour. Wheat, lemon, and grass in the aroma. Tastes - grain, metallic, pepper. Wasn’t impressed overall.
Hazy orange, medium beige head. Very grainy aroma with some skunk. Taste is very acidic and strange.
Pours a lasting but no lace off-white head with a golden body. Smells of clean malt and grain. Flavor is clean and crisp. Sour, cardboard, lots of carbonation, band-aid, dog’s back. Infected.

Bottle: Thanks Secret Santa! Pours golden with good clarity and an enormous white head. Oxidized & sweet in the nose- some papery notes, mild caramel and a light off tartness (is it infected?) Painfully over-carbonated. Voluminously effervescent- masks the actual body. Lightly sweet grains mesh with a nondescript tartness and some papery dusty notes. It’s apparently infected, and oxidized. This bottle was either past it’s prime, mistreated, or something went wrong during bottling. I’d give a fresher/better condition bottle another shot- potentially a mediocre beer.

Old bottles showed up at a local shop, brewery rep says it has not been brewed since Dec 07. Clear golden color with lots of carbonation, three big fingers of lumpy white head that falls slowly in a dome the sides of the glass left clean. Aroma is wheaty, grainy. Taste is grains, toasty malt and some spiciness.
Another beer from TC that is not terribly impressive. I enjoy the grain flavors and am a fan of the style, so i enjoyed this a little more than i feel i should have.

hazy greenish/gold pour with a large white head. honey, butter, and hop aroma. the usual sourness expected from TC is in full effect here. a total infected mess as usual. has some hops, lemon, and pepper notes though.
A light body and pleasent malty flavor. Some grainy and hay also. Nothing special. But not "bland".

Bottle courtesy decaturstevo. I love the Commercial Description: "a refreshing pallet." But this beer tastes better than a pallet to my palate. Kinda boring though. Maybe they can grind up some of the pallets to make a high fiber version.
12oz bottle. Light amber color with wisps of white head. Aroma is spicy with a flavor like sweet multi grain bread. The first few sips were really interesting. Then I just slugged it down.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Wisconsin Brewing Company--Rainbow Red Ale--2001 Release--12 oz. Bottle--4.30% ABV--42 IBU’s. (3.5 / 5.0) Red Ale--Cloudy rich amber red color. Mild floral hop front. Toasted fruit aroma. Mild crisp light sweet dry toasted red fruit body. Caramel bisquit notes. Crisp dry balanced mild hop spice end. Mild. Sampled 9/27/2001. Wisconsin Brewing Company--Ex-Sand Creek Brewing Company--Rainbow Red Ale--2005 Release--12 oz. Bottle--5.00% ABV--50 IBU’s. (4.25 / 5.0)--Red Ale--Beer of the Month Club Selection May, 2005. Mild lacy head. Clear pretty bright rich thin red color. Toasted floral hop front. Crisp tangy toasted caramel dry sweet earthy mild fruit bisquit body. Dry sweet ESB hop spice end. Sampled 5/25/2005.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: This is a cool looking beer. It is medium brown in color and reminds me to tea. It also has a nice tan foam that doesn’t last long. The aroma is sweet and malty. Flavor is sweet caramel malt with some hops underneath. The malt clearly dominates. Occasionally the hops show up more that at other times.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: This amber ale smelled and tasted a lot more like a brown ale than an amber ale to me. Barely noticable hop presence made this red overly malty. The malts were very sweet and sugary in taste. Not at all representative of a good amber.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Pours out a somewhat dark shade of orange with a small off white head. Aroma is sweet. THe taste is sweet with some notes of fruit and some sweet caramel finish. A very drinkable beer, solid effort

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Color was a deep orange-like brown color and rather opaque. The head came up slightly with a tan color and dissipated fairly quickly, leaving only a few traces behind as I drained the glass. The aroma overall was sweet with fruity tones to it, although I could detect a whiff of caramel. My first impression was the sweetness from the malts which resulted in the flavors of fruits and caramel. After a bit more of a taste, I could detect the hops better and the taste seemed to take on a more toffee-like flavor to it with grapefruit undertones. It’s definitely a complex brew with a medium, rich body to it. The hops kicked in a bit more on the finish, giving it a spicy-like taste. There’s no great kick from the carbonation which is mild.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: "Medium to dark amber color. Small head with good lacin. Aroma was sweet and floral. Medium bodied. Taste sweet and friuity. Taste better as it warms. Has a spice to it pepper like others said. Sweet after taste."

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: I got this one in my beer club. I have never heard of the brewer before. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a ruby chestnut color with a small tan head that faded quickly. The aroma was sweet and grapefruity. The flavor was fruity, nutty and lightly earthy with a sweet nutty finish.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Yep, it’s red! Nice solid creampuff of a head. Interesting caramel aroma. The flavor reminds me of gingersnap cookies, or something ... bready, yet sweet, with a dry honey-clove finish.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Reddish orange. Nose of candied oranges, sugars, few hops. Flavor is sweet, lots of caramel, some bright fruit, hops for balance at the end. Quite dry and toasty in the finish. An enjoyable session beer, could drink a number of these.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Fairly dark amber body with a yellowish head. Aroma of bourbon, peaches and a little perfume. The taste is relatively dry orange peels. There is also some bread crust and grapefruit background. The caramel character comes to play after you have a few drinks.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: 12 ounce bottle, Sand Creek label, from Woodman's Oak Creek. Dark brown, thin fizzy tan head fair retention. Aroma of roast, clay, green coffee. Taste is chocolate, roast, sunflower seeds. Thin. Very weak porter. Meh.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Tasty sweet with little roast. Kinda sticky I guess. Just very sweet malt standard porter. Better than what it's rated rn

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: 12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted grains, coffee and toffee. Taste is chocolate and coffee.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: From bottle, the pour is dark amber in color with a very airy off white head that is dissipating quickly. The aroma is malty, yeast, and notes of toffee. The taste is toffee, a little coffee, and roasted grains. The finish is slightly sweet and roasted. The mouthfeel is thin.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Bottle: Pours dark, clear, ruby-brown with a creamy beige head. Cocoa, dark grain aroma. Taste is a light chocolate/cocoa malt, caramel, barley... A really nice, if a bit light, little porter. "...if we built this large wooden badger........"

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Bottle. Chocolate barley malt and straw aroma. Amber with moderate head. Mildly sweet chocolate, roasted barley malt, and mildly bitter herbal hay flavor. Decent body. Pretty good - "Badger, your book on "How to Pick Up Trashy Women" is here".

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Pours a dark brown color with light tan head. Coffee, roasted malts, and raw cocoa on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with coffee and chocolate, light sweetness too.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: bottle shared with myself, right now, dark briwn clearish pour with thin white head, coffe and sugar aroma, taste is sweet with mild cocoa hints, not bad,

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Honestly, fuck this. It’s not 2002 so why are these guys making 2002 "microbrew." This stuff looks okay and even has a nice chocolatey smell at first but digging deeper, it is just laden w/ off-notes and brewing flaws. Oxidized cardboard and weird cherry-ish notes abound along w/ salty soy-sauce notes which you normally only find in high gravity stuff. One needs only to look at the bottom shelf of the cheap beer section of your grocery store to find a better Wisconsin brew.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: An okay porter. Dark, but not particularly thick. Mild at the beginning with roastiness coming on strong at the end.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it. I like some more complexity.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Pioneer Lager--2000 12 oz. Bottle. 5.40% ABV. 18 IBU’s. (3.5 / 5.0) Amber Lager. Clear rich amber color. Light hop front followed by rich malty body with lightly toasted fruit flavors. Dry sweetness. Incomplete lager smoothness. Tight chalkiness in end with light citrus note. Sampled 8/17/2000.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Wet grainy nose. More orange pour than most lagers. Actually doesn’t taste that bad. A little watery, but plenty of grain on the tongue. taste quickly departs.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Courtesy of Skyview. Very murky brown/orange color with a quickly collapsing large head. Fairly heavy floral and citrus hops for a pale lager. Those fade in the flavor a lot. Mostly grains and caramel.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: June 2008 Beer of the Month Club Overall Impression: Average looking, average tasting amber lager.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: hazy amber, medium quickly dissipating head, tiny white bubbles with slight lacing. not at all pale lagery looking. very sweet malt, perhaps hint of hop in nose. flavor is earthy malt and floral hops which do not offset each other very well. no body, mildly bitter finish. i like lagers, so this one is disappointing in its complete lack of lagerliness. 6 pack from liquor depot in monee.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Amber in color with no head and low carbonation. Aroma is a bit nutty with some biscuit aromas. Flavor is nothing really special, low caramel sweetness and little bit of a walnut taste. Overall not too impressive of a beer but definitely better than the macro options.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: A none too impressive lager, tasting largely of malty corn. The Beer of the Month people need to try a little harder.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: This came from the BOM club. Really not that good. Oh well. How much can you say about a beer you will probably never drink again?

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: 12 oz bottle. Poured a clear dark orange color. Head was two fingers high and off white with decent retention. Some lace was left behind at the end. There were whiffs of biscuity malt and subdued caramel, but not much else. Dry and grainy flavor accented by white paper and some grassy hops. Eh.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Pioneer Pale Ale--2002 12 oz. Bottle. 4.20% ABV. 48 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Malt of the Earth Beer of the Month Club Selection November, 2002. Clear rich golden color. Nice lace. Light head. Very floral hop front. Rich mild sweet doughy crisp tangy clean biscuit caramel malt body. Balanced light citrus hop end. Earthy chalk nut note. Sampled 11/24/2002.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Medium gold color, small head. A full bodied pale ale. Malty and slightly hoppy. Full smooth taste. Lots of flavor. Slightly smoky taste. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Hazy orange color. Head was decent. No aroma. Dry- little bit of sweetness. This one falls into the category of- "please introduce me to the brewer responsible for this sad excuse for a beer so that I can have his/her head checked". Why do some people bother? Please, someone answer that for me.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: This pours a hazy light honey. Floaties. The average frothy white head is mostly diminishing with good lacing. The tame nose is piney and slightly flowery and bready. The flavor though shallow has decent balance. Average hoppy nutty finish, though not as bitter as I was anticipating. The light watery body is soft and feels metallic at the finish. Good session beer. Better than average.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: The pour is a clear amber, the head is white, the lace is adequate. Nose is malt, and a bit buttery. Front is sweet, the top light, the finish is dry, acidic, lightly hopped and pretty mediocre as pales go, can't say I disagree with the other ratings. Ranks #929 on my current 1000 beer master list.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: I never heard of Pioneer before receiving a six-pack via a mail-order beer club. Wisconsin has great breweries in all sizes and styles. This brewery (from its website) looks small and "hands on". Not the best example of Wisconsin beers but it was a new brewery for me.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Very well balanced, and a very easy beer to drink 6 of......................

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it. I like some more complexity.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Poured a deep red-amber with a decent head that faded to a nice lace. Aroma was of sweet malts with a hint of apple & fruit. Taste was of a nutty malt with a fairly smooth light to moderate hop finish. Palate was decent. Overall, this is a nice malty Marzen that the folks at Sand Creek should be proud of.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: The pour is an amber/orange color with a minimal off-white head. The nose is very buttery (lots of diacetyl) with some light notes of roasted/toasted malts. The flavor is bland and watery with some mild toast and a hint of candied orange peel. The body is thin and water and the carbonation is medium at best.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Pioneer Brewing Company--Pioneer Black River Red--2002 12 oz. Bottle. 4.50% ABV. 25 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Red Lager. Malt of the Earth Beer of the Month Club Selection November, 2002. Clear thin amber red color. Light head and lace. Light toasted floral hop malt front. Sweet caramel doughy biscuit crisp smooth dry malty body. Clean lingering malt mild smooth hop end. Nice. Sampled 11/23/2002.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Draft @ Clark Street Ale House, Chicago,IL. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a slightly roasted malty fruity caramel finish.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Amber, light haze, thin off white head, no real lacing. Aroma of chocolate malt with a sulfury undertone. First taste was downright bad, lightly roasted malt ruined by a touch of rotten egg. Fortunately the sulfur element mellows out quickly, and the rest comes across as a palatable malty amber, chocolate and cider. Medium body.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Draft at OF. Filtered red-brown color. Solid off-white head. Mellow sweet amber-lager aroma. Mellow and creamy, with some orange-vanilla amber malt nuances. Medium bodied, quite drinkable. Doesn’t really capture much of the Oktoberfest flavor, certainly more of an Amber Lager. Quite smooth, with a very pleasant Lagfer yeast mouthfeel.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Courtesy of Skyview. Dark copper color with a medium head. Aroma started light caramel, and quickly vanished completely. Thick body and chewy, yet somehow almost flavorless, malt. Caramel sweetness.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Amber body with a thin but lasting beige head. Sweet aroma of caramel, bread, and just a touch of hops. The palate is a bit thin, but very smooth. Fairly well-balanced flavor starts in with the caramel sweetness. In the middle is a flavor almost like tea which is followed by a hint of hoppy bitterness. The finish is sweet again with a hint of brown sugar. This is a good beer, but not as full-flavored as some other Oktoberfests.

column2: Black River Falls, Wisconsin, United States
column5: Thick reddish copper with next to no head. Aroma of caramel, nuts, sweet malt and brown sugar. Taste of sweet malt and not much else. Some nut bitterness, some cloying properties but mostly bland and ho-hum from first to the last drop.

column1: Lang Creek Good Medicine Brown Ale
column5: Tap @ Barley’s Kalispell, MT. Nice dark amber/brown color with a ruby tint, thin beige head that didn’t last. Aroma was weak. Flavor was of molasses and soy sauce. Dissapointing. The Tri motor amber was considerably better but it too was rather weak and unremarkable.

column1: Lang Creek Good Medicine Brown Ale
column5: Faint malty aroma. Over carbonated. Faintly roasted. Low hops. Watery. Bland. These are not positive things. Have to be a much better brown to compete with moose drool as far as montana browns go.

column1: Lang Creek Good Medicine Brown Ale
column5: I didn't care for this one at all. It definately didn't explode on the palate, as it says. the beer was somewhat thin, light brown in color, The flavor was of light malt, nothing distinctive about it. Unimpressive.
On tap @ GF Blues and Brews Festival. Pours a golden yellow color. Aromas of wheat bread and a touch of hops. Flavor is sweet wheat with a scattering of hops at the end.

Medium gold color, medium head. Light bodied wheat ale. Full flavor, somewhat malty and hoppy for a wheat beer. Mouthfeel is full. Taste is a little rough. Finish is crisp and slightly harsh. Aftertaste is bitter.

Date: 10/12/1996 Source: Brewfest, Newport, OR cloudy light amber, sweet malt plus hop aroma, smooth hop flavor but not a lot of bitterness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Score: **+/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
on tap at the viking. pours a slightly golden color, with a sweet, fruity aroma. flavor is of fruit and hops. a solid beer for a night at the bar.
On tap @ GF Blues and Brews Festival. Pours a medium dark amber color. Aromas of caramel malts, crisp citrus. Flavor is malty with a nice hop action.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Oakes. Hazy golden colour with a thick white head. Sweet malty aroma, loads of biscuit, cookie dough and medium crystal along with some earthy and citrusy hops. Flavour is also malty, cookie dough and biscuit, some honeyish flavours as well. A bit thinner and dryer than the body might have suggested. Very faint diacetyl. Good, if typical.
Bright copper colour. Earthy hop, vienna malts and a spicy yeast make up the flavour profile. The aroma is mainly the yeast spiciness and straightforward bread/caramel malt character.

Summer 02 (?). Bottle. recently discovered notes...I like this beer, but not as much as the other APAs I've tried. Pours clouded and amber/orange. Lots of hops on nose, floral, but also bell pepper. Not cascadey, I don't think. Flavors are dominated by hops, but not very bitter. This beer can't seem to make up its mind - it's not very bitter, nor very malty, nor giving me a great sense of balance. Back to the drawing board with this one. Finish IS very clean and dry and beer looks great.
Hazy pale amber. Good fruity hop nose. Highly hopped throughout. Long finish is more like an IPA. Great lace

Medium orange gold color. Medium head. A medium bodied pale ale, smooth flavor, slightly bitter. Nice balance, Mouthfeel is full and smooth. Smooth taste. Finish is crisp and hoppy. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Gorgeous dark brown color with a light tan head that lasts forever. The nose is malty and delivers of chocolate and carmel. Thick, solid mouthfeel and a nice, hoppy bite on the tongue. My favority Montana dark beer. Get to Marion and try some.
Dark brown with small but lasting head.Hoppy nose. Starts malty, then becomes very aggressively hopped

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: not bad, much too sweet for me. Some caramel and nutty malts. From bottle in Vancouver, WA

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: 12oz bottle acquired in trade with jake65 (thanks!). Poured a medium and cloudy brownish color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, toasted malts, and some citrus. Tastes of caramel, toasted malts, a trace of dark fruitiness, and toffee. Body a tad on the thinner side. Lacing left on the glass.

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: On tap at The FrontDoor Boise, Pours out a dark brown topped with a sand head. Aroma of sweet malts and light spice. Tast more malts and a light hop on the end. Nothing to great.

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: Richy, full, woody brow-amber with frothy-browned cream head. Sweet hops greet the nose and an inkling of holiday spices, perhaps allspice and cinnamon. Mouthfeel is mildly hoppy and spicy, and again lightly spiced and with the noted presence of caramel malts. Rather thin body. Some cardboard hop finish on back-end. Dissapointingly under-bodied for an ESA. Had they boiled off more wort and fermented a higher OG brew, this would have the chance to be stellar stuff.

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: 208 Bottle - Pours a dk brown with a small off white head...aroma is rich with honey malt but something is missing...flavour is horrendous, thin on the front and bitter on the end with very little character in between, finishes with a bit of roasted pine...sory to say this was a drain pour for me...

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: I am finally getting near the end of the incredible selection from bhensonb and this is one of them, Poured a dark brown with a fat tan head and good lacing .Nose of roasted malts with some chocolate. Rich moufhteel. Lots of flavor with again good roasted malts. Very smooth drinking and quite enjoyable.

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: This black ale poured with a nice beige head and a mellow malt aroma. There is a hearty caramel malt flavor with lots of carbonation. Sticks to the palate.

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: Bottle from John’s Marketplace in Portland, OR. Beautiful mahogany color with a multi-finger beige/tan head. Aroma of resin backed by citrus. Near full bodied with vigorous, near creamy carbonation. Flavor is quite resiny, backed by heavy caramel, finishing balanced, evergreeny, and mouthsmacking. Just excellent. Makes me think of gin.

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: 2007. Dark beer that smells like trees. as it warmed the tree smell mellowed and tasted less like a tree and more like a beer being consumed in a forest. A chocolate flavor emerged as it warmed. They didn’t go crazy trying to add too many competing flavors, and did try for something original. Perhaps a bit of coriander would have assisted the mid-palate.

column1: Lang Creek Glacier Pilot Winter Warmer
column5: 2007 edition in the bottle from 99 Bottles in Federal Way WA. Pours an extremely dark brown to almost black with a very thin and hardly present off white head. Some roastedness to the aroma, but not much otherwise. Good mouthfeel, as it warms, I get a pleasant burst of milk chocolate. This is like Our Special Ale, if Anchor put not spices in the beer. Still, I get a mild bit of pine and juniper to the flavor. OK, but not great.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Sample at Autumn Festival of Ales - Hoppy nose, citrusy hop palate, some depth in flavor. I’d have it again.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: This was a standard amber ale that had been kicked up a bit with some nice American hops.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Great malts. Medium bitterness. Full flavor. A very good beer............

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Had some pints a few weeks ago from what I was told will be the last keg made for Leisure’s. A middle of the road session ale with good malt balance and classic amber finish.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (draft @ 2006 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY) Dark red in color with a thin tan head. Aroma is very sweet and malty. Some chocolate in the aroma as well. Flavor is sweet and malty as well with some chocolate malts at the end. Light-bodied and slightly fizzy. A little too sweet.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: This was different. I was expecting generic crappy amber. What I got was creamy and smooth. Caramel and doughy. Enjoyable.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Uniqueness was it was both hoppy and brown and malty and smokey. Carmelized malt. Very fresh for St. Paddy’s. Earlier Rating: 4/27/2004 Total Score: 3.7 Uniqueness was iIt was both hoppy and brown. Very good and a reason why I will come back again. Could be bottled. Carmelized malt

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Great smoky flavor. Good malts. Way too dark for the style...............

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: ( on tap) Aroma: malt, herbs Taste: semi-dry, flavour of malt, herbs Palate: medium body, medium carbonation. Overall: Decent one

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: Przeciêtny Czeski ležak. Œrednia pó³ka so started fron the bottom now we here. Aroma nie czuje od tygodnia mam katar. Oceny jak przysta³o praktycznie na œredniej jak przysta³o na czeskie nie najgorsze p i w k o

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: A bit dark in color. The Aromas are malt and Spice. The flavors aren't anything like the lagers that I had in Bohemia. These flavors are wet paper and sweet with carbonation to balance. Some bitter and metallic in the Finish. Not very good beer.

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: # 246; 3/2016. Sladový èeský ležák s ne pøíliš pøíjemnou dochutí a ulpívající hoøkostí.

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: Bardzo porz¹dny czeski lager. Jest oczywiœcie g³ównie s³ód, ale wyraŸnie uzupe³niony kwasowoœci¹ i goryczk¹. OrzeŸwiaj¹ce, nie rozwodnione, przyjemne.

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: 0,5l Flasche. Goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Typisches tschechisches Pils.

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: 0.5 l bottle. Pours solid golden with decent head. A: hoppy, yeasty, banana, T: crisp, medium/full body, bitter, malty, balanced

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: Porz¹dny czeski pilsner, mo¿e ciut zbyt s³odowy. Klasycznie z³ocisty, ³adna bia³a piana, zaznaczona saaska goryczka. By³o godnie.

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: Pours a bright clear golden with a rocky white head that stays around. Bread dough and grain aroma. Taste is sweet pale malt, bread dough, biscuits, grass and some mild hop bitterness at the swallow. A really decent and refreshing pale lager.

column1: Bernard Svìtlý Ležák 12° / Premium / Bohemian Lager / Dvanáctka
column5: Great lager !!! Aroma: Noble Czech hop (grassy) Taste: Slightly malty, sweetish Aftertaste noble bitterness.

On tap at 2013 CB Autumn Festival of Ales. The aroma is caramel and fig, dates, malt, cookies, floral hops, and light woodyness. The flavor is dry malt with some caramel sweetness, some light toast, dark fruit, and faint bitterness. Dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
nice malt flavor, smooth finish, wished for a bit more hops but overall a decent brew

(draft @ 2006 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY) Copper in color with a thin white head. Aroma is malty with some light sweetness. Flavor is semi-sweet with a nice malt backbone and some slight bitterness at the end. A little watery.
Copper body. Nose is rich & malty, a hint of chocolate. Flavor is caramel malt, a little nut/hop in the finish.
Slightly sweet, toasty malt aroma. Copper/orange color. Similar flavor. Decent O-fest.
The 2002 is a vintage year -- perhaps a little more hops in the aroma, but other than that, an excellent Wies''n. Better than years previous, which were good.
Growler, brother-in-law purchased from CB. This one was heavy like a stout. Thick head, smoky aroma with some chocolate. Palate was hoppy and toasted. Very good!
Draft. Dark red to black body, roasty nose with some diacetyl notes, nice head. Very one-dimensional: mildly roasty, light. Not much in the hop department.
Very well roasted barley as evident by the aroma and intensely roasty flavor. Nice head. While it is definitely roasty the bitterness is mild.

Tasted on draft at the Tap Room. Deep dark-brown color with a tan head that quickly dissipated. Has an coffee-chocolate aroma. Has a medium-strong flavor of dark roasted malt and coffee. Not much in the way of hop flavor and a the hop bitterness and bitterness from the roasted malts combine well for a good, balanced finish. Mouthfeel isn’t as thick as you might want from a porter, but all around its a nice beer.

[draft - 2004 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY] Dark black pour with a thick tan head. Roasted malt and coffee aroma. Dry and roasty malt taste with a bitter coffee finish. Not a bad porter.
Average Porter. Not their best beer. Roasted coffee flavor with typical ending bitterness.
Decent porter, nothing special. Roasty aroma, roasty flavor with some bitterness on the end. A bit thin.
Pretty much a standard porter. A little thin, some nice mocha flavor and a touch of biterness in the finish.
Man i love this porter. Not too a dark color. With a dark tan head. Nice roasty aroma and flavor.
Dark. Fruity, roasty nose. Good hop and roast tastes. Nice long palate...

2010 Autumn Festival of Ales. Translucent yellow pour. Big aroma of lemons. Mostly lemons in the flavor with a thin body. Some malt in there to hold this together. It was a good change a pace from all the IPA’s.
Draft at Buffalo Tap Room. Pours gold with a white head. Light aroma, a hint of lemon and a hint malty. The flavor has sweet malt and some fruity lemon sweetness. Pretty good.

Very light yellow color. Maybe bleached by all the lemon? The aroma and especially the flavor are very lemony. While the flavor seemed almost artificial, it was refreshing and not unpleasant to drink.
Cloudy yellow color. Lots of lemons on the nose and in the taste. Not bad for a hot day, but since you can only get it on tap at the tap room you'll be inside anyway.
Ultra-lemony. Unique and refreshing, but very difficult to finish. Def an experimental beer that just didn't work.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales - A medium brown pour with a small white head. A malty aroma of coffee and chocolate. A roasted malt flavor with nuts. Some bitterness at the end.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at Hogan’s Hideaway in Rochester NY. Poured maple brown with a beige head. Aroma is light roasted malt and semi-sweet chocolate. Medium body. Flavor is roasted malt, caramel, toast and floral hops in the finish. Pretty well balanced and quite good.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at Hogan’s Hideaway. Not really a memorable brew. Balance was poor, and the finish is bitter. Sampled at the brewery just in case my initial tasting was off. I’ll pass on this from now on.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: [draft - Custom Brewcrafters - Honeoye Falls, NY] Brownish color with a thin but creamy white head. Faintly sweet aroma with hints of coffee, chocolate and other earthy notes. Very nice rich and roasty flavor of malt and nuts with a smooth hop blend and a very smooth and ever so slightly bitter hop finish. I really enjoyed this beer. It was the first beer I ever bought a growler of to take home with me.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: An apalling experience - a train wreck. Almost non-existent aroma, some weak coffee and chocolate and tree bark - flav was of some roastiness and black malt, a bit bitter, but completely awash in wateriness - incredibly thin and watery.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Rich and dark. Not very complex. Competent................................

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales - Is this another IPA. Better than some of the others. Golden pour with a citrus and hop aroma. A medium hop body with a bitter ending.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at Hogan’s Hideaway in Rochester NY. Pours gold with a fluffy white head. Aroma is citrus hops, fruit and caramel. Medium body, very clean and crisp. Flavor starts almost like orange candy, then a hint of brown sugar and caramel followed by a all hop finish, with floral hops lying underneath throughout. Nicely balanced, very drinkable.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On-tap as "American Pale" at Mr. Goodbar. Good citrus aroma. Attractive soapy white head. Citrus taste, very bitter like an understated IPA or extra-bitter.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Growler from the brewery and draughts at Hogan’s Hideaway. Pours medium golden with a white head and moderate lacing. Aroma is floral and hops, with some malt additions. Hops are well balanced and finish is classic APA bitterness. Very good representation of the style.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pale muted gold color. Not much hops aroma. Served very cold and has a dry hopped appeal. Though there is little malt character. Tastes leafy/floral but the body is only medium and ends with more dry hops and a little subdued on the finish body wise.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: I like it alot. Great malts and hops. Full flavor. Great hop flavors...
A gift from a friend, Marks & Spencer's Staffordshire IPA. A decent & very drinkable IPA
Run of the mill IPA. A bit thin on the body. Wouldn't close my mouth it was poured on top of me.

Bottle from M&S, thanks to/shared at folks in London - (as M&S Staffordshire IPA) golden amber pour with white head. Sweet and toasty malty, with some vague citrus fruity notes, sweet caramel malty, some cereal, light to medium body, twiggy subdued hoppy finish.
As m & s stafforshore ipa . Gold fine head. Peppery. minerals. Finish is dry as a bone.

[Mark & Spencer, Staffordshire IPA] Pours crystal clear golden colored body with a white head that settles quickly. Aroma is slightly grassy, citrusy with a hint of pine. Taste is sweet up front with a grassy, almost floral hop note following. More sweet than bitter. Light mouthfeel, crisp carbonation, medium body.

Pours golden/amber, fizzy and very carbonated, with a medium white head and some lacing. Aroma is lager malts and hops, to understand that the IPA in its name it’s a fraud! Tastes bitter, lager malts, some lemony notes, thin body, lively carbonation. Feel like a boring lager with 1 hop cone in it. Boring boring boring.
From old tasting notes. Amber orange color topped by a fine creamy beige head. Soft fruity malt aroma. Faint malt flavor has a brief bitter backdrop. Very peppery and dry.
Bottle for my birthday from in laws. Golden amber beer with large head. Aroma of malts. Taste is dry malt, spice, dried fruit, citrus and hop bitterness. OK.
Marks & Spencer bottling. This is OK! It’s certainly the original style of IPA rather than the very hoppy style of today’s craft brewers. It is hoppy but in a gentle way. It’s alright!
Bottle. Golden in colour. Fruity; citrus orange and lemon. Hoppy; grassy hops. Malty; toasty malts, caramel. Slightly metallic taste. Citrus fruity hoppy bitterness over sweet malts. (2010-01)

From old tasting notes. Deep Amber red color. Thin white head. Sweet toasted malt aroma, reminiscent of oatmeal cookies. Tangy toasted malt flavor. Nice coffee-like character with a pinch of hoppiness in the finish. Cloying mouth filling aftertaste.
2010 decent malty ale. served ice cold, so it takes a while to open up and is pleasantly sweet with a light hop bite when it does.
Tap. Nice beer, but not true to style. Aromas of caramel, and butter. Aroma is sweet, with average length. Palate is silky, with a thin body. Amber, with a frothy head.

On tap at Windmills in Kingston. Deep copper with a thick nitro-looking tan head. Aroma is not good: veggie compost with sweet undertones. Flavours are decent enough-- toffee, vague dark fruits, low bitterness.

Bottle shared by Dogbrick as a precursor to his Portland beer tasting. Pours a clear gold/copper with a medium off-white head. Malty nose with cream and caramel. Creamy malt flavor with a bit of a bitter hop finish. Not knocking my socks off, but better than I expected.
Pours a dark amber with a small white head. Light malt aroma. Taste is mild caramel, malt and hop. Nice balance but nothing special.

Sample at the "Portland? Psh More Like Beerland" tasting on 03/10/10. Bottle courtesy of a traveling colleague. The beer is a clear dark amber color with a medium thin and foamy off-white head that dissipates slowly. Stringy lacing on the glass. Grainy malt and hops in the nose. Medium, smooth body with flavors of sweet malt, mildly bitter hops and a touch of molasses. The finish is malty with a lingering light hops aftertaste. Okay overall.
deep reddish/brown, big beige head. nose; smells good, malty, herbacious, bread dough, taste is a little nutty, crisp, some roastiness, overall pleasant.

At my hotel in Niagara Falls. This was a lot like an amber ale. The appearance was amber, white head. The aroma was bread, caramel, malts. The flavor was caramel, and a sourdough bread taste, actually enjoyable. The finish was bitter, mainly from noble hops. The mouthfeel was thin/medium. Not bad at all.

On tap at the Woolwich Arms in Guelph The aroma was almost no existent slight sweet hops Pours a pale cooper with a small white head with good lacing The taste was fairly mild and i am unsure whether the keg was old or not so this one will need to be revisited at some point
Tight bubbly tan head stayed on a reddish brown still body. Malt, caramel & spice aroma. Medium bodied, highly carbonated & thin on the back. Bitter fruity tastes with caramel, spices & malt.
Many thanks to Marc for this bottle. Smooth malty, easy to drink with a nice caramely back. Very nice and fruity ending.

330ml bottle. Dark brown colour with ruby glimmer and average to huge, thick, frothy to creamy, moderately lasting, minimally lacing, off-white head. Yeasty fruity aroma, hints of cherry, morello, plum, minimally nutty, dark malty aroma. Taste is slightly yeasty fruity, minimally nutty dark malty, diluted hints of cherry and plum, minimally metallic finish.
A standard dubbel, quite good, clean, but not too strong. Mild notes of fig and maple syrup-like flavours. online belgian beer factory
Bottle, 330 ml, courtesy of Krešo or Bir. Pours brown with beige head. Caramel, malty, some fruity notes, brown sugar, yeast. Low carbonation. Medium sweetness. Medium bodied.

Dark ruby-brown with a beige head. Rich malty aroma. Taste is a blend of malty flavoury, but not the sweet kind, accompanied by a gentle but distinct bitterness. Underneath are some fruity notes. Good.

Bottle from Drankenhandel Leiden. Aroma is dark malt with caramel, dried fruits, raisins, and spicy yeast. Flavour is medium sweet and lightly bitter. Body is medium. Pretty average Dubbel, not bad but nothing special either.
Bottle @ home. Brown w a tan head. Aroma medium malty (caramel, roasted, dark fruit). Flavor medium sweet, light bitter. Medium body, medium carbonated.

Een roodbruin abdijbier met een klein beetje schuim. De Aroma's: karamel, gebrande mout, chocolade, fruit. Smaak: Hop, karamel, bitterheid, gebrande mout. Afdronk: Droog en verder niet spannend genoeg om er nog eentje te nemen.
Aardige dubbel, hoewel ik toch echt een beetje smaak mis. Beetje flauwtjes allemaal. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Close to one of the nicest lagers I have ever had! Not too strong but not too light, a perfect beer for a light dinner!

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: On draft at the Kelowna BC Airport. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Bready aroma. Sweet malt flavors.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Edmonton 14/7 2018. 47,3 cl on draught at The Old Spaghetti Factory. As “Cobblestone Lager”. Pours clear pale yellow with medium sized white head. Settles as thin layer of foam crawling up the side of the glass. Substantial lacing. Aroma is on the Generic and non descipt side. Sweet pale malts, citrus, light saltiness and hints of Grass. Strong carbonation. Thin, watery, lively texture. Flavor is medium sweet followed by and balanced by medium bitterness. Aftertaste is lightly bitter and short. A Well balanced but extremely generic and quite uninteresting pale lager.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Good lager, a little bitter but has a medium aftertaste. Pretty good beer to have with pub food. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: pours a pale yellow with thin white head. light body. a touch of malt, a touch of hops and a clean finish. Take this for what it is - a macro masquerading as a micro. Would beat almost any of the macro lagers - just not by much.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Draft. The body is clear yellow with a thick white head. The aroma has yeast and is weak. The tastes is fresh though.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Pours a huge foamy white head that sticks around for a while. Has a straw/light golden appearance. Quite active carbonation. Aromas of grainy malts and mild bready notes as well as earthy hops. Definitely that lager aroma quality. Sweeter than usual lager flavours. Light malts and very mild citrus hops. Hints of lime and a bit of corn notes as well. Has a somewhat astringent mouthfeel with fairly lively carbonation. Slight tingling sensation on the palate. Not bad.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Clear dark straw color with a good layer of activity. Very faint foamy white 1 finger head, lasting around 5 minutes, making a bit of lacing. Flavors of sweet grains, barley, light caramel and lemon, with herbal spices. Thick sugary feel, with almost sour hops. Oily full body with soft prickly carbonation. Light to medium strength finish, biscuity and bready, highly syrupy with very coarse leafy hops. Badly flavored, almost with an aftertaste of puke from a wet bitter corn feel, and it’s way too syrupy. Doesn’t feel very fresh, hardly smells anything...no enjoyment here. Overall bad quality craft.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Average lager at best. Sort of sweet and really malty. Pours copper with a tan head. Had out of a bottle in Vancouver ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Draft. Golden beer with a cream head. Malt and light grass aroma. malt and light mineral flavor. Medium bodied. Malt and light mineral lingers.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Deep brown, tan head. Small bead. Malt nose. Malt flavor with a mild alcohol heat

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Very fresh, smokey, surprisingly strong "dark". Seems more like a porter to me. I guess the marketing geniuses decided that "black lager" would sell more beer.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Let's see - this used to be called Bock, now its Black Lager and its described as 'american dark', a "style" which doens't actually exist? This beer doesn't know what it wants to be, and it shows in the taste.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Malty, little stouty. Slight chemical aftertaste. After-aftertaste is good.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle. Very dark amber in colour. Very malty (lots of caramel, lots of toffee, lightly roasted malts). Fruity (dark fruits). Hoppy (light grassy hops). Sweet malty throughout with slight sour fruity/hoppy edge. Drinkable. (2008)

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: On tap. nice color on this one. Little to no head. Aroma was sweet caramel and malt. A bit of breadiness. Flavor was overly sweet, too much malt, to much caramel, kind of cloying and sticky. Pretty gross beer.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: (Bottle) Pours amber to brown. The aroma is toasted and a bit fruity with a note of burned butter. The flavour is of butter, caramel, toffee and fruits. The mouthfeel is soft, round a light watery. Medium bodied.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 341mL bottle poured a deep amber color with modest off-white head and little lacing. Aroma of caramel malts and some floral hops. Taste is caramel sweetness with a dry hop finish. Decent carbonation and light to medium body. A fair amber ale.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Clear dark copper colour. Rockey off white head that fades quickly. Dry malt nose with slight yeasty hints. Slight dry malt taste.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 341ml bottle purchased at the Taproom store in Granville Island, Vancouver for $2.50CAD Very good.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: A - Roasted caramel A - Amber brown T - Sweet M - Medium and soft O - Full amber

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Very little head, and what’s there is fizzy and disappears quickly. Aroma is alcohol, tin, and malt. Taste is smooth cardboard with a tin finish and a slight cream aftertaste. This one isn’t working. How did it become an "instant favourite"?

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 341 ml bottle. From Vancouver, BC, Canada. Dark mahogany colour with tiny off-white head. Caramel malt in quite dry aroma. Dry hoppy bitterness and caramel malt in flavour. Quite thin.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Draught at the taproom Amber color, creamy head. Caramel aroma, lightly nutty. It has an average nutty caramel flavor, and correct bitterness. It’s a fairly well brewed Amber, without excitement.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Can: Poured an orange with white head. Aroma is light honey. Taste is light honey and grain.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Pours a faint orange with thin white head. aromas of sugar and old grass. light - medium body. taste is light caramel malt with subtle hay and some residual sweetness. finish is a noticeable bitterness, but still balanced. Of the standard Granville Island offerings I have tried, this is definitely my favorite. It certainly doesn’t light the world on fire, but a refreshing lawnmower beer that could serve as a great "gateway" for macro-loving hold-outs.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 355ml can from mix pack. Pours a large frothy eggshell coloured head and has a pale golden appearance with moderate carbonation. Fairly good retention. Thick dirty lacing. Aromas of bready and toasty malts, notes of honey but somewhat faint. Very subtle honey flavour, some sweet and toasty malt notes as well  slick and slight drying mouthfeel. Smooth and refreshing making it good anytime of year but perfect for hot summer days.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Clear dark straw color with moderate activity. Slightly foamy white 2 finger head, lasting around 2 minutes, with faint legs. Flavors of caramel, sweet corn and barley, faint honey and lemon, and some herbal spices. Sugary cereals, minimal bitterness. Slick full body with prickly carbonation. Light weak finish, a dash of caramel and very subtle honey, and a bit of grassy and leafy hops..hardly no honey. Very soft and bland. Okay freshness, weak flavors, overly accessible, but doesn’t feel too adjunct. Overall poor quality craft.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Appearance: clear pale gold with a short-lived white head, minimal patchy lacing. (3/5) Aroma: grassy, pale crackery malt, corn, honey, light fruit. (5/10) Taste: moderate sweet, mild bitter. (5/10) Light body, moderate carbonation, medium-dry and crisp mildly bitter finish. (3/5) Unsurprisingly, it’s pretty similar to their Island Lager. The honey is definitely present, but doesn’t make the beer appreciably sweeter. It’s also not significantly better in any realistic way. One could certainly make for a decent break from the other, perhaps. I could see alternating between the two on a hot day floating on the Shuswap, for example. Again, however, I wouldn’t necessarily go looking for this. (11/20)

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Good for a light lager, but still quite bland for a beer. Could use some more body, but it's not overly carbonated like most in this style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 341ml bottle. Pours a clear, golden amber with a thin, short lived, fully dissipating, off-white head. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, bread, honey and light grain. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, honey, corn and bread with a mildly dry, bitter, metallic note in the finish. Meh.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle hold pour white head, nose and taste are honey laver, pretty good overall for real

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: On June 19, 2015. At Granville Island Brewing, in Vancouver, British Columbia. Clear golden color, white head. Malty, clean taste. Light malty aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness. Clean malty scent.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Drinking from a 33 cl bottle. In the aroma some grain, citrus, honey. The clear golden beer has a medium white head. A sweet lager taste, not very special. Medium carbonated.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Unique cherry aroma. Initial mouthfeel is soft, good for this brewery but the carbonation is still too fizzy. Mild, smooth body that is round and relatively well-balanced. Definate lager characteristics but not reminiscent of any others I’ve tried. As it warms the beer tastes better, fuller in body. Nice effort.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Yes, mine was rather skunky. Would like ti try again, I had a bad one.......

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: a very fruity beer,real nice and refreshing.Do not buy it in cans,it will be skunky.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Great beer, i've been looking for it without success however................

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Can (random shop, Canada). Straight from the can. Malty, watery, grainy, fizzy in aroma/taste. Quite pointless brew.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: On tap at Batch, pours a clear golden with a small beige head. Aroma brings out fresh grassy notes, a herbaceous character, and bready malt. Flavour is fresh and clean, with grassy hops, biscuity malt and a nice herbaceous character. Very clean and bright lager. Good stuff.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Not sure what the hell is going in here, but it ain’t good. Weird buttered popcorn malts on top of sweet corn and yeast, followed by a mineral-laden mild floral bitterness. Canadian Yuengling?

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Pours amber colour with minimal white head. Bit hoppier than other lagers. Lively carbonation. Medium body. Taste of bitter hops at the end.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 16 ounce can. The beer is a clear gold with a white head of creamy foam. The aroma is dough, lemon, some herbs. Sweet throughout. Medium body and medium carbonation.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Creemore Springs Premium Lager has a thick, creamy, off-white head, a hazy, amber appearance, fine bubbles, and heavy sheet lacing. The aroma is of tea, white wheat bread, and yeast. Taste is of tea, bitterness, brown bread crust, and a touch of fruit. There is also a steam beer aspect, here. Mouthfeel is medium, and Creemore Springs Premium Lager finishes crisp and refreshing. RJT

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: I liked this lager (not my favourite style) because it trended toward a malty hop ale taste And was slightly darker in colour.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Sampled on draft this beer poured a dark honey gold color with a medium sized foamy white head that left decent lacing. The aroma was sweetish with sour mash and light fruity hops. The flavor was sweetish and malty with sour mash and light fruity hops. Medium length finish. Medium bodied and smooth.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle on the slopes in Canada. Aroma of grains, a bit oranges, but rather malty. Poured light blond, with a lot of sparkling. Taste is pils, grain, grass, straw. Watery finish.

column4: Creemore Springs Brewery (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: This beer used to be one of my fav's. it was very tasty. Ever since they were bought by Molson-Coors, the beer is NOT the same tasting brew. I won't seek out.
Bottle. A hazy golden amber color with a tan head. A sweet malt body with a dry and slightly tangy palate. Malts coat the mouth and leave a long aftertaste.
Cloudy amber,beige head. Small but scarce bead. Corny nose. Corn grainy palate.

Medium brown color, small head. Medium malts, medium hops. Slightly roasted malts, somewhat hoppy, mild taste, good flavor. Smooth taste. Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is slightly malty, slightly bitter.
Reddish well balanced märzen with crystal malt flavour. ...................

Fruity esters little else in the nose, few bubbles thin head, dark amber color. Milky texture. A gaping hole between the front and back ends. Something evil lurks in there -- bacteria? Another undrinkable at the Pyramid brewery in Berkeley.
Not much in the way of aroma. Flavor is not intense, but what is there is enjoyable enough. Nice carbonation, and does have enough going on to make it somewhat unique. Not bad.
strange red-amber colour, few foam, caramel, quite light-bodied, slightly disturbing sourness
A good Marzen. Not the best by any stretch. But it's good, clean malty fun. A nice little beer, with a pretty good nose.

Hmmm...wondering where all this talk of robustness comes from. I had it at the Portland Spring Beer Fest in '99, and found it to be like the festival itself - kind of thin and without a lot of character.
Dark and mysterious color. Heavy aroma. Strong malt. Bold and strong body. Some slightly sour off-flavors interrupted my enjoying this beer to its fullest.

Before try this beer i seen very good comments everywhere but the beer surpass any imagination.. This beer is really insane.. All here is almost perfect and difficult you can find weakness.. First of all the Aroma is great and remind you some "Rochefort" or some classic dark beer. The mouthfeel is even better.. You feel the flavors when the beer touch your mouth.. The flavors go very fast in your mouth and the finish is just endless and amazing too. Some awesome bitterness in there.. But the most important of this beer is the taste. The taste is incridible good.. Many chocolate, caramel and dark fruits notes.. The beer give you some refreshing flavors in your mouth despite the "12°C" serving temperature. Overall one of the best beers i have try in my life.. This beer is simply amazing..

Dark dark brown pour with tan head. Smells of malted chocolate, light smoke, roast, a little coffee. Flavor is much the same - a smooth beer that hides the abv well under a simple but pleasant maltiness.

nearly pitch black with a crisp head that dissipates quickly. figgy flavour balanced with toasty dark malt, delivered through a clear and concise filtered body. great winter beer. doesn't go overboard on anything that a porter can go overboard with (sweet, dry, boozy...). bang for your buck at 8.5 percent abv doesn't hurt it's rep.

This has been my favourite beer for years. having immigrated from Germany i have missed the dark and malty beers that many pubs still tho this day brew themselves. This porter is smooth with tons of flavor and a rich but yet mellow finish.. This one is a winner.. love it

Dark brown color with small head. A lot of dark malts, and light liquorice feeling; good body strength, a bit of alcohol; moderately sweet; some stale feeling too; it reminds me of South German dunkels, but bolder.
Pours a dark brown with red tinges when aimed at the light. The taste is roasted malts, cocoa, dark fruits and coffee. Has a nice bitterness that gives balance. good beer
Pours dark, frothy head. Aroma of cherries and chocolate. Taste is the same, chalky mouth feel.

341 ml bottle. Pours black with deep amber highlights in edges, very dissipating tan head, some lacing. Aromas of chocolate coffee caramel roasted malts. Taste coffee chocolate and caramel malt. Nice lasting finish, well balanced.

Only the second decently done beer from Okanagan Springs I know of(brewmasters is the other). Pours and almost opaque black with a frothy brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, cocoa, dried fruits and something lightly off and maybe buttery. Taste is roasted malts, chocolate, cocoa and dark dried fruits with a dry finish. Nice big full body porter. But just not the balance that the style requires... Needs some fine tuning.
Drank out of small bottle. Minimal aroma above a slightly chocolatey malt. Taste is sweet. Thin mouthfeel.

This porter poured a deep black colour with a big, beautiful, creamy, light brown head. Scents include ripe fruit, cocoa, roasted malts and caramel. First swig was creamy and sweet with flavours of caramel and roasted malt being the most predominant. Finish is thick, sweet and roasty with malt flavours lingering.
Quite forgettable, but drinkable. Tastes of pale malts and grass. Has a light watery body with some carbonation. I forgot anything else about this standard lager.

341mL bottle pours pale golden with small white head and virtually no lacing. Aroma is very mild grain. Taste is very plain with little hops in the finish. Decent carbonation but a light body. Just another run of the mill lager.
Slightly better than the bavarian but still lacks real taste of aroma. Nice in appearance but appearances can be deceiving very bland tasting lager.
A - Yeasty and spicy A - Yellow with thin white head T - Dry with subtle bitter finish P - Thin, but nice and crisp O - Not a bad lager, just a bit light for me

The bottle says Original Lager and its a new package but OH WELL.... Not much of a smell there, but if there was, I would call it new and improved cardboard lite! Smells less cardboardy than our usual cardboard! I mean beer! HAha we don’t put cardboard in our beer... not much head or lacing or haze, but I’m struggling so I’ll give an extra point for the almost red hue. Taste isn’t BAD, but it isn’t good either. This isn’t sessionable, cuz after 3 I’d be sick of it and never buy it again, except it’s pre-mixed into the multi-box. Why don’t they let you make your own multi-box?

Marketed under the Okanagan Springs label. Pours a clear yellow with a small, dense, creamy white head. Aroma has a grainy, slight corny sweetness and a mild spicy noble hops nose. Flavor has a very harsh graininess to it at first, mild lemon note in the middle, slight spicy noble hops toward the end and a sour acidic ending. Body is light and fizzy with a slight dryness at the end. Overall not too enjoyable as the grainy and lemon flavors really don’t seem to work well on my palate.

Bottled sample via my brother-in-law’s mixed twelve box. Clear gold in colour with strong carbonation. Grainy upfront on the nose, along with some sulfur and a hint of citrus. Flavors are of white bread dough, minerals, and a bit more of that faint citrus note. Medium bodied. Hoppier and better than expected.
Acceptable pale lager, nice hoppy notes on the aroma and has a slight sweet maly upfront followed by a firm bitterness.
Pours light yellow. Fairly standard pale lager, but better than average for a mass produced one. Weak and watery mouthful. Nothing special.
Golden body , a good micro lager with a more full bodied taste then mass pale lager , a bit mild and grainy

341mL bottle poured a pale straw color with small white head and no lacing. Aromas of cereal and some citrus. Taste is lightly sweet and has only faint hoppy finish. A very mild pilsener with a light body and some carbonation.
As others have noted, the OK Spring Pilsner had potential that went nowhere, like many of the brewery’s other beers.
Their lager was so good the introduced this but it never gained the popularity of the Lager and Pale Ale
I loved this beer, although it tastes more like a Kolsch than a Pilsener. Nice citrus undertones but not a lot of hoppiness. Still a good beer.
A respectable hop aroma and floweriness of palate. That said, this is not an overly hoppy beer. It's really for lack of anything else that the hops stand out.

341mL bottle poured a pale straw color with small white head and no lace. Aroma is very mild honey and grain. Taste is lightly sweet with very little hop in the finish. Nice carbonation but light body. A slightly below average blonde ale, especially compared to some of the bolder tasting Belgian blondes.
Aroma is pretty weak, and the taste comes off skunky. You get used to it after awhile, but I would not recommend this beer.
smells lightly of alcohol. and pours pale yellow with a big detergent like white head that leaves no lace. tastes of sickly honey. not worth having twice.
Slightly thicker looking yellow/gold. Quickly dissipating head. Very light bee pollen aroma. Honey like start with a unpleasant metallic/rust middle and finish.

skunky aroma. Pours golden yellow, high carbonation, mid-range head. Low malt, palate thin. Honey Blond? This is marketed under the "Bavarian purity law" so I can't figure that out. Finish is flat and dull. Another weak effort from a snooze-fest brewery.
Not bad, blond ales tend to be watery and flavourless, at least in my opinion but I did notice a little honey in this beer. Bad head, and aroma but decent easy going summer beer for the porch.
Poor nose, unpleasant off flavor. Tainted?. Will re rate when I get bored...
A great little ale. Had some of this on Halloween when the whole fiasco took place. Ha, halloween and Honey blonde mix great
Tastes like beer. No more, no less. I have no greater insight to offer. It’s like elevator music.
Pours dark copper, thin head. Aroma is caramel, grain. Flavour is malty, caramel sweet. Finish is pretty thin, but dry and a bit of hops.
On draft at the Keefer Lake Lodge. Pours a clear dark copper with an off white head. Aromas of grass. Flavors are moderately sweet malt with mild bitterness.
Deep copper colour. Big, frothy head. Smells a little grainy. Tastes a little malty.
Draft pour in Bruno Sports Bar in Montreal. Clear amber with medium sized white head. Caramel malt. Smooth with bitter finish. Good mild pale ale.

Draught: This one pours a clear amber color. There was a thin off white head that left some lacing. The nose is OK. Some malts and grain, even fainter hops of the earthy and pine variety. The taste is good. A touch bitter, with some malts and graininess.

341mL bottle poured a clear amber color with small white head and little lacing. Aromas of caramel and some hops. Taste is lightly sweet up front with some faint hop bitterness in the finish. An average amber ale at best.

Many thanks for this old beer to Koelschtrinker. vintage 1970 in small unlabeled bottle. Beer more old than I. Almost half a century. without foam. Pale yellow colour. Drink only half beer. Acid, minimal hoppy, some cider vinegar, some verry dry white wine. Taste some like unblended Lambic. I like sour beer and I like this beer. Still good to drink with only little more than 3% ABV? Whow it's incredible. Thanks Again

1970s unlabeled bottle. Clear golden, no head. Smells quite clean, mostly resembling a semi-dry cider rather than a Berliner. Light clean lacto, qiute thin lacking carbonation, very light generic bitterness. No signs of oxidation or any obvious long term defects.
Old bottle from Max. Pours a murky brown with a thin white head. Old paper, soft toasty malt. Medium bodied, soft acid, tangy acidity. Definitely old.

1970s era bottle returned to former GDR territory near Gatow for consumption with Matthias. Nice fizz with cap removal. Pours cloudy yellow color, few bubbles. Aroma of cider and subtle feet. Taste is lightly tart cider and lemon. Amazing that it survived in decent condition.
15+ year old bottle. Never realized people kept this stuff like a precious treasure. Still pretty drinkable, a tad dusty bit decently sour and fun to drink.
Poured from a bottle, thanks to Jerry. Light color. Light lactic acid, doughy, lemon, dusty, light tannic quality. Refreshing. Very subtle.

Bottle circa 1979 from Koelschtrinker. Appearance: rusty lid hahah. Damp cardboard, pepper, a little sour. Flavour: tastes dusty, cardboard, pepper, lemon, paper, yikes. Delighted to try something so old all the same. Y

On tap at a resturant in Berlin. Hazy pale golden with white head. Aroma tangy, mild sour, lemon, hay, lacto, citrus and light wood. Taste is medium sour, tart, lemon, citrus, grass, grapes and light apples. Pleasant

Ein Klassiker. Gießt ein trübes Hellgelb mit dünner weißer Schaumkrone ein. Zitronig-säuerliche, hefebetonte Aromen. Im Antrunk anfänglich angenehm sauer mit etwas umami, wird allerdings etwas wässeriger im Abgang. Süffig.

(from notes) Moderate lactic, milky aroma with some underlying grain. Initial taste is moderate to low lactic up front with some graininess. Much more sour and tart in the nose than the flavor. Good, but I like them puckering.

This lager has fine persistent foam, aroma of malt and a little hops. The taste is slightly caramelized with an appropriate balance between hops and malt. The hops are the classic Czech Saaz with spicy bitterness and little overtones of flower. Very nice lager beer.
Tap. Surprisingly good. Rich malty taste, just a bit of metallics if you are really after that. Sweetish. But good.

Da die Starobrno-Brauerei ebenso wie die österreichische Brau-Union zum Heineken-Konzern gehört, bekommt man es auch schon in vielen Wiener Wirtshäusern. An besten schmeckt es aber sicher im Brauhaus am Mendelsplatz in Brünn (cz.: Mendlovo námìstí bzw. im Brünner Dialekt: Mendlák) oder in der Brauerei-eigenen Bier-Straßenbahn. Diese kann für Feiern gemietet werden und ist eine Straßenbahn, welche mit einer Bar, einem Klo und bequemen Sitzplätzen und Tischen ausgestattet ist -ich kann sie sehr empfehlen. Aber zurück zum Bier: Es ist ein klassisches tschechisches Helles, das eine enorme Süffigkeit aufweist. Ein frisches Malzaroma unterstreicht die leichten Hopfennoten ohne sie zu überdecken. Ein Bier das vielleicht nichts besonderes ist, aber ein gutes, gemütliches Bier -auch zum Essen dazu.
pretty pissweak. only worth drinking if it's on tap at a berlin kebaberie. slightly australian tasting

roasty, cereal, spruce, basement aromas, butterscotch, soy sauce, smoke, licorice, brown, cloudy, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, medium body, sticky, average carbonation,
little bit of red fruit in both appearance and aroma. Come citrus, maybe peach too. Too watery. Had this at a restaurant in Berlin
Drank at Alcatraz in Berlin. Black rubish with thin beige head. Aroma is weak with just some malt. Flavor is too dry a little bit of roasted malt. Mouthfeel is dry and long.

Had this in Berlin in a cafe outside one of the museums on the Island. Not too bad. Slight mineral metallic taste(not in a bad way) Slight roasted flavor. Maybe not the strongest example of Schwarzbier but quite drinkable. Serving: Tap

One of my favorite beers of all time. Drank this while on a trip to Berlin, at a bar I just happened to wander into. From the presentation (stem Schultheiss glass with gold trim and a Schulthiess paper "bib" around the bottom) to the head, to the temperature, to the finish, this beer is to me fantastic. While it is indeed a very dark beer, the flavor is quite light, possibly due to the high carbonation. This beer is ideal served highly chilled, and should have around a 1/2 inch head when pulled from the tap. Very nice.

Berlin Trip beer No. 15. On draft. Cola Dark body, small lose head. Very light body flavour wise. Tar, roasted nutty stuff some citrus. Short bitter finish. Kinda coats your tongue. Very highly carbonated. Ok - bit thin and didn’t really make much of an impression.
Draught. Clear red brown coloured with an off white head. Aroma of malts and caramel. Flavour of malts and caarmel with metallic and light roasted notes.

Draught from the Alte Kantine in Berlin’s Kulturbrauerei. Somewhat subdued notes, even for a Schwarz, very quaffable. Lightly roasted, a touch of chocolate, light and smooth. Would like to re-rate from the bottle.

Sampled this one on draught at a tavern in Berlin. Excellent example of schwarzbier, with lots of good dark malt aromas and flavors, and a touch of roast. Schultheiss Lager Schwarz pours to a beautiful, bright, deep brown to black color, with a thick white head, and a good bit of carbonation. The nose on this beer is excellent ,with good dark chocolate and nutty malt aroma, paired with light aromas of roast. The palate is polished and clean, with a sea of smooth dark malt flavor, coffee, and mild roast. This beer finishes with more of that great dark malt flavor, then ends bone dry and slightly roasty. An excellent schwarzbier, that works well with a number of hearty dishes. A great before and after dinner beer as well.
Bottle - nice chocolate malt aroma. Very dark brown color - opaque. Milder chocolate malt flavor with moderate hops. Nice schwarzbier on the lighter side.

Schultheiss [Schan.k Bier] GroterJan Berliner Weisse @Noogfest High5 Thanks lithy-11.2oz bottle-20-30 year old Berliner Weisse from an extremely generous koelschtrinker –pours no head and cloudy straw/yellow color. Aroma is tart lemon, musty. Taste is tart lemon, musty, wheat/grain.

Gentle green and yellowish pour topped by a light white cover. White chocolate, almond paste, smarties and general kids’ drug aroma. Strange palate, the sweetness is enormous, but the flavours more muted than you would have expected from the nose. They take a rather herbal and relatively sour take. Surprisingly easy-drinking as well. Certainly not very pleasant, but not quite the chaos one would expect.

Served in a small tulip bowl glass. A light minty green color. Coincidentally drank one on St Patricks day in Rothenburg. Slightly hazy. Small head. Sweet aroma of candy, tartness, almonds. Taste is very light and refreshing. Syrup, tart lime, sort of like sour apple jolly rancher, pistachio, marzipan candy, hint of vanilla. An experience I enjoyed but I can see why traditionalists might not like this. Very un beer like.
bottle. clear green color. no head. lots of marcipan aroma. very sweet of marcipan. nothing in this berish. oh shudder...
Green colour with a white head. Sweet aroma with notes of cherry and almonds. Flavor is sweet with notes of marzipan and fruit. Finish is light sour.
Bottle. Green colour with a weak head. Aroma of marzipan, sweetness and candy-like. Sweet flavour of candy and some very too sweet and a lot of soda-taste.

(Bottle 33 cl) Pours a clear green (sic!) with a small, light green head. Aroma is pure marzipan. Light-bodied with a marzipan sweetness and an underlying tartness. Very special but not absolutely horrendous. Thanks to Elisabeth for this. 151206
Bottle. Clear green coloured with a white head. Aroma of marzipan and fruits. Flavour of marzipan and fruits with light acidic notes.
Bottle. Green colour with a green head. Sweet aroma and flavour of mint and mazipan.
Bottle. Green colour with a good mostly lasting greenish head. Aroma and taste of sweet mint and pistacio. probably a very good beer on a hot summer day.

Malty, alcohol aroma. Amber/orange color, small white head, fair lace. Sweet, little fruity, syrupy. Little dry and sweet finish. Had it on tap at the 6 Tage Rennen in Berlin, but only drank another one because the other choices where Schultheiss Schwarz and Pilsener.
metho. used 90% of it for cooking as it was no good for drinking............
clear amber-orange colour, few head, malt and alcohol in the nose with fruity notes, full and very malty, good balance between sweetness and maltiness, dry alcohol finish

Bardzo stara rzecz, ale dobrze go mam w pamieci. Piwo Ciemne z reflaksami czerwonymi, odcien jakby buraczany. Kolor sredniej lecz trwalej pianki byl bezowo kremowy. W smaku slodkosc, karmel troche zrumienionego pieczywa tostowego. Sliwkowy likier oraz nalewka wisniowa. Przyjemne wrazenia pozostawione w pamieci.
Dark brown/red. Ok head. Quite swwet with raisins, caramel and coffee. Burnt feeling.
Dark brown color, light brown head. Carmel malt-coffee and chocolate flavor of the sweet kind. Rich flavor. Sweet. Not too much alco feel.

Very dark brown color with just a bit of red shining through to make it brown instead of black. The nose is alcohol and a little fruit. A smokey roast is also evident in the nose with just a touch of fudgeyness towards the back of the aroma. The body is thick with malt which is slightly sweet, but not reaching cloy. Some bitter maltiness in the middle and a touch of bitter hops at the end. Nice long flavors here. Comes together well, not perfectly though and lacking a bit.
deep brown colour, beige head. brown sugar and malt aroma. toffee, sweet malt, fruit, mild roast. the alcohol is well hidden, but the flavour isn't as big as I thought it would be.
Clear dark brown. Brown head. Light aroma of sweet dark malt & molasses. Full, sticky body. Flavour of sweet fortified Christmas cake w/ some woody, oakish notes.
Malty nose, ruby with a medium toffee head. Sweet malt flavour, bitter, light bodied, alcohol is robust, different than I expected. Thanks for finding this Radek.
Mahogany brown, thick creamy head . Softer, nice way hidden alcohol. Sweet malt, coffee. Nicely balanced.

Very dark mahogany. Sweet, molasses, pears. Thick malts, toffee, brown sugar. Long, dry woody note. Seems lighter than last time I had it. Even amongst Polish porters, this tastes the most Polish. Not the best example of the substyle, but maybe the truest.
