column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 355ml can tried many years ago pours a pale straw color with a white head that settles to leave no lacing behind. Aroma is cereal grains and grassy hops. Taste is grainy malt sweetness with a grassy hop bitterness. Just below average for the style.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: IF YOU ARE THIRSTY DRINK THIS BEER COLD!!! WHEN IT IS HOT DRINK THIS BEER!!! IF you want taste, get something else, but definatley one of the better drafts out there if you can get your hands on it. Yeah, I am the guy buying it by the flat in the summer.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Canned/ Pours a light yellow with no head. Stale smelling not much else. The taste is less than uninspired, fizzy carbonation, malt? Thin, bland, useless.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Moderately dark gold. Bland aroma - maybe a little bit of malt. Palate is light, little watery, sweet. Malt-accented, some alcohol notes, with a hint of acetaldehyde. As mainstream lagers go, it’s okay.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 355 ml can. Very pale straw coloured beer with a fluffy white head that quickly disappears. Dusty aroma, light malt, no hops. Flavour is similar, the thinnest bodied beer I’ve ever had. Why do they even bother making this crap?

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Another impressive beer from Granville. Slightly sweet, no hops to speak of. Mouthfeel is watery and thin. Serve extra cold to avoid taste.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Gold with thin fast fading white head. No nose. Rather bland, slightly sweeter than a mainstream beer.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Not one of the better beers from Granville Island. Not much of an aroma or flavour but pretty smooth.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: A "draft" beer that tastes like an NA. Very watery with a poor short-lived hops flavour. Cheap it is.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Good for CHEAP beer. 6 pack for under $6. Goes down smooth. Unsure if it is a Ale per say, almost a Canadian taste, except lacking the punch. Good if you're a 'cheap drunk' (I only bought it to mix other drinks with, not to drink alone)
Draught at The Market Cat, York. Gold with white head. This proved to be quite a thinnish, light, herby lager, malt lead. Some sweetness. The herbal notes last throughout. A little watery.

500 ml bottle. (Kaufland) Kutná Hora, Czech Republic. Enjoyed on Jul 25, 2019. Clear golden color with a medium size foamy white head. Dry grainy malty aroma with some cardboardy notes. The flavor is dry grainy malt, mild grassy hoppy notes and some cardboard vibes. Easy low abv pils.

Butelka 0,5 l. Piwo z³ote, klarowne. Piana bia³a, doœæ obfita, gêsta, trwa³a, z ladn¹ koronk¹. W aromacie nuty siana, s³odu pilzneñskiego, chlebowe, lekki skunksik. W smaku s³odowoœæ, delikatny chlebek, suszona trawa, zio³owoœæ. Pe³nia niska, wysycenie œrednie do œrednio wysokiego, goryczka niska, choæ zaznaczona, zio³owo-trawiasta. Niez³y, czysty w smaku czeski pils, nie czuæ, ¿e to tak niski ekstrakt, pijalny.

On tap. Clear golden body with an average, frothy, white head, mostly diminishing with fair lacing. Moderate malty (hay, grains) and light hoppy (herbal) aroma. Moderate bitter and light-to-moderate sweet flavour; average-lasting bitter finish. Light-to-medium body with watery texture; soft carbonation.
A bit weak and waterly. Sure, it is not supposed to be strong, but it was a bit disappointing anyway.
Aromat maœlano-s³odowy. W smaku mase³ko, wychmielenie trochê zbyt niskie. Piwo jest dosyæ g³adkie i pe³ne. Ca³kiem nieŸle.
Draught at restaurant. Golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, malts, a bit of hops and grass. Bitter finish with citrus, malts, a bit of hops and grass. Okay lager.
Prague keg beer. Pours orange golden with a thin head. Aroma of fresh mild hops. Fruity taste of malt and mild hops. Nice bitterish lager.
Butelka 0,5 litra, zakupiona w zwyk³ym monopolowym. Barwa z³ota, klarowna. Bia³a piana, wysoka, ale szybko opada. Du¿e wysycenie.

Z³ociste, piana z pocz¹tku obfita, doœæ rzadka, szybko opada, ale zredukowana pozostaje na powierzchni ju¿ do koñca. W aromacie trochê s³odu, trochê chmielu, trochê daje sierœci¹. W smaku goryczkowe, lekkie.
Very good Doppelbock. Nice full flavor. Very dark liquid with a nice head. Good weight and texture. Nice flavor finishes cleanly.
Dark amber color, and a creamy head. Not as heavy and syrupy as the other bocks I've tried.
Good strong chewy bock.... Needs a bit more flavor to be a strong contendor, Little head, but I will try iy again this Spring to see if the new batch is better or worse.
A pretty good version but not a world classic...............................
Very nice doppelbock. Now it's only available in kegs. Nice, malty body, high alcohol (as a bock should be) and good overall body and flavor.
I love this beer. The carmel taste and the small presence of hops in the taste is what i like most about this beer
bocks are a favorite lager style, probably my favorite. Strong, rich and robust. Big malt nose with hints of caramel. The hops are not so proniuced, but present. A good representative to this style.
Very nasty beer. Light yellow color. Faintly metallic smell. Faintly metallic taste. Sorta thin. Not really a good beer.
this is really a bad beer but it is no where near the dopplebock this brewer produces. I am not one for american lite

I first had this beer at (Where else?) a Browns game. I forked over my $6 and asked what it really was. The vendor told me that I could tour the brewery which was just down the road a few miles. A grear beer for watching a football game. Crooked River's Ballpark brew (Which they used to serve at Indians gmaes) is pretty much the same thing. Do I buy it for home use? no.

A nicely balanced every day lager. Brewed with 2-row malt instead of the cheaper 6-row variety. Subtle hops but they're apparent and offer decent bittering to counterbalance the malt. This lager is super smooth and perfect for washing down a bratwurst or pretzel at a football game. Much better than the normal lagers available at football games. Nicely done. Cool can too.

This beer tastes like the actually put it in a stadium first. Its Terrible. Even worse that Watered Down Staduim beer. Its Watered Down Beer, that got watered down again, and canned. Avoid unless you REALLY like that flavor.

column1: Holy Cow Amber Gambler Pale Ale
column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Date: 01/06/1999 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub light amber, thin head, slight floral hop aroma, light malt flavor with a good dose of citrus hops, just a hint of bitterness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Holy Cow Amber Gambler Pale Ale
column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: on tap: i havent had this one at the draft house as stated below...yet. had it at old holy cow, several times. very overhopped with little head or malt character. for you hop lovers you would this would be the choice.

column1: Holy Cow Amber Gambler Pale Ale
column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Now under the Big Dog Brewing Co. moniker. It's an amber beer with a malty nose. Overly hopped with no malt balance. Very citric finish.

column1: Holy Cow Amber Gambler Pale Ale
column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Sparkling amber, lasting head.A well balanced brew with lasting hop finish..

column1: Holy Cow Amber Gambler Pale Ale
column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Arizona Beer Fest 03/23/02: Pours a nice amber, white head and fair lace. Malt nose, some floral tones, sweet. Front is sweet, middle a bit thin, mild to medium carbonation, finish acidic, slightly dry nice hop presence, clean and fresh.

column1: Holy Cow Amber Gambler Pale Ale
column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Color of apple juice, weak head. Cascade hops were very prominent, floral aroma. The hops lasted from start to finish.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: on tap holy cow: used to love to go to this place, its closed now. but probably some of the better brewpub beers in vegas and good bar food. it was a light bodied beer and easy to drink. yellow tan in color. the draft house has resumed brewing holy cow beers. dont know what they have on tap over there and if they are using the same recipes.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Fizzy yellow with slight orange tinge under a thick foamy head, light flowers and bread on the aroma, watery body has a pleasent malty aftertaste.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Now made under the Big Dog's name ... dark yellow, smooth standing. This cream ale is fruity and hearty.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Light bodied, crisp, easy to drink, light but tastey hops...................

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Cream ale? I didn't get that impression at all. Just a good middle of the road ale.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery

column5: Hvala zeni sto mi je sa putovanja u Belgiji donijela ovo pivo! Duboko crvene/višnja boje prema smeðoj, smeða pjene srednje debljine, veoma trajna. Arome voæa, jabukovog siræeta, karamela, likera i alkohola. Srednje gorèine, duzeg gorkog finiša.Uljano-kremaste teksture, umjerene prema jakoj karbonizaciji.
Brown with brown foam. Fragrance: Malt, caramel, wood, burnt sugar, overripe fruit. Taste: Stock flavors, light malt, burnt sugar, overripe fruit, hard roasted nuts.
I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it. I’ve had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh. Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.

Name: Pale Rider Date: 07/06/2004 Mode: Draft Source: 4 Queens Casino nice clear copper color with a whispy white head, sweet grapefruit aroma, lots of good hop flavor with just enough sweetness to keep it honest, grapefruit shows up late followed by a lingering bitter finish -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Pale Rider Date: 09/07/2004 good sweet grapefruit flavor from the start, a touch of resony pine character in the finish -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Pale Rider Date: 12/12/2004 a bit stale, nice hop flavor but lost the citrus and piney edge, Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.8/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Sampler at the Four Queens Casino Brewpub - Also called "Pale Rider" at the Brewpub. Poured a orangish-amber in color wth a whitish head. Aroma was heavy of citrus-pine hops with a hint of malty sweetness. Flavor was pretty hoppy... citrus-pine and cascade grassiness too... the way I like it. Very good.
Orange, with a thin white head. Big citrus hop aroma. Nice hop flavor, too - Kind of rough, fresh resiny hops. Decent smoky malt in the background. Remains nicely hopped to the finish.
I had this playing cards in Vegas and it was called Pale Rider as well. Nice pale ale but not overly hoppy and more of a citrus flavour.
My beer was also called Pale Rider, available at the Cigar Bar in the Four Queens. West Coast style pale ale with heavy citrus flavor. Flavor has cascade hops written all over it.

(called Pale Rider at Four Queens) Clear apple juice body, some bubbles within, off-white head, nice lacing. Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, some pine. Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit, light pine, earthy. Medium, undercarbonated body.

Called Pale Rider at the brewery. Clear medium gold colored. Dry, bitter with a cloudy wheat or burlap flavor. Dry wood and charred fruit but not in a good way, think old cardboard and carrots. Has a fresh hop nose, somewhat resembling thje dry-hopped note of Alpha King, but still with the stale presence and so something I would not drink again.
Nice almost tropical(mango?) citrus nose. Clear yellow/straw color. Good citrus/floral bite with a good balance of malt and a dry finish. Very nice drinkable pale.
Tap @ Reno Festival. Amber color with an off white head. Citrus, smooth, refreshing, malty, and a little grassy.

On tap @ Chicago poured a clear pale yellow with a lasting white head. Aromas of bread, straw and light citrus. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, hint of carmel and light citrus with a lingering bitter finish.
About as decent as you’re going to get for a lighter beer like this. Hints of malt and even a hop or two. Light, fairly refreshing. Still average in the grand scheme of things, though.
Completely average, and for a light beer, that’s quite an achievement. Pale yellow, big white head. Clean, spicy aroma, with a slightly fuity flavor up front. Clean, tangy finish.
The stout got a mellow taste in the front but a hoppy end, though dark it's low malt more with a balanced hops ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught at Chicago Brewing Company Las Vegas. Very dark black in colour with a sliver of tan foam. Vanilla and chocolate aromas also carry over into the flavour and the beer finishes dry.

This beer now has a different name but it’s the same beer. Pours black with a frothy tan head from the nitrogen. Very low aroma with some roasted malt. Taste is typical dry stout with predominant roasted and black malts. Finish is dry and clean. Very much like Guiness only not.
Draught sampler. Deep black colour with tan head. Aroma of espresso, smoked meat, chocolate. Beautiful creamy mouthfeel. Taste is smooth, rich, sweet, roasted. Very good.
Nitro - smooth creamy palate. Nice charred touches, some chocolate. Tastey session stout. Tap handle had me believing I was drinking Guinness.
I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it. I’ve had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh. Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.
Draught at the brewpub. Black, creamy head. Licorice aroma Dry and roasty with plenty of coffee. Fairly light bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Long bitterness. A solid standard stout.

On tap at the Four Queens location, and poured with a black/brown color, modest, tan foam that diminished to a ring and film, and left some dots and dashes of lacing. The aroma was roasted, mocoa, and light caramel. The flavor added some dryness, moderate hop bitterness, and some light smoke and wood. Light and smooth on the palate.
Dark black pour small white lacy head. Aroma was roasted malts and not much else.Taste was very dry with some roasted malts and a mild bitterness. Lower carbonation. Decent

On tap at Four Queens. Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head that lasts awhile. The aroma is a roasted malt with chocolate. Thin mouthfeel with a roasted malt flavor with chocolate and light smoke with a nice dry finish. Easy to drink a good dry stout from Chicago Brewing.

I’m not a big Hefeweizen fan but this beer did the trick me, in the blazing Las Vegas heat. A very juicy refreshing Hefe with the taste of watery melons and banana/clove. Cloudy and yellow with a touch of orange with a good head. One of the best Hefes I have tasted and much appreciated in the beer wasteland that is Las Vegas. A 22oz $4.00 bargain.

Date: 09/10/2004 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy orange with a quickly disapating fine white head, strong sweet banana and clove aroma, light body, nice banana flavor with a bit of bubble gum sweetness that fades with time leaving just a touch of bubble gum and very little sweetness, best chilled -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 06/30/2005 Words: 4 queens light sweet banana flavor with a touch of clove, not much wheat, still a touch of bubble gum, a little bit of orange citrus character, not much weiss ultimate or otherwise, but tasty neverless Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: **+/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Sampler at the Four Queens Casino Brewpub - Poured a cloudy yellow-amber in color with a fairly thick off-white head. Aroma was pretty strong of yeat with a medium amount of the classic sweet clove-banana of a good weiss. Flavor was also somewhat sweet with a hint of the clove-banana and plenty of yeast. Enjoyable...
Pours a hazy reddish/orange color. Quite a bit of yeast in the aroma. Sweet banana smell. Mild yeasty flavor. Smooth and slightly sweet. Fairly tasty.

Very cloudy body with off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, tart, banana, clove, some wheat. Taste is medium sweet, not much up front, banana and clove does show up from mid-tongue on back. Watery light-medium body, undercarbonated.
Cloudy yellow/orange. Big sweet banana/clove nose. Good head and lacing. Lots of banana, clove, and bubblegum flavors. Very creamy with a great finish. Very good beer.
Golden milkiness. Wheaty nose. Very, very smooth with just a light banana/citrus flavor. Very nice.
On tap GABF 02: Listed as Ultimate Weisse. Nice banana/clove aroma, cloudy yellow color. Finishes malty and quick.

Keg at the village pub McCarran Airport. A clear mid amber orange coloured pour with a a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet and malty, toffee, burnt sugars, cakey malts. Flavour is composed of jammy fruits, strawberry, toffee, little burnt sugars. Palate is medium sweet, pithy, moderate carbonation. Weird aftertaste.

Ar: Very clean—cracker and a bit of roast. Ap: Amber-brown and clear; small white head with moderate-low retention, leaves a wisp of white foam. T: Steely toasted malt; a little caramel; very clean profile overall; a little sweetness; bitterness is medium-low, with a touch of black licorice flavor. P: Medium body with medium-high carbonation; dry finish. O: A standard, easy-drinking American amber ale; clean and simple.
Draft at the brewery. Clear amber body, almost no head. Fresh fruity aroma and very hoppy and well balanced body.

29/6/2018. Draft at the Ellis Island Casino & Brewery, Las Vegas. Pours clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma of toffee, malt, fruit and hops. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation. Fair.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a golden pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with weak hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel grainy weak hoppy finish.

Village Pub, McCarren Airport. Clear, light amber brown color but really pale. White foam. Sickly sip, buttery malt with a hint of darker roast. Extremely watered down amber, if you can even call it that. Another wide miss.

Where and how: at brewery (pint) Aroma mild, smooth malty nose, mild diacetyl. Appearance : Top: small, white lasting cap. Base: clear amber. Palate : medium thin, dry , easy going with frisky carbonation. Fades quickly. Taste: bland with faint sweet malt hints. other notes meh.
Aroma: Toasted Bread, Mild Crackers Appearance: Amber Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Rink, Minimal Lacing Taste: Bready, Caramel Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying
Draft at LAS. Clear golden color, white head, solid lacing. Aroma of caramel. Taste of toasted caramel. Acceptable.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a dark orange-amber color with a large fluffy orange-white head that lingered and left incredible lacing. The aroma was faint sour mash, a touch of yeast and faint vague fruity hops. The flavor was tangy and sweetish with a bit of sour mash, tart citrus and a touch of perfume. Medium length finish. Light to medium body. Blah.
Eh, decent beer. Pours dark brown. Aroma is primarily roasted malt. Taste has light hints of coffee.
Draft. Dark mahogony beer with a cream colored head. Malt aroma. Bready malt flavor with light toffee. Medium bodied. Light toffee lingers with bready malts.
Had this with the steak lunch special back in June. Not too exciting but better than I expected. Was included with the meal.
Pours copper with a thin off white head. Smells of sweet malt, earthy. Tastes of tea, some light grassy hints, sweet malty finish.
Clear, copper colored. Tan head. Aroma of sweet malts. Fizzy mouthfeel. Kinda light and boring.

Name: Dark Date: 01/10/1999 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub ruby red, thin head, medium malt flavor Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.3/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Had a taste from the grimreeser and I guess I said it tasted better then killians. I haven’t had killians in a couple of years, so what the hell do I know. Better then a kick in the head though (literally).
Nothing special here. Tasted like killians. OG said it was better than killians, but he also managed to split a helmet in half earlier in the day while wearing it. Seemed very watery.
Auburn crimson edged color, nose of light fruit and roast chocolate. Flavors with coffee and something...bad, very bad. Finishes astringent and forgettable.
on tap at ellis island: this is just like their other bad beers, watered down without much character at all, brewed for the bud drinker and maybe not even him.

Keg at the village pub McCarran Airport. Served with a fucking lemon on the top. A light hazed dull gold coloured pour with no head. Aroma is sharp lemon rind, light grains, clove,. Flavour is composed of light grains, tart lemon, light grains, sharp tangy lemon. Light chalk. Palate is light and tart watery moderate carbonation. Lingering dry banana.
Draft. Hazy body, small white head. Good aroma and the taste is traditional.

29/6/2018. Draft at the Ellis Island Casino & Brewery, Las Vegas. Pours murky pale yellow gold with a small white head. Aroma of orange, wheat, banana, hops and light herb. Moderate sweetness and bitterness. Light body, slight oily texture, average carbonation. Ok.

12/15/17: At Ellis Island Brewery and Casino on Koval, $2.50 plus tip, large flute served with orange wedge. Very light body, cloudy straw colour, generous white cloudy head. Nominal wheat aroma beyond the orange slice, taste very light, lemon and wheat. Very thin and smooth drinking. Overall good offering, my favorite from Ellis Island Brewery.
Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty weak banana spicy aroma. Fruity wheat malty banana flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty banana finish.

Village Pub, McCarren Airport. White cream on a light hazed yellow. Big ole lemon in the tasting glass. Lager nose, big lemon but I think that’s from the literal lemon. Very pale body, some soapy wheat character. Boring, weak, annoying.
Tap at airport brewpub. Pours golden hazed. They tried to put orange in it for me but declined. Tastes of nothing. Maybe some wheat but almost pale lagerish.

Where and how: at brewery (pint) Aroma mild with wheat bill, lacking esters. Appearance : Top: small white cap. Base: hazy golden brew. Palate : soft medium bodied, easy going with average carbonation. Thinner walls.. Taste: simple American wheat brew. One of better choices of EI brewery.
Typical wheat beer appearance and aroma. Light fizz. Taste of sweet oranges. Not bad for $2! (K)

Aroma: Spoiled Orange Juice Appearance: Hazy Orangish/Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Minimal Lacing Taste: Wheat, Mild Oranges, Mild Dishwater Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, Mildly Bitter

On tap, and dispensed to a tall lager glass, described by headbrewer Joe, as an American Lager, spiced with Challenger hops this time around. Displayed a clear & bright, golden hue, with persistent, fluffy, white head foam, and good cling to the sheet-like lacing. The aroma was a typical, light lager nose, with light grain, and a touch of DMS/corn husk. Light bodied, as lively enough carbonation worked well with the moderate, slightly peppery & earthy bitterness that lingered, and intensified some into the finish. Not that it sat too long, but just a hint of grainy tartness began to appear as it warmed. Fairly clean, crisp, & sessionable.

Draft. Poured clear golden color with an average frothy white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Light to medium balancecd grainy aroma. Light to medium body with a thin smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of short to moderate duration. Soft beer that was worth having once.

This is as good as it can get at Elis island. Its not good. As all there beers... but this is the best of the worst. Very sweet, not horrendous... not good. No aroma, light body. Maybe good for someone who has never drank beer before.

On tap at Ellis Island casino. Pours a clear golden with a small frothy white head. The aroma is a faint corn malt with wheat grass. Medium mouthfeel with a honey wheat flavor with a nice crisp finish. Easy to drink. a decent pale lager from Ellis Island. Cant beat 22 oz for 1.50 in Vegas.
Aroma is somewhat sweet with some citrus notes. Pours golden with a thin head. Light citrus, lemon, sweet grainy notes. Some odd sweetness noted as well. Finishes crisp.
Sample at Ellis Island casino. pours straw gold, thin white head. Aroma is fruity, cookie dough malts. Taste, malts, citrus/apricot fruits, some spices and gingerbread/cookie crust malts.

Deep gold pour with creamy white head and lace. Floral aroma with just a hint of malt. Perfumey or floral I’m not sure. Very light maltiness. A coppery taste and an odd sweet. Medium bodied and foamy. A drinkable beer.
on tap-pours a white head and yellow color. Aroma is mild grain. Taste is slightly sweet grain/light malt, some floral/copper hops.
draft at ellis for 1dollar.. not to bad.. light sweet caramels,malts.. light on the hops.. sweet..

(draft @ Ellis Island Casino & Brewery - Las Vegas, NV) Golden color with a thin white head. Aroma is light and sweet with some hints caramel, malts, and light hops. Flavor is lightly sweet and malty at the beginning with a mild grassy finish. Not too bad.

Keg at the village pub McCarran Airport. A mostly clear pale yellow coloured pour with a fine thin white head.. Aroma is corn, clean, cereal,. Flavour is composed of light and watery, corn, some grass, watery hops. Palate is thin and watery, grainy, moderate carbonation. Not much to it. Fairly clean.

29/6/2018. Draft at the Ellis Island Casino & Brewery, Las Vegas. Menu says 5% but hard to believe. Pours pale gold with a small white head. Aroma of light hop, fruit, grass and sweet malt. Quite heavy sweetness, minimal bitterness. Light body, slight oily and watery texture, above average carbonation. Really nothing to it so in terms of it trying to be light it's a success.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours a yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma. Fruity malty grainy weak buttery flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy weak buttery finish.
Village Pub, McCarren Airport. Super pale water yellow, small head. Pale, pissy malt with some lemon character. Pale, watery, bland but fairly innocuous. Not good. Fizzy finish.

Where and how: at brewery (pint) Aroma bland yet clean malty nose. Appearance : Top: medium lighter white rocky top. Base: pale golden with fine haze. Palate : medium thinner body with above average carbonation. Thinner walls. Taste: mild diacetyl with creamy feel. Beyond that straight refreshing light lager for hot summer of LV.
Draft at LAS. Clear pale yellow color. Aroma of light lemon. Taste is watery and bland lemon.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a clear light golden color with a large soapy-foamy yellow-white head that left a bit of lacing. The aroma was faint sour mash and odd vague hops. The flavor was very mild with a bit of sour mash and a semi sweet undertone. Short finish. Light body. It is what it is.
Pours clear piss water, minimal white head Smell creamy corn lager Taste clean, nothing Light body Well done

Tap at the casino/brewpub, 30/10/13. Dead gold with a trickle of bead and low white head. Wax and honey nose. Waxen, soapy, stale fat flavour with background tortilla and rice becoming dominant. Is this the IPA? Feels more like an IPA than the IPA did. Just about drinkable but pretty appalling.
A blonde lager with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet biscuit malt with light hops. In mouth,a nice sweet malt with mineral notes, faint hops. On tap at brewpub, June 2013.

Keg at the village pub McCarran Airport. A clear nutty brown coloured pour with a lasting beige head. Aroma is lightly burnt toast, malty brown bread, nutty roast, mealy. Flavour is composed of semi sweet, nutty malts, brown bread, toast, light jammy fruits. Palate is dry and earthy, highish carbonation, little chalky, little abrasive. Meh.

29/6/2018. Draft at the Ellis Island Casino & Brewery, Las Vegas. Pours almost black with a small beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, dried fruits, light coffee. Moderate sweetness, medium roasted bitterness. Moderate body, watery texture, above average carbonation.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma. Roasted malty caramel flavor with weak hints of chocolate. Has a roasted malty caramel finish.

Village Pub, McCarren Airport. Creamy, offwhite cap on mostly red brown dark body with clear sides. Creamy, toffee body. Some lactic milk chocolate, a little roast. Feels like watered down extract, like the rest of their beers. Milk coffee aroma. Least bad of their beers that I’ve tried, but it still annoys me. Warm buttery character throughout these beers; tastes like the worst that Europe can do if they were imitating the American versions of these styles.
Very average, but for $2 I can’t really complain. Perfectly drinkable. Quite smooth, not as thick or creamy as most stouts.
Draft at LAS. Dark hazy brown color, beige head.Aroma of chocolate syrup. Taste is coffee grounds. Watery.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a black color with a large creamy tan head that lingered and left exceptional lacing. The aroma was dry and bitter with a brewed coffee presence. The flavor was a bit sour,malty and mildly bitter with notes of wood and brewed coffee. Medium finish. Medium body. Decent.
Pours black, red around edges. Min light tan head. Smell light chocolate roast, sweet and pleasant. Taste smooth and chocolaty, bit nutty, vanilla. Light smooth body. Good beer

Tap at the casino, 30/10/13. A stout-presumably this. Pick of a piss poor bunch. Looks stout-like; deep ruby speckling with cream lace. Butter and blueberry-hinting aroma. Buttered blueberry, milky coffee taste in a mild-like or buttery English porter stylee. OK.
A dark brown stout with a thin mocha head. In aroma, caramel malt with light peaty chocolate, grassy notes. In mouth, roasted malt with light chocolate, grassy notes, OK.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Had back when. In vegas. Cherry aroma with some roasted aroma as well. Taste bitter roast and cherry cola. On tap nice carbonation. May be Bette on nitrogen.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft at the source 12/28/13. Clear dark brown color. Aroma of cocoa powder and coffee grounds. Taste is coffee and cherries.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 28 dec 2013, tap at Triple 7. Dark brown/black. Nose is cherry chocolate cake. Med body and mildly fizzy. Very burnt toast with hints of cherry. Meh. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Aroma is like black coffee. Poured black in color with a tan head. Cherry flavors meet coffee flavors. Notes: GABF ’09

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Pours red-tinged black. Sweet cherry aroma with a hint of spice. Palate is bitter and full-bodied, neither fruity nor sweet, with a black cherry flavor. Very well balanced. Really fantastic.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Smells really good, just like black cherries, imagine that. Flavor is sweet cherry, with a bit of stoutness to the body and some dark chocolate notes as well. Really okay as a change of pace Christmas-time beer.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: GABF 2011. Pours opaque with a medium-small, bubbly tan head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is an amazing cherry nose, dark chocolate, and cherry skin. Flavor is dark chocolate cherry cordial and a dry finish. The roast malt really dries this one out. Medium body and carbonation, low warmth.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: I found my notes from visiting this brewery during my honeymoon in 7/2003. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a black color with a large tan head. The aroma was tart black cherry. The flavor was tart and sweet cherries with a sweetish malty base and a long cherry finish. Our favorite of the bunch!

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Overall nice, but nothing spectacular. Seemed a little disjointed. The aroma and beginning of the flavour were more gentle notes with some black cherry meat, bitter chocolate and roasted malt but the finish was a fairly burnt, bitterness like a dry stout.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On draft at Triple 7 brewpub in Vegas. Dark pour. Light smell of cherries. Creamy mouthfeel, with a taste of cherries and chocolate. Mild finish. Overall well balanced and decent.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Hate to give this a 3.4 because of the previous four ratings, but that is what I came up with. On tap at the brewery. Comes dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is the same. Middle of the road Porter.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draught at the brewery. Pours clear brown with a medium, frothy off-white head, long retention. Roast and chocolate malt, light earthy hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 25/6/2018. Drought at the Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station, Las Vegas. Pours dark brown with a small slightly foamy beige head. Aroma is roasted, coffee, chocolate, malt and fruit. Moderate sweetness and medium bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation. Not bad.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tap, 10cl, bought @ Triple 7, Las Vegas. Pours deep chestnut - not black. Small, staying, creamy off-white head. Aroma has sweet malts, roasted, soft hazelnut. Medium carbonation, fine dry and light creamy mouthfeel. Flavouris sweet, lots of. milky chocolate, Nutella, hazelnut. Soft bitterness. Okay.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft @ the brewery. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma. Roasted malty caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty caramel finish.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 16oz pour from the source in Vegas. Only here because guaranteed Mich St game viewing opportunities. Dark brown, basically black. Minimal head. Nose is roasted nut with a light peanut butter quality. Pretty inviting. Taste is pretty standard porter but would score highest on a homebrew adjusted scale. Roasted malts, some mild chocolate. Relatively thin. They have basically gone with a by the book rendition of the style. There are so many better options. This is a miss.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Part of a tasting paddle at Triple 7 Brewery and Casino in Las Vegas on 11 October 2017. Black in the glass with a nice chocolate flavour, slightly bitter and rather tasty. Light In the mouth.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: At the brewpub with lunch. faint pour for a porter. Nose is light coffee and smoked malt. Tastes of flat cola, hint of coffee, earth, some malt tones. Watery palate. Despite that not unpleasant.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Dark copper color, very bright for a porter. It’s transparent. Not a massive head, but it’s ok and its leaving super nice lacing. Dark chocolate, touch of coffee, a little just a flight of hops. Like the taste very much. Has a lot of flavors in a small body and abv. Coffee and chocolate dominates. Not much of tanned notes, but they appear in the aftertaste in some form of bitterness. Very drinkable, session porter. Low body.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Dark opaque with thin tan head. Smells of chocolate coffee and vanilla. Tastes the same. Overall a decent porter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at the brewery. Comes a somewhat cloudy gold with a decent white head. Aroma of malt, grain, and grass. Taste is the same. Easy to drink, but missing something.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draught at the brewery. Pours clear yellow with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention. Medium biscuit and grainy malt, light hop bitterness and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 25/6/2018. Drought at the Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station, Las Vegas. Pours clear pale gold with a small foamy white head. Aroma of straw, fruit, butter and grain. Medium sweetness with moderate bitterness. Light body, slightly thin texture, average carbonation. Ok.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tap, 10cl, bought @ Triple 7, Las Vegas. Pours clear pale golden with a small, staying creamy white film head. Aroma has sweet malts, soft grassy hops. Medium carbonation, fine dry and light creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is kinda simple, fine malts bill, hops are subdued to please the masses. Okay grassy and light bitter finish. Nothing wrong, but a bit dull.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft @ the brewery. Pours a clear yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma. Fruity malty grainy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy finish.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tap at brewery in vegas with commonmac and samalito and rosskyle. Clear gold with small white head. Unimpressive grain aroma,. Off flavor grain taste, slight skunk. Thin body. Not pleasant. Cash out now.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at Triple 7 Brewpub in Las Vegas on 11 October 2017. Relatively light and watery wheat ale with a pale straw colour and a clean white head. Thin in the mouth with a tropical fruit flavour.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: At the source: pours gold with white head. Aroma is light graininess. Taste is lightly sweet. Not much flavor. Easy to drink. Not great.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tap again as part of flight it looks like this place barely changes line up. Faint cloudy pour.nose is like nothing maybe light citrus and wheat. Tastes of straw, light strawberry, lemon, some stale aftertaste. Not a good one

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: "free" shaker while playing at the Boar’s Head Bar. This gets horrible rates, but I gotta tick me all, you know? Pours copper gold witha white head. Aroma is light grains, mild banana. It’s light, it’s wet, somewhat grainy, a bit of honey. A hint of banana and pepper at the finish. Not great, but nothing objectionable.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at the brewery. Comes a mostly clear gold with a decent white head. Aroma of malt, citrus, and grass. Taste is malt, grain, grass, and citrus. Decent.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draught at the brewery. Pours clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, long retention. Heavy dank, resin and grassy hops, medium bitterness, grainy malt and a dry finish. Medium-light body and medium carbonation.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 25/6/2018. Drought at the Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station, Las Vegas. Pours slightly hazy mid gold with a foamy white head. Aroma of hops, citrus and grass. Moderate sweetness and medium bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tap, 10cl, bought @ Triple 7, Las Vegas. Pours light hazy golden with a large, staying creamy white head. Aroma has grassy hops, a slight cheesy edge, crisp malts. Medium to low carbonation, fine dry and quite creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is balanced, some citrussy hops, light Earl Grey. Fine balance.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft @ the brewery. Pours a yellow golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty weak citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity malty weak citrus hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy finish.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at Triple 7 Brewpub in Las Vegas on 11 October 2017. Deep honey amber colour with a sand coloured head of sticky foam. Caramel maltiness in the flavour and a sweet aroma. Medium bodied and enjoyable to drink.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tap at brewpub as part of what would be very drunken day. Pale yellow colored. Nose is some hop pine. Tastes of resin, caramel, crackers, some black pepper, and earthy notes. Sweet malt finish.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Super bright, clear, poor head but nice lacing. Almost no aroma, just a bit of hops in the back. Same in taste. Super watery, just a touch of fruits in the end and quite pleasant bitter finish. Very drinkable, session beer.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Had to rate this my tenth beer as it is one of my fav pale ales. Aroma of pine and citrus. Crystal clear, light bread and crisp hoppy finish.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Excellent pale. Nice lively carbonation brought out cascade type aromas. Flavor very crisp and hoppy with slight bitter edge. Drank at casino at blackjack table. Free when you are playing.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at the brewery. Comes a clear golden red with a decent beige head. Aroma of malt, grain, and caramel. Taste is malt, grain, caramel, and a bit of grass. Pretty good.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draught at the brewery. Pours clear amber with a medium, frothy off-white head, medium retention. Clean lager character, rich caramel malt, light hop bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 25/6/2018. Drought at the Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station, Las Vegas. Pours red/brown with a foamy off-white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, hops, light herbal and grassy notes. Medium sweetness and moderate bitterness. Medium body, oils texture, soft carbonation. Quite enjoyed this.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tap, 10cl, bought @ Triple 7, Las Vegas. Pours copper with a large, staying creamy white head. Aroma has sweet malts, soft butterscotch, light toasted. Medium carbonation, fine dry and somewhat creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is not fantastic, some cardboard, light diacetyl, toasted caramel malts. No real bitterness.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft @ the brewery. Pours a pale amber color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty weak hoppy caramel grainy aroma. Fruity malty caramel hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel hoppy finish.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at Triple 7. Clear red color with a white head. Malt aroma. Malt home brew flavor. Medium light body. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at Triple 7 Brewpub in Las Vegas on 11 October 2017. Malty and sweet with a deep red colour. Thin in the mouth but it does build a bit thicker. There is nothing not to like about this beer.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: At the source: pours dark red with an off white head. Aroma is very malty. Taste is malty and toffee and caramel. Not a bad amber.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tap at brewpub part of a flight. Pale amber pour. Nose is faint caramel and toast. Tastes lightly of earth, copper pennies, caramel, toast, maybe touch of vanilla. Pale watery body.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Another "free" beer at the Boar’s Head Bar. Pours mahoghany with a grayish off white head. Aroma is caramel, fruity esters, a hint of pine. This is sweet and malty, not enough hop to balance.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: I found my notes from visiting this brewery during my honeymoon in 7/2003. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a red-amber color with a large off white head. The aroma was lightly sweet and a touch fruity. The flavor was malty, a little nutty and had a light fruity hop note. Ok.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Tap at brewpub. Pours a weak and thin amber with a head of thin white. Aroma is whipsy and weak smoked malt. Flavor is blunt nut and feathers of hollow nut. Made for low rollers.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Date: 01/06/2000 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: red, fine white head, Aroma: sweet carmel malt aroma with touch of hops, Flavor: slightly sweet flavor, nice bitter finish, shifts from sweet to bitter as it warms Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Bottle from the casino. poured a rich copper to amber color with a good head. Aroma of caramel and sweet roasted malts. Tasted of lightly roasted malts with a mild hoppiness. A pretty average beer that is very drinkable.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Draft in the Casino. This is my favorite of the casino’s offerings. Nothing remarkable about the bier but definitely better than the standard mass-produced bottles passed around the tables.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: This is the one I was most impressed with per the style. A pretty good light caramel aroma and a beautiful red color. Not that malty, but nice and smooth.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: On tap at the Monte Carlo. Copper colored beer with a thin off white head and a faint sweet grain nose. Light sour grain tinge with the first sip. Some roastiness follows, but mostly just caramel sweetness. Okay but not very interesting.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Tap, Monte Carlo. Dark amber color on the pour. Slightly sweet/acidic malty aroma. A hint of hops. Slightly malty flavor with English hop character.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: This draft brew from the brewery poured a head of light foamy finely sized brown colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated copper brown colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was caramel malty. The weak flavor contained notes of malt mild hops and caramel. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: 12oz bottle pours nice and clean amber/red color with no head. Aromas of chocolate and toffee with a small amount of hops. Huge malt taste with no bitterness and a nice carmel finish. Overall a good amber ale that is clean and full of specialty malts, but lacking the hop balance.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: I found my notes from visiting this brewery during my honeymoon in 7/2003. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured an orange color with a medium sized yellow-white head. The aroma was bitter fruity hops. The flavor was bitter, fruity and hoppy. Bitter hoppy finish. Decent.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Date: 01/06/2000 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear amber, scant head, bitter hop aroma, dry malt flavor, bitter finish, medium body, decent pale ale, but lacking any destinctive character Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Draft at the casino. Decent but it seemed shallow on taste. Of course it is brewed at a casino so I didn’t expect much.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: A great floral hoppy aroma. The taste is slightly bitter, with a nice dry hoppy finish. A little weak in the middle, but okay overall.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: On tap at the Monte Carlo. Amber colored with a foamy cream colored head. Nose of grassy hops. This is a full flavored, full bodied pale ale with lots of grass, resin, and caramel sweetness over a dark bread foundation. The citrus comes out in the end with a long finish dominated by orange peel.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Bottle: Poured a hazy/cloudy pale yellow color ale with a small bubbly head with minimal retention. Aroma of citrus hops is a bit faint for the style. Taste is dominated by faint citrus hops with some weak malt. This beer is definitely lacking character and this is also the worst beer that I have taste from this brewery.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Tap, Monte Carlo. Poured a very light amber color. Slightly citric hoppy aroma. Light citric hop profile. Finish is a little bit hoppy and bitter. This shouldn’t be called an IPA.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a softly carbonated light yellow-orange colored body. The mild aroma was caramel malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish hoppy aftertaste. The thin mild flavor lacked character and contained simple notes of malt and hops.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: actually suprised me...expected alot less. everything was mediocre but palate was smooth, a little heavy and light bitterness.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Wow. Forgot to rate this when I cam back from vegas. Oh well. Guess I will have to visit again and re-rate it. If memory serves me, I quite liked this beer. Consumed quite a bit of it while playing poker.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: I found my notes from visiting this brewery during my honeymoon in 7/2003. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a pale yellow color with a white head. The aroma was tangy macro. The flavor was basic macro - maybe a touch of sweetness. Thin body. Yuck.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Tap at brewpub. Hey, wanna roll the dice and roll a loser? Roll this one; rice, con syrup, and dog food greet the nose and the taste buds. I’d rather surrender to the house outright.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: No bad aroma, looks thin like yellow water. Taste is very thin and nonexistent. Poor even for the style.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: On tap at the Monte Carlo. Light golden color with a thin white head and a light sour grain nose. This is actually pretty flavorful for a brewpub’s light offering. Yeasty, citrus with light breadiness. A little hot on the tongue.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Tap, Monte Carlo. Light golden color. Slightly watered down grain aroma. Flavor is malty and grainy. Not bad for a light.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of finely sized white colored bubbles that was quickly diminishing and left behind a transparent softly carbonated straw yellow colored body. The almost non-existant aroma was mild malt. The mouth feel was tingly and mild at the start with a mellow finish. The weak flavor contained notes of malt mild hops and slightly astringent.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: 12oz bottle pours brilliantly clear gold with very little sign of any head. Aroma is slightly corny with some yeasty notes. Nice and smooth taste with very little flavor at all. Good light lager for a session beer.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: On tap @ Monte Carlo poured a clear pale yellow with a small diminishing white head. Aromas of straw, bread and a hint of carmel. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, light carmel and light citrus with a lightly bitter finish.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Blonde in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas of some kind of floral honey and cereal grains. A bit of a toasty note in the mouth, with some sweetness and a bit of yeast. Definitely lacks some snap on the finish, but this wasn’t nearly as bad as I had expected it to be.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: An easy to guzzle crappy beer, it was 107 yesterday, so I drank the beer pretty fast, weak flavor, corn water, but really weak attempt, terrible.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: 26-Feb-06 (Growler: Monte Carlo Resort & Casino) In exchange for taking care of my ex-girlfriend’s cat while she was in Vegas, she had to bring me back some beer, so she came back with a $45 growler of this stout from the brewpub in the Monte Carlo. $45 for a growler! It pours black and opaque, even when held up to the sun that is gradually setting over the Pacific Ocean. Medium-dark tan head forms slowly, but vanishes fairly quickly, settling to a wispy film. The nose is all dry roast and yeast, unimaginative and quite ordinary for a brewpub stout. Again, more of the same dry, bitter roast in the flavor, some yeast and herbal hops flavor, a hint of chocolate perhaps, but as for the bitterness, it’s mostly from burnt roast rather than hops. Medium body on each sip, but thins out in the finish leaving kind of a watery impression. Not a bad beer, but in the end, this is pretty much like a boring, average brewpub stout that you’d find in a large chain.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Bottled. Poured medium-deep brown with an explosive cap of tan head.. I’m talkin’ 3/4 of the glass worth. The aroma was soft and dusty with dry chocolate, raw oats, and light dark fruit skins represented.. pleasant enough, but it seemed a touch off. The flavor had dry, somewhat abrasive chocolate and dark fruits on the core surrounded by herbal and spicy notes.. the finish had a drawn-out, ugly, tacky sourness that attached to chocolate that didn’t have much character to it.. kept going downhill the longer I drank it. A bit shy of medium-bodied, and it didn’t feel too good on the palate. Meh.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Date: 01/06/2000 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black, fine tan head, slightly sweet roasted malt aroma, creamy roasted malt flavor, coffee hints, slight bitterness, rich to the very end Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Draft at the casino. Nice appearance but there was something missing that I can’t quite ID. The taste just seemed slight with a thin mouthfeel.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Nice and dark, coffee in the aroma and flavor. Not too dry, just a fairly decent coffe stout. Not something I like in my stout too much, but this one was okay.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: On tap at the Monte Carlo. Dark mahogany beer with a foamy light brown head. The roasted grain nose had hints of malted milk balls. Dusty chocolate flavors with some berry sweetness, roasted grains and an almost maple flavor. Lightish for a stout.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a bid bubbly dark brown head with average retention. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee is dominant and very interesting overall. Taste is dominated by slightly bitter malt with long coffee finish. Body is about average and carbonation is a bit too lively for the style. Bottle was drank at close to room temperature, which really powered the coffee side of this beer. I thought this beer was very enjoyable overall.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Tap, Monte Carlo. Very dark pour. Weak malty flavor with only a little roastiness. Slightly sweet mmilky flavor. A hint of coffee with a little bit of a bitter finish. Fairly bland for a stout.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Draught @ The Brewpub: The bartender took his time pouring this one properly, and I even caught him pouring himself one, which I figured meant I was in for a treat. Never trust a thin chef, or something along those lines. This one is all roast and toast in all aspects. Pours jet black with a thick oatmeal-y head that made it almost all the way to the end. Aroma of roasted malts and currants, hint of oatmeal. Flavour was awesome off the top with roasted malts, toasted cereals, and hints of coffee. Nice all the way through, I was surprised to find something so good in a hotel brewpub.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: This bottled brew from the brewery poured a medium sized head of finely sized bubbles that was long lasting and left behind a no visible carbonation dark ruby red brown colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was malty. The thin mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish with a dark malty aftertaste. The thin flavor contained notes of smooth malts mild dark malt and mild brown malt. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Pours medium gold-orange with a good off-white head. Aromas of fruits, wheat, banana, etc. Flavor has lots of malt and much the same as in the aroma. Disguises its 10+% alcohol well. Quite true to style; unlike the only other rating from 3 years ago. They must have just got this one on tap. If you are a "beer geek" and are on the LV strip, you really should check this one out. Beats all of the other macro-swill crap that you find all too much of.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: And just how exactly is this a Belgian Tripel? Ok, the alc is there but the taste has quite a bit to go. Attractive deep orange/red color, unimpressive head and medicinal taste all lead me to the belief that this was the brewers first job.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: I found my notes from visiting this brewery during my honeymoon in 7/2003. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a cloudy pale yellow color with a white head. The aroma was light lemon pepper. The flavor was lemony and wheaty. Basic but decent.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Tap at brewpub. Pours an average yellow with a slightish aroma of off-bubblegum. Grassy, almost hay-like aroma gives way to a taste of the same. Thin, vinegary mouthfeel. Keep rollin’ the dice; this is a loser.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Name: Winner’s Wheat Date: 01/07/2000 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy yellow, whispy head, Aroma: citrus wheat aroma, Flavor: light wheat flavor, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: I had numerous beers at Monte Carlo before the brewpub closed, the only ones I remembered are the Wheat and the Belgian Wit. This is a pretty generic American Wheat. Always served with a lemon. Cloudy. Wheaty with some citrus. Gets a higher rating due to it being made in the casino and served there as well.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Looks nice and cloudy. Smells like a lemon since they stuck one in there. Very stingy and effervescent. Not what I want in my beer. Soda maybe, but not beer.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: On tap at the Monte Carlo. Hazy yellow beer with a foamy white head. There is very little to this beer. Some doughy flavors, with some bitterness in the finish. Nothing offensive, and very chuggable, but it looks like a German wheat without delivering the taste.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Bottle: Poured a slightly hazy yellow color beer with a small bubbly white head with minimal retention. Aroma of wheat is a bit weak but still enjoyable. Taste of wheat is enjoyable but a bit too weak for my taste and lacking a bit of the banana feel I usually like. No hops were discernable and body is a bit watery with too much carbonation.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Draft, Monte Carlo. Hazy golden color on the pour. Slightly sweet aroma, somewhat grainy. Low carbonation. Flavor is grainy and somewhat bitter.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a hazy no visible carbonation yellow colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was mild malt and mild wheat. The mouth feel was smooth at the start and mediumly tingly at the finish. The weak flavor contained notes of mild hops and dough.

column4: Monte Carlo Brewpub at the Monte Carlo Casino
column5: Draught @ The Brewpub: This one was sadly disappointing. Poured a cloudy yellow with no trace of head or lacing whatsoever. Aroma is really gentle, almost non-existent, but a touch of wheat and citrus can be found if you strain. Flavour is HEAVY carbonation, distracting amounts. If you can get past it you might find some malted wheat and citrus flourishes, but it’s just an irrational amount of carbonation. Pour effort.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy aroma. Fruity wheat malty spicy banana flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy finish.

Tap, 10cl @ Tacos and Beer, Las Vegas. Pours light hazy yellow with a small, staying creamy white head. Aroma has sweet malts, wheat, oranges, soft banana. Medium carbonation, fine dry and light grainy momouthfeel. Flavour has sweet wheat, grainy notes, herbal hops. Surprisingly bitter for the style. Quite drinkable.
On tap at Cap Tap. Pours clear gold with a thick white head and a floral aroma. There is a light wheat malt flavor with a mildly bitter finish.

On tap at Umami Burger Beer Garden & Sports Book in SLS, Las Vegas, and shaker served displaying a murky, lightly ambered gold color, with a modest layer of off white head foam, and some wavy ribbons of lacing. The nose was soft grain/wheat, touches of dankness & earthiness, and not very expressive yeast notes usually attributed to the style as banana, clove, and fruitiness. Light to medium bodied, with decent carbonation, the taste was similarly light notes, and contributed a modest, earthy bitterness. Still went down easy, and refreshed.
Standard hefe, but done well enough to hit the spot when it is hot out. Light banana and clove, easy drinking.
Spicy banana aroma, cloudy as it should. Lean mouthfeel mostly banana and some phenolics. Some sweetness in finish.

Draught at the Tenaya Creek, Las Vegas, NV. Hazy yellow colour with a small white head. Dry grainy malt, wheat and some citrusy hoppy notes in the aroma. The flavour is wheat, dry grainy notes and hay. American Wheat Ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Wheat, Mild Lemon, Mild Banana Appearance: Hazy Golden Straw/Orangish Hue, Passes Some Light, Thin White Head Ring, Minimal Lacing Taste: Wheat, Mild Lemon Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying
Part of a flight at the brewery - cloud dirty yellow, very little head, has a light lemon and wheat taste and a perfume-like lemon aroma.
A quality Hefeweizen. Does not need to be ruined by adding a lemon, it only masks the natural citrus and tropical flavors.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: Roast and a little nut but not a ton going on here. Pours brown with decent head and lacing. Light toasty finish. Not a lot of character.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft at the brewery. Pours clear copper/brown with a fizzy beige head. Tastes like nutty malt, dried fruits, earth, and faint booze. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like nutty malt, earth, and wood.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draught @ Public house - Luxor. Clear reddish brown with very small frothy off-white head, faint caramel malt aroma, medium carbonation, pretty watery caramel taste with almost no flavor, thin body, abrupt finish. Meh.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: From a self-serve tap at the Book at the LINQ. Pours a clear, light, brown color, with a thick, beige head. The nose is cocoa, walnuts, syrup, and dust. Sweet and syrupy, with a faint bitterness. Light body, with a thin, syrupy, and slick mouthfeel. This is a weak brown ale, but not too bad.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: Aroma - mild amount of nuts and limited but. Appearance - copper body. Good lacing. Taste - has mild malt and some nut. Palate - body is medium, texture is smooth, carbonation is fair, finish is slightly astringent.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: 29/6/2018. Draft at Michael Mina Pub 1842, Las Vegas. Pours bright amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, sweet malt, moderate roasting, nut, hint of chocolate, fruit, veg and syrup. Medium plus sweetness, light bitterness. Moderate body, oily texture, average carbonation.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft @ the brewery. Pours a dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: From notes, tasted at Great American Beer Festival 2017. Will add more notes if I get to try this again. Very good brown.

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: Can. Pours a dark amber color with a thin head. Aroma of malt, nuts and trace of chocolate. Taste of roasted malt, nuts and light touch of chocolate. Mild bitterness and finish is fairly dry. Medium body, smooth with a nice malty feel. Easy drinker

column1: Tenaya Creek Bonanza Nut Brown Ale
column5: Can shared at DCLawyer’s, thanks Chris! Clear amber brown with beige head. Aromas of skunk, caramel, light roast. Tastes of caramel, malt, skunk. Light body with a dry finish.

"Meh. This middling NV brewer has decent prices (though still more in bombers than it would be in a 6pack). this has some spicy and earthy hops, but is fairly bland and malt driven. not really what i was looking/hoping for."

On tap @ Tenaya Creek poured a clear light amber with a small lasting ivory head. Aromas of carmel, pine and grapefruit. Palate was light to medium bodied and dry. Flavors of light carmel, pine, earthiness and grapefruit rind with a dry lingering bitter finish.

on tap at brewpub: im pulling this one from my memory banks because the brewery isnt brewing this one regularly anymore has been replaced by the ring tail IPA. as all their beers a bit thin for me. built for the masses or the macro crowd whos feeling a bit risky. seemed to me to be better when the brewpub opened and got little thinner as time has marched on. the IPA and this one are pretty identical. not a lot of hops but enough to be the only character to speak of and after that crisp and clean and easy to drink. pretty snappy. not that i dont like it but to fit the class we need a bit more robust flavor...all across the board.
Nice orangish-yellow color. Bit weak on the nose, but nice hoppy palate. Decent brew.
Not bad for a beer....but it definitely lacked character to make it a legit pale. Rather watery with hints of hop flavor throughout.
This is a pale ale? Not nearly enough hoppiness. Rather watery and flavorless but somehow it did have a nice texture.
This isn't the best pilsner I've had. It doesn't have great flavor or aroma. Not one I would drink again

Can as "Craft Pilsner" at 5.4% from Total Wine in Sacramento, CA. Pours light, bright gold with a white head. Aroma is lightly grassy with bready support. Near med body. Flavor is lightly grassy with bready support. Not all that dry; not very bitter. Needs more hop IMHO.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours a slightly hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma. Fruity malty grainy weak grassy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy weak grassy finish.
Golden and smooth. A little sweet, mild and inoffensive. Sharp finish. Tried at the brewery in 2018 during NCPH.
At the source: golden with a white head. Aroma is light grain grass. Taste is lightly bitter and grass. Not bad.

Can says 5.4%. Pours clear bright gold with a fizzy white head, Tastes like doughy malt, corn, light grass, and straw. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like doughy malt, corn, light grass, and straw.
Can. Pours very clear gold. Aroma and flavor are crisp and dry with Pilsner malt, light toast, very faint hint of corn, and clean noble hop character. Light body.
12 oz. can. Pours a pale straw color with a slight haziness. White head. Aroma of pils malt, floral notes. Taste is honey, pils malt, a bit of spiciness. Finish is mildly bitter and somewhat sweet.
Thin fading head. swirling brings back. Flavor and aroma pilsner malt. Very thick sweet body. A very nice beer. Medium body. For a pilsner needs a bit more crisp but still a good beer.
Tap at Banger Brewing, Las Vehas. Colour is clear golden with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Some hints of fruits, some grain and malts. Very boring.
Big stout with generous roast, chocolate, coffee. With a slight astringency.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty licorice and chocolate aroma. Roasted malty licorice and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty licorice and chocolate finish.
Bottle thanks to AJ. Pours black with medium tan head that lasts. The aroma is roasted malt and dark chocolate. Slick body, dark chocolate, licorice, roast, bitter finish, very good.
A well done average Imperial Stout. Creamy body Nose is chalk and grain. Perfect standard Imperial Stout. But nothing to return to here.

The smell is caramel, chocolate, coffee beans, the look is black, brown head and the taste is chocolate, vanilla, caramel, coffee, sweet on the sip, bitter on the swallow, smooth with a little afterburn. Great beer.

22oz bottle pours out black topped with a small tan head. Nose is roast malts chocolate vanilla black licorice and some coffee notes. Taste is more of the heavy roast malts a nice coffee touch vanilla cocoa and a little bitterness on the end.
Jet Black and Tan head that hung around. Malts of roasted badly some black malt bitterness smoothed out with caramel and licorice. Flavor of chocolate and anise. Flavor lasted on and on.
A bit to mild for me, but a very drinkable beer for the non-beer-lovers. Clear and golden in color, fresh, clean, no after taste. A real palate pleaser.

Pacific Rim Brewing Company--Alki Ale--1997 22 oz. bottle. 5.00% ABV. (2.0 / 5.0) Golden Ale. Pacific Rim Brewing Company--Alki Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 5.00% ABV. (2.75 / 5.0) Golden Ale. Amber Color. Medium light body. Slightly fruity.

Draft at the Pac Rim tasting room. Medium coppery amber with slim gray rim and intermittent lace. Not much on the nose. Medium body, nice solid carb. Lots of grapefruity columbus business on the mid-palate, and that’s about it. Mild finish.

Tap: Brown caramel color, light head and lacing. Nose of light grassy and citrusy cascades. Some husk and pale malt. The flavor is nicely balanced, crispy bitterness. Finishes dry and falls flat. Surprising how dissipointing this rollercoaster was.

I would have never called this one an amber ale. This is very light, it is really easy to drink, quite palateable. Fruity, with some great biscuity maltiness, bread crumbs, with a great crisp hop bite. Nice session beer.

Cloudy, medium head, persistent lacing. Aroma of spice, fruit, malt and fresh bead. Light bodied for its style, fruity, mild but dominant hop bitterness, malt and bread balance it out. A good session beer
Cloudy bronze appearance with some hoppiness in aroma and flavor and an offkey ale flavor. A decent ale.
Full flavored with a great malt nose at the start, semi-sweet in the middle and a nice hop crisp finish. Very drinkable beer.
Light gold color with white head.Faint grainy hop nose.Clean and well balanced with a very brief finish
Cloudy banana color with a and aroma of hoppiness and grain that also seems to have a banana twinge. Well balanced clean flavor makes this an easy drink. Interesting combination of hops and rye.
Excellent beer, robust, big grainy nose and a winner in anyones book. Hops and malts quite well balanced.
Pacific Rim Brewing Company Admiral ESB--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 5.50% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Excellent Rich ESB. Bottled right out of fermentation tank.

Copper color with a thin head. Aroma of toasty caramel malt with some floral funky NW hops. A tad grainy, toasted malt, and floral/bitter hops in the flavor. Finishes a bit funky. A sessionable, but albeit average brew.
Mild amber color, a nice floral ESBesque bitterness. A souped up version of Redhook’s ESB, similar flavor profile, but with more bitterness. Quite enjoyable. Great rainy day brew.
Tap at Buckaroo, called Buckaroo Bitter. Deep amber,small beige head. Rich malt nose. Carmel malt profile,well hopped. Lots of malt too, well balanced.
floral herbal bouquet, weak bitterness. slight burnt bread. nothing stands out as great but it’s nice.

Tap at Barcade. ABV was listed at 7.5% on the beer I had, and it was definitely more than 5.0% so I’m not sure if it’s a recipe tweak or what, but here goes anyway. Hazy deep ruby-amber beer with a thin tan head. Aroma is very malty with lots of sweet caramel and toffee notes. Slightly chewy on the palate as well. There is enough leafy hop character to restrain the sweetness a bit, but it still tends toward the cloying end of the scale. Light orange marmalade fruitiness along with a touch of cascadey type US hops. It’s an okay brew, but nothing really special either.
Tap: Amber color, light head and lacing. Nose of light pine and spruce, clean hop and medicinal notes. Lots of c hops. Full body, nice esb, balanced and rich with the right finish. Tangy!

This was a killer ESB, one of the better things I have tried today. Fuller bodied, and a bit more malty for the style, but has some great bitter hoppy bites in the aftertaste. Very crisp, even though it is quite malty, has a very clean flavor.

Clear amber-copper with a tan head. Citrus and earthy hops with some caramel. Fruity, earthy, citurs flavor. Crisp palate medium body. the hop choices are odd making it seem more like a lager but I still enhjoyed it.

Hazy copper body with beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, some grapefruit, earthy. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, some earthy, light grapefruit. Medium body, some syrup. Seems more like a maerzen than an ESB.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: (Draught) Sampled at the Dog & Pony Alehouse in Renton, WA. Lasting white head with a clear mildly carbonated gold body. Rubbing alcohol nose with a slight hops flavour. This was a weak offering.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: Dog & Pony, RentonGolden colour. Some snappy hops, diacetyl. Bland but sort of breezy pale maltiness. Surprised that it’s strong or supposedly well-hopped. Seemed a bland amber to me.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: salty seawater aroma and solid average appearance. pale flavor vanishes quickly. some lemon.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: Cloudy yellowish orange. Sweet piney aroma. Flavor is sweet and bisctuiy with a bitter funky finish. I like this one.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: Amber,small beige head. Nice malt nose. Full bodied ,malty,cereal grains, medium hopped, long finish

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: Tap - Dog & Pony Ale House - Renton, WA A deep golden color with a thin head. Had a good hops presence. This was billed as an old al butt his was fresh and came across with a good balance of hops and malts. A decent drinkable beer with some nice flavors and finished nice.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: Draft at brewery. Light orange color. Fruity and a little sweet. An interesting beer.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: Tap at Hop Devil: Pours a deep orange color with only a film for head. The aroma is simple with some apricot-like hop notes and some oat hints. Flavor is somewhat hopped, with a light-medium body. Has a fruity (apricot), herbal flavor with a hint of honey in the background and a grainy malt touch. Simple, sessionable.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
column5: Tap: Hazy orange, light head and lacing. Nose of husk and malt. The flavor is buttery with light diacetyl and pale malts. Plenty of honey and hop in the flavor. The finish is creamy and balanced but it doesn’t put it together well.

column1: Pacific Rim Vashon Old Stock Ale
