column5: Draft at the Barking Dog in Seattle. Mild aroma leads into a flavor that is curiously peach- and mango-driven. The mouthfeel seems thin and watery to me; the flavor exceptionally mild both in the areas of malt richness and hop presence. I’m underwhelmed.
Draught, BPPNitro. Black, with light brown head. Nice chocolatey notes. Some fudginess fading to a predictably watery finish. Your basic stout.

Draft at the Pac Rim tasting room. Black. Thin orange-y tan head. Huge coffee nose. Thick and creamy on the attack. Endless waves of coffee on the mid-palate. Decent dark chocolate flavors emerge and stick around for a solid little finish.
Tap at brewery. Black with dark brown head - indication of a good stout? Oh, yeah. There is coffee and something smoky going on in this beer, but at the same time not overpowering. A great stout.
Tap: Black, light head and lacing. Nose of fresh bright and ripe roast, sweet malt and chocolate coffee notes. The flavor is smooth and malty, nice balanced mouthfeel and body. Quite tasty I thought.

Dark black, with just a hint of cherry in the center, which is kind of fitting cause that is kind of how it tasted, some rich fruitiness, and some moderate coffee roastiness, just a bit to acidic, creamy but somewhat tame. Overall not too bad.

Dark brown body with a good amount of red light appearing at the bottom of the glass. Somewhat of a fizzy mouthfeel, with a decent oak wood and coffee flavor. Overall it’s empty all over the tongue with a cola like body but lacking the sweetness. Butter defects also noted. I was not impressed.

Opaque black with a dense mocha head. Roasted malt, choco-coffee aroma. A Starbucks stout if there ever was one. The falavor is also dominated by the roasted malts. Bitterness seems to come from the roasted malts rather than the hops. Medium dry and roasy palate. Enjoyable if a bit one-dimensional.

Creamy tan head atop black body. Aroma is moderately sweet, strong coffee, some chocolate. Taste is moderately sweet, espresso, some chocolate. Creamy, medium-full body. Imbalance from too much coffee.

This was black bodied with a too thick chocolate head. Deep, rich foocee roast characterizes the aroma and flavor. Chocolate tastes appear as well and their is a coffee bean bitterness about the finish. Surprisingly, this is brewed without coffee beans, as the brewer assured me. Quite a robust stout---esp. for the advertisied 4% alcohol content.
A great stout, rich and flavor laden. Chocolate and coffee malt nose. Semi-sweet finish and a fair hop bite to make it perfect.
Very faint tan appearance to the head, very rich and full in body with a creamy mouth feel. Chocolate and coffee notes
Color marrón intenso con espuma densa y duradera. Aromas a café tostado, chocolate negro, cacao, caramelo. Una Imperial Stout muy recomendable.
Strong chocolate-roast aroma. Sticky sweet, deep roasty-chocolate flavor that lingers. Notes: on tap at the Portland tap room , Spring '17

From Apr 2007 This one pours from 750ml ceramic bottle(no date on bottle) an almost pitch black as I can see some slight reddish hues. The tannish head of foam is quite small and there's very little lacing. The smell has a lot going on. I get a lot of chocolate, toffee, sweet caramel, coffee, and a pretty strong nose of the more than ample alcohol. The taste is huge. Lots of chocolate and coffee with big notes of caramel hit my taste buds on my first sip. As I take further sips, I'm getting some dark fruit, plum and maybe some semi sweet cherry, but the complexity is really very tasty. The finish on it is a mix of bitterness from the coffee and a slight tartness from the dark fruit. Alcohol wise, I'm not getting a burn from it that I imagined I would judging from the smell but once it goes down, there *is* a slight warming in the stomach for me and man, is this one a thick rich brew when it comes to the body! But it's nice. Yep, this is very nice. I think I'll get another couple of bottles(here in Casper, US$11.99 each) and do a bit of aging to see how things go. Well, I've finished the 1/2 a glass I had in my New Belgium Goblet and I'm going to put this baby away until tomorrow. "Resealing" the bottle was a bit of a chore but I'm happy that it was as it should keep the beer fine carbonation wise...heck, it's lightly carbonated to begin with, eh? ;^) Bottom line: It's been a few years since I last had this Imperial Stout...I'm glad it showed up in town again as I think it is one fine sipping example of the style. Highly recommended! PS: I see a few people reviewed the 750s and mentioned seeing a vintage year. It's not on mine.

From old tasting notes. Brown/black color. Creamy tan head. Soft lactic roasted malt nose. Wow! Intense bittersweet roasted malt flavor. Notes of coffee, chocolate, licorice, smokiness and treacle. Very big and chewy. Lots of hop bitterness in finish to balance the intense malt flavor.

2007 Bottle. The aroma is sweet, caramel. coffee, chocolate, a little licorice, roasty. Pours almost black, with tan head mostly diminishing and excellent lacing. The taste is light bitter and a touch of sweet. The body is medium, the texture creamy, the carbonation lively and the finish long. Very Very Good!!

7 oz bottle shared, purchased at Tops Liquors in Tempe. Aroma of chocolate malt, roasted grain, coffee, light earth and light fruity esters. Similar flavor, rich, smooth and complex, hiding the ABV pretty well. Medium to full body with a lingering finish. Nice.
I will Re rate this. Having a 2002 and it is way too old. Chalk and bitter taste. Really just tastes super old.

12 oz bottle recieved from friend. Bottled date says 2004...its now 2017. This will be one of the oldest or longest aged beers I have had. Bottle also says best when aged one year. Poured into a narrow top stemmed glass. Very thin medium brown head dosnt last very long. Aroma consists primarily of dark malts. Taste is dense with heavy malts. Notes of chocolate and some coffees. A lot of hop character behind the malts. Full bodied beer with low carbonation. Low carbonation may likely be related to 12 years + aging. Over all a very strong and rich flavored beer. Has held up surprisingly well for over 12 years. I would have guessed it would have gone sour, 100% flat or stale by now.

Butelkowane w 2010 roku W aromacie ciemne owoce, gorzka czekolada, kawa W smaku srednie cia³o, niska gorycz, d³ugi posmak kawowy i ciemnych owoców wiœni Podsumowuj¹c do piwa dodano chinook ale jakiœ goryczki Ameryki w ogóle nie ma, dosz³y na pewno aromaty dobrego starzenia sie jakas wiœnia jest
Good local Richmond, VA beer. Best to get on tap, but the local stores that carry bottles do a brisk business. Good taste, aroma and head. Bitter aftertaste that mellows as you get used to it.
This reminds me of a German Helles. Super light, well topped. Light and fruity. Lemony. I'd call this a girlie beer, though.
My buddy brought this up from Richmond for me. Standard light lager, reminded me of a Schmidt''s beer. I have a feeling this beer is more expensive then a "Schmibt-ies".

Recently had a bottle "fresh" from the brewery. In no uncertain terms, and in no way am I exaggerating here: the beer was absolutely HORRID. Pours absolutely headless, very light, faint yellow, though slightly cloudy - as if Coors Light became a hefeweizen. Severe carbonation overload! Copper/metallic tartness assaults my tongue while overcarbonation kills it. Harsh bite. Has a chemically-alcoholic aftertaste. This was really an odd tasting brew, but odd in a way that I would not like to experience ever again. Have had from tap in the past and don't remember it being THIS bad, but it was never good. Extremely poorly done. I feel bad busting on Main Street, but I am only being absolutely honest. The six pack has been sitting in my fridge, and no less than 3 people who have dared sample the leftovers have told me how bad the beer was.

Slightly cloudy, dark golden in color. Little head retention. Sweet-malty flavor; slightly dry finish; bread-like; by the way, "Fan" describes the way the streets, laden with row houses, "fan" out away from the city.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: on tap holy cow, sampler: this was another one of those experimental beers. that didnt pan out. some weird extract used, not real fruit. poured clear yellow, very light head and fizzy, really carbonated, like coke. blueberry nose and thin taste, not really much wheat flavor. ive heard of this concotion before and it seems that the flavors would gel well but the beers are always sub standard??? stay away or if you want a soda try it.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Maybe I just came at a bad time, but this was horrible. The best part was the appearance, deep amber to light brown, but there was nothing on the nose, and way too watery on the palate. Barely could tell it was a beer.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: loved it,just might have bbeen really drunk that night in vegas.............

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: I tasted this beer many years ago and now Holy Cow is gone. It was my first pumkin ale and still haunts my memory on well the pumkin taste came through. Never had that since, but now years later I am trying to recreate it.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: on tap at the holy cow: dont know what this guy is talking about sonora brewing co, it was brewed right on premis at sahara and lv blvd., i knew the brewmaster and several people who had worked there and looked forward to this seasonal every year. this was one of my favorite pumpkin beers out there. typical nutmeg, clovey nose, orange-brown in color. a bit thin at times and sweet but pretty easy to drink with good pumpkin character. not sure if real pumpkin was used or just pumpkin pie spice. this ones gone so dont try to find it.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: As I understand it, this beer is brewed by Sonora Brewing Co. for the “Papago Brewery” and also I believe for Holy Cow in Las Vegas. I’m not a real fan of “Pumpkin” beers, but as I sat there listening to a new local band called “Powerstump”, just banging away some great head rocking tunes, and for an “Old Coot” like me who is more inclined to Perry Como and Tony Bennett, I was totally impressed with their music, just goes to show you that you can teach and “Old Pooch” new tricks, look forward to seeing them again. Well I digress, now back to the beer. The head prodigious in size setting on a limpid amber body, creamy in its texture with a vellum like sheet of lace covering the glass. Sweet pumpkin aroma with hints of nutmeg and cinnamon, scrumptious this nose and a real treat, start is “ambrosial” pun intended, nicely malted with the top middling in its feel to the palate. Finish is mellow in its carbonation, the hops powerful in their spicy bite, quite dry aftertaste, and I must say this is the first “pumpkin” beer I’ve tasted that I really like, and hopefully it will be back next year as it was quite a treat.

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Amber orange. Pumpkin pie nose. Spiced pumpkin taste........................

column4: Holy Cow! Casino, Cafe and Brewery
column5: Hazy pale gold. Light vinegar nose is only overshadowed by the heavier vinegar flavor. A bad keg?

Most unique labelling of beer bottle I've seen this year. Slogan on the bottle cap exclaims "You earned it!". Slick packaging makes me nervous about the contents, so I sipped cautiously. With it's dark amber appearance and thin head I wasn't sure what style to expect. Aroma quickly gave it away as a pale ale. Reminds me of a Geary's English Pale Ale. Same bitterness, just no lobster on the label.

Dark yellow with collection of collection of bubbles on top. Bitter but not in a good way. Sharp. Malted cereal in the bulk of the gulp. This tastes like a standard American lager to me, but labled as a English Pale Ale here. Not.

RERATE: Yep, it sucks from the bottle, too. ||| Extremely uneven. Off tap, I've found to be absolutely undrinkable to adequately satisfying. Do they not know what they're doing over on Main Street? On average, a little too filling/carbonated. Almost no head. Not thin by any means and almost slightly orangish hue. Usually gives me a wicked hangover. I've never tried it out of a bottle, only off-tap. Will re-rate after a few bottle tastings, if somebody ever offers me a bottle, because I won't buy it off the shelf. If I want a 'working' man's beer, I will stick with the High Life. And by the way, I never see anybody at Main St. Beer Co. except flaming yuppies whose idea of hard 'work' is a 75-minute conference call with the marketing dept.

This review is from memory, but here goes. I remember this ale being extremely dry, with a paper taste. Like dried wood. It's been over a year since I've had it and the only other thing of significance I can remember is the fact that it had very unique bottle caps. Try it the next time you're going through Richmond, it's pretty decent.

Crystal clear dark-golden color. Shines and sparkles in the light. Tastes "bready" and dry. A little sticky and sweet, but also kind of "nutty," with a whole-grain kind of taste to it. Aroma is a little musty, although it's not too disturbing. Not extremely impressive, but after a hard day of work, any beer tastes good I suppose.

I quite enjoyed this beer when I had it at the Main Steer Beer Company. The appearance was nice, not much of a head, but it looked tasty. The smell was nice and refreshing. The initial taste wasn't great, but a second sip did the trick, and I found myself enjoying this beer quite a bit.
Golden, flat with no head. Fruity nose and a light orange-like juicey flavor. Bit of yeast there too. English Pale Ale? No way.

Real thin white head. Pale golden body, all different sizes of bubbles. Light, creamy and mild all around. Hints of flowers and fruits. a faint caramel malt character. Rather one dimensional initially. Does have a discernable dry hoppy character as well. Citrucy and crisp. Adry barley finish. Not too impressive, but I could drink a bunch of 'em in a pinch. so that makes it decent at least, just nothing to write home about.
malty nose, tiny thin head and transparent thin body, light feety maltiness, east coast yeast, no bitterness

after the first taste, I almost could have sworn it was a Malt Liquor, it had that strong sweetness to it! Nice golden color. No head, lots of bubbles, but it tastes kind of flat!!?!?! It's o.k., but the sweetness is starting to get to me, where's the hops? And another thing, the bottle and packaging both indicate "Amelia Island Brewing Company" doesn't mention Richmond anywhere, but that makes sense, I found this at OBX, not too many miles from Richmond.
Undercarbonated, almost flat. Slight carmel flavor. Good beer.............
Good summer beer. Light, crisp, refreshing, with enough hoppiness to keep it going. Slighty nutty flavor-wise.
Not bad, but not overly impressive. Refreshing, a little "bready," and almost a hop aroma, but it fades. Easy-to-drink light beer.

Named after Amelia Island which is a barrier island just north of Jacksonville, FL. This is a fairly decent Pale Ale. Generously hopped with a nice bready/yeasty malt profile. Clean and refreshing, although slighty overcarbonated. However, the last six pack I bought had some infected bottles in it. Right down the drain!

Pale orange/yellow. Zero head. Highly carbonated. Slight twinge of bitterness on back of tongue & roof of mouth; however dry aftertaste. Lifeless & Indiscernable. But you can't beat $1 drafts on a Saturday night, so drunks like me will surely drink anything!

Date: 05/17/1997 Source: Brewfest, Richmond VA amber, thin head, strong sweet mango aroma, medium body, solid mango flavor, noting else going on, like drinking mango juice Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Draft at Main Street. Medium copper body, little head. Sweet mango nose that smacks you a bit. Flavor starts off with mango that is definitely on the sweet side. It finishes oddly enough quite bitter, almost as if the brewer at the last second thought, "oh yeah, this is beer, not a fruit smoothie" and threw in a pile of Chinook hops, boiling them to pure bitterness. Disjointed, didn't care for it.

once again, i was prepared to despise something yet found myself pleasantly surprised. i have never been a fan of fruity beer, and i bought this on a whim because it was (chuckle) 1.99 per 4 pack at a local yokel ABC--not a big seller for the big bud boys i guess. i found the fruit aroma and taste to be immediately overwhelming, but the sip mellowed out nicely into a gen-yoo-win malty ale. after a couple of sips, i was hooked. hey mikey, i liked it! i went back the next week and bought the last two 4-packs, and alas, have seen hide nor hair of this beer again. lovely how florida vendors support local brewers, isn't it?
Ive never had a mango or and orange flavored beer. I have to say that i was impressed. It wasnt one of those weak ass flavored malt beverages, but a true ale with a hint of mango flavor.

You had better like mango, the smell hits you when you pop the cap. Big head, slight bitter finish, not my style but I do like mangos so I had to try. Something good for a tourist to take home and the locals to avoid

Very unique; provided you like the taste of mango, because it is right up front with this beer. Amber/orange color; crystal clear; thin,diminishing head; tasty balance between the mango flavor and malts; as expected quite sweet. The mango flavor is right on; not off or artificial at all. Good stuff!

Name: Porter Date: 04/12/2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory, NC dark with ruby highlights, nice chocolate aroma, full bodied chocolate flavor, only a touch of (malt?) bitterness in the finish, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Score: **+/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
A hearty, full-bodied Porter. Smooth and thick with an intense roasted malt flavor with dark chocolate and black coffee overtones. Flavor seems to wane a bit as bottle is finished.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: Date: 05/17/1997 Source: Brewfest, Richmond VA Appearance: brown, thin tan head, Aroma: slight floral hop aroma, Flavor: light and dry flavor with slight choclate and slight bitterness, Overall: not a whole lot going on, what’s studley about this? Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 2/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.3/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: Dark amber with a good head, but boringly still. This has a strong nut aroma, but there's only a off-center roasted nut/wood flavor that did not appeal that well.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: Rolling, lumpy, shiny, off white head. Mild brown hue. Lightly roasted nose, nutty and caramely. Solid malt profile, some earthy hops, but don't stand out well. Roastey and initially subdued hop character. A hint of dark chocolate near the finish. A little weak in body, could use some more carbonation. The finish is overly bitter, the subdued hops then pull through to overrun the malts by a longshot. The balance is not harmonious at all.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: brown sugary malty aroma, auburn color with a frothy tight head, nutty, sweet, tons of hops with a pretty sketchy finish

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: Well-hopped ale, though I didn't particularly care for the variety. Cool label, but screw-off cap. Reddish brown with lasting raft of foam. A decent value at $4.99.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: When ya call your beer studley do you really need to know what i think. It was good, as bitter as a 90 year old woman after a night of hard luck at the bingo hall. Good stuff, get my seal of approval.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: Bitter, no body, there are many much better brown ales. I immeadiatly followed with a Samuel Smith Brown Ale and what a difference. I was surprised, I expected better from the comments below.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: i liked the fact that there was little bitter aftertaste, but the beer seemed somewhat less hefty--not much body-- than i was expecting...i mean, with a name like studley.... not bad at all, but not outstanding either.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: Aroma was a little musty, but I liked the burnt/roasty/caramel flavors. As far as head goes, maybe I got a bad bottle/batch, because the bottle I poured was WAY TOO CARBONATED. It was extremely difficult to pour and drink.

column1: Main Street Beer Studley Brown Ale
column5: A well done English Brown. Deep brown color; fairly hefty body; roasty and nutty flavor profile; hops of course very reserved; sweet side finish.

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: Bomber poured into a pint glass. Golden amber with a nice tan head that has decent retention and excellent lacing. Strong pumpkin spice aroma of nutmeg, cinnamon and clove as well as having notes of pumpkin, vanilla and a little bit of caramel. Finishes smooth with spicy flavors. One of the best pumpkin beer, will recommend to friends~

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: Clear orange brown with thin beige head Aroma is mild grain Flava is grainy malty and spice notes of nutmeg cinnamon Feels light to medium silky with decent fizz Finishes tangy malty mildly sweet

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: Pours a chestnut golden with tons of swimming particulate matter. Faint tart fruit nose with pumpkin and faint cinnamon. Flavors are the same with notes of horehound.

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: Bottle. Strong pumpkin spice aroma of nutmeg, cinnamon and clove as well as having notes of pumpkin, vanilla and a little bit of caramel. Pours clear caramel colored with a thin tan head that has decent retention and excellent lacing. Starts with pumpkin and caramel malt flavors as well as a bit of vanilla. Finishes smooth with spicy flavors of the aforementioned spices with nutmeg and cinnamon front and center. Pretty nice pumpkin beer.

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: Shared bottle. Pours a dark brown color, with a thin, tan head. Strong pumpkin spice aromas, with some cloves and vanilla. Sweet and no balance. Light to medium body, with a thick, creamy mouthfeel. Good spice, but nothing special.

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: This beer has a decent pumpkin flavor. It’s not the best pumpkin you’ll ever have, nor the worst. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: Pours deep amber. Mouthfeel is almost creamy. I love that this is not too heavy on the spices. There are notes of burnt caramel that is great with the pumpkin pie flavors going on.

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: A pretty decent pumpkin ale. Pours orangish gold with a thick pumpkin spice character. Cinnamon, nutmeg, squash and brown sugar. Tried for the first time in 2007.

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: From old tasting notes. Brassy golden color. Fine bubble white head. Interesting pumpkin malt aroma with a hint of cloves. Flavorful spicy malt flavor with hints of cinnamon and allspice. Yes you can taste the pumpkin. Smooth, mild spicy finish.

column1: Buffalo Bills America's Original Pumpkin Ale
column5: Appearance is dark brown. Aroma and taste is a pretty nicely spiced pumpkin ale.

Bottle part of a mixed 6pack. I couldn't find any dating. It pours a clear light gold with a small head of foam. I smell wheat, little bit of caramel malt sweetness. The taste has wheat, the malt is overly sweet imho, and there's a vegetable flavour that isn't appealing to my palate. Earthy vegetables? Best that I can describe. Good enough mouthfeel. 1 bottle will do me.
Bottle at Pebble Beach. A little too grainy and cereal. Taste a little oxidized. Faint carbonic bite in the back. Slightly hazed old Gold. Not terrible, but not very interesting.
Not my favorite. Taste like a Budweiser but more expensive! Probably won't buy again. Mainly tried it due to the name. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Monterey Tides in Seaside, CA. Aroma is light banana, mild caramel. Taste is mild and creamy banana. Soft carbonation. Not especially great but very drinkable.

Bottle at Asilomar. It’s very hard to complain about free beer when you are chilling on the beach at Asilomar. So I won’t complain. This was perfectly drinkable, not too much banana or anything, and I’m pretty sure it had beer in it.
light citrus aroma; soft, light wheat base with mild citrus hop notes; much more of an American style wheat - no banana or clove notes typical of a hefeweizen

Keg at A.W.Shucks, Carmel, 30/04/14. Lightly hazed golden orange with a moderate white swirl and edgework. Nose is citric rinds, lemon, ornage peel, straw. Taste is pretty bland, citric forward, grass, light spice, metallic rinse. Medium bodied, prickly carbonation, crisp close. Pretty blah, rates a rate ! More mediocrity from Menodcino!

Was going to buy a sam adams but I figured I'd try something new, at Flaherty's in Carmel... Wish I hadn't... Golden yellow, watery flavor with a hint of sweetness, minimal to no wheat richness, very disappointing... Don't waste your time. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
gold blond coloured body with a little white head a yeasty sweet fruity aroma a spicy yeasty sweet fruity little bitter taste with a sweet bitter finish

12 ounce bottle. Might be old? Picked up at liquor store in Tulsa last month. Pours a clear dark gold with a small white head. Aroma of grain, yeast, and citrus. Taste is wheat, citrus, and yeast. A bit of hops at the finish. Average.

Poured from 500ml bottle into pint glass. A thin tan, sudsy head drops quickly with mild lacing. Color is opaque brown. Aroma of rich roasted malt, chocolate, nuts, citrus rind. Mouthfeel thick and creamy with a long slowly drying finish. Flavors of dark roasted malt, slight char, cream, chocolate, cocoa powder, nuts, earthy and citrus hops. Overall: outstanding.

Kolor czarny bez przeœwitów, mêtny. Piana wysoka, br¹zowa, wysoce trwa³a. Konsystencj¹ przypomina mus kwasowy. Aromat czekoladowo kawowy z mleczn¹ nutk¹, raczej s³odki. W tle odrobina chmielowych akcentów trawiastych. Smak jest kwaskowy, wytrawny, brak kompletnie s³odyczy która pojawia³a siê w aromacie. Ponownie jest kawa i jej palonoœæ, t³em s¹ tu delikatne akcenty popio³owe. Goryczka wyraŸna o œredniej intensywnoœci, jej charakter zdecydowanie jest palony. Wysycenie œrednie do wysokiego, p³yn ca³y czas musuje w ustach. Œrednia iloœæ cia³a sprawia, ¿e piwo jest chyba trochê za lekkie. Faktura p³ynu jest g³adka ale nie "kremowa".

500ml bottle at Sternbräu, Rabkweil. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt with a slight alcoholic smell. Appearance is darkest black with a thick brown foam. Taste is light sweet, light bitter. Medium dry, soft carbonation. Good.
Smooth drinking stout. Flavour is suttle and not to aggressive. Taste is lightly coffee with chocolate after.

Milk chocolate aroma with slightly charred wood Pours black with minimal tan bubbly head Coffee, chocolate, cream flavor with wood. Medium full bodied with medium co2, lingering toasty finish. Solid stout. Well balanced and easy drinking

Flasche 0,5l: Schwarz, kräftige Trübung, mäßig stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; kräftige + würzige Nase, sehr kräftige Röstaromen, nussig, dunkle Schokolade, trockene Hopfenaromen, würzige Süße, Vanille; sehr würziger + kräftiger Körper, sehr kräftige Röstaromen, nussig, dunkle Schokolade, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, trockene Hopfenaromen, würzige Süße, Vanille, etwas Tabak; angenehmer würzig-trockener Nachgang

Typical stout. Deep dark brown colour with a very small tan head, nose is malty, roasty and a bit smoky and boozy with notes of chocolate, vanilla, coffee and bacon, taste is sweet and roasty with a roasty and dry finish, full bodied as expected. Delicious

500mo bottle from Metro, drunk overlooking the Sea Garden in Burgas on a windy August evening. Pours opaque, almost black with a fluffy beige head, heavy lacing but no visible rising carbonation. Aromas of burnt toast, bitter coffee, chocolate and molasses. In the mouth, sweetness, soft dry toasty sourness and bitterness entwine in perfect harmony, flavours of roast, toast, coffee, bitter chocolate, molasses and burnt caramel, medium to thick texture with a long mid-bitter finish. Just about perfect and amazingly good for a macro craft Stout.
Dark brown, smells like traditional stout. Flavours are coffee, smoked beer and raisins. Lovely beer.

Birra stout dal colore nero impenetrabile e leggera schiuma color cappuccino. Odore di cacao e affumicatura tipico delle stout al palato arriva anche un pizzico di vaniglia oltre al tostato e al cacao. Corpo medio, forse un po' acquosa. Buona ma mi aspettavo di meglio.
Dubbel dal colore intenso, schiuma non molto persistente ma compatta, profumo intenso. Aroma di malto, caramello e mou. Sentori di spezie. Dolcezza un poco invadente.

(Flasche) Es hat eine warme dunkelbraune Farbe mit einem leichten rot Einstich, es ist filtriert mit einer rötlich braunen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist hefig, Brett, etwas röstig, mit etwas Rinde im Kopf. Der Geschmack ist karamellig, schlanker als erwartet, leicht samtig mit einer leichten Hefenote im Abgang.
Bruinrood. Ruikt metallic, karamel, mout, kruiden. Smaakt karamel, rozijnen, vrij waterig en nietszeggend.

Botella 500ml Color marron-rojizo,espuma de color beige,fina,alta,resistente.Aroma malta tostada,azucar moreno,caramelo,cereza.Sabor domina dulzor con ligeras notas amargos, malta tostada,caramelo,cerezas,muy suave
Donkerbruin bier met beperkte schuimkraag. Redelijk vlak van smaak, licht zoet, licht wrange afdronk.

Bought at a small Hoogvliet in Zoetermeer/Holland. This beer is dark and has a beige, frothy head. Earthy smell of caramel and peaches. Extremely sweet taste for a dubbel. Not my case. It was so bad, I had to throw it away after a few sips.

Excelente cerveja. Surpreendeu! Cerveja escura cor caramelo escuro, espuma marrom. Aroma alcoólico tostado e caramelado. Sabor caramelado levemente adocicado e com sabor alcoólico típico do estilo. Me surpreendeu o destaque dos maltes tostados e o amargor equilibrado. Retrogosto alcoólico quente tostado. Muito boa!
Backlog. Dark Belgian. Roasty taste. Could be a little more complex, but well made.

Bottle. Color: Clear ruby, off- white head. Aroma: Caramel malt, brown sugar. Taste: Moderate to medium sweet, moderate bitter, dark malt, caramel, brown sugar. Medium body, bit watery, just below average carbonation. Too thin.
Klassisch malzig mit Noten von Karamell. Etwas schwer, dabei ausgewogen in der Perlung und zum Schluss hin leicht süß und schwer. Nicht schlecht.

(Flasche) Es hat eine bernsteinerne Farbe, ist klar filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist leicht alkoholisch, etwas hefig, ein paar dunkle Früchte und dazu etwas helles Malz im Hintergrund. Der Geschmack ist schlank, prickelnd leicht süßlich, etwas alkoholisch und ein bisschen Hefe. Abgang ist schlank.
Pours an amber color with white head. Malty syrupy sweet aroma and taste; light sugar and cola character. Notes: bottle from Valkenburg NL, Nov ‘19
Flaska. Klar brun öl med ett smutsvitt skum. Doft och smak av karamell, malt, mörka frukter, fikon, torkad frukt och en lätt alkoholsötma.
Dark, bitter with a hint of a sweet note. Alkohol content hardly noticeable, very delicate considering the percentage. Definitely worth a try.
Black with a small head. Malty but not a lot of body considering its strength. Some presence of alcohol but not as much as you would expect for its strength. Definitely a wolf in sheep's clothing.
Can be described as a diluted quality barleywine or a strong dubbel. Drank mine quite young though. Roasty, sweet taste. Warming alcohol. Slight sharp bitterness. Not good not too bad. Mediocre.

I had high hopes from this beer but in the end little disappointed me.. I love "Quardrupel" beers and i give a try to this because has this style and also some good ratings but in the end i get something different that i'm used to get from this style.. First of all the aroma is the ordinary for that style.. Lot of caramel and chocolate in there. Also remind me little the aroma of "Het Anker gouden carolus imperial dark".. But the taste was little weird.. I'm used to get some sweet taste from "Quad" beers but this has a lot sour taste inside and less sweetness.. Also the alcohol is very noticeable and hit you in the palate.. And i get very dry taste in my mouth.. Overall is ok beer.. Has some "Quad" character but can't touch the stardards of the good and classic beers on that style..
Te gekruid te hoog alc alsof je een roggebrood eet. Niet vies maar veel te dik.

Bottle at home from Schiphol Amsterdam, 5th September 19. Pours a chestnut brown beer. Aroma is dark fruit, malts, caramel and molasses. Taste is sweet, dark fruit, brown sugar, molasses. Very good especially for the price.
Overgezet van Untappd. Het is een helder donkerbruin bier met weinig schuim. Het heeft een moutige wat karamel achtige geur en smaak.

Notities gevonden van meer dan 20 jaar geleden. Ik kan me nog wel herinneren dat ik het toen wel aangenaam vond, mits koud geserveerd. Anno nu zou ik er hoogstwaarschijnlijk niet zo snel meer aan beginnen omdat oud bruin bij mij onder de categorie: zoete futloze pulp valt. Uiterlijk: bruin bier met redelijk wat koolzuur en redelijke schuimkraag voorzien van bruine vlokjes. Smaak en geur komen overeen: karamel, gebrande mout en een toffeezoetje.

Typical Dutch oud bruin, not to be confused with the totally different Flemish oud bruin style; close to the equally mass-produced Dommelsch Oud Bruin in terms of appearance, aroma and taste, but a bit less sweet and a bit more metallic. Serves its purpose as a daily low alcoholic, I guess.
Deep red brown, thin frothy tan head; sweet malty nose, roasted, brown sugar, syrupy, bread; very sweet, sugar; thin texture, watery mouthfeel, light body; sweet roasted finish

Bottle: And here’s another Dutch sweet beer, rather go for the Flamish Oud Bruin. A medium off white to light tan head on top of a ruby brown colored beer. Smell sweets, some malts and darker fruits. Taste is also sweet, brown sugars, sweet darker fruits and sweet malts. All these Dutch Oud Bruins’ seem to taste so much like eachother, not interesting and just too sweet.
Dark brown, thin head, very sweet one with hinds of cola and candy, almost no spices and no beer hinds. had better oud bruin.
Ruby body with smallish head. Sweet nose. Sweet flavour, more than usual perhaps due to low ABV. Light. Not my thing.

This was something totally new for me. Sort of a low alcohol porter or bock. Not too bad, but very sweet. Actually quite similar to finnish "kotikalja", could be translated as homebrew. I would have this with a meat soup when you still need to drive.
Oh my god, really not a great beer, tasted it once and never again! Have thrown away. Much too sweet. In one word: disgusting!

28 May 2005 - Big malt aroma and damn sweet. Clear brown-red colour poor head and lacing. Lots of caramel and too sweet given that it lacks some complexity. Sweet lingering malt finish, but too sweet.
bottle. Golden colour, tall white head. Full-bodied, malty with a touch of honey, vanilla and gingerbread., and a special flavour I cannot point my finger on. Loved it.
Clear yellow with a white top. Wet dog, sweet malty aroma. Over medium sweet and mildly bitter. Medium body with average carbonation. Hm, not great. Bit one dimensional.

33 cl. bottle @ home, bought @ Albert Heijn Culemborg. Clear golden with a thin white head. Sweet grainy perfume aroma. Sweet taste with an even sweeter finish. Typical macro blond Belgina strong ale. Expected a bit more from a Hertog Jan beer to be honest, even has some alcohol burn. Didn't even manage to finish it.

Thanks to Erzengel for sharing! Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts strong, malty, a bit alcoholic. Some sharp soapy notes. Light spicy. Finish still alcoholic, intense malty. Okay.

Smooth fresh fruity nose. Beginning with banana and dry hops. Fresh floral, fruity and easy to drink. Moderate bitter fruity in the aftertaste, round and refreshing with a banana-fruity and nice refreshing bitter resin aftertaste.
30cl bottle shared with Erzengel. A clear pale golden beer with a white head. Aroma of sweet and strong pale malt, belgian yeast and spices. Taste of strong pale malt, honey, spices, belgian yeast.
Is niet verkeerd maar is toch wat aan de “dunne” kant .Van een winterbier verwacht ik eigelijk dat hij zwaarder en voller is . En dat is deze niet .

Bottle from Albert Heijn supermarket in Gorinchem, The Netherlands. The beer is clear golden colored and has a small, little unstable white foam, with average carbonation. The aroma is malty and spicy, with notes of caramel, yeast, vanilla, bananas, little citrus, cloves and other spices. The taste is medium to full bodied and malty sweet with notes of caramel, bananas, fruits, honey and goes to light bitter with yeast and spices. The finish is light bitter, little alcoholic and short. Not a winterbier in my opinion. Misses alcohol warmth and also dark malts.

Jongens en dames uiteraard dit is gewoon een trippel die onder de naam winterbier verkocht wordt. Ah maar ik zie nu dat de stijl Belgian Ale is dat verklaard een hoop. Maar dat is dus net niet wat ik van een winterbiertje verwacht. Maakt het beoordelen ook meteen een stuk moeilijker. Zoetig honing smaak. Redelijke zoete licht medium moutige geur. Klein bittertje Overall voldoende om het boven het gemiddelde te doen uitsteken. Maar winterbier??? Nee als het niet op het etiket stond had ik daar nooit aan gedacht. Hertog Jan het zeker geen verkeerde Belgian Ale maar maak volgende keer een winterbier dat de lading van de naam dekt. Proefglas
Clear golden pour with small white head, retaining well. Sweet, malty and spicy aroma; not very special. Taste same: medium sweet and spicy. Nice but easy winter beer.
Bottle at New Market in Amsterdam. Dark brown. Toasty, caramel and dark fruit aroma. Pretty smooth. Pretty good.
Aroma of prunes, plum & raisins. Black with a creamy tanned head. Light sweet & medium bitter. Full bodied creamy texture & soft carbonation.
0,3 l Flasche. Braunes Bier, cremefarbener, flacher Schaum. Riecht und schmeckt malzig, deutlich alkoholisch.
Clear red-brown with a cappuchino-colored head. Rich malty aroma. Taste is malt, strong licorice, then a little watery on the palate. Still quite interesting to drink.

clear ruby-mahogany colour, one inch of creamy beige-ish-yellowish head; aroma of intensive dried plum/cookies made with plum jam (szilvalekváros kifli hájas tésztával, leginkább :) ), raisins, slight toasted rye bread and burnt sugary notes; taste is more or less the same witha bit less intensive dried fruitiness and more intensive burnt sugary-caramel notes; not bad at all! Many thanks for the bottle, kapusil!

0.3l bottle. Clear ruby red body with basicaply no head. Aroma of caramel, burnt sugar and a bit of orange zest. Taste of toast, caramel with a bit of orange zest and a tiny bit of cocoa. The toasted/burnt character is a bit overdone. I had better examples of this style.
Bottle from Spar. Dark red brown, clear, with thin beige head. Med carb. Sweet caramel and coffee, a little on the candy side. Not bad for HJ

Bottle thanks to kapusul. Pours reddish amber, no head. Grainy, syruppy malt aroma. Taste is caramel, cough syrup, bread and toffee. Not much remains except some sticky malts. Not the best. Too much cough syrup flavor for me. Not so enjoyable.

30cl bottle at home. Appearance: chestnut brown with medium sized beige head. Aroma: bready, grains, caramel, dried and red fruits. Taste: above medium sweetness and medium bitterness. Notes of brown sugar, caramel, red fruits and metal. Palate: medium bodied, oily texture and medium carbonation. Overall: okay.
Bottle. Color: Ruby, beige head. Aroma: Sweet, brown sugar, caramel, malt. Taste: Over medium sweet, brown sugar, caramel, dark malt. Medium body, average carbonation. Too sweet.
30cl Flasche. Mit 7,2%. Gelbes Bier mit luftigem Schaum. Fruchtig-süsslicher Duft. Hopfen und Alkohol im Geschmack. Bitterer Abgang.
Classic Dutch spring bock, golden blonde with fruity and hoppy character and a relatively long, dryish finish. More bitter than usual in this style.
Bottle@tasting (1998), 300ml. Head: some off-white foam. Colour: clear, brass. Aroma: fruit. Taste: some bitter-sweet. Palate: small bitter-sweet finish. Overall: ok

Bottle White head on top of a dark orange amber colored beer. Smell hops, flowers, some sweets. Taste malts, caramel, hops, citrus, sweets. Bitter sweet aftertaste. Medium carbo, tingly bit sharp mouthfeel, low to medium body and a watery texture. Strange brew. nothing spectecular.
On tap at Arendsnest. Golden body, nice head. Some malts but hoppy too. Quite sweet with fruits in the taste and the finish.

This must have been revived for the spring season 2008 as a draught beer as it was on sale in ’t Arendsnest in Amsterdam in May. Not the most interesting spring bok on sale at that time, probably cold fermented. A clear winy golden colour with a creamy white head, and a restrained sweetish and spicy slightly Germanic hoppy aroma. Palate was malty, slightly grapy and gunpowdery with a bit of hops and some odd fruity flavours that suggested it might be about to go off. A smooth malty finish had banana esters and a winy note.

A Mes rate: Bottle from Lowlander I think. Has one of the best aromas for a bock beer I have tried so far. Smells like something much more serious. Almost like a chunky quad. Is this right? Complex fruit, cream, and lashings of alcohol. A smell that is as intoxicating as it is divine. I could smell this all day. Sadly the drink itself does not quite live up to the initial promise. Lots of bock characteristics but quite blondish too. All the flavours come through at the finish leaving you with anassault of apple and liquorice and alcohol that does not seem to know what it is doing. That said it went down ok, it’s just not anything outstanding. But OH MY GOD that smell!!! I could get high off it.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Nice hoppy aroma. Average finish. And very oily palate.

Bottle (traded with Bierkoning, thanks !) Deep golden coloured, small fluffy white head; sweet, malty and citric aroma with a touch of alcohol and honey, some herbal hops in the background; moderate sweet bitter flavour, a little, little bit acidic; sweetish citrousy finish. Decent Bock, a bit - as usual - too sweet....
Bottle, 7.2%. Slightly rough, citric hop aroma. Golden colour, soapy white head. The flavour is yeasty with some OK aroma hops, citric and fruity. Well-balanced with the alcohol.

Primator, da's een tijdje terug dat ik die gehad heb. Was het van oorsprong niet meer seizoensgebonden? Zal wel niet. In oude aantekeningen zie ik een meer dan gemiddeld goed cijfer, wat sterker en pittiger, maar niet overtrokken.
Overgezet van Untappd. Het is een goudgeel bier met een volle witte schuimkraag. Het heeft een moutige geur. De smaak is moutig en wat fruitig.
Fles 30cl thuis. Lekkere volle smaak. Rondborstige pilsener. (1-2009).----.

On tap at Hotel van Oranje (taster) on 13-Jun-2017 - Speciaal bier. Hazy pale / golden amber colour with a thick white head. Aroma of sweet fruit, malt and banana.Medium body and carbonation. Taste is banana, malt and hops. Bittersweet. Simple and fruity.
bottle @ auchan (budapest) brown colour, normal body, average carbonated, light brown head, caramel, roasted malty, toasty, bittersweet, easy to drink
Canned, 0.5 l. Pours clear mahogany with a medium sized beige head on it. Malty nose and aroma with caramel, toast and dough, taste of toffee. Sweetbitter, toasty, mild hoppy finish.
Lara. Arooma: Toasty malty caramel grass. Ok palate. Flavour: Sweet like, toatsy maltiness and toasty caramel, fair. Thin like but ok.

0,5l can. Clear brown colour with quickly disappearing white head. Aroma: Caramel, honey with a hint of yeasty and boozey tones. Taste: Has a short malty sweet start with a quite sourish rye-like tone and mouthfeel without any bitter feel. A little bit watery too. Light body with fizzy carbonation. Medium lasting fading sourish finish.

0,33 bottle. Szín világos- gesztenye barna, áttetszõ, habja gyakorlatilag nem volt, pedig megfelelõ pohárba, megfelelõ hõfokon került kitöltésre. Illata kávés, földes, picit édeskés karamelles, száraz. Íze a minõségi pörkölt német malátától édes, telt, kávés, zamatos, égetett cukros, és még picit keserû is. Kinézetre rosszabb volt, mint ízre, bár picikét azért vizes.
Dark Brown (Tea) Nose. Caramel, toasted bread and a bit of hops. Taste. The beer body is velvety, pleasant. The taste is malt, slightly sweetish, turning into bitterness from hops and roasted malt.
atom. antis. pörkölt malátás illat és ízvilág. mégis könnyû, vizes test, marha jó ivódunkel.
De geur is lekker fruiting. Normale schuimkraag. De smaak is verrassend goed. Best te drinken

Ar: Grass, hay, and some toasted malt; herbal hops. Ap: Chestnut and crystal clear; medium light tan head with good retention, settling into a solid cap of foam. T: Toast and steel; hay, chalk and light coffee; bitterness is low; herbal hop flavor; clean fermentation profile; finish is lightly toasted malt and more coffee. M: Light body with high carbonation; finish is very dry. O: A quaffable, clean dark lager; lots of hay, herbal hop notes, and steely malt.
Pours dark brown with light head that fades quickly; sweet roasting aromas on the nose; mild, off dry, bitter finish. I like it despite the reviews and mass production brewery!
Mediocre red ale, lacking body and a full mouthfeel. But at least it's not overbitter like most. Brewsters calgary.
On holiday in Canada amber coloured body with a white head and a spicy fruity malt hops aroma a spicy fruity herby hops bitter sweet taste with a bitter finish
Light Amber color. Malty aroma. Taste is the same with some caramel notes. A tasty Amber
Draft to taster Consummation: Pepper and malty Adjunct: Ancho chili and malt aroma; clear light amber, no head, but lacing; some orange in the taste too

Thanks to Reimer for this. Pours clear amber brown with a small white ring. Aroma is earthy, caramel malts and small oxidation with light hopping. Taste is sweet caramel and toffee from the malt with light earthy hopping bitterness. Very quaffable.
Pours a ruby red colour with a little head and some lacing. The taste is sweet malts, breadiness and dark chocolate. Had a soapy aftertaste. Average
Tap at Brewsters. Red, low offwhite lace. Fruity melonoidin roast, a bit dry chalky at the back of the throat. Grassy hops. Dry wooden finish.
On draft at Brewsters in Calgary. Pours a clear light amber with an off white head. Light malty nose. Flavors of rye and other grain notes. Medium bodied. Light toasty finish.

A really rusty looking copper, quite a regal looking red indeed. A big helping of caramel, nut, toast and earthy malts all come together enjoyably and are well balanced by very minimal citrus and floral hops. I wish Canada would become friendlier in the beer trade between provinces. Decent medium feel to the body with soft carbonation.
Aroma is roasty maltiness with caramel and very slight honey and toffee. Taste is a subtle maltiness and bland hopiness. Body is a clear amber with a pearl head that retains ok.
Draft - Sweet toffee and some nutty notes. Clear Amber with a rich beige head. Light toast. Sweet caramel and some nutty notes. There is a bit of a syrupy artificial note.
Taster from draft at Brewsters Consummation: Sour mashed cilantro blackberry...weird Adjunct: Toasted barley, nutmeg, sour blackberry; reddish amber with a long lasting thin, tan head;
pinte de brune prise au bar. arome de malt caramel et café le tout assez léger. au gout c’est plus puissant mais bien équilibré entre les notes de café et le sucre
On draft at Brewster’s it is a clear amber color with a flight head. The atoms is malty the taste is a sour apple with a bit of smokeyness
On draft at Brewsters in Calgary. Pours a clear reddish amber with an off white head. Nutty nose. Mild smokey flavors. Thin mouthfeel. Light roasty finish.

Aroma is a rich maltiness with nuts and a slight smokiness. Taste is a pretty smoky maltiness with some caramel and roastiness that is met with a basic bitterness. Overall the body finishes fairly flat. Body is a very dark amber. Creamy head is thin and retains fairly well.

Tap at Brewsters Alberta. Pours clear brown with a small, fizzy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is caramel and toast malt, dates, cinnamon, nutmeg, and earthy hops. Flavor is nutty, chocolate, and roast malt, light hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Very dark, almost black with some frothy head. Smells malty. Tastes almost like a stout, with a good strong flavour throughout.
Pours a clear brown with a small beige head and very little lace. Aroma of cocoa, coffee and nuts. Taste is the same as above but very thin. This beer could be great if it had a deeper body.

Single bottle purchased at Brewsters in Calgary, AB on 08/22/2012. Colour: Dark brown/red mix. Low but steady cream coloured head. Nose: Great mixed roasted nuts, chocolate truffle, freshly rained upon soil. Taste: medium-light sweet, medium-light bitter, medium-light sour. Lots and lots of roastiness - grains this time. Semi-sweet cocoa nibs. Nice dry grain-hop fusion late. Enjoyable stuff!

Pint on tap at Brewsters Oliver Square location. Poured a nice golden color with small white head and little lacing. Aroma was light floral hops and some caramel. Taste is malty sweet with a lingering hoppy finish. Overall, this was quite a nice pale ale.
Tap. Surprisingly not bad. Hoppy. Weak body, too thin. Watery finish. Not much more to say. If im at brewsters i’ll drink it.
Golden pour. Lemony scent with a bit of hops. Fairly watery with some pale ale bite. Not as good as expected. High carbonation. A bit of berry in the taste noticed late.
hop in aroma.. English style pale, hoppy for a Calgary beer. Some lace otherwise not much to look at. Too carbonated but drinkable. Lots of carmel, malt.
On tap, Oliver Square location. A simple, pleasant pale ale. Poured golden, small thin white head. Some faint hop in the aroma, falvourwise its caramel malts with some Cascade hop bitternes.
Light amber color, sweet... really the sweet palate is something brewsters seems to have become known for. Soapy indeed. Not terrific, but good.
I don’t find much of an aroma at Brewsters. Very light amber colour. Served only slightly cooled. In need of a stronger hop note or maybe that is just me since they do not have an IPA.
For Alberta, this has some fine hop flavours. Overall, it's not bad, but not a lot of Californians will be making any pilgrimmages.
not the best of bitters out there, but living in Saskatchewan we dont have much of a selection for beer, has a light hoppy taste to it, a little smooth for a bitter, nice deep copper appearance
Not very good. Some bitterness which was abrasive and then a watery finish, so it doesn’t even do the bitterness (if you like that) well.
One of the better beers I sampled at Brewsters. Hoppy aroma balanced with sweet roasted malts flavour. Pretty decent.

Pint on tap at Oliver Square location in Edmonton. Poured a light copper color with light film on surface and spots of lace. Aroma was mildly hoppy. Taste was cereal and light hop finish. Carbonation was adequate and body was a little thin. Overall, this beer was a little to light on the hops for a bitter style.

Draft at the Victoria Avenue Brewsters in Regina. Pours clear amber, thin off-white head; poor lacing. Nose is caramel, spicy hops, a bit of clean cardboard. Flavours of light spice, big sweet caramel. Watery and out of balance. A weak effort.

rerate June 21 ’10 - pour was half asses like usual so I guess the last pint I had was a one off in terms of looks. Taste is still ok but of course needs work. So damn gassy and it just cost me 7$ for this - are you kidding me? I’d say fuck this place forever but find me anoher place in he city that brews anything drinkable. Well.… easily the best looking Brewsters beer I’ve had. One finger deep crown, thick and light tan on light copper brew. The aroma really needs some warming to come out. Caramel, grainy bread, lots of fruit. Taste wise this is very drinkable. Caramel, bread, medium hoppy spice (for brewsters), nice fruit. It’s too gassy even after half a pint. It’s on the edge for the style but it’s tasty and drinkable. A bit thin on some sips but overall pretty good.
Not too bad. Aroma is hoppy, sweet malts and caramels. Nuts and toffees mixed in with an overall sweet aroma. Taste is bland and not too impressive. Bitter aftertaste, but not too much here.

Bottle: Orange-red amber with only a thin head. Thin caramel aroma. Very caramel-candied flavor, with just the barest thread of bitterness follow-thru. I’d put this in a Vienna category in a blind ... where’s the ESB-ishness in this? (#2893, 5/15/2007)
Golden with a hint of orange. Sweet and very fruity. A little watery, and not very bitter, but still perfectly drinkable.
Pours a amber brown with a creamy head. Looks like a nitrogen tap the way it was settling. Has an off-putting plastic taste that just doesn’t sit right. Not one of their better efforts.
Pours a clear black color with a thick brown frothy head. Aroma of roasted malt, cocoa, chocolate and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and finishes dry. Nice easy drinking dry stout.

from tap to growler. Dark chestnut brown, very little short-lived head. Roasted malt aroma, a little ashy. Mostly coffee flavour with a dry finish, rather thin mouthfeel and a little carbonation. not a bad stout.

Pours a black colour with a tan cap on top and some decent lace. Aromas of roasted barley, unsweetened chocolate. Flavours are unsweetened chocolate with light coffee, a small bitterness on the dry finish Overall a bit watery but session able.

Not a bad Guinness alternative, a little light but definitely not on par. Pours deep black brown. Aroma of tobacco, coffee, and chocolate. Tastes similar and helped along by its creamy palette. One of the better beers served by Brewsters.

Dark brown, almost black pour with small fluffy tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Taste of roasted malts, unsweetened chocolate and a hint of coffee. Low carbonation and creamy mouthfeel. Not bad.

Brewsters Irish stout is a typical, if not exactly creative loaf in a glass. It’s thick, creamy, and not too bitter, but not all that memorable as good guinness approximationa are. It’s finish doesn’t, almost as if it’s missing something that could make it a great beer. Bottom line this beer is like a fake accent, nice as long you ignore the way it slips from time to time.
Not great, but the pint I was given was at least not unpleasant. Near black, 3/4 inch of off white head. Roast, dry. A touch of cooked vegetable in there. Okay.

Originally reviewed Mar. 1, 2007: got the draught and head showed super thin to non-existent. what head there was, was light tan colour i'm guessing. as i was drinking, it showed light roping with spotty lacing at best. aroma reflected coffee beans. perhaps as good as safeway brand or western family might be. the taste is like as if i was drinking bitter water. the aftertaste is again, bitter, and very undesirable. it lingers. if i had a choice of stouts to choose from at this place, i wouldn't be choosing this one i'd guess.
Black in colour. Roasted malts and chocolate, typical of a dry stout, thought this is not a great stout. Passable.

Pint on tap at Oliver Square location in Edmonton. Poured a deep black color with some red highlights with a beige head and some spots of lacing. Aromas of roasted malts and coffee. Taste is light malty sweetness and a coffee bitterness blended quite well. I almost always have a pint of this when visiting Brewsters. This is one of my staple beers.

2015-06-06. Crisp yellow body, small white head and lace. Aroma is mild, muted hops over pale malt. Flavour is very lightly bitter over sweet lightly cereally pale malt. Smooth average to light bodied palate, soft carbonation. 6/3/6/3/12 On tap at Brewsters Century Park, Edmonton.

Rating #2693 - 2016.07.28 - Unsure why this has been missed until now. Clear pale yellow pour with a weak white foam that fades quickly. Aroma is caramel, biscuit, grass Taste is light, grainy with a lingering sweetness into a smooth, and rather refreshing finish. Medium carbonation, lighter body.

Bland sweet malts and sulphur aroma. Also corn amd rice adjunct smells. Taste is bland light hops with slight honey and a basic hop character with little to no complexity. Appearance is a clear gold with a thin pearl head that retains fairly well
typical of a macro lager but id say it taste a little better. still glad its jut mer helpiong a buddy out finsihing his beer for him... not a pint i actully ordered

Tap at Brewsters Alberta. Pours clear pale gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is Pils malt, light spicy hops, and clean. Flavor is malty with light hops and bitterness and a dry finish. Light body and moderate carbonation.
Clear golden colour with white head. Kind of nutty flavour. Watery, but a bit of sweetness and yeast flavour. Okay.
Clear light yellow with small white head. Fine lacing. Subdued malt aroma no hops. Taste is crisp with decent malt. Not too sweet. Very easy to drink lager. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pint on tap at Oliver Square location in Edmonton. Poured a pale golden color with small white head and no lacing. Aroma is of light hops. Taste is undesirable hop bitterness. Light body and decent carbonation. This beer is slightly above what the macros offer.

Poured slight dark yellow and quite clear. Nose has fresh buttered white bread, candy floss, dusty clothes. Taste has more bread notes, celery, hints of vanilla, and mild hop attributes. Finish is medium-long with some bitterness. Touch over-carbonated but palate is smooth. Typical lager and not even remotely the worst I’ve ever tasted.
Clear yellow appearance. Little aroma but what is there is of a standard lager. Tastes of peanuts and light bitter hops. A little more to it than expected.

Aroma is a sweet roasty maltiness with some caramel notes. Taste is a sweet two row maltiness with a slight bitterness that matches generally quite well. Body is a darker gold, almost ale like. Head retains moderately.

Tap at Brewsters Alberta. Pours clear orange with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is caramel and cookie malt, toasted notes and dates. Flavor is malty with light hops and bitterness, and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
This was actually a decent lager. Reddish colour with a sweet aroma. Yeasty sweet flavour. Way better than an average lager.

A brown-coppor colour, this lager has caramel accents and definite taste of malts. A passable lager, but nothing to write home about. I guess this exists as their stab at a macro lager. Buy the Original Lager instead.

Pint on tap at Oliver Square location in Edmonton. Poured a clear light amber color with a film of white head and some spots of lacing. Aroma is pleasing. Taste is light malty sweetness with a lingering hop finish.

Overall, this is a fantastic lager. The pour is a yellowish light brown with a figner of thick off white head. Predominantly caramel and bready malts with a hint of nuts and slight grassy hops. Very drinkable and crisp finish with mild carbonation. The taste is very refreshing and surprisingly bready and nutty malts. Overall, a very solid lager.

Pours a misty light brown. Nice colour, a shade of brown that you don’t see often. Caramel nose with hints of mustard and bordeaux. Odd but nothing to stick your nose up at. Nut dominant taste with a malty background. A strong entrance of tap water kicks in and certainly doesn’t add to the quality of this one. Fairly quiet finish.
On tap in Edmonton, downtown location. Clear copper lager. Sweet, malty, but easy to drink. Citrusy, and pleasant tasting. One of my favourites when I stop in there.
Clear copper pour. Sweet malts on the nose. Slightly sweet and malty but easy drinking. Approachable.

Crystal clear amber brew with an ok white head and decent retention after you give it a healthy swirl. The aroma was of non-descript hops and some citrus. Actually, this beer is pretty tasty and I’d recommend it as a go-to beer at Brewsters. Hops..zippy hops and blahblahblah. Somewhat smooth with some good bitter aftertaste. Hey, that’s a pretty lame review! Oh well.

Pint on tap at Oliver Square location in Edmonton. Poured a pale golden color with little white head and some spots of lacing. Aromas of grain and hops. Taste is grain and hops. A decently refreshing pilsner.
Tap. Pretty similar to Molson’s pilsner. Golden yellow with thin white head. Strong bitter taste upon the first bit. A little too much carbonation for my liking. Not great but far from horrible.

Bottle to plastic cup Consummation: Wheat, hay, lemon, and skunk...sucks Adjunct: Aroma of cheerios, lemon, and wheat; light body with a frothy sawdust astringency, this damn beer makes me thirsty; piss yellow with a white head
It smells like a wheat ale. Clean tasting. Slightly clingy aftertaste - a bit mouth drying. Would drink again and would recommend. Better than the Brewsters raspberry ale.
Pours a straw colour with a serviceable head but very little lacing. Very weak wheat flavour, but you can states the grain with underlying bitterness.

The base wheat beer of all Brewsters fruit beers. Pours a hazy yellow with the Aroma of sweet crisp wheat. Taste is lightly tart from the large amount of wheat used but after that just a basic wheat beer... Crisp and refreshing finish.

On tap 5%. Hazy golden pour, but haziness fades as sediment seperates, leaving a bubbly lager appearance. Aroma has a hint of wheat, and a herbal whif, mixed with a strong maltiness. Taste is pretty much the same, a malty dominance with hints of wheat character built in (wheat, citrus, cloves, etc.) Finish is dry and crisp. This beer is light and refreshing, and would make an excellent patio beer

Tap at Brewsters Alberta. Pours clear pale yellow with a medium, creamy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is earthy and spicy wheat malt with citrus notes. Flavor is wheat malt, light citrus, and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
This was one of the worst wheat ales I’ve had. Really weak and watery. I wouldn’t have this again.

Pint on tap at Brewsters Oliver Square location. Pours a clear golden color with small white head and little lacing. Aromas of wheat and floral hops. Taste is light sweet malt and wheat with a light hoppy bitterness in the finish. Not as good as Gunther’s or Farmer’s Tan, but is a decent beer.

Poured light honey colour and just a touch cloudy. Certainly some traces of wheat, sugar and lavender on the nose but in all its a bit muted. Mouth entrance of cream soda. Wheat germ and liquorice follow suit and the finish is dominant oat grains. Light and cheerful but missing an edge.
I was pretty dissapointed by this beer. Pour of straw with a light with head. No aroma is discernable at all. TAste is a little wheat with a bit of hops. Boring palate and lacking overall in taste.

Pint on tap at Oliver Square location in Edmonton. Poured a pale golden color with little head and no lacing. Aromas are light with some grain. Taste is light sweet and a mild hop finish. Body is thin and carbonation is adequate. A slightly better than average light beer.
Pale gold with a mediocre white head. Low grainy aroma. Thin grainy palate. What else can one say? This was made for the folks with a narrow comfort zone on the palate... not for me.
Original Light Lager in Calgary. Yellow. Uninspiring aroma. Really not much taste. Made me want to order something else. Nice palate. Better than a glass of water.

I never thought I would give a Brewster's beer this high of a rating. All their beer is shit....except this one. At least that I've tried. Anyway lots of great bourbon and caramel notes in the aromas and flavours along with vanilla and pipe tobacco. Delicious.

So, this actually makes me all the more disappointed in Brewsters other beers. If they're capable of this, why such mediocre beers otherwise? Reddish brown body, off-white head. Sweet, rich malty aroma. Taste is sweet, dried fruit, some cocoa. Quite nice.

2016 vintage, 355ml bottle. (10.0% ABV) Pours a clear amber with a thin, short lived, fully dissipating, beige head. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, butterscotch, dried fruit, bread and vanilla. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, butterscotch, spice, dried fruit, biscuit and vanilla with a warming alcohol finish. Medium body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Pretty decent.

Appearance: clear medium amber with one fat finger of rocky light beige head diminishing gradually to a thin skim, moderate lacing. (4/5) Aroma: orange peel, bready caramel malt, dark fruit, resin. (6/10) Taste: moderate-high sweet, moderate-high bitter. (7/10) Palate: medium-full slightly slick body, soft carbonation, lingering bitter and warming finish. (4/5) A decent implementation of the style: the double-digit alcohol is definitely present, but not solventy or excessively hot, and there are pleasant citrus, dark fruit, and hop notes present. I suspect the year’s cellaring has helped mellow this out, and in any case certainly hasn’t hurt. I’m interested to see how the bourbon barrel-aged version of this compares. (14/20)
Bomber pour. Cloudy copper brown pour. Big sweet malt, caramel and some fruitness. Drys out towards the end, turns to a bitter finish. Alcohol comes through fairly hot. One of brewsters better beers.
Poured from a 650ml bomber, light copper thin creamy head. Aroma candied oranges some bread toasty malt. Lots of resiny sticky hops more candied oranges, bread crust. Medium body medium carbonation.

Bottle: Poured a clear amber color ale with a medium is foamy head with OK retention and some lacing. Aroma of light cereal notes with some hints of toffee is interesting. Taste is also a mix of dry cereal notes, hints of toffee and dry biscuit notes with some light residuals suagr notes and warming alcohol notes. Body is about average with good carbonation and warming alcohol notes. Straightforward example of the style.

Roasty, nutty malts, toffee and caramel with clean cereals, and not overly sweet. Hints of sherry, some ripen fruit and pine resins. Light soap, clean, crisp mouth feel. Medium to high bitterness with a great toffee, nutty finish. Hint of earthy woods and vanilla round it out. Light alcohol warms and sweetness, well rounded and balanced. Would barrel age very well.

Well hey, finally a Calgary beer. Is it just me or are there aren’t too many breweries in Calgary-town just of yet? Compared to the others, hells it’s Friday night and I’ve had too much already. This pours with a very nice antique white head and orange-slightly foggy body at 7.4 celcius; soft aroma of yeast, hops, and hazelnut. Flavour is strong malt and nut wit vague hints of yeast on the end. Medium finish. Really good and the abv is very well hidden, be sure not to drive after a bomber of this one.

Tasting at Matt’s Hazy dark amber color with red shades, small head. Flowery aroma, hoppy, sweaty, a bit spicy, with biscuity malts (7+). Lean body, nice malt and caramel flavor, old sweaty hops, average sweetness. An interesting old American style Barely Wine, a bit oxidized.

Pint on tap at Oliver Square location in Edmonton. Poured a golden color with small white head and spotted lacing. Aromas of some fruit and cinnamon with a hint of ginger. Taste is of some fruit with maltiness and winter spices and a dry finish. A fine Christmas ale which is slightly different than most. Very much enjoyed.

Was told it was a Christmas Belgian Ale. 6%. Dark tea-amber with light lasting head. Light but very nice ginger cookie and spice scent. Flavour is similar with a light Belgian edge,; dark malt and warm spice.

My waitress told me this is brewed with ’cinnamon, nutmeg and something else’. Hazy and a deep iatnge going red is as best as I can do in the lighting here. Ok white cap - another nice pour. A sneak taste revealed that this is not disgusting - just the opposite. Soft aromas of nutmeg, lots of honey, caramel, light spice, maybe cinnamon, nice soothing aroma without a stupid load of strong spices. Decent taste and standard for a Xmas spiced beer but thankfully less powerful. Toasty malts, numeg, cinnamon, a bit of sweetness. Drinkable seasonal brew.
Overall I enjoyed this one. Pours a dark almost black colour. Lots of pronounced coffee AND CHOCOLATE FLAVOURS. it’s fairly balanced WMD tasty

Palatable porter with tons of coffee. Hits all the right notes, chocolate, coffee, etc, reasonable bitter/sweet balance. The espresso they used seemed to bring a lot of acidity into the beer - a mellower coffee might have been nicer.

This is back on tap as a seasonal. Had copious amounts of espresso notes in the beer such that I can’t get through them with my measly palate to find the underlying beer. Seems to be a decent porter under there somewhere but I can’t get over the espresso. I happen to love coffee and espresso in beer so I still enjoyed it.

675ml brown bottle from Oliver Square. Label states best before Jun, bottle purchased in early March. Label is standard Brewsters seasonal label with a "P" written in marker on it. I seem to remember "Kona" in the title, hoping this is the same beer. Pours deep brown, winey red highlights. Head is tan, sparse, fades fast, leaves no lace. Beer is a bit oily looking. Nice coffee aroma, some chocolate. Flavour begins with a bit of sweet dark chocolate, black coffee, light hops and roasty notes in the finish. Body somewhat light, as is level of carbonation. Nice effort from Brewsters.
Very nice fruit beer, the blueberry is quite strong, but the base beer itself is complements it very well too. Brewsters calgary
355 ml bottle poured at the Steeves household. Pours hazy orange with no head. Smells awful; like fermented berries. Tastes better than it smells but still like cheap beer. Not good.

355 ml bottle. (As Brewfoot Blueberry Ale) Pours a hazy, pinkish-copper with a medium, short lived, off-white head that laces. Sweet fruity aroma of blueberries, wheat and yeast. Sweet flavour of blueberries, wheat and light malt with a lightly bitter, tart finish. Light to medium body with a watery texture and average carbonation. Pretty decent for a fruit beer.
33 cl bottle, Calgary, AB, Canada via Coop. Hazy amber with a very slight purpleness. Musty fruit aroma with yeast. Fuller body than anticipated. Slight berry undertones with a bready finish.
On tap at Brewster’s in Calgary. It is a clear golden color with a slight head the aroma is minimal with the taste of sweet bluerries but thin on the palate
On draft at Brewsters in Calgary. Pours a clear light pinkish copper with an off white head. Fruity nose. Flavors of blueberry and biscuit. Soft finish.

Aroma is sweet grains and light blueberry notes. Taste is like the aromas with the addition of some light hopiness that finishes smooth. Body is a cloudy orange with a pearl lace head that retains fairly.

On tap 5%, served with blueberries as a sort of garnish? Clear, pale yellow pour. Aroma is blueberries and barley. Taste is blueberry jam, extremely sweet. Finish is that of a standard macro lager, nothing extravagant, but smooth enough to keep you drinking.

Tap at Brewsters Alberta. Pours clear orange with a medium, creamy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is blueberry with straw and meal malt, pear and apple esters. Flavor is sweet malt, blueberry, and a sweet finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Pours a murky strawy copper with a nice white hat and sticky lacing. Aroma is of sweet blueberries and wheat. Taste is sweet artificial blueberries with some wheat and a very slight bitterness/sourness on the finish.

A good English Pale ale.....almost like an ESB. Flavors of caramel malt with a lot of bitter in the end. Pairs good with a lot of styles of food. Finding these northeast brewers consistently solid with this style of beer. Not in love with this, but could see sampling again down the road.

Cask conditioned in Bourbon Wooden Barrel imported by Brass Castle at York Beer Festival '18. Cloudy amber with very slight head. There is a drying apricot fruitiness to this with a slightly roughish alcohol note. Some leafy hopped notes. It's okay.
Draft at the source. Clear amber color light tan head. Aroma of fruity caramel and burnt toast. Taste starts sweet, malt forward caramel then a bitter finish. OK

From Dec 2007 I got this bottle in a trade with Wasatch. Thanks John! This pours from 12oz bottle a clear medium gold with a 2 finger head of foam. The smell is very malty and very nice. I also get a fruity nose that makes it a pleasure to sniff. The taste has big caramel malt, dark fruit, some grain, and a surprisingly ample but not overpowering hop presence in the background that adds just the right touch to somewhat balance it out but to tell you the truth, I'm enjoying the hell out of the malt. Nice bit of bready notes here as well and the alcohol is completely hidden, asaic. Lovely drop! It has a fairly thick mouthfeel(yeah!), the carbonation is medium light, and it finishes malty semi sweet. Again...lovely drop! Oh, and the foam hangs around like forever. I'm *really* impressed with this English Strong Ale and I'd seek it out again.

From old tasting notes. Winter of 1990/1991 Vintage. Deep Amber orange color. Bubbly beige head. Malty caramel-like aroma with a hint of yeastiness. Big toasted malt flavor upfront. Plenty of hop flavor right through to the finish. Very much like a Pale Ale, but with more oomph! Very good. Well balanced and full bodied.
Bottle from Chevy Chase Wine and Liquors. Nice brown body with slight head. Nose is faint. Taste malty, bread, some fruits and toffee. Nice floral finish.

Beer club offering. Mahogany w tan head. Floral pine aroma. Taste has same elements w hints of butterscotch. Hop dominant but not excessive. Slightly slick mouthfeel. Higher alcohol notes in the aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Had as part of a flight in their tiny tap room in Portland Maine. Dark orange with the good old English taste. Ok
Drunk in Switzerland from bottle. An average tasting pils beer with some touches of bitterness. Nothing special
This was good beer, not like the BS american version, very European flavor and weight
Like Edelspetz with a more earthy bitter finish. Schützengarten flavour and aroma
Getreidig-neutral-herber Antrunk. Leicht süßlich, würzig mit brotig-getreidigen Elementen. Süffig-würzig, ein Hauch Malz, viel Getreide mit neutraler Herbe. Schade.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein klares goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht hopfig, getreidig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, muffig.

Bottle 330ml. @ home. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, cabbage water, light to moderate cardboard. Flavour is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, sweet malt, grain, acrid bitter, light cabbage water. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20111113]
Golden color, large white head that settles quickly. Aroma of hay and light spice. Tast is bitter straw and spice.
Bottle. Sour milk malt and light grass hops aroma. Golden yellow color with small head. Lightly sweet malt and moderately bitter grass hops hops. Pretty boring.
golden colour, few head, medium hoppiness, peanuts in the nose, full-bodied, sweet with a dry and quite unpleasant finish

Having two of those at the hotel I'm staying in Basel/Switzerland. Golden and lightly hazy with a thin, one finger wide head. Hoppy, strawy smell. Light citric taste with a malty finish. Low carbonation.

330ml bottle, from Christmas gift box thanks to Eric for this. Pours gold with a faint mist, small white head. Aroma is light pale malt, light bready notes. Taste is similarly smooth, bready, doughy sweet, yeast, some mild grains, diacetyal and honey hints. It's a passable blonde.
[Basel 2018] Sampled @ brewery. Golden, small white head. Nose is butter grain, sweet plastic. Basic oily plastic, sugar & butter meh.
On tap at Hotel. Pours a clear gold color with a lasting foamy white head, aroma is grains and wet hay, tastes is sweet grains with some herbaceous notes.

Review: 33cl bottle of Unser Bier Naturblond: ABV: 5% On pour I get a very nice looking yellow colour and a big frothy white head which settles nicely. A good bit of carbonation making it all look pretty good...... Very strong on the nose, I get a strong fruity aroma which is very enticing, very nice and sweet. Also some malts present in the smell......... On taste It is a slow burning beer, more fun to relax and enjoy the tastes of the fruit and sweet malts, not a session beer anyway Very tasty, nice pleasant mouthfuls, a very filling beer. I find it very hoppy, possibly a bit too hoppy, but is manageable. Ok, nice and tasty, good enough beer, not bad, not terribly complex, but nice all the same.

Tap at tibits Basel. Pours golden with the slightest hint of haze, but almost no foam. I assume that?s the tap that they use. Aroma is dominated by light malts with some grassy hops, not too shy altogether. Taste of the medium body is lightly sweet with some hop flavours waving from afar, as if to show they were actually used, but not taking the stage. Round and pretty smooth experience until there. A bit flat, maybe. Bitterness is more notable on the palate. Speaking of it, the palate is an undecided mix of the body leasing into it, some hops that finally want to be noted, the bitterness finally kicking in and the carbonation deciding it doesn?t exist anymore. Needs more harmony there. All in all nothing outstanding, with an aroma and a taste which work and a palate that disappoints.
On tap at brewery. Golden body with slight head. Grassy nose. Taste is hoppy, floral, toasty. Not overly complex. Decent.

Appearance: Pale yellow golden, clear. Small, fizzy white head. Aroma: Malt, slight hops. Standard. Taste: Malt, some hops and fruit. Initial harshness transcends into nice aftertaste. Bought: Free mini-bar in hotel (Basel), 330 ml, CHF 0.00 Info: 27/11-2015, BB: 19/5-2016
