Bottle brought home from Switzerland by a relative. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and hay. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. Very little bitterness for a pilsener. 021115

0.33 l bottle. Aroma: alcoholic, cereals. Appearence: yellow to orange, minimal hazy beer, little white head. Taste: alcoholic, malty sweet, some bitterness. Palate: Long lasting bitterness. Overall: Solid beer.

Bottled 50cl. It pours a beautiful, slightly hazy deep golden beer with a lovely, nicely lasting creamy whitish head. The nose is extremely strange and rather interesting. Cinnamon, leather, cereals and chicken with some washing-up liquid. Burnt plastic and glue showing up as well. Indeed, a very strange nose. The taste is a catastrophy.... Chicken and burnt plastic flavors. Just a hint of cinnamon. Grainy, weird and extremely artificial. The finish is of washing-up liquid. This beer somehow really doesn’t work out with me.
Nice gold color; generous head. Malt and light rosemary aroma. Round, quite sweet in the front, quite malty, corn, ending with a better bitterness and rosemary touch. Original.

(Bottle 33 cl) An organic, dark blond hemp beer - well, it had to come eventually. Unfiltered and lightly hazy, small, dense and quite stable head. Sweetish, almost fatty beer, but at the same time dry and aromatic with only a discreet bitterness. Lovely spiced from the hemp. Very nice indeed. 120702
Deep orange, somewhat cloudy. Nutty hemp flavour. A bit thin................
amber colour, practically no head, weak aroma with notes of plum, acidic, full-bodied and uniforme, oily
Sweet - odd flavour (it's not hemp). Simple palate, slightly oily..........

Bottle at Restaurant Schlauch, Zurich, Switzerland, Friday 24th June 2016. Pours lemony silvery gold with a white head. Soft in the mouth, a little sweet but pretty refreshing, a little metallic and mineral twangy bite, dry end. Like it. A6 A4 T7 P3 Ov14 3.4
On tap at the brewpub. Metallic aroma, some low malts. Very hoppy and bitter even for a pils, but quite unbalanced. The hops appears in several stages but none feels right.

Golden color with some foam. The smell has malty notes and some hints of hoppy bitterness. The taste is malty but has a certain hoppy bitter tart note. Not bad for a pilsner. Little dry in the aftertaste.
Weich herber, in Teilen bitterer Antrunk und weiterer Verlauf, monoton. Dann bitterer, wie zu Beginn weich. Ein trinkbares, sehr simples Pils. 6/7/8/6/7/7

Bottle, thanks Allen. Pale cloudy golden, heavy pearling, white head. Honeyish floral and citric aroma. Light body, dry mouthfeel. Quite citric entry, almost tilting into the laundry detergent, herbal notes, orangepeel, pineapple. Light on the strawlike malt. Grassy, sticky hops in the aftertaste. Quite bold.

***** SWISS BEER # 100 ***** bottle, herzlichen Dank Allen! Slightly hazy golden colour with a rocky creamy white head, very persistent. Lovely hopy nose with hints of citrus fruit. Clean and crisp hop flavours dominate the beer, with hints of lemon, lime and grapefruit. Pleasantly ydeasty with a solid underlying malty base. A delicious Pils.

Bottled 33cl. 5.1 ABV. It pours a surprisingly murky golden beer with a quick diminishing initially tall white head. The aroma is rather pleasant , nicely hoppy, grassy and fruity. Quite inviting with pineapple, yeast, grapefruit, peach, bread crust, light grain, apricot, arabic gum and elderflower appearing. Unfortunately faintly sulphury. Impressive flavor with a lot of aromatic hop showing up. Hints of elderflower, white bread, peach, apricot, arabic gum and grapefruit. Medium bodied. Subtle carbonation. Good bitterness. Mediocre lacework. One deficit: slightly grainy and soapy with hints of breakfast cereals (sugar puffs). Extremely refreshing. Lovely long dry hoppy finish which is reminiscent of elderflower and honey. A very good beer from this brewery I really like.

especially labelled "WM-Bier 2006" but this is probably the same recipe - pours a hazy blond-orange colour under a very foamy, white head; the aroma is yeasty with grapefruity and herbal notes; medium- to full-bodied, astringeant and with a solid bitterness; moderately dry and long hoppy flowery finish - much better that it was in my memory

Having one in Basel/Switzerland just next to the Rhine river. The beer is clear golden with a thin head. Malty smell. Very refreshing, slightly citric taste with an agreeable bitterness. Medium carbonation, decent body.
On tap by the Rhein in Basel. Brilliant clear fold. Faint nos of lemon, peppery goos, light malt. Somewhat wsweet, lemony flavor, light, crisp. Not much happening, but crisp and nice in the heat.

Review: 33cl bottle of Warteck Lager: ABV: 4.8% vol Bought it in a ten pack as I couldn’t get any singles in the shop. Clever marketing? Green bottle, screw top, simple but effective logo, I like it. On appearance, it was a very fizzy beer, that produced a nice crystal clear golden yellow colour, but once it all settled down we are left with a very flat beer with no head at all. very flat, very disappointing considering the initial lively carbonation. The smell is nice enough of what you can get, a lagery kind of aroma but also a bit like a sweet perfume, must be the grains! Not much smell overall though. Taste is nice enough, the initial mouthful feels good. Nice maltiness there. A light lager taste that is fine. It is an Ok beer, smooth and decent to drink but no great outstanding tastes that are going to set the world alight. It is a very light tasting lager. Smooth, easy to drink, but boring and bland, even for a lager Overall, I won’t be drinking again I don’t think!
Hoppy bitterness, little sweetness. Simple, slightly metallic, just drinkable and no need to repeat.

From old tasting notes. Bright medium gold color. Thick creamy white head. Fresh malt/hop aroma. Flavorful sweet toasted maltiness upfront. Underlying hoppiness throughout. Well balanced. Very drinkable.

Tap at a bar in Basel. No outstanding tastes as far as pale lagers go, but also no bad ones. Malt sweetness is decent, with a lively carbonation to give a counterweight. A bit oily on the palate, but altogether round and smooth. Well done for a lager.
A very light lager with sweet notes and rare hops. Still well brewed and thirstquencher for a summer day or lawnmowing.
pours clear greenish yellow with a frothy white head and little lacing. tangy green hops in the nose. flavour grains, herbs, grassy hops. nice and refreshing, hops as promised.

500ml on tap served in its own glass. Standard euro lager. Pours a clear golden yellow color. Medium white head formed. Low retention. Thin lacings left in the glass. Sweet grains and flowery hops in the nose and mouth. Metallic notes. Medium to low carbonation. Grassy hops. Light body and good carbonation. Grassy aftertaste. Medium drinkability. Not bad
C’est une lager classique, encore une brasserie tombée sous le joug de Carlsberg. Elle passe bien, sans plus.
Okay, sorry I'm redoing all of these ratings, but I had some trouble with my other account. See comments below...
red-brown colour, almost no head, aroma of caramel and butter, slightly burnt, light-bodied, flowery - quite discreet
golden red colour, dry hoppiness, bitter taste .............................
Another quality Ice beer. Molson Ice seems just the slightest bit more complex than some of the other Ice brews. Very enjoyable. Cheers.
Darker golden with a medium head. Notes are skunk, grain alcohol, malt, and toast. Tastes a little metallic as well. Thin and gross.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into pint glass. Thin white head, pale straw color. Aroma of sweet grain. Mouthfeel is light and frothy. Flavor is too heavy on the sweetness, somewhat cloying with little to no hop balance. Overall: I occasionally enjoy an Ice beer, but I will not be trying this one again.
Aroma and flavor is malts/corn, mild fruit, not much really in the middle and a slightly beery/mildly alcoholic finish.

24 ounce can into lager glass, best before 8/20/2018. Pours crystal clear medium golden yellow color with a 1 finger fairly dense and rocky white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, and light herbal/grassy earthiness. A bit of fruity/metallic aromas, but not overwhelming. Okay aromas with pale malt/corn and mild earthy hop notes; with solid strength. Taste of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, and light herbal/grassy earthiness. Mild herbal, grassy, spicy bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, and herbal/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice robustness of pale malt/corn and light earthy hop flavors; with a nice malt/bitterness balance, and zero cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Very clean on lager flavors, with minimal fruity notes present. Light-moderate increasing dryness from bitterness and carbonation. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, bready/grainy, fairly crisp, and lightly sticky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Mildly increasing warmth of alcohol through the glass. Overall this is a pretty good pale adjunct lager style. All around nice robustness of pale malt/corn and light earthy hop flavors; very smooth, crisp, and pretty refreshing to drink. Very flavorful and not watery. Other than the slightly off aromas, this was really tasty. Very clean barley/grain flavors and solid earthy hop balance. Not overdone on adjuncts. A nicely enjoyable offering, and well made style example. Pretty close to the regular, but more flavorful and fuller mouthfeel as expected.
24 fl.oz. can. A clear golden coloured beer with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, citrus, straw, hops and with a mild bitter finish.
Not very good. One of the cheapest beers around here in the single coolers.
Bottle. Pours pale yellow with small off-white head. Aromas of grain and corn. Single note sweet flavor. Thin bodied. Pretty meh.
It's a smooth light in color beer. A Canadian beer that is made in Texas!!! Ice brewed. Great for Knocking a few back on a summer evening sitting on the porch ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle @ Liquor Barn / Danville KY --- Clear medium amber, white head that drops quickly to the rim, strings of lace. Taste is malt with an adjunct, medium fizz, and slight bittering. Simple, similar to most other big brewery offerings.

When I would bartend in Ottawa in the early 80's we sold lots of it. Reminds me of WW 2 Quebicous veterans and plain end cigarettes. If you could get shot with hot steel through the intestines and go back to the field a couple of months later this is the beer for you.
I drank this beer above all others when I could afford it in the 80's! Only available in eastern Canada. :( So smooth and full bodied. Sure miss it!
Bright yellow gold color. Dense white head. Mixed nose of sour malt and light hops. Flavor is a mirror of the nose with a clean bitter hop finish an aftertaste.

Holy old school!! This shit has been around forever-- sexy new label though. Medium gold, white head that recedes rather quickly. Tinny sweet malts, a touch of apple, sweet and corny. I’ve got a pile of obscene malt liquors in my possession, and I have to start somewhere, eeerrgghh...

okay so had this a long time ago a different yr. Don;t normaly see this around but some beer stores have 12pack’s. I drank a bunch but couldn;t do all 12. To me it tasted like a combo of apple juice & pee back when I had it. Pass.

Wow, no rating from me on this yet? A staple of trips over the border many years ago, was always smooth and fresh and potent. Not much flavor, silky body. A bit of an overstatement on the high alcohol content if it is truly 6%. Seemed like a lot at the time.

Bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a medium golden with a small white head. Aroma of corn and alcohol. Taste of the same. Had this back in the late 80’s when it was distributed to the U.S.A. Not a bad tasting malt liquor but I didn’t consider it back then.

A: Clear Golden Straw Hue, Passes Lots of Light, Thin White Head Ring, Mild Lacing S: Sweet Corn, Musty Grapes T: Sweet Corn, Rotten Fruit M: Mediocre Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, Lightly Sweet Overall, a blast from my youth golfing in canada, but man, what a piece of crap.
Look golden dark, smell better then I expected, taste better then I expected, palate is not very pleasing, I just want to take another sip to cover it.

341 ml bottle from the beer store in honour of Dave Rachars upcoming Brador commercial . Uh this is not how i remenbered this beer awful corn smell Not as dark as i remember pours a light copper with lots of fizz The taste is very sweet malt water not good
12oz bottle(8/02)-Contract brewed by Two Brothers. A golden body with a decent head and an aroma of grains. Taste of grains and nothing. Another pale lager with nothing to write home about.

Bottled. Pours a medium golden color. Aroma is somewhat sweet and grainy. Kind of sour and acidic as well. Flavor is sour and malty. Almost a creamy mouthfeel. Sour and bitter finish. Not really very good.

found this at some store in wisconsin once on a camping trip: $2 for a 6pack. figured, why not, right? ratebeer.com offers four good reasons why not: aroma, appearance, flavor, and palate. my friends and i spent the whole first beer trying to figure out what it tasted like. we decided "pistachios" or some other inappropriate nut. then i gave the other 5 bottles away to some homeless guy who was sleeping on our campsite when we had arrived. his name was mark. this beer’s named Cugino. I reckon i’ll see them both in hell.

Had this one bottled. I got it in North Aurora, Illinois, if that means anything to anybody. I have no idea where Cugino is brewed -- maybe Huber makes it? Anyways, a decent lager, corny taste, thin watery head and mouthfeel. Not much going on here.

This is darker than their light beer, almost gold with the same white head as their light and big carbonation. This is worse than their light beer. It is offensive...drain pour. No need to use your liver as a sieve for this one.

The bottle says this was brewed in Monroe Wisconsin, Huber country. Anyone live near Fermi labs who can see if this place really exists in Batavia? It’s really not worth the effort. It’s pretty sweet and grainy for my tastes with little hopping. Wherever it’s from, I don’t want any more.
Not a lot to sneze at. Golden in color, decent head. Slightly sweet- corn? Claims to be America's first Italian beer? What the heck does that mean?

Another new micro-brewery and another micro American standard. Interesting and well done with a notable American hop finish. Better than macro surely but us nuts are waiting for you to expand your offerings. We hate to pay micro $ for standard. Best of luck, your efforts are appreciated.
12oz bottle(8/02)-Brewed by Two Brothers-A light golden body with a decent head and an aroma of any typical lager. Taste light with a little of a funky taste. Not the worst I’ve had.

Bottle from the sale rack at Foremost, Oak Forest. I suspect I’m sampling from the same batch as the previous raters, cause this bottle may be pretty aged. It opens with a surprisingly sweet smell, first fruity then a bit winey. Pours way too dark for a light beer. Not quite cloudy, but there are a few floaties visible. Just a light scum of bubbles. Taste is a little less interesting. Just a light, oxidized malt with some corn sweetener. Thin, watery texture. Geez, and I thought when I smelled it they might have added a grape tannin or something to make it really "Italian." But it’s just olf. I will try a fresh one sometimes. Meantime, I notice our listing for Cugino Brewing’s web site just returns a placeholder search page. If this stuff is still being brewed, it’s not controlled from Batavia, anymore.

I thought this was from Italy but, alas, I’ve now tried yet another beer from Illinois. Golden/amber with a little sediment and a tiny head. Musty aroma with burnt grain, slight caramel, coins and DMS lurking beneath. A "dirty" taste, bittersweet, with slight spiciness and mild sourness at the end. Foremost Liquors, Oak Forest, IL

Dark yellow with a short-lived big-bubbled head and a corny sweet aroma - - - this is what I look for to entice me into drinking a beer. It’s light bodied with a light sweet corn & malt taste with a slightly crisp finish. My first and last. Foremost Liquors, Oak Forest, IL

Big bubbles rise from a surprisingly darker than straw-colored beer with a fat-bubbled, white head. Aroma is lager ferment sulphur and a toasty grain. The beer shows flavor of a nice pale lager for 2 seconds then the CO2 overwhelms the delicate body. Almost ethereal with a damp, musty basement finish.
A descent light brew, nothing special. Carbonation, watery, "light beery" not bad.
Bright hoppish type of macrobrew nose. Very light color with micro-bubbles. Very thin and watery. The nose is more sweet than bitter. Not bad for a light beer.
Light head disappears quickly. Light colored light bodied. A sweet and smokey aroma. Clean flavor, no bite. A good lawn mower beer.

What? Bottle conditioning of a light beer? Interesting show in my pilsener glass of the yeast bouying and sounding. Otherwise, looks nice with a sweet and lightly smokey hop aroma. Crisp and and fresh tasting and biteless. A bit wet. Gino and Vito done good. Would I drink this again? Fughettaboutit!!

12 oz. bottle poured to a fest chalice at home displaying a clear & bright, orangey/gold color, a layer of soft white froth that quickly reduced to a persistent, bubbly ring, with light dots & dashes of lacing. The nose was expressive apple, skins, & core, with a touch of ripeness, and slight hints of barrel & white wine. Light to medium bodied, with modest spritz to the effervescence, the taste was similar, not overly sweet or tart, and somewhat mellow like apple juice, thus making it quite drinkable, but lacking in familiar, cider-like pizzazz.

This is a backlog rating from 2012 from a bottle, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are sweet, lightly tart apples, no reason to have again.
Sweet apple smell. Pours a lovely, clear gold. Sweet apple taste with a dry finish.
50cl can. Pours pinkish with quickly fading white foam. Aroma is apple and alcohol. Body is average, with good carbonation. Taste is fairly sweet but excessive. Finish is average.

Bottle at Thyme Restaurant in the Premier Inn in Colchester. Wouldn't normally go near a hotel restaurant, but was staying there with elderly in-laws who didn't feel up to going anywhere further so was stuck here. The restaurant was as dire as I'd expected, but at least I managed to get this unexpected rate (I was surprised that I hadn't already rated it). It's a disturbingly artificial orange colour. It tastes of sweet stewed apple and cheap apple juice. There's a pleasant hint of vanilla but a touch of vomit. It's not great, but it's better than the worst of the macro ciders.
NERAX '02 Hazy in appearnce,aroma of grass and citrus.Dry finish for such a pale ale.

Washed out autumn leave orange. Sticky, off white foam. Slow but steady carbonation. Aroma of grass, light citrus and faint malts. Soft and mild with a playful crispness. Citric hops and a caramel toastyness start it out. Grassy bitterness and a touch of crystal sweetness. Medium body. Turns grassier and less citric as it warms. Alcohol is tasted as well, which is strange for such a low ABV brew. Finishes bitterly grassy and a touch spicy. Seems to be missing something, besides an R or two.
Decent color and head; fruity and hoppy, but also a bit sour, and the finish seemed off. Had at the pub; maybe the tap line was bad?
NIce cloudy orange color, slightly thin tasting after a while, but starts off fairly robust. A good one to gulp cold on a hot day.
Nicely hopped. This is one that you could easily toss many down............
CASK- tasty pale! pleasantly bitter, more full flavored than many pales, medium body, citrus flavors on the palate, and a dry finish.

English-style Bitter with small head and relatively low carbonation. Has a real "homebrewed" earthiness to it. Soft, somewhat rich, smooth and creamy. Def easy to drink as a session beer. Has kind of a slippery mouthfeel, if that makes sense. Decent dose of hops in the back end, but leaves behind a curious bitterness. Willamette seems to come through just fine, but it was difficult to discern the Cascade hops.

Originally reviewed: 5/12/10. 12oz bottle picked up from my local Whole Foods. "Brewed and bottled by Goose Island Beer Co., Chicago." printed on the side of the bottle. Best by date: 7/15/10. Poured into a pint glass. Pours a cloudy, rusty orange with a thin off-white head on top. Retention is lacking. No lace left behind. Plenty of carbonation rising through. The nose is pretty underwhelming. Some mild grains, light syrupy-sweetness, and some floral tones. Good crisp, clean body. Moderate carbonation on the tongue. This beer starts out a bit sweet with some honey notes. There’s some mild bitterness, but pretty much lacking there. My favorite part is the finish. There’s a nice bready taste that is very pleasant. All-in-all, this is a pretty tame, average APA. I’ve had better, but I wouldn’t turn this one down.
Bonus for organic, but this just wasn’t grabbing me. In the spectrum of average pale ales this was on the lower end. Serving: Bottle
An average ale. Really nothing too special. The taste you can tell its well crafted. Quality malts. Crispness and nice hops Overall good but nothing great.

Dark amber color with no head. Aroma of apples, raisins. Maybe some spices. A bit of funk, but otherwise no hint of hops. Flavor is very bland. I’m not sure what they were trying for here, but it didn’t work.
A golden brown beer with a small head. The aroma was grainy, & the taste was somewhat bready,very basic less than run of the mill APA.

12 oz. bottle that I received as a gift. Pours a hazy amber with a moderate linen white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace. There is really not all that much happening in the aroma department with this beer other than perhaps a few very subtle wisps of malt. The flavor is malt, somewhat grainy, with just a bit of apple. Mouthfeel is slightly slick with a somewhat thin body. Very mild hoppy finish. Not something I would look to revisit.

Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy orange copper with a small frothy white head that leaves decent spotty lacing. The aroma is a fruity malt with caramel and coriander. Thin mouthfeel with a bready malt and caramel with a nice crisp finish. Easy to drink a good pale ale from Goose Island.

no hops whatsoever, just pale malt. not bad, but not good either. i’d be happier with something i know is good. but at least i get to add another tick to the tally. Bottle at whole foods, miami beach.
Overly sweet. Nice crisp hop profile that hints at some grassy notes, but overall the malt in this one is too syrupy. Pours cloudy copper with white head.

Brewed from organic ingredients by Goose Island for Whole Foods, and sold at a low price. Aroma is lightly sweet and hoppy with a whiff of skank. A light/medium weight ale that tastes like a malty lager, with a bit of citrus and pine. A good brew, and not a bad deal at all.

A sweet aroma with a trace of brown sugar. It’s a very pretty copper color with a large, lasting off white head that laces the glass. It has a smooth flavor with slight traces of hops, a little orange, and barley. Smooth on the palate- a very nice beer! Pairs well with pasta and veggies with garlic/alfredo sauce! :) Actually gets better as it warms-- smoother palate.

Very light flowery aroma with a bit of malt. Slightly murky amber gold color (could it be bc, being from Goose Island?), with virtually non-existent white head. First swig really grabs the mouth; it is full bodied. The taste is lightly flowery, there’s light malt, and the finish is bitter on the edges of the tongue and somewhat on the top(?). Except for the surprising initial impact it’s not particulary unique. However, it is very drinkable - thanks no doubt to Goose Island.

Wow, can't believe I'm only the third person to have this. Didn't realize it was this "rare". Came as a sample bottle from a distributor and I had this as the fifth and final bottle from the set. Pours golden brown with a medium white head. The nose is perfumy like it's brother but has some hints of sweetened malt. The taste is also perfumy and somewhat thick and chalky. It's sort of cumbersome and has little redeeming qualities. My friend Vince and I rather disliked this beer. It is OK, but nothing I'd drink more than a glass of in an evening. We split a bottle, so that's fine. Mouthfeel was chalky as previously described. Finish was hoppy and perfumy. Worth trying I guess, but nothing to brag about.

Medium Gold color, medium head. A medium bodied ale, malty and slightly sweet. Smooth taste. Not very hoppy. Nice flavor. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is smooth and clean. Aftertaste is slightly malty. Nice mild tasting beer.
Excellent golden hue, good foam and retention. Very well balanced and the aroma is a light blend of carmel, cocoa, bushy hops, and fruit.

This beer pours an interesting brown colour that is slightly transparent (You can ’see’ your hand on the other side through the beer). The head is weak, fluffy, and tannish in colour. The flavour is slightly sweet, with malt up front, and a slight sour tinge on the tongue.

First tasted this in the Last Post, Paisley (JDW) in October 1999. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear garnet redf in colour with a thick white creamy head. Distinct note of pineapple in the sweet aroma. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a fiery maltloaf base with syrupy pineapple, cherry, redcurrant and a hint of butterscotch. Slight spicy note in the bitter aftertaste. finish is sweet and malty with vinous cask notes rich in the palate. A decent session ESB.
Pour is amber with almost no head. Nose and taste of sweetness, flowers, malts and a dry finish. Rated 6/15/02

Date: 01/30/2002 Mode: Bottle Source: Whole Foods Market Appearance: Rusty amber, scant head, Aroma: sweet malty aroma wth floral hops, Flavor: light malty and hoppy flavor, nice bitterness, dry finish, touch of honey sweetness, Overall: bottle desc: Rarest fine amber malt balanced with the choicest Worcestershire hops give this beer an intense bitterness leading to a long dry finish. Oxfordshire honey is added to the brew giving a fhuity aftertaste savoured long after the last drop has slipped down. Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Bottled, pasteurised, 500ml. Amber with bubbly white head. Good looking beer, but thats as far as it goes. Harsh bitterness with burnt malt and boiled hop notes. Pungent bitterness on the finish. Unfortunate.
Aroma:good malt caramel aroma... Appearance:brown with chunk of yeast,Light head... Flavor:good bitter,caramel and bitterness...
Cloudy light brown with almost no head. Lots of sediment in the bottle. Aroma is fruity and a bit hoppy. Flavor is pretty plain, but has an almost cidery taste to it.

I might have had a bad bottle, since there was an undue amount of sediment. I wish someone whould tell these English brewers that, if they want to export to the U.S., they need to use brown bottles to minimize possible damage caused by improper handling. Mine poured a hazy nut brown color with a thin white halo rather than a head. The aroma was liquor-like, sweet but piercing. Smooth medium-body, but in flavor almost watery. There’s a nice malty flavor with a touch of bitterness and a wine-like fruity finish. I don’t think what I drank is what Wychwood intended. DiCarlo’s Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL

If this Old Devil is named for the wicked chap on the label, it must truly be a monstrous brew. Bearing a most horrific countenance, this minion of Hell is seen stabbing an angel with his bloody trident, and grasping another with his other hand, as he sneers at us from a graveyard, where he’s also been busy beheading tombstone statues. Must be one abominable ale, right? Appearance: a swirling, carbonated mess that settles into a thick, dull morass of brown, though thoroughly transparent at the bottom, with a creamy, 1/2 " head. Aroma: nutty, spicy, with a certain stinging hop presence and the promise of malt. Taste: bit of hops upfront that disappears quickly...time for another sip..warm, round, nutty flavor, and a short, but not unmemorable finish. Actually, it’s growing on me, leaving more of a mellow fruit flavor ringing around the mouth, but yet a minor one. Bright, but, ultimately, bare. Halfway to being an above-average brew of the ordinary stripe, this little scamp never remotely resembles the frightful demon of the label. Shows me for judging a beer by it’s cover. Nothing Satanic here, just smooth, slightly flavorful, semi-tasty...

This pours a ruby red with hints of dark magenta in the color. A mild head which disappeared fairly rapidly, some mild creamy brown head. The aroma yields hints of a doctors office, yeah, go ahead and imagine that with other hints of leather and caramel malts. Definite caramel malt presence here because the finish is extremely dry. The flavor is fairly refreshing up front but damn does that cardboardy maltiness bite in the end. Heavy sugar candy in the finish, for at least 60 seconds after the sip. Absolutely no alcohol presence. Some almost sappy qualities to the beer mid-taste, somewhat hard to describe. Not the best UK beer ever... I’m ready to move on now...I guess thats what you get when you buy a beer thats in a clear bottle.

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: KRS 110317. THX to Bergstaden. Deep golden color with an off-white head. Aroma is apple, sugar, malt, fruit. Flavor is apple, sugar, malt, fruit, caramel, apple peel. Very easy drinkable beer.

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: Thank you very much for these bottles GT - Hazy amber with off white head - Very good apple aroma - Very good apple flavour - Good apple flavour that lasts for a lonng time - This was very good and tasty

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: 12 oz. bottle. Originally reviewed 2/7/2015. Slightly hazy deep amber. Medium white head. Medium collar. Smells like apple juice, but a little less sweet. A little bit of an earthy aroma. Taste is an unsweetened apple flavor. Earthy maybe isn’t the right descriptor anymore. Slightly acidic. Then the sweet apple juice kicks in. Finishes like apple juice. Medium body. Well carbonated. It’s pretty good, but apple just isn’t an interesting enough fruit for me.

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: Pours clear amber with low white head. Aroma of apple juice, light bread. Taste is apple juice, mild tart apple and green grapes in the finish. Light and smooth body with average carbonation.

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: Bottle 355ml vintage 2015 @ geokkjer [Courtesy of bergstaden] Pours hazy amber/copper with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, sweet red apples and hint of vanilla. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long sweet red apple finish, Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft. 7 4 7 4 14 - 3.6 Bottle 355ml vintage 2016 @ geokkjer [Courtesy of bergstaden] Pours deep golden/copper with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, apple and hint of sourness. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter and light sour with a long apple and malty finish. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft. 6 3 6 3 13 - 3.1

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: Bottle, 12oz, shared by Bergstaden. 2015 edition. An unclear, copper colored beer with a small, off-white head. Lots of apples in the initial aroma, then mashed apples tending towards diacetyl and vanilla. Candy, white sugar. It’s smooth, soft and medium bodied, with flavors of mashed apples, candied apples and some vanilla. Long mashed apples finish. Pleasant indeed, perhaps with an apple cake of some kind. 7-3-7-3-14-3.4 Bottle, 12oz, shared by Bergstaden. 2016 edition. Clearer than the 2015 edition, and a bit lighter in color. More mellow aroma and flavor than 2015, much less apple. Smooth and medium to full-bodied, with a mellow carbonation. Sure prefer the 2015 edition, but it’s a decent beer anyway. 6-3-6-3-12-3. 170311

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: Bottle, courtesy of bergstaden. Pours deep golden with an off-white head. Aroma of red apples, malt, fruitiness and apple peel. Flavor is sweet and malty with red apples, caramel, apple peel, apple pit and malt. Medium body, average carbonation.

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: This Ale totally shocked me! I am not a big into ciders at all so I was a little skeptical to buy it. I am glad I did!! It pours a copper to light amber color with a strong aroma of apples. The taste is all apple with a dry finish. I want more!

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: Fall in a bottle. Not much carb but it’s there, pleasant apple aroma. Taste is crisp apple cider...this beer is everything I love about apple cider in beer form.

column1: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale
column5: The only negative about these are that they are way too easy to drink, so you end up running out of them too quickly. Pours a hazy copper. Aroma is fresh apples with caramel malts. Taste was fresh apples, sweet on the front end, but with a dry finish, allowing you to have multiple beers for further inspection and analysis. These are phenomenal.

Very rich, slightly glowing copper coloured body with a bit of an orange and honey tint and a nice three centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of light biscuity malts, some citrus, a bit of caster sugar, some cardboardie funk and some pale yeast. Light-bodied; Strong biscuity flavours with lighter and less assertive malt coupled with some mellow fruits and grain flavour and a touch of bitterness. Aftertaste shows some grass, caster sugar, funk and a bit of stale malt - nothing too special here. Overall, if you pulled off this label, it would be decent at best, with a lot of mundane flavours, nothing exciting and no real profiles to sample, so sadly, I was disappointed, given the pedigree and the typically good ’classic’ beers from the brewery, but this wasn’t one of them. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from the Edelweiss Shop in Verona, Wisconsin (of course) on 24-September-2016 for US$3,00 by my mom - thanks Mom for bringing another NG beer back from Wisconsin, even though it wasn’t the bes, sampled at home in Washington on 11-October-2016.
Pours a nice golden color with white head. Cereal grains mostly on the nose; follows onto the palate. Nice easy drinking pils.

A very refreshing and well balanced pilsner. Slight sweetness from the malts, toast, light hops. Feel was adequate for the style. Though delicate and complex, it wet down fast. Nice n fresh too. Via heybeerman."

[Bottle] Bright golden pour with a rocky head typical of the style. Sweet grain, grass and light perfume in the aroma. Flavor notes of more grains, cracker, light citrus and mild hop bitterness. Great palate/mouthfeel for the style. Not sure what the availability of this beer typically is, but as of 4/30 the Woodman’s in Kenosha had plenty of it.
Bottle. Realistically, has to be one of the best pilseners I’ve had. Sweet grain, a bit of carbonation, slightly syrupy on the palate. Slight fruit. Delicious.
Bottle @ Aaron’s basement. Clear golden pour with a white head. Apple on the nose. Light malt, some yeast, floral hops, and dough. Flavors of dough, apple, and bread. Floral and some grassy hops.

Clear amber pour with a white head that leaves really nice lacing. Aroma has a sweet graininess to it with a hint of citrus. Taste has some honey sweetness with some grain and a little plastic. Slight bitterness. Medium body.
Gold Color, Big Head, Decent Lacing. Lightly sweet, Light Malt, Light Bitter. Mellow. Soft Carbonation, slightly Creamy. Pretty Good. Enjoyed It. Worth A Try.

Pours a medium golden color with good clarity and a big frothy three fingers of white foam. The nose is very bready, touch of honeyed sweetness and traces of grassy spice. Mouthfeel is crisp, a touch thin but true to style... could use a touch more carbonation...the flavors are very focused doughy bread with a some hints of bitterness. Easy drinker.

Pours clear gold with white head. Aroma is grainy with a hint of citrus. Creamy texture with a little citrus from the hops coming through and some corn bitterness in the aftertaste. Another solid offering from New Glarus.

First time having this. Pours a dark brown/black. Nice head with the subtle smell of coffee. Taste is of roasted malts and cocoa. Low carbonation. Not quite as robust as I hoped, seems to be a little watered down. Nonetheless, I’ll say it’s a decent brew.
From a bottle. Pours dark.brown with a fizzy beige head. Smells like roasted coffee and earthy malt. Tastes like roasted coffee and dry earthy malt. Light body and low carbonation.
Dark brown with a cream head. Aroma is coffee, roasted nuts, and molasses. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Palate is light, slick with soft carbonation.
April 28, 2018 - bottle at Chula Vista. Dark brown pour with some head. Aroma was roasted malt and coffee. Taste was roasted malt with a bit of coffee flavor.

12floz bottle, no date, $8/NG-mix-six, nonic glass. Looks fine dark brown with tan head, but the aroma comes across as cardboard and hints of dry pet food. A pretty basic stout, mildly roasted, vague coffee, and body is medium-light - kinda watery for a stout. Decent if thought as a dark lager, but it's supposed o be a coffee stout.
Mild aromatic and flavorful. Creamy wet and smooth lmao. Good stuff but newglarus never fails
A pretty decent coffee stout with a nice toasty coffee flavor to it. Not super exciting but solid.

Intense, dark roast coffee, dark, toasted malts, chocolate. Hazy black, medium, creamy, beige head. Light bitter and sweet. More dark, sweet, toasted malts, chocolate, dry, but not too bitter finish, soft carbonation. Very decent Stout, well-balanced, nice coffee in aroma. Bottle from brewery, New Glarus, WI.
12 oz. bottle purchased at the brewery. Poured black, lasting tan head. Aroma was coffee, dark chocolate. Taste was creamy, coffee, sweet. Very nice.
Pretty darn good coffee stout. Surprising really. Coffee and chocolate nose. Mild malt backbone, some Char. Mildly bittersweet the whole way. Tasty.
Pours a hazy yellow with a nice white head. Smells citrussy and dry with some nice tarte splashes. Tastes of wheat, some pale malt, pepper, light spice, lactic. Very enjoyable.

Date: 06/18/2005 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Noog I opaque light orange, whispy head, huge sweet banana aroma, creamy body, lots of banana flavor, clean finish, Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
I really liked this Hefe. Spicy, fruity nose and interesting flavor, with clove and coriander (???) and some more citrus fruit. Bright white head with dull golden color.
Reddish orange in color with a white head. Had a great fruity/spicy aroma. Flavor had some clove to it and a great finish.

Sampled at Dutch 70’s "Tasting in the Woods; Part Deux". Pours only slightly hazy golden with a white head. Wheat and light caramel/fruitiness in the nose - not much banana/clove though. Flavor has notes of herbal/grassy noble hops, some caramel, wheat, a little lemon and some light fruitiness. Medium bodied with a smooth texture and moderate carbonation. Somewhere in between an American Wheat and a German Hefe.

TITW Part Deux - 12oz bottle, courtesy of growler. Thanks, Scott!! Light yellow orange; pleasant white head. Beautiful aroma: bananas, cloves, and spice; overflowing. Chewy mouthfeel: plenty of sugar, bananas, vanilla, cloves and spice; slightly watery. Minimal oxidation; crisp, sweet finish. An excellent German Hefe.

Bottle... TITW Part Deux... Cloudy golden ale with a small, frothy, white head. Fruity, beefy aroma with apricot esters; smoke and light clove phenols. The flavor is very sweet, fruity and gently tangy. Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and mild carbonation. Sweet, fruity finish. How many wheat beers does New Glarus brew? Not a favorite style of mine. Thanks go out to growler for providing the bottle!

12 oz bottle This was shared with hezron and malachi at a Friday night tasting of several New Glarus beers. For a two year old hefeweizen it has held up well, though I would love to try it fresh to see how much better it is. I can understand why it is one of the highest rated hefeweizens on the site. Aroma / Appearance - A thin half-finger head bubbled up out of my sampler glass. The body was a cloudy copper color with lively carbonation. It looked as good as a hefeweizen can get. The nose was bananas, wheat, Laffy Taffy, Honeycomb cereal and almonds. I could smell this for a long time. Flavor / Palate - Creamy vanilla and butterscotch open the flavor profile of this beer. A fruity mouthfeel of bananas and some other tastes please the palate before the wheat, bread and malt come through. For a two year old beer it has held up remarkably well. The finish is sweet and dry, teasing the throat. I would love for New Glarus to rerelease this so I could try it fresh.

I’ve had this beer a couple times although it’s been a while. I found a spoiled bottle in my crisper yesterday. Cloudy amber color avg sized fluffy white head w/ decent lacing. Aroma of wheat light bread dough a touch of banannas and some spices maybe nuts. Palate was nice & full. Flavor was shot.. I remember this being a much better beer...

Bottle shared by beerhugger, thanks Steve. Light copper in colour, thin white head circle, some lacing. The aroma is slightly sweet, some apples and bananas, light spice and yeast. The flavour is much the same as the aroma, turning tart and spicy. Creamy mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation. Finishes spicy, some light cloves and lots of lingering bananas. Not to bad.
Bottle. Pours a burnt orange with a thin white head. Bready aroma. Flavours of malt and caramel with a medium body. Low hops in aroma and flavour. Moderately dry finish.

Tried this beer for the first time at the brewery with Jess on our way to Wausau in 2019. Pours reddish orange, thick off white soapy head. Nice malty aroma - a little caramel and soap. Tasty is malt forward as well - bready and smooth.

More like HOPtoberFest. Not really to style. Doesn't stack with the German boys. and is this really a lager or is it an ale? It's fruity. Almost like the Pebbles thereof. this isn't a bad beer, it's good as a generic amber lager/ale, but I don't see how it is Oktoberfest.
Backlog, bottle that pours an amber orange with smaller head. Nose and flavor are dark fruits, bready malts, spice, grain, apples, and caramel. Light to medium bodied for the style. Sweet finish

12 oz. bottle from Tmoney99. Pours a clear dark golden color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have lager malt character, caramel, sweet bready notes, just a hint of spice, a general fruit character, clean, easy to drink but not very exciting.

Last O'fest of the season... Pale amber. Sweet and yeast aroma. Flavor follows... lightly spicy, lightly sweet caramel notes. Definitely sweet on the palate. The yeast and sweet notes are nicely balanced. One of the better O'fests, American style.
Bottle. It pours and amber color with an off-white head. The malty aroma is bready and caramel. The taste is mildly sweet.
Bottle. Pours crystal clear orange, small beige head, goos lacing. Aroma ia roast, nutty, caramel, toast, noble hop. Flavors isia and plus sweet, light bitter. Medium body.

not a big fan of ambers, viennas or marzens but when the weather cools and i stop shaving my balls, i can get down on one .. its got caramel, nicely dry, and is quite full. a solid american example. .. . Cat stares at me, damn those beady eyes!

Got in a trade with The-Adjunct-Hippie. 12 ounce bottle into dimpled mug, best before 1/9/2017. Pours slighjtly hazy orange/light copper color with a 1 finger dense and fluffy off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of bread dough, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness/caramel/pepper, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of bready malt and light earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of big bread dough, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness/caramel/pepper, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Minimal herbal, grassy, spicy hop bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of bread dough, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness/caramel/pepper, and herbal/grassy earthiness on the finish for a while. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of bready malt and light earthy hop flavors; with a nice malt/bitterness balance, and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Minimal dryness. Perfectly clean on lager flavors, with zero yeast notes present. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, creamy/bready/grainy, and slightly sticky mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 6.25%. Overall this is a delicious Oktoberfest style. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of bready malt and light earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to drink. Nothing but rich and clean Pils/Munich malt flavors, with just enough hops to balance the sweetness. A very enjoyable offering, and spot on style example.
Draft at Stamford brewpub. Looks like a Vienna, but unfortunately could be a textbook example of diacetyl in beer. No thanks. Bring me a wine, please. (#4210, 8/20/2011).

Pours coppery gold with a soapy, stubborn white head and nice lacing. Smells of lemons, nuts, pilsner malt, and some mellow grapey elements. Tastes lightly malty with a roasted nutty character. Unusual light fruity elements and some sugar are present on the finish. Mouthfeel is surprisingly thick on this one.
Nice rendition of the classic style. Toasted malt flavor in a light and sharp mouthfeel. Decent hop buzz as well. Good brew.
Draught at brewpub. Fairly light in color with some light malt and a bit of hops to it. Decent.

On tap in pint glass: pours golden orange with a thin white head. Aroma is light citrus and a distinct rye aroma. Taste is cracker malt, light citrus, spice-like flavor from the rye, and caramel. Medium body, nice bitter hop finish, perfect carbonation. Quite tasty!

Visited the brewpub 1/25/2014. Sample glass shows a translucent amber color. Nose is mostly spicy rye and pine hops. The best thing in this brew is the balance. The spicy rye malt and pine hops marry well with the level of toasted grain and biscuit malt. The rye lingers a good amount after the sip. Medium body with correct carbonation level. Decent.

Tap at the source. Pours clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, long retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is spicy rye malt, earthy notes, resin and pine hops. Flavor is moderate hops and bitterness, spicy and earthy rye malt with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Draft at the source. Hazy amber color, bright white head, solid lacing. Aroma of nicely spiced toast. Taste is rich rye bread.

Draft at the brewpub. Light orange amber color. Not much to it at first. After two IPAs this seems a bit vapid. Suffices as a decent sessionable drink. A bit rough around the edges. (#4907, 1/15/2013)
on draft at brewery, you cant really go wrong with rye and ipa. These guys really make a great ipa and rye adds such a great spicy component. Good thickness, awesome pale ale
On tap. Pours hazy golden/amber with a small head. Aroma of spice and light hops. Flavor of dough, hops, and some spiciness at the end. Full bodied.

Listed at 5.6%, growler from the brewery. Hazy medium golden with a 1/2 finger off-white head, low retention. Aroma of some sweaty Cascade hops, moderate sweet rye notes, and some caramel malt, though not too spicy. Flavor still has plenty of Cascade hops adding a bit of a floral note with moderate rye presence,some toasty malt and light caramel following. Bitterness peaks at a 5 in the dry finish. Light to moderate carbonation with a medium body. Pretty good, considering I get whiny when Cascades are used

Serving: Draft at the brewpub It pours a cloudy gold color with a pillowy white head. The nose has some spicy rye notes, grains, a good bit of florals, and some pale malt. The florals really come across in the taste. Light honeysuckle, pale malt, and an understated rye note round out the flavors. Light to medium body with soft carbonation and a lingering floral finish. A very nice rye ale. All I would ask for is a touch more rye.
On tap@Bar Bruselas. 16/11/2019 Lager industrial mala sin mas. tomada en un bar sin mas.

De color ámbar, con cuerpo ligero y carbonatación media, esta cerveza tiene una cabeza espumosa de poca retención. Aroma a malta y lúpulo, una vez en boca resulta agradable, mejor que muchas de su estilo y precio.
Tap. Clear pale golden. Lacy white head. Basically nothing happening here. Some grain and corn aroma and taste. Weak.
Seems more like a lager than a Pilsner. Clean enough with slightly funky aftertaste. Worth trying and is easy enough to drink a few. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap, hazy golden pour with a white head. Aromas of yeast, banana, and subtle spice. Flavor is malty upfront with banana notes in the finish. Very drinkable.

Draft: (re-issue at 5.3%/36 IBU....at brewpub) Very cloudy, light yellow-orange with a small, off-white head. Banana, light wheat, orange aroma. Taste is sweet..banana, wheat malt, a bit of bubblegum...very little spicing.....a light white peppery-ness. A little plain, but solid....not over-spiced like so many others.

On tap in Bloomington (IN) At $2.00 a pint on Sunday afternoons you cannot beat the prices at the Upland draft room. Among the ten taps I went with one of the last pours of a decent hefeweizen that was on its last legs. Assuming you are still sitting on bottles drink them now. If they are still on the shelves wait until next summer to grab some fresh. Aroma / Appearance - The cloudy rose gold body was wrapped under a dense clean white head. Banana nut bread, sweet malts, and lemony notes highlight a fresh feeling beer. It isn’t really at either end of the hefeweizen spectrum but squarely in the middle. Flavor / Palate - Chocolate chips, lemon zest, and orange glaze start with a mild impression. As it moves into the throat it adds some doughy textures and a dash of honey. Almost like a meal in a glass it has a filling presence. With no glaring flaws or major strengths this beer is worth a tick if you catch it on sale.

Draft to taster at Upland. Labeled simply as "Weizen" on the draft board. Looks solid; transparent for a heft though. A very slightly hazy gold with ample white head at dissipates into lacing. Smells of dough and heft yeast with mild notes of clove and banana. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. Okay.

Tap at Brewhaven. Sweet banana, wheat, and citrus aroma. Cloudy golden with a small white head. Banana, wheat malt, and citrus flavor. Medium body. I was looking for clove or coriander, but just didn’t get it from this beer. Good, but didn’t blow me away.

Flight pour on tap at the Indy Tasting Room (Indianapolis, IN). A new rate. Pours a richly hazed golden hue, like a lemon milkshake. Healthy bright glow, good haze, and big cakey bright white head that dies to a thicker film, good lacing throughout. Aromas are rich touches of banana esters, some apple and pear, with firm lemon, touches of spicy clove. Flaked wheat, bready malts. A vibrant banana life comes in and takes hold, touches of lemon and other fruit. Initial is creamy and smooth, light bodied overall, but on the more girth end with banana, a bunch of apple. Gentle lemon, flaked wheat and bread dough. Firm growing estery banana, touches of pear, with gentle spice, more apple and crisp malts into the middle and backend, apple and banana take over, touches of lemon, gentle grassy element. Doughy and crisp cereal malts. Finish is mellow sweet, a touch tangy tart fruit, apples really take over with firm banana, a rich fruity element. Still, quite a drinkable wheat beer. A unique spin. Nose is a bit muttled but flavors are good and the beer is quite pretty.

On tap at Bloomington pub. Pours gold with little head. Nose is strong spices and various bright citrus with background notes of bananas and pears. Flavor is again spicy, lightly citrusy, light bananas, pears, and apples. Also some light vanilla in the finish. Drinkable. Low in malt richness but flavorful. Heavy on the spices. Moderate carbonation. Liked it.

On tap at the brewpub, Bloomington. Fairly nice pour, cloudy deep golden with a decent carbo level. This one’s a money-maker in this heat for sure. All in all it’s a more or less competent take on the style. Bright hops, quaffable and smooth mouthfeel, a bit of yeast and banana (not much evidence of spice). Average.

Reviewed from notes. Pours a cloudy yellow-straw color with a decent head and a bit of lacing on the way down. Nose is some faint banana and even fainter clove along with some light grain. The taste is slightly yeasty with a bit of straw and grain. Light feel with good carbonation. Comes together in the end, drinking fairly well. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-24-2010

On tap at the brewery. Pours a heavily hazed golden with a white head. Cloves are the main aroma with just a bit of mustiness. Flavor also leads with cloves and is slightly tart with wheat, bubble gum, and a bit of sweetness. A solid hefeweizen.

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: 750ml bottle @ the office. ABV 5.0%. Pours a hazy copper colour with a thin white head. Nose is semi sweet apples, apple skins, and some funk. Flavour is a nice light apple character with some funk. It is semi dry and has a slight bitterness to the finish. Very tasty!

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: Bottle - Stone fruit, sweet cooked apple. Cloudy gold with a small white head. Peel and funky fleshy notes with a decent finish. Not bad.

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: 750mL bottle, pours a hazy bright golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out lots of honey-like sweetness, champagne effervescence and grape must. Flavour is bone dry, yet somehow has some honey-like sweetness followed by some grape must, champagne, and funk. Rather oxidized, but it’s suitable. Palate is highly carbonated, but fitting the elegance. Very good.

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: 75 cl bottle, bouche. Juicy apples, spice, some caramle and a touch of butter. Light citrus. Nice nose. Complex. Nice dryness, bit tart, green apple, pits, tanins. Dry, mineral finish with a touch of citrus and apple skin. Good balance, refreshing and crisp. Like it.

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: Clear, golden colored, fizzy, small+ white lasting head. Aroma is of apples, strong apple peel, bit funk, some wood. Taste is medium- sweet apple juice, apple peel, bit woody, light funk, very dry finish, very light to no tartness. Light bodied, average carbonation, watery. Refreshing and light, summer stuff!

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: Bottle consumed at Cropredy ’Fairports Annual Reunion’ Festival, Cropredy, Oxon, courtesy of Bob (cheers Bob) Friday 8th August 2014 Pours warm gold, pleasantly refreshing sweet apple pie cider. A reasonable sweet cider it is a little dry but mostly sweet juicy apples. A6 A4 T7 P3 Ov14 3.4

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: 750ml bottle, cork and cage opening. Clear amber / golden pour with sweet apple aroma. Dry finish. No overpowering taste - like everything has mellowed and blended. Enjoyed this.

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: 750mL cork and cage bottle. I only bought this because JoeMcPhee and Can gave it good ratings. I should have listened to the average. Aroma smells like Motts apple juice. A little bit of sweet apple skins to slightly offset the strong apple. Just a little too much sweetness. Flavor sweet apple up front but ends decently with not dry but way less sweet finish. The strong carbonation helps offset the apple. I feel like the cider starts in a bad place but everything else pushes it forward. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: Thanks to Eugene for sharing - smells kind of "juicy," sweet, like Mott’s applesauce - flavor is simple, but not as sweet as the nose suggests - there is a moderate, balancing acidity - some light calcium/mineral through the middle - finish has some mild phenolics - it’s alright, but a bit simple and sweet.

column1: Duché de Longueville Antoinette Brut Cidre Bouché de Cru
column5: Visual: Sealed with a twisty top + real cork. Be careful this one is a gusher when opened. Pours a clear deep golden orange with a smallish mildy lasting bubbly head, clusters of fast activity, a thin layer of retention. Nose: fruity apple juice but without much sugar, airy and slightly acidic (lvl-4)-pungency Attack: dry, fizzy, yeasty Mid-palate: (lvl-0)-fruity-yet-dry sweetness, medium acidity, (MAIN) oaked apple, yeasty, light lemon citrus Finish: tart & dry apple finish. Summary: This one is deceptively dry considering the rich appearance and lively activity. I appreciate the burst of natural apple flavour but actually prefer my ciders somewhat sweeter. Thus I can’t say I love this one.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: Got it In the big bottle at a Safeway in Oakland. Not too much rye malt flavor, just enough.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: Out the bottle it's a cookie and light caramel aroma. Nice and light. Taste is heavy and basementy. Biscuit and burnt baked goods. Long lasting burnt sort of cookie butter taste.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: From backlog. Bottle at Extended Stay America, Cypress, Ca. Dark amber with offwhite head. Malts, hops, sweetness, rye.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: Tap at ray jays. Copper red with medium white head. Nice malty nose. Taste is perfectly balanced. Good hop character, with heavy sweetness. Very well done. A good beer to always have on hand.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: Draft at Rohnert Park location. Dark amber with creamy head, curtains of lacing. Malty aroma, some funky hops. Taste brings in the rye, dark bread flavors, more of the hops, and leaves with a nice lasting tingling on the tongue. Flavorful.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: Draft. Pours ruddy brown with off-white head and lacing. Spicy nose with bready malt notes. Spicy upfront with bready malt and stone fruit notes.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: Draft pours deep amber with a off white head. Aroma of citrus, spice and caramel. Taste is spicy grains, citrus and some caramel

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: From Jun 2006 Poured from 22oz bottle a deep amber gold with a large head of foam that dissipated slowly leaving a nice billowy layer that stayed for the entire session. The smell is very hoppy with a bunch of grapefruit and spices hitting my nose very nicely. The taste is big on hops up front. Nice flavours of grapefruit and spiciness hit my palate causing me to make a smacking noise. ;^) There's also a bit of malt presence that sweetens it up just a tad mid way through and the finish is the closest this brew comes to being balanced but...no matter how you slice it, this is one hella good tasting IPA that really satisfies in every category. Oh yeah, aboot the 8%abv...not a factor! Bottom line: This is a world class IPA. See it? Buy it.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: $2.19 bottle from Rio Hill Wine. Pours amber with a large beige head. Aroma is heavy rye, citrus (orange), roasted rye. Flavor is bittersweet, with plenty of bitter in the ass end. Orange, rye, spice, licorice, light alcohol, dark fruit, pine.

column1: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale
column5: 22 ounce bottle. Deep amber orange color. Large rocky beige head with clinging lace. Sweet toasted malt nose. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor has earthy, spicy notes. Notes of rye grain, brown sugar and peppery hops. Lots of piney hops in finish. Very flavorful with warming alcohol notes as well. Well done.
Cask at Ye Grapes Mayfair. Copper body with slight head. Nose sweet, floral. Not much taste to it at all. Pretty dull and nondescript.
Amber with barely any head. Aroma of some caramel and some hops. Taste is malty and sweet with some honey. Hints of fruit and bitterness with some hops.
Cask @ Farmers Arms, Swinton. Golden with a small head. Has a good slightly smooth session texture to it but not much aroma or flavour.

Full pint, hand pulled cask at Mr. Thomas Chop House. Near clear copper coloured body. Tiny layer at the top. Malt-fruity nose. Ditto taste, rather jam-like leading to a resin-like bitterness. Watered. A little floury on the swallow, otherwise a quite decent one in great pub surroundings and company with Adam and Finn (Manchester, 22.01.2013).
Flowers IPA Enlish pint cask, clear light rust hue, kind of Flat and watery, bit of a rust taste too 3.0

Sampled this in the Bar Point, Paisley in June 1992. Cask, handpump dispense. Dark amber in colour with a thin creamy white head. Aromatic hop flower bouquet, short on the nose. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives a digestive biscuit base flavour with slight gooseberry fruit notes. Dry dusty hop resins gives a slight bitter astringency to the short aftertaste. Finish has a sweetness of barley sugar fading to leave a dusty resiny palate. A poor session bitter.
Cask, The York. floral aroma. Some caramel and butter. Hint of spice on the finish.
Cask. Light, malty nose. Amber color. Flavor of caramel malt, minerals, pepper hops. Ok but a bit boring.
On tap at the Slug and Lettuce, Birmingham. Pours an orange/amber colour with small head. Aroma and flavour of caramel with light floral hop aftertaste. Drinkable.
On tap at Slug and Lettuce, pours clear bronze. Aroma of bitter English malts and light caramel. Flavour of traditional bitter English malts, light toasted caramel and light spices. Not too good.

I had this beer many years ago at one time when I was only giving ratings to the beers but was too lazy and stupid to write down my thoughts. I will update this as soon as I get my hands on this beer again.
Nice lighter pilsner-like beer. Was nice to stop for lunch and be treated to freshly brewed beers.

I had this beer many years ago at one time when I was only giving ratings to the beers but was too lazy and stupid to write down my thoughts. I will update this as soon as I get my hands on this beer again.

I had this beer many years ago at one time when I was only giving ratings to the beers but was too lazy and stupid to write down my thoughts. I will update this as soon as I get my hands on this beer again.
amber colour, fine lace, well-hopped, nice bitterness ......................
very dark colour, fine lace, nice fruity aroma, full-bodied, lot of character, long berry aftertaste
very dark colour, few head, bitter chocolate aroma with herbal notes, full-bodied, slightly tart, long dry bitter finish
Dark lager. Very nice hop and roasted malt aroma. Very good malt, nice hop. Average palate. Very good example of 'Dunkel'. 32 IBU Beers of Switzerland
orange-amber colour, fruity aroma, orange, slightly spicy - very pleasant ..
An amber beer with a fine head. The nose is loaded with caramel and hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel. A simple but nice beer. Derfinately not a Bitter.

2010-08-25, hand pump at the brewpub, 5-3-6-2-11 Cloudy blond color; creamy head. Smooth and creamy. Very simple aroma, with light fruitiness. Light malt flavor, again a bit fruity, and maybe some diacetyl. 2002-08-02, hand pump at the brewpub, 7-4-7-3-15=36 Hand pumped. Frothy head, but persistent; cloudy orange colour. Sweet fruit aroma, not really strong; but some nice hop. Low carbonation (almost absent), correctly ’warm’, good balance, quite similar to an English pub bitter, just sweeter; quite nice malt and hop in the taste and in the palate, very easy to drink.
red-amber colour, slightly fruity, creamy, bitter but not enough ...........

On tap the at the brewpub. 20/07/2015 one day after the Etape du Tour. Aroma is big root ginger, dirty straw, grains, ginger ale. A bit stale on the nose. Mostly clear orange coloured pour / amber with a fleeting head. Flavour is dry spicy ginger, little sweet caramel, dusty stale dry malts. A bit one dimensional. Palate is dry and dusty, highish carbonation. Uber dry finish, Lingering spicy ginger.

Ginger in colour with a thin lacy white head. Very strong ginger smell with a vinigar element. Tastes like a ginger ale soda with a stronger ginger finish. The finish is very frothy and chewey. I like it but its a bit bland.
Draught at the brewpub. Hazy golden coloured with no head. Fruity aroma of spices and ginger. Fruity flavour of spices and ginger with notes of citrus. Spicy finish.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden orange with no lasting head. Aroma is citrusy and sharp ginger. Fizzy mouthfeel. Citric and sharp ginger flavoured, subdued sweetness. Light bite in the citrusy flavoured finish. I just don’t like ginger.

Bottled 25cl. It pours a clear pale golden beer with a small head. Perfumy nose. Hot taste! Spicy with quite a lot of jasmin accompanied by ginger and elderflower. Light bodied. Very low bitterness. Not much carbonation. Easy drinkable. Some jasmin in the finish which is mainly of ginger. This beer delivers quite a burn in the back of the throat.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, jerc & gregclow - courtesy of blankboy. Very light yellow pour, small thin white head. Strong ginger aroma - fresh root - some honey as well. Thin mouthfeel. Strong ginger in taste, and it is very sweet too - a very unique tasting ginger beer. Refreshing. Spice shelf like! And lemon! Not to bad at all.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, jerc & tupalev - courtesy of blankboy. Pale yellow colour with no head. Aroma of ginger, honey, and harsh, chemical-like alcohol - really strange for such a light beer. Body is crisp and sharp. Lots of ginger in the flavour and not much else. Aside from that weird bit in the aroma, I actually kinda enjoyed this, but I’m a sucker for ginger, so I can see how a lot of folks wouldn’t dig it as much as me.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & tupalev. Pours a clear flat yellow with a spare white head. Aroma is mostly ginger with a touch of honey and candy. The first thing you notice in the flavour is that it doesn’t taste like beer and the predominence of ginger but that’s exactly what a Ginger Beer should taste like so one can hardly fault it for that. I personally love ginger and thought that it tasted pretty good hence my higher rating. I hope more ginger fans rate it as it doesn’t deserve such a low average in my opinion.

Bottle (330ml) - Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc and tupalev - courtesy of blankboy. Poured a slightly hazy pale yellow with minimal head. Aroma - whoa! - ginger, obviously, and sugary honey-sweet malt , floral cheap perfume, and alcohol, but not the good kind of alcohol, this was more like sniffing aerosol lysol. Yuck. Taste was still sweet ginger, with lemon oil, a bit of wheat and perfume. Mouthfeel was very sharp and spicy, not at all like any beer I’ve ever had. Weird.

Headless pale golden yellow body. “Holy crap what is that?” initial aroma leads to ginger, lemon cleanser, touch of varnish and Lysol as Harry pegged. Flavour is dilute ginger with a bit of lemon, ginger ale like. Grew on me a bit after initial shock. Thin watery palate. It’s not healthy or medicinal in any way – It’s just Swiss. - Tupalev

A light orange beer with a small head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and malts. The flavor is matly with notes of what I believe is wheat, which is weird. The flavor is very simple and the body thin.

Bio (organic beer). Poor head. Very nice hop aroma, deep, herbal (very good hop perfumes), honeyish. Good malt and hop, but maybe too bitter in the mouth (too long infusion?); aromatic palate, but same comment. Beers of Switzerland
pale yellow colour, no head, herbal aroma, slightly spicy ..................

It is an average beer. The chateau is a famous place in Lausanne to drink a beer and to eat a really tasteful pizza. The color is orange-brown and troubled. The foam is typical from a stout, creamy and white, low carbonation. The taste is a bit disappointed, watery but there is a side of "prune" not bad, missing some hop

Draught at the brewpub. Hazy orange coloured with a medium sized off-white head. Fruity aroma of caramel and spices with notes of yeast and puke. Fruity flavour of caramel, spices and eyast. Yeasty finish. Boring.
weak and simple. a crystal malt mess with notes of damp moss, scorched rope and wet wood. suffers from poor recipe, poor execution and has a slight infection.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours cloudy dark orange with a small,creamy and dense white head. Aroma is mild roasted malty. Smooth mouthfeel. Nice breadish roasted malt flavour with a nice citrusy hops touch. Nice toffee roasted malt flavour into a smooth finish.
An amber beer with a small collapsing head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and malt. The flavor is pretty bitter and very hoppy and flowery though I can’t pick out the exact flowers.

AKA Pale Ale Thin creamy head; golden blond colour. Very nice aroma of hops and malt. Less interesting malt and hop than the Pilsner, but smoother, lighter and more balanced, both the taste and the palate. Beers of Switzerland
pale amber colour, nice head, spicy aroma, sweet with a dry spicy finish ...
Tap at the brewery. Pretty, glowing, cloudy orange. Nicely fruity nose, banana, melon, orange, light tropical fruit. Flavor is fruity, wheaty, estery. Finishs dry. Light body. Bit of bubble gum.
On draft at the brewery. Pours a cloudy gold with a white head. Aroma of bubble gum. Flavors of wheat and citrus. Smooth finish. Nice weissen.

0.5l flip-top bottle from globus in basel. pours a hazy pale orange with a frothy white head. aroma of coriander, yeast, eggs?, a bit harsh. no bananas? flavour of coriander and soap. something?s wrong with this bottle.

500ml bottle from Drinks of the World, Basel (4.50 CHF): Fruity tasting & pleasant with a lively feel & good, strong carbonation. Lots of flavour with bananas dominating but not overpowering thanks to some bubblegum & various other fruits & flavours helping to balance things out; an excellent offering & definitely the best of the three from the brewery that I’ve tried.
Tap at Fischerstube. Pleasant bananas, crisp, bit with a rather low and short lived foam, thus a bit flat pretty soon. Otherwise a pretty good draft, though.
Nice yeasty banana aroma. Taste is similar with lots of banana and bubblegum notes. A nice weizen but nothing special.

100ml, 5.4 % abv, draught at the brewpub. A wheat haze to golden body. A bubbly ring at the surface. Dotted spots on the glass. Spiced fruity aroma with banana sweetness. Flavours of ripe banana, wheat, and clove with a touch of citrus to the ending. Medium bodied. Not overly sweet, decent version of the style (Basel 27.07.2014).
On tap at the Brewpub. Leicht trübes hellgelbes Weizen mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht hefig, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig fruchtig nach Banane.
Leicht bananiger Antrunk, hell würzig. Erfrischend, die Bananigkeit wird noch etwas intensiver. Hefig, wenig herb. 11/11/10/9//10
Tap @ Fischerstube. Hazy yellow amber, good head. Sour resin grain banana aroma. Clove wheat flavour. Bitter sweet aftertaste. Fairly average hefe.

Draft in the Basel taphouse. Pours dark bronze with a lasting head. Aroma of dark fruit, prunes, raisins. Grainy, malty and sweet in the taste leaving you wanting more. Very easy drinking. A really nice dunkel.

Tap at the brewery. Dark brown with orange tints and a low, fine, thick head. Caramel malt, nuts, raisin, some root beer, chocolate in the nose. Nice and rIch. Tasty malt, brown sugar, caramel. Somewhat thin body, but that’s ok for summer. Bitter finish works.
On tap at the brewpub, dark orange-brown with a fine crema, malty-sweet nose with faint hints of toasted orange, dry-sweet and roasty malt on the palate, light bitterness. A solid Dunkel.
On draft at the Fischerstube brewpub. Pours a clear mahogany with a tan head. Nutty, caramel aroma and flavors. Smooth and slightly sweet finish.
0.5l flip-top bottle from globus. pours a slighly hazy deep chestnut. flavour of nuts, leaves, rye bread, toasted malts. flavour of dark fruits, rye bread, coriander seeds.

500ml on-tap in Fischerstube brewpub, Basel, Switzerland (6.80 CHF): This one was quite a nice, easy going dunkel that was a major step up from the only other Swiss beer that I’ve tried to date (Feldschlössen Original) & the fact there was actually some flavour to this one was definitely a plus. There was plenty of sweetness throughout but it didn’t seem overdone & the balance was quite good with some pleasant bitterness towards the end as well.
Tap at Fischerstube. The dark version of the Lager Hell it seems. A bit less dusty and much more beautiful. Another good beer for its style.
Runder und frischer Malzantrunk. Geringe Bitterkeit, leichte Röstnoten. Süßlich herbes Ende. Gelungen. 10/11/11/11//11
Draught @ Fisherstube , 1/5/2014 Brownish amber red colour, hazy. Good off white head. Good malty flavours with a steely finish, toasty caramel undertones, decent.

100ml draught at the brewpub. Patchy beige head to a clear, amber-brown coloured body. Smell of dark bread and nuts. Mixed taste profile of caramel malts and dark fruits, slightly roasted. Bittersweet endnotes. Medium bodied. Just alright, worked well with our food (Basel 27.07.2014).
Tap at the brewery. Bright, clear gold, tall head. Rich malt, butter, light hop, bread. Sweet and malty, diacetyl, some lemon. De cent but diacetyl really hurts it, even though it is quite light.
On draft at Fischerstube. Pours a clear gold with a white head. Light biscuit aroma and flavors. Smooth and crisp finish. Decent lager.
Tap at Fischerstube. A very malty lager, I like! Sweet on the tongue but not on the palate. Almost a bit like a syrup. Very muddy color though.
Herb getreidiger Antrunk, mild hopfig. Erhöhte Karbonisierung, milder im Mittelteil. Unauffällig herber Nachgeschmack. 10/8/9/8//9
Draught @ Fisherstube Pub, 1/5/2014 So far, Ueli is the best of the Swiss beers i have tried, so far. Good hoppy, slightly hazy straw coloured, bitter Fine aftertaste. Good Session Lager.
On draft. Pale golden color. Malty aroma. Bitter taste with a short aftertaste. Decent beer. Switzerland is super expensive though.
On tap at Fischerstube. Leicht trübes goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht malzig, getreidig. Geschmack getreidig malzig, leicht süß.
Tap @ Fischerstube. Golden yellow, big foamy head. Creamy biscuit malt aroma. Mild corn malt flavour. Quite smooth & good for a pale lager.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a cloudy golden yellow colored body with an inch thick, frothy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is grainy, lightly sweetened pils malts with a good amount of DMS, some apple fruits, and touches of grass. Flavor is similar. Grainy pils malts with a touch of sweetness and a good amount of DMS and acetaldehyde with just a slight grass. Finishes fairly dry and very lightly bitter with a short aftertaste. Light body and a moderate carbonation. Overall, not a very good beer. Thin and off flavored with too much acetaldehyde and DMS.

Draught @ Fischerstube, Nov.2012. Pours hazy blond with a quick dissolving white head. Fresh aroma, malty and a little fruity. Taste is very German, grainy bitterness. Light-to-medium body, grainy finish.

opalescent pale yellow colour, medium sized dense white head; aroma of grains, grapeseeds, even some minimal grape juice, green tea, herbal and grassy, as well as slight cardboard notes; taste of a grainy lager with some citric, grapeseeds and herbal-spicy notes; not bad at all
Having one from the tap at the Kohlmanns in Basel/Switzerland. The beer is orange hazy with a thin head. Spicy smell with a hint of clove. Light carbonation with a slight fruity taste.

3Nov2018 Sweet grain and cereal malts, caramel, molasses, bread. Hazy gold, medium, creamy white head. Light sweet. More sweet grain and cereal malts, caramel, soft carbonation, medium carbonation, medium bodied. Decent for the style. Can shared at Marco’s - cheers!

Tap in the brewery Biergarten. My first MJ500 beer of this trip. Hazy bright gold, tall head. Fresh, yeasty, light malt, herbal hops, touch of lemon. Bready. Medium sweet, bready, great noble hops. Lovely stuff. Crisp, very fruity, nice bitter finish, peppery. Love it. This is one of the few of the lesser-known lagers included in Michael Jackson’s top 500 that still lives up to that badge. This would have been something like a newer craft brewery when MJ first visited, and this beer still have that craft pilsner quality, with huge hops and very late, if not dry, hopping. A wonderfull surprise.
0.5l can from coop in birsfelden, brewed in lörrach. aroma of biscuit, coriander, a hint of flowers. flavour of citrus, green tea. sweetish and slightly astringent finish.
On draft at Fischerstube. Pours a clear golld white head. Toasty aroma and flavors. crisp finish.
Appearance: Slightly hazy, yellow golden. Aroma: Hops, citrus fruit. Taste: Light hops, lots of fruit, citrus. Refreshing. Bought: Basel Zoo, 300 ml tap, CHF 4.20 Info: 27/11-2015
Tap at Fischerstube. Definitely the highlight of this place! A very hoppy helles indeed. Probably as tasty as this style can get.
On tap with Stuart on a sweltering summer evening. Paleish lager, fIrly clean, some hop notes, a touch bread. Soft mouthfeel. Very acceptable.
Herb hopfiger Antrunk mit passend bitteren Noten. Vollmundig getreidig hopfiger Mittelteil, rund, zum Ende fruchtig. 11/11/10/11//11
Draft. Pale yellow color, thick white head, solid lacing. Smooth and bitter citrus taste. Decent.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy dark orange with a small white head. Light fruity hoppy and roasted caramlish to breadish malty. THick breadish malty flavoured, light bitterness coming through. Medium dry and bitter finish, roasted breadish.
