Sampled at Lago Lodge in Nidau. Draught. Appearance: It pours a golden beer with a nicely lasting white head. Lively carbonation. Beautiful lacework. Aroma: The nose is grainy, citrusy, sour with some hops showing up. Biscuity, slightly sulphury. Flavor and palate: Decent taste with hints of tobacco, grain and melon. Bready. Medium bodied. Good bitterness. Sulphury and lactic. Herbal finish. Overall impression: Interesting but not all that good.
orange/golden color, thin head, grassy with citrus and herps,..nice one with emmentaler.
Bottled. Hazy golden coloured. Strange aroma. Sweet flavour with sourish citrus notes. Rather light bodied.

Sampled at the RBESP 2004 Acidic citrus nose. Yellow with floating yeast, low creamy head. Lemons, a bit milk flavor, some pepper. Lightish body, only slightly parkly, but probably lost some pressure during transport.
Light herbal aroma. Hazy, golden color, white head, good lace. Malty, light sweet, light bitter, bit herbal, medium body.

A hazy orange beer with a small white head. The aroma is a little sour - as if it is a low alcohol beer, the aroma also contains notes of hops. The flavor is sweet and slightly spiced with coriander being the most dominant, before a good hoppy end takes over. Thanks to Phillippe (Bov) for shipping this to the European Summer Party 2004.
Thanks to Bov! Hazy blonde colour. Aroma like cookies. Body is tobaccoey, a little fruity (melon) and slightly tart.
Bottled. Hazy yellow. Yeasty, sulphury nose. Flavour is watery, sulphury and just thin. May have been a bad example...?
Draft. Hazy amber color, thick beige head. Aroma of chocolate covered caramel. Taste is roasted coffee and chcolate. Nice
Tap @ Lago Lodge. Pours dark brown with little head. Perhaps served a little too carbonated. Lovely malt aroma. Flavourful, dry. Caramel, hints of chocolate.

really dark brown beer, with a beige head. smells malty, roasty, of coffee,chocolate, has a hint of puffed breakfast-cereals, bittersweetnes. aftertaste is bittersweet, of breakfastcereals, hops, roastyness, and a hint remembering me of liver-bred-spread( le parfait).

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is Roasted toffee, breadish and light liqourice note. Roasted breadish flavoured, light liqourice note. Good hops balance. Mild acidic touch into the finish, vague infection yet with a nice lingering breadish and liqourice flavoured.

Sampled at Lago Lodge in Nidau. Draught. It pours a beautiful dark brown beer with a heterogenous head. Weak aroma - inferior to the flavor. Lovely taste. Great finish with hints of dark chocolate. A very good beer.
Aroma of skunky malts. Hazy, brown color, beige head, good lace. Light sweet, light bitter, bit roasted, medium body, quite neutral.

Dark amber color; creamy head. Caramel and roasted malt aroma, not very strong; note of coffee. Typical Swiss Dunkel, with strong caramel and roasted character: good body strength, dryer in the front and sweeter at the end. Final characterized by the caramel, sweetish, with a background note of roasted barley.
Sampled draught at Lago Lodge, Nidau. Dark brown. Strong coffee aroma. Light bodied, soft texteure. Medium dry, mild and discrete with some coffee in the finish.
ruby colour, fine head, caramel aroma, sweet, slightly toasted, dry but somehow flat aftertaste
Draft Cloudy yellow color, small white head, solid lacing. Huge clove and banana aroma. Taste is sour citrus bubblegum. Medium body. Nice!

1.5 L plastic bottle, courtesy of Bov. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is dry yeasty, estery and spiced. Dry wheaty and phenolic flavoured, light estery fruity too. Ends dry and estery.

Sampled at Lago Lodge in Nidau. Draught. Hazy orange. Strong spicy nose. A lot of cloves in the taste. Sweet. Refreshing. Light acidity. Cloves again in the finish. Pleasant. Not exceptional in my opinion.

[2003-09-22, 8-5-8-4-16] Very strong spicy aroma. Quite sweet, malty and a lot spicy (cloves). Some sweetness in the (good) final. A very interesting German Hefeweizen. [2002-09-15, 8-5-9-4-17] Cloudy blond colour, creamy foam, beautiful lace. Wonderful hop aroma. Malt and hop immediately invading the mouth, pretty sweet. Not a traditional one (it's closer to a lager, it misses the spicy notes), but anyway a great beer.
Sampled draught at Lago Lodge, Nidau. Mustard yellow, cloudy, small head. Strong banana aroma. Soft and rather sweet. Refreshing and very stylish. This is a great little brewpub!

pours a cloudy bright orange colour with a little foam remaining; robust aroma of matured banana, corn and orange peel; slightly oily and with a medium malt body, some finishing acidity brings a good balance; the finish is a bit dusty (yeasty) with more banana notes - clean and very well brewed
Draft. Cloudy variegated amber color, tan head, solid lacing. Aroma of pumpernickel and rye bread, taste is similar. Very nice.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head. Skunky to grassy aroma. Sweet malty flavorued, light grassy bitterness coming through. Bitter, light citrusy and vague grassy finish.

Sampled at Lago Lodge in Nidau. Draught. It pours a hazy amber beer with a creamy off white head. Lively carbonation. Unique aroma with hemp, a huge amount of apricots, elderberries, banana and cereals showing up. Nice taste. Well balanced. Light acidity. Sweet finish. Pleasant. The taste isn’t dominated by the hemp.

[2003-09-22, 9-5-8-4-17] Special, original aroma: elderflower and elderberries, cannabis. Good body, with some sweetness, malty, roun, very well balanced, till a good final, hoppy and quite strong. The Special has improved a lot, becoming a very original one! [2002-09-15, 8-4-7-4-15] Orange, pale amber colour, thin collar of creamy head. Very nice aroma, of hop, lighter than the Blonde and the Blanche. Good malty taste, with a residual sweetness. The malt and hop are good but less interesting than the Blonde; the hop shows up again in a very good final. There is a subtle note quite original, probably the hemp [2002-01-12, 9-5-7-4-13] Gold lager. Wonderful hop aroma, fruiter then the 'blond'. Very similar to the 'blond', equilibrate and nice hop final, but the hemp adds a new element that lightly differentiates it; heavier body.

Sampled draught at Lago Lodge, Nidau Hazy amber with very little head. Fruity and estery, bubblegum and perhaps some hemp comes across. Lovely soft malt character. Mild finish with just a hint of bitterness.
orange colour, full bodied, nice hemp aroma and flavor which are not too overwhelming like in some others hemp beers
This is a fantastic oatmeal stout. I will be getting this one again because I like it so much.

Please note that on my older reviews I used a 100 point scale. To make up for any scoring discrepancies, all palate and apearance scored are assigned a neutralized 3/5. 12/18/02: A Nice dark color with a persistent brown head. This tastes like dark sweet malt and has a nice oatmeal breakfast feel to it. Some chocolate is there when smelling this one. A good recipe.
Dark, dry, roasty. My favorite domestic oatmeal stout so far. Really really good.

Clear dark mahogany with a thin tan head. Moderate carbonaiton. Roasted barley aroma, dry nut skins, oats and light coffee. Thinnish body with notes of oats, barley, dry coffee and subtle but tasty anise. Nicely malted, as always. Deeply roasted and mellow. Dry and quaffable. Finishes a bit thicker and still heavily malted in flavor. A smooth brew. Kudos to the homebrew winner.
Lata 0,5l Dorada con espuma blanca,fina,alta,resistente.Aroma malta,cereales,herbal.Sabor ligero amargor,malta,cereales,herbal,acuosa,falta cuerpo
Ok beer. Low ABV. Too high price for not so high quality. Not standing out from others.
Algo de caramelo y poco más. Cargante en boca. Falla también en el supuesto caracter refrescante propio del estilo. A evitar.
Tipikus Cseh sör, nem nagyon lehet róla mit mondani azon kívül, hogy jó.Nálam hozta az elvárt szintet.
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnieñ z degustacji w ramach uzupe³nienia profilu.
Ich muss sagen, dass es ein durchaus brauchbares Bier ist. Etwa 60% von 100%. Ein Top-Bier ist es aber sicher nicht.

Zwar nicht so bekannt, wie das Schwarze der Brauerei, aber auch ein guter Tropfen. Mit der Brauerei Krusovice hat sich anno dazumals Heineken auf den tschechischen Markt mit einem Qualitätsbier eingekauft. Gottseidank ist der Geschmack erhalten geblieben. Im Glas zeigt sich eine nette Farbe und auch im Antrunk recht ordentlich,
Deep color, not overly bitter - mild hoppiness, pronounced maltiness. Tougher for a classic beer.
Pivu chybí nìjaká vyšší plnost a hoøkost, je pomìrnì zøedìné. Sladovost sice pøíjemná a pìna také drží, ale jinak je toto pivo bohužel slabší. I tak ale díky za zkušenost.
Fles 50cl in Benesov. Maltig, ver weg wat bitters, interessante zoettonen. (7-2014).
On tap near Vysehrad Kastel. Golden color with active carbonation. Smooth taste. Smells like biscuits, which is in the flavor along with a sweet and light bitter refreshing finish.
Prakticky tady pøidávám tento komentáø, jen aby tady nìco bylo, protože zpìtnì dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.

Keg at Soukromy Klub (station bar), 13/07/17. Clear golden copper with a decent egg shell white head. Nose is cereals, grains, light bread, pretty bland. Taste comprises bread dough, vanilla, caramel, sweet notes, light almond. Medium bodied, fine massaging carbonation, semi drying close. Average and lacking flavour.
Výèap Rudolfinum. Tmavšia zlatá farba, biela pena, rýchlo padla. Vôòa sladová, sladká, jemne kukurièná, ovocná. Chu sladová, nasladlá, trávnatá, jemmne horkos v dochuti.
Backlog. Przenoszenie ocen z innego serwisu, z czasów przed za³o¿eniem konta na ratebeer
Beer with gold color, light body, unfiltered style, some foam in the top, soft carbonized, (drunk a 50cl tap beer in St. Patrick, Brno, CZ).
on tap-pours a white head and cloudy yellow color. Aroma is clove, banana, lemon, wheat. Taste is clove, banana, lemon, wheat, nicely balanced. OK effervescence. Easy drinking.

Sampled at the RBSG ’07 Grand Tasting. Pours a cloudy golden yellow brew with an average white head. Aroma of light wheat, yeast, strong banana esters, and a touch of citrus zest. Taste is medium bodied, dry with some clove and banana in the background. Finish is slightly dry and good balance of yeast and malt. Nice to see the historical Richbrau brand has returned after being lost for over 30 years.

RBSG 07. This is a solid hefeweizen. The aroma has banana, and more than usual. Flavor has light wheat, citrus, and a little more banana. Well balanced. Proper, cloudy appearance but no visible sediment.
Sampled at the RBSG 07 Grand Tasting. Cloady orange bod on this light yhellow pour. Standard banana nose and taste among the wheat/grain flavor.
Cloudy orange body with a small creamy white head. Sweet banana aroma. Sweet banana flavor with some light caramel in the background.

A pleasant surprise. Hazy lemon yellow, slight head. Nice aroma of lemon and cloves. Grainy wheat flavor gives way to a slightly sour, quenching beer with some nice phenols going on, clove, lemon, and slight banana. This was a really nice hefe.

Draught @ Old Dominion Beer Festival 2005: Very cloudy, opaque yellow with a medium frothy white head that lasts. I was pretty excited to see that they definitely were not filtering this one. Aroma has banana, clove, bubblegum, sweet fruity yeast. They definitely didn’t hold back with the yeast on this one, and I like them for it. Taste is light banana & clove, with sweet but not cloying wheat, and has generous helpings of yeast. Full bodied, moderate carbonation, rich & creamy texture. This was one of my favorites at the festival, though it seems many other ratebeerians and also my friend disagree with me, it may be that I was just so excited to see an unfiltered Hefe in a sea of pale ales.

Draft at Old Dominion Beer Festival 2005... Very murky, yellow ale with a small, creamy, white head. The aroma and flavor are filled with banana and clove. Well-balanced and extra light-bodied. Watery mouthfeel with lively carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish. Not very good, even for a hefeweizen.
I am a wheat beer fan and this was a good hefe...golden and hazy in appearance with a slight head...aroma and flavor of bananas and other frutis...very refreshing nice beer.
Cloudy gold. Nose sweet with some bubblegum. Flavor is sweet with clove and wheat, malts have a nice cookie character. Bubblegum and lemon. Dies a bit at the end, just doesn’t have quite enough malt.

Purchased at LCBO while on vacation in Thunder Bay area. My 330mL bottle stated 5.5%ABV. Poured a cloudy pale golden color with white head diminishing quickly with little to no lace. Aromas of orange zest and yeast. Taste is lightly sweet with some citrus and yeast. Light bodied and slightly below average carbonation.

Originally rated November 2008. Bought at the LCBO, with an added sticker written 5.5% alc./vol. Pours a pale golden-yellow colour that is hazy. Carbonation is decent, with a small white head that does not leave much behind. The aromas are very mild with little orange zest and Belgian white yeast. A refreshing mouthfeel that is semi-crisp. Again, not much to the taste. A little citrus, a little yeast and a little apple aftertaste. Not much here at all.

[1995-20090213] Bottle. Sweet heavy celery yeast and floral toasted hay aroma. Slightly hazy, pale yellow body with a long-lasting creamy white head and some central bubbles. Mild floral yeast flavour with toasted sweet hints of corn. Light-medium body. Good.

330 mL Bottle picked up at an LCBO outlet March 26; Best-Before Date 05/09. Pale cloudy straw yellow body, very lively carbonation with a small quickly dissipating soapy head leaving some lacing. Grainy-yeasty aroma with a hint of lime. Very sweet but thin in the mouth, as if a sweetener was added, wheat stands out in the taste along with notes of pear, bananas, citrus, peach, and green grapes followed by a whisper of cloves. C’mon, Belgium, you can do much better :(
Draft. Amber beer with a cream head. Malt aroma. Malt and light cocoa flavor with light backing hops. Medium bodied. Malt and light cocoa linger with light backing hops.

On tap at brewpub in Brattleboro, Vermont. Pours amber-brown with a tiny spritz of light tan head and lacing. Aroma: faint caramel, fruitiness. Flavor: caramel, pears, peaches, raisin brown bread. Mouthfeel: light- to medium-bodied, a bit thin.
Pours a clear amber-orange with white head. A caramel malt and fruit aroma. A malty base with fruits and caramel that also linger.
Golden amber pour with aroma of bread, caramel, and grape. Grape and caramel sweetness with a solid bread backbone. Very nice beer.
dark yellow grapey nose. Sharp mineral taste with grape and strawberry and kiwi quite liked this one.

22oz bottle. Pours a red hued amber color with a massive clumpy,frothy, patchy off-white head. Big hop aroma. Piney, yeasty and a tad fruity. Taste is grapefruit citrus, but the sweet malts seem to smooth it out some., into a bready taste, like a fresh baked sour dough. Light to medium body, with moderate carbonation.
Bottle. Pours muddy caramel orange with off white head. Nose and taste of caramel toffee, malt, orange peel and citrus. Touch of sea salt. Finishes bitter. Medium body.

Deep coppery amber in color with a humongous foamy tan head. Slightly tart and sweet, with a maltiness combined with fruit (grape, cherry, orange). Not very bitter, but there is a hint of hops to the finish.
Nice gold color; Light to medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, some yeast, & light floral hops; Flavor of slight sweet malt, some yeast, grain/cereal, & some citrus; Better than average lager.

Slightly merky, golden with hardly any head. Pilsner-like aroma. Sweet on the tongue, gets a little bitter at the end. Quite good, actually. Needs to be cold on a hot day. Better than any pilsner but nothing against some really good stuff.

Bottle. Pours golden with a white head. Aromas are nondescript corn, grain and cheap whiskey. The flavour profile is not quite as pungent... being creamier, with a honey flavour note and more balanced than the average macrolager. Nothing to write home about but, overall, more correct than the majority of flawed pale lagers.

Színe klasszikus arany, habja nagyon sûrû, krémes hófehér. Illata alap láger, pici gyümölcsösség is érzõdik a háttérben. Az üveg szép, de összetevõk nincsenek rajta, én kukoricát nem éreztem, de picit édeskés. Sõt. Édes. Elég érdekes, mert nem "büdös kukoricas", inkább különlegesen, lágyan édes. Komlót nem tolták túl :) Nem az igazi.

Zasada terroir znakomicie dzia³a w przypadku tego piwa - lekkie, wyraŸnie s³odowe, minimalna goryczka - w ka¿dym razie na Kanarach smakuje dobrze. Obawiam siê ¿e jesieni¹, gdzieœ na Mazowszu lub w Wielkopolsce by³oby takie samo jak ka¿de inne piwo koncernowe. A tak, to dostaje 2.8/5. Dodatkowo plusik za ³adn¹ butelkê i etykietê.

33cl Bottle from SPAR Maspalomas. Clear deep golden colour, white head. Aroma is sweet, corn, some toffee, light malty. Flavour is medium sweet to sweet, toffee, hint of toast, corn syrup, light malty, hint of metal, soft bitter finish. Light bodied. Highly drinkable.

330ml bottle. Pours clear golden colour, medium sized white head. Aroma is grainy, malty, quite sweet. Taste is rather sweet, grainy, malty, quite watery. Light body, average carbonation. Very light, watery lager
Buena cerveza de estilo industrial light lager ligera de cuerpo y alcohol pero con sabor a cereal
Suave, color pálido, notas a miel. Suavemente carbonatada. Bastante buena para su rango de precio.

Bottle at the Fira, golden with a tight foam, corny sweet nose, then honey-sweet on the palate, a little dry malt and a slight bitterness. A bit dull, and my dog is more Alsacian than this, but it's inoffensive and probably OK to wash down food.
A friend drank it and said he got pretty drunk. He bought it in Torrance LA and was in party mode after one. Taste was ok. I like it!

This beer is cheap and great! If you don’t like IPA beers then this probably isn’t for you. This is a great pregame beer. Also a beer on the budget that gets the job done. Who doesn’t like a little buzz of a beer. Cheers!

Here's the simple reason why this brew gets a bad rap in USA - most beer drinkers here are not accustomed to a what is really a normal (unfiltered by law) alcohol content of a "malt liquor", which is a marketing made up term for BEER that usually signifies something cheap and high in BAC content (St.Ides, Old English, Colt45, etc.) It is actually a very decent brew that offers one an opportunity to enjoy how real beer is made before state/federal regulations get to it and water down the flavor. And to the idiot (lehers) that thinks that it tastes like coors light but with more alcohol - I strongly suggest you not only seek professional help to check your taste buds, but also stop drinking beer altogether. You are wasting too much of your money and beer that others can actually enjoy.
Very strong alcohol content, standard beer flavor, but it feels extremely carbonated. Tastes very medicinal but gets you buzzed faster

Okay so basically I found this beer at Walgreens and noticed it was 8.1% so I bought it because I wanted to get sauced fast. Little did I know, this tastes just like shitty coors lite. If u like coors lite, you will love this. However, I hate it and was pretty disappointed. Although, it is super cheap and I should have noticed you get what you pay for when it comes to beer.

I know it's all a matter of taste and individual perception, but I don't know how some people here have given this beer a 1 or 1.5 rating. I have tried almost every beer sold in the USA, and this is undoubtedly one of the best, if not the best. Besides the aroma, the color, the taste and the high alcohol content, I don't get migraines from drinking this beer! Almost every other brand triggers my migraine. Fan for the rest of my life.

Best beer so far and by far! I tried so many other beers and I'm not saying that they all bad but the STEEL RESERVE is by far the best! I like the full aroma, great taste over all! The perfect beer for somebody who likes it a bit heavier and hoppier! The price is right too! I wished it would be available in my area just like any other beer! Why is it so hard to come by? Even after I put a special order in my local store, it is hit or miss to get it! I even tried on line, but much better!

Bottle for 2000! A: Pitch black with a very light head.N: Leather, oxidation, earth, malted milk balls, some toffee, molasses, smoke and treacle. Peppercorn and some cocoa.T: Very sweet. Bitterness from the age.M: Medium body, no alcohol, good carbonation.O: A real treat. Having this next to 2010 and it?s more mature.
Bottle thanks to Luke. Pours a clear red brown with almost no head. A big oxidized cherry nose. The flavor is big sweet cherry, toffee, pine, caramel. Smooth. Very good. Has held up.
Magnum at TalkBeer Charity Event- pours brown- nose and taste of candied fruit, sherry, oak, burnt caramel - medium body

14 years old still rich and complex. Pours thick amber like cognac with no bubbles at all. Aroma is less sweet more dark fruit malts with some liqueur notes. Flavor brings burnt and sweet boozy toasted malts that go down smooth with remnants of spice. Oxidation is minimal.

At Holiday Ale Festival in Portland. Pours light brown with a cream head. Aromas of cola, cherries, spices and whisky. Tastes of rye, sour, chocolate, dark fruits, has a bit of an alcohol burn...think it’s more than 7%
12 oz. bottle; thanks alex for cracking this one; clear dark brown; no head; caramel and oxidation; smooth drinking and a little harsh; oxidation is there plenty; smooth, old, creamy texture

Tap @ Holiday Ale Fest... What a historic beer to have by such an innovator in craft beer. Poured hazy/cloudy dark brown/ruby-ish with an off-white head. Way past its prime here unfortunately. Leafy, oak, mild yeast. Oxidization lent towards caramel and berry fruit juice.

Appearance: Pours out a very dark, garnet-hued body with a scant, bubbly head (though it’s a bit of stretch to call it that). Smell: Sweetish dark caramel malts, touches of toastiness and woodiness as well, and a fruitiness of cranberry and cherry compote. Tiny sniff of chocolate, too. Taste: Modestly sweet maltiness akin to dark caramel and brown sugar rounded out with a nice level of toastiness. Subdued cocoa hints. Subtle herbaceous, though the hop bitterness has all but deteriorated over the last decade. Punchy fruitiness carrying over from the nose. Little spritz of sherry. Very light alcohol warmth on the malty finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-low carbonation. Drinkability: Though time has tired this one out somewhat, it’s still a pleasant, decade-later sipper. Now, then, on to the 2010!
tasting on 7/30/10. deep red pour with no head. big aged malts and caramel on the nose. medium to thin body - dark fruit throughout with caramel, apple and yeast. past its prime in my opinion.

Pours an amber red color with no head. Aroma is fruity, tobacco, roast, coffee, toast, chocolate, and a touch of roast. Flavor is caramel, roast, chocolate, toffee, some tobacco, and a chocolate roast finish.
good aroma of hops. nice amber color, not too much head. very assertive hop flavor/bitterness, with solid body of malt to balance it out. not my favorite style, but this is a good version of it.
Rated the Stoudts Y2K IPA bottle. Pour is golden amber. Taste is very sweet molasses, resins and hay. Rated 11/27/2000

750ml bottle Y2K consumed in 2007, yes i should have know better. Amber body with a white foaming head. Hops were a bit soapy as to be expected. Caramel pine and some faint floral characteristics. Warm and malty. Eh.

750 ml bottle. Pours a deep, slightly hazed red with a moderate off-white head that lasted though the first third of the glass and left partial lace. The aroma is grotesquely sweet. Sweet caramel, honey and rotting apples are all present in the nose. Thankfully, the flavor in no way resembles the aroma, although it is hard to escape without inhaling a bit with each sip. Caramel and malt up front followed by some musty apples. Light bitterness at the finish. Were it not for the off-putting aroma, this would be a decent IPA.

NICE brew sweet with amber and hops piney and with citrus -basic grapefruit- there is also a bit of other fruit flavor. sweet tawny and maybe musty never had it before. how i made this one boys you wish you could know! helps to be surrounded by women from a very young age, and certainly worth the effort. prune and raisin way in the back of the flavor profile. this is gonna be a good year!
Cloudy amber colour with a creamy beige head. Light caramel sweet and hoppy piney aroma with fruity notes. Caramel sweet, hoppy fruity flavor with pine bitter notes.
Bottle. Blind tasting. A dark amber beer with a off-white head. Makt, fruit and a great balanced hop doze, the taste s also great. Medium body with a light sweet, bitter finish. I like this one.

Bottled. Tasted blind. A hazy amber beer with a lazing orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of grass, citrus, and malt. The flavor is swweet malty with notes of citrus and grapefruit. I find the body thin.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy ofBrianK. Comes as "Stoudts Y2K IPA". Pours an almost clear amber golden with a beige head. Fresh and fruity nose. Medium body, soft mouthfeel with fairly sweet caramel notes and a soft and smooth finish without much bitterness. Pleasant and drinkable. 190408
Hazy orange with medium off white head. Sweet fruity aroma with notes.off hops, grapefruit and and caramel. Sweet flavor that holds hops, caramel and fruity notes. Ends bitter.

From old tasting notes. Hazy copper red color topped by a rocky beige head. Wonderfully spicy toasted malt aroma. Flavor mirrors nose with floral hop notes. Complex, bittersweet malt flavor is balanced nicely by the spicy hops.
On tap at the brewery. Pours out a crisp golden topped with a white head. Nose is wood grain and some grassy hops. Taste is more of the nice wood notes and a light pale hop.

10oz on tap at Cock & Bull in Hyde Park for $4.25. Clean, toasty flavor up front, mild earthy hop. Touch of caramel. Pretty on-point. Moderate bitter taste, lighter sweet, nice dry finish. Great kind of herbal and toasty malt aftertaste. Half hazy amber color, with dark particles suspended within. Bubbly off-white head, leaving good webs of lace initially, but it fades to a minimal ring with some bits. Lighter to medium body. Light carbonation, kind of crisp. Mild slick texture. Mild hint of butter, not noticeable until the end. Very nice english-style bitter. Complemented my burger & fries perfectly.
473 ml can. Bought near Mendoza. Grass smell. Very ckear color. Taste is kind of good, grains. Ok.
Consumed various places in Argentina. Currently at iguazu falls. Pretty non descript. Wet. 100% malt apparently. Could be fosters.

Cerveza ligera, aroma casi total a Malta, gusto a cereal y levadura casi nulo amargor, leve gusto a metálico. Es una de las cervezas industriales mas baratas del Argentina, pero es totalmente bebible y cumple con su etiqueta de "100% Malta". Una buena opción precio calidad. Si bien hay varias industriales que son superiores
De las mejores cervezas industriales. Muy buena relación precio calidad. Fácil de tomar y muy refrescante a la temperatura apropiada.

On tap in some restaurant at Tigre. Pours golden yellow colour with moderate white head which disappears quite quickly. Malty bit corny aroma. Malty and bitter taste. Rather bitter and watery aftertaste. Light bodied, usual macrolager.
This is an excellent light lager. No real complexity, but good flavour and easy drinking. Crisp is a good adjective.

500ml can at a KFC in Buenos Aires. Enjoyed straight from the can. Dry malty taste with a bit of hops. For SA lager this one has a surprising amount of taste. Nothing special, but for market lager this might be even above average.
Notes from the South America trip, drinkable lager, nothing too special. Wouldn’t search out but better than much of the beer available in SA

Color, de pajizo a dorado. Espuma de baja retención pero blanca y cremosa. Aroma, Malta y más Malta. No logro encontrar lúpulo. Sabor, como indica su etiqueta "doble Malta", el grano es lo que más se siente. A temperatura indicada es muy refrescante. Tiene un buen cuerpo, ni demasiado ligera, ni demasiado pesada. Lo normal en una lager de calidad. A comparación de otras Lagers industriales del mercado, esta se encuentra por encima de muchas.
(600ml bottle) Pours a clear yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of corn, herbs, and light citrus. Flavor of grain, caramel, lemon zest, and grass with a moderately dry finish.

column1: Black Mountain South Of the Border Porter
column5: On draught at the brewpub, adjacent to the brewery in Cave Creek, AZ. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that leaves behind a thin ring and some film top. Aroma of dark roasted black malt, some flowery hops, a touch of chocolate and sour caramel. Taste is medium to full bodied, light carbonation with flavors of toasted dark malt and some hint of chocolate. Finish is slightly sweet with a toasted malt aftertaste.

column1: Black Mountain South Of the Border Porter
column5: 12 oz. bottle my brother picked up at the brewery - Pours a dark brown color with a thin, light tan head. Aroma is light roasted malt. Flavor is also roasted malt. Light to medium body. A slight fizzy mouthfeel. A decent beer.

column1: Black Mountain South Of the Border Porter
column5: Aroma was burnt like the odor after burning wood. Little musty bar aroma. Black body with small tan head that was gone in seconds. Bitter bite at first but a sweet malt at the finish. Carmel aftertaste. Avilable in bottles at the Satisfied Frog in Cave Creek.

column1: Black Mountain South Of the Border Porter
column5: Bottle poured black with a small dissipating head. Sweet malt and caramel aroma with a roasy malt flavor, medium body and sweet finish...cool label. Thanks beer hunter!

column1: Black Mountain South Of the Border Porter
column5: Chocolatey color with smoked head. Sweet on the nose. Smoked wood flavoring. Their best.

column1: Black Mountain South Of the Border Porter
column5: The beer pours a deep brown to almost black with some ruby highlights, the head modest and somewhat creamy, the color a light tan and as it dissipates a nice clinging sheet of lace forms on the glass. The sweet aroma of toasted grain with a hint of caramel combines with the fresh crispness to make a pleasing to the senses nose, sweet malt laden start leads to a middling top. Finish is pleasantly acidic, hops are spicy but not overpowering and the semi-dry aftertaste is a pleasant ending to a quite nice middle of the road porter, and one I enjoy whenever I get a chance to get out to the “Satisfied Frog”, for a porter and a pulled pork sandwich, some real yummies for the tummy.

On draught at the brewpub, adjacent to the brewery in Cave Creek, AZ. Pours a clear golden pale blonde brew with a fast dissolving white head that laves behind a thin white ring and a film top. Aroma of light bready malt with a touch of citrus, some flowery hops and some honey. Taste is light to medium bodied, light carbonation with mostly a light grain malt with a touch of citrus. Finish is smooth, creamy with a semi-sweet fruity malt and citrus aftertaste.

Pours pretty clear for a wheat, with little head, and little lacing. Aroma is rather odd, not sure what it was exactly. The taste is the same, rather odd. Not a typical thicker wheat style, with banana and fruit scents and tastes....Funky aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle from my brother - Pours a hazy golden color with a 3/4 thick white head. Very light spotty lacing. Aroma is light grain and diacetyl. Not your typical Hefe aroma. Flavor is light grain, diacetyl, and light citrus. Slightly bitter palate. Light body. I’ve had better, but worth a try if you can find it. Thanks Bro.

Grainy aroma and also bitterness stands out. Hazy Yellow body with white fizzy head that was gone fast. At first I thougt maybe the lables at the brewery got mixed up. Flavor was the same as the Frog Light bitter. But as this warmed up had a somewhat lemon flavor ligering on palate.

The beer is a “Chill Hazed” light gold or lemon yellow, take your pick, portly white head, creamy in texture and the residual lace a fine covering for the glass. Nose is lemon like, hints of wheat or “bread dough”, once again your choice, quite a pleasant nose with a sweet start, top is fair to middling in feel. Finish is crisply acidic, the hops are mild but flavorful in their spiciness, dry long lasting aftertaste, a great beer for the hot Arizona summers, tap only at this time.
From file last updated 2010. Bottle. Amber pour. Malty aroma/flavor. Sweetish.

On draught at the brewpub, adjacent to the brewery in Cave Creek, AZ. Pours a clear light copper amber brew with a creamy off-white head that has some good retention and lacing. Aroma of light caramel malt, a touch of citrus and some apple juice. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with a caramel and apple malt flavor with just a hint of citrus zest. Finish is slightly bitter with a sweet caramel aftertaste.

Pours a nice amber color...and thats it. No head, no lacing, no aromas, no bitterness, no malt character....extremely bland, except for that bad taste it leaves in your mouth. Not good at all! Bad actually!

12 oz. bottle part of a mixed 12er from my brother in Mesa - Pours a clear amber color with a one finger thick off white head. Head fades pretty quick. Very light spotty lacing. Aroma is a toasted malt with a touch of diacetyl. Flavor is much of the same. Medium body. Worth a try, I guess.
At Black Mountain brewpub. Light amber in color with no head. Faint sweet malt aroma in the nose. Light bodied, with a touch of carbonation and sweet malt flavors. Boring and weak.
Bottle poured a nice dark amber with very little head or lacing. Aroma is all malt and very sweet. Flavor is sweet malt with maybe just a hint of hops. Finishes with a metalic, very bland aftertaste.

Aroma is like candy, sweet licorice. Amber body no head to speak of, bland other than body color. Sweet malty flavor that is dry on the finish. Man I would want something more refreshing than this on a hot Az summer day.
Light amber hue. No head. No carbonation. No aroma. Malt/caramel liquid. No bitterness. Bad.

The beer pours a nice golden amber color with a modest head and pertinent lace to cover the glass. The nose is all malt, crisp fresh and clean, quite pleasant to sniff. Sweet at the start, top skinny, and the finish stinging it its acidic bite, the hops adequate, dry and lingering aftertaste, a drinkable beer and one suited for these hot climes.
From old J tasting notes. Hazy orange gold color topped by a bubbly white head. Overly sweet malt nose. Sweet malt flavor is reminiscent of bubble gum. Faint hops in finish. Not very good.

On draught at the brewpub, adjacent to the brewery in Cave Creek, AZ. Pours a clear golden pale blonde brew with a creamy white head that has some good lacing and retention. Aroma of slightly roasted mujlti-grain white malt, a touch of citrus zest and honey. Taste is creamy, smooth, light to medium bodied with flavors of light bready malt and some citrus zest. Finish is slightly water, some malt flavor and then a clean aftertaste.
Basically the average pale style lager...well, average in taste. Nothing great about it. Bland, lacking character in all aspects. Decent at best

First whiff of this one thougt I had a Miller Lite. Aroma of lite pilsner beer gainy. Gold body small head that goes flat. Light bitterness to the flavor. Clean and fresh I would have to disagree. Kind of stale on palate.
Light yellow with lacy head. Sweet scent. Malty. Mellow. Average........
Unimpressive to say the least. Drinkable to say the most....................

On the pour a translucent gold with a decent white head that is frothy in texture, the lace adequate to cover the glass. Nose is fresh, crisp and clean, start is somewhat sweet, and the top thin to middling in feel to the palate. Finish is moderate in carbonation, the hops apropos to the style, a beer meant for the hot times of the year, drinkable but as I said before lagers, just don’t do a thing for me.
From old tasting notes. Hazy yellow gold color.mcreamy white head. Sweetish wet cardboard aroma. Tangy sweet malt flavor I somewhat flavorful. Light hop finish.

On draught at the brewpub, adjacent to the brewery in Cave Creek, AZ. Pours a clear golden pale blonde brew with a creamy slow dissolving white head that leaves behind some spotty lacing. Aroma of light bready malt, a touch of citrus zest. Taste is light bodied, some carbonation with a watery citrus grain malt flavor. Finish is crisp, clean cut with no aftertaste what-so-ever. A typical diet beer.

Had this on tap at their brewery...not very good. Pours very light with not much head...very little lacing. Hop character lacking, malt character shines through, but nothing to write home about. Very bland, but normal light lager. Would rather a Bud Select anyday.

12 oz. bottle my brother picked up from the brewery this past Winter - Pours a clear light golden color with a one finger thick white head. Light spotty lacing. Lively carbonation. Flavor and aroma is diacetyl. Medium body. Not bad.
Aroma was skunky. Good gold color to the body. Had a very small fizzy head that was gone in 30 seconds. Got a bitter beer face at first gulp. Good thing I was using this for dinner wash.
Nearly clear yellow. Cucumber sweetness. No bitterness, little malt. Unimpressive.

The beer pours the prototypical lager golden yellow with a modest white head, frothy in texture and a bright white in color. Nose is citrus crisp, fresh and clean, somewhat sweet like the start, top is thin in feel. Finish has a prickly acidity, the hops are mild as one would expect and the aftertaste dry and lingering. In all honesty lagers and pilsners are not my style of beer, but it is a drinkable beer as it thirst quenching and made for the hot desert summers.

As it sets in the glass a light gold color, the head personable in size, frothy in texture the color off white and the lace a fine sheet to seal off the glass. Tangy lemon aroma, sweet, crisp and refreshing is the nose, start tangy sweet, nice malt profile with the top light to medium in feel. Finish crisp and refreshing, hops mild and pleasant, somewhat dry aftertaste. A good drinking beer for the hot summer months, tap only at this time.

Hazy dark gold with a white head. The aroma was bready with some mushrooms. The taste was bread crust and peanut shells. Light and bland overall with a soapy finish. The body was flat liek all of their beers on tap.

Very light with some assertive maltiness, slightly sweet with a bit of a grainey texture. Crisp and clean, light bodied and is decent on a hot summer day, but not something I would regularly choose to drink.
Draft: Nothing in the way of head, like all blondes easy on the eyes. Nothing reall there in the way of aroma, a bit grassy was the only major taste a little bland.
Bright yellow with a razor-thin head. Candy character, almost gumbally. OK if you like a sweet malty beers.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a golden color with a medium head. Medium carbonation. Has a happy aroma of grain. Pleasant and moderated malt flavor to the taste. Smooth palate with a crisp finish. Not my favorite style, but a competent entry nonetheless.
Okay, with a bad aftertaste. Almost acid-like. More of a beer for people who don’t like microbrews, as this also seemed flat. Probably tastes a lot better outside on a hot day.
A light and refreshing beer, nice light maltiness. Very smooth palate and finish. Not much carbonation. Okay for summertime, or for those who don’t normally drink good beer.

On tap at the river market brewery. Pours a clear and pale gold with a small white head. Not very lacy. Some light smells of earthy and piny hops with a breadlike character. Pale malt gives it a little sweetness. Taste is really light, not as hoppy as other cheap microbrews (like a Boulevard), but the light pale malt taste balanced well with the limited amount of hops. Overall, meh.
24 oz pour is golden with a white head. This batch is light on the hops wet grain and balanced maltiness. This beer varies from pretty good to very average depending on the batch.

On tap at the brewpub Pours pale golden with a bit of white head. Light earthy hop aroma, with some grainy character and light esters. Balanced, but light, hop and malt flavors. Light body. High carbonation. Balanced finish. Very avarage, but it managed to quench my thirst.
THis was not the greatest pale ale that I have ever tried, but it was certainly quaffable.
On tap: A decent beer here. It had a browninsh amber color with a thin whispy bubbly layer around the edge of the glass. Aroma was a little malty. Taste was a bit of caramel, and steady dose of hops.
Nice eye-appeal ... with a beach-wave-foam of a head that’s still stuf-like after 15 minutes. Mashy aroma, milky texture with an almost sweet, almost hoppy flavor. so-so.

On tap at the Brewpub. Dark gold in color. Medium palate. Slight buttery flavor. Some bitterness at the finish. Slight hop aroma. Nothing harsh about this one. It just seems to be there. Probably my least favorite from what I think might be KC’s best brewpub.

Nice pale ale. Not nearly as good as the India Pale Ale. Nice clear brown color, again with little to no carbonation. Light hoppiness and bitterness that pale ales are known for. Almost tasted water-down. Still good, but not terrific.

Update: Okay, I don't know what's going on at ol' River Market, but the beer I sampled tonight was like a brewer's first and none-too-successful recreation at a guess of what this once tasty brew must have been like. Faint aroma of lightly bready malt, some lightly citrusy hop. Dark golden color, hazy, no head or effervescence. Flavor has a slight amount of malt sweetness, then some sourish, lightly tinny and citrusy hop flavor washes in, leaving nothing in its wake. Watery palate, distinct lack of body. Finish is bitter but bland. This is a mere shadow of its former self. Too bad. Original rating: This beer is a hop-lover's friend. Very nice Pale Ale interpretation, always a winner. Just the right amount of creamy carbonation, and nice aroma. Mmm, hops...

On tap at the river market brewery. Pours a clear red with a light tan head that lingered for awhile. Pretty good lacing on the glass. Not a bad looking beer. The aroma, like most reds in my opinion, was tough to pick up, but what was there was some roasted nuts, caramel malts, and an evident amount of piny/breadlike hops. Compared to the other beers that this brewery makes, this was cleary the winner when it came to taste. It actually tasted like the brewer knew what he was doing. A sweet and grainy malt background finishing with a light bitter hop taste. Not a lot of lingering, but the balance was nice. Overall, nothing special, but damn better than anything else the river market offers.

Medium chestnut body with a yellowish khaki head. The aroma was walnuts and bread crust. The taste was roasted almonds with some caramel in the finish. There is barely a kiss of hops in this one even though they tout the hops in it. Meh.

Decent amount of caremel maltiness, sweetness upfront, with some nice hop charateristics up front, that kind of fade into the background, melding into a smooth nicely balanced bitterness combined with the bittersweet malts. Decent, easy drinking beer.
This is a deep amber/red beer. It presents a fair caramel malt basis, is smooth and lightly bittered. Slightly above average.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours dark amber with reddish overtones. The beer is cloudy from chill haze. Pretty good head retention. Very nice balance to this ale. Up front it is very hoppy, but then finishes with a malt sweetness. Toasted malt is pronounced. This is somewhat better than the Ska Pinstripe Red Ale. This beer deserves neither of the other two previous scores.
Decent Irish Ale. Nice color, similar to Killian’s. Little to no carobonation, which may have led to its sweeter than normal taste. Little hoppiness, with pleasant aftertaste.

Update: I'm not even sure this commercial description is accurate anymore, so different was the beer I sampled tonight from the previous tasting... Light aroma of sweet, caramel malt and a tad of hops. Head which quickly diminished to nothing, no visible carbonation. (No wonder either, the beer is basically flat.) Red color, clear. Some grainy maltiness and a bit of caramel sweetness, then a slightly spicy hoppiness creeps in. Watery palate, finish is not much to speak of. Way disappointing aspect of the revisit to this once fairly respectable brewpub. Original rating: A bit of tanginess at the start of this brew, with a nice hoppiness on the finish. Somewhat malty body. Not too bad; I've had better, though.

on tap at the river market brewery. pours a watery looking black with a small tan head. Decent amount of lacing. Aroma was more chocolate than roasty with some coffee and burnt malt hints. The flavor was extremely watered down with a real sour and acidic taste. Just a tad smoky, but thats about it. Pretty dreadful. Very light and lacking body, character, and taste. I was disappointed with this brewery.

Normally, I look forward to a subpar brewer’s porter. How can you mess up this pedestrian style? Well, River Market found a way. The body was black with ruby at the edges and a khaki head. The aroma was caramel and almond bark candy. There was also a little bit of light roasted coffee. The taste was light, watered down coffee with some hints of nasty hard raspberry candy. Very sweet finish like something I have never expereinced in a porter. Dreadful.

On tap at the brewpub Poured mostly black with a little bit of brown head. The aromas and flavor were pretty much the same. Chocolate and coffee, with some light roasted notes. A little bit hoppy. Medium body. Light carbonation. Roast dryness and a bit of creamy sweetness in the finish. This beer was pretty good. I drink it again.

This was a bit too astringent and roasty with above average carbonation to be really enjoyable. Has the right amoun tof roastiness, with some light coffee and chocolate notes, but not very well balanced with some bitter hoppiness in the finish.
Very black with a thin tan head. This is sweet and bitter at the same time with a hint of smoke but no real character that spoke to me.

On tap at the brewpub. mahogany black with reddish overtones when held in the light. Pronounced hazelnut aroma! Rich sweetness, smooth rich complex palate. Must have a high OG. This is an excellent porter.

Roasty American-style Porter. Semi-sweet chocolate and coffeeish maltiness, creamy head and body. Very dark in color, opaque. Scores extra points for not being served on nitrogen! Nice coffeeish, roasty, tangy flavor, slightly bitter and dry finish. Medium bodied. Great for a ’last beer’ at River Market or on the rare occasions where you can grab a bomber to go.

Bottle 500ml. shared @ BAF! 2018 [ Borefts After Festival ] @ Brouwerij Kaapse, Veerlaan 19-D, Rotterdam, Netherlands 3072 AN. [ As Schoune Ma P'tite Gueuze ]. ABV: 5.5%. Light unclear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wood, pale malt, sweet malt, horse blanket, barnyard, leather, farmyard, tart fruit - apricot - apple - citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and acidic with a long duration, tart, apple, apricot, sweet malt, farmyard, leather. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20180923] 7-3-7-3-15

Bottle shared at BAF thanks to the kermis. Bit hazy light golden with white head. Light lemon funk, hay, sour grains, light plastic, caramel, bready, light mineral, puke. Under medium sweet and sour. Medium bodied. Really not that bad at all.

Thank a lot to Kermis! Large bottle sampled. Orange golden. Some vinegar in the nose, lemon, rotting orange, lambiek-esque but bad lambiek with vinegar & rotting fruit. Taste is bit less lambiek with more sour plastic, lemon, watery, sour lemon, orange rind,… Watery plastic body. Bad as expected but not horribly bad. Calling this geuze is sad.

6 3 7 3 13 Bottle shared at Borefts After Festival ‘18.  Hazy golden with a white head.  Aroma of light funk, citrus, oak and malt.  Flavour is light to moderate sweet and sour.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

BAF! 2018. Bottle massive thanks to kermis! Unclear golden with white head. Sour grain, funky, apricot fruity edges. Sweaty and buttery. Moderate sweet and bitter, light sour. Medium body and soft carbonation.
Sampled @ BAF Rotterdam 2018. A almost clear golden colour, small white ring. Aroma of tart pale fruits, riped apples, brett. Taste of sour apples, brett, apricot, some vanilla. Thanks kermis!

Pours darker u clear blonde. Foam is gone within a second. Smell is tart ( lemon acid) bit plastic as well. Taste is sharp, dry tart ( lemon sour) intense lemon tartness, but it's gone immidiatly. Not very complex, no depth... I respect their attempt, but it's not even in the same ballpark as the real stuff.

The head builds up tall, thick and foamy. It is light tan in color and has good retention. As it slowly fades down to thin covering, which lasts until the end, it makes some slick spotty lacing on the glass. Under the head is a nice amber colored liquid with very good clarity. The aroma has a simple sweet floral hop bouquet. Its flavor has a mildly sweet malty body with nice floral and citrus hops that produce a soft mellow bitterness that balances the malt flavor well. The texture has a soft easy drinking feel with good carbonation and a medium body. It had an enjoyable flavor and an easy drinking body. Overall solid.
It would be hard for this beer not seem balanced as there’s next to nothing to it. Incredibly mild and watery.
Has the hop/malt balance of an ESB, too thin and a little watery for it to be a good ESB.

Poured into a pint glass. I have no doubt that this beer is going to suck, as just about everything Saranac makes does, but let’s see. 4.5 A: Looks great. Nearly three fingers of thick frothy head. Great retention and plenty of lacing. 3.0 S: Barely anything at all. A bit of floral hops, but that’s about it. 2.0 T: Where the hell is everything? There’s barely any taste at all. Worst of all is that the hop characteristics barely show up....and IN AN ESB! 2.5 M: Light body. Smooth because nothing’s going on. Terrible. 2.0 D: I’d drink this over BMC, but that’s about it. This beer is neither extra special or bitter. Once again Saranac has produced a great looking shitty beer. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 01-18-2009 01:31:20
Nice golden amber pour in the glass. Nose and taste of sweet bitter, light spruce and malts. Rated 12/20/2000

One thing I enjoy as a beer critic is getting to try new beers and especially new beer styles. You’d think I’d have drunk everything by now but the ESB style has eluded me until recently. Thanks to the Saranac “12 Beers of Winter” mix pack I can now say I’ve tried an Extra Special Bitter and I quite liked it. It seems to be something of a hybrid of a lager and a pale ale, plus it was tasty and easy to drink – seems like a good beer to me. POUR, COLOR AND AROMA Saranac ESB poured very smoothly to a dark red/copper color that was crystal clear and without much carbonation evident. It formed a white, fizzy head that didn’t last long but never completely evaporated, either. The aroma seemed like that of a generic mass-market lager but with a distinctive character of extra hops. I didn’t notice any citrus notes, but I was thankful for the hops instead of adjunct ingredients. TASTE Well, they don’t call it an Extra Special Bitter for nothing. As soon as the beer hit my palate, bitter was the first flavor I noticed. It was very similar to an India Pale Ale, the difference being there was no tart or citrusy underling flavor here. In fact, it’s quite dry, but I wouldn’t call it bland. Overall, the strong bitterness made up for what would otherwise be a fairly standard beer taste. FINISH Sometimes the tastier beers can be difficult to drink, especially if their taste is derived from bitterness. Such is the case for Saranac ESB which has quite a rough edge to it. The dry palate might make for a good taste, but it’s not proportional to the finish. Not that this is a challenge to drink, certainly not for the connoisseur, but a little smoother would have been nice. BODY It’s actually difficult to make an honest comment on this beer’s weight since neither its potency nor its number of calories is printed on the bottle and is not listed on the brewer’s website. Since it’s a very hoppy beer I’d estimate both statistics are quite high. I wasn’t overwhelmed by the beer, but it did feel quite heavy afterwards. FINAL THOUGHTS I don’t have any frame of reference to compare Saranac Extra Special Bitter against another beers of the style, so as a beer on its own I found it to be tasty, original and genuinely enjoyable. It’s not a perfect beer by any means, but it’s enjoyable and that’s what counts. NOTE: watch the video version of this review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CP5obF_1hfU

Light copper, almost gold. Very pale in color for an ESB. Whispy white head retains well. Not very aromatic but does have a musty, old chest hop aroma. Reminds me of an old dusty room. On the palate the body is rather thin and tepid in flavor. Not a very exciting ESB at all. Finish is short with some odd "off" flavors.

Dark orange, looks like a glass of clear honey. Solid English ale head, bubbly and light brown. Nice color, inviting. Very good toasted English malt aroma. Sweet and slightly nutty. Hop is ever so mild. Like a nice toasted, nutty English ale. An initial toasted malt, only slightly caramel sweetness. Woody hop comes in at the end. Good combo of sharp and soft bitters. Decent. Somewhat fizzy, creamy, with a little bite. A solid ESB. Sweetly bitter and very drinkable.
Overall Impression: Another beer you find in the Saranac mixers, and another decent example of its style...
Bottle. Pours a copper body with an off whit head. Bread y, grain y, light earth hoppiness floral hints bitter earth and a light malty body. Caramel malts, simple and decent.
Nice ballpark brew. Mellow and flavorful with a nice subtle chocolate aftertaste. Good beer for sipping while watching a ball game.
(Tap) cloudy, bright yellow colour with a small white head; aroma of lilies, balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish

On tap at brewery. Pours cloudy, milky, yellow with a white head. Aroma is banana and cloves. Flavor is light wheat and hint of oranges and coriander that are quickly taken over by banana and cloves. Yeasty finish.

Cloudy golden orange pour with a thin white head and very light lacing .... Aroma of clove, banana and orange with some coriander ..... Taste is of wheat and grainy with light notes of orange, banana and clove .... Finishes with flavors of wheat and orange/coriander ..... Sessionable and well done aroma smells better than the taste
Ordered the sampler tray with a friend and we both agreed that the Lancaster HEFE is the best Hefeweizen in Central PA. Earthy and full of flavor.
Very very cloudy orange appearance. Leaves a residue in the glass. Smells of oranges. Some herb, citrus. Good texture.
Everything you expect in a quality hefe is here- banana, clove, yeast. Hazy yellow with 1-finger head, slight spice in flavor. Good.

Pours a hazy honey/orange color with a medium white head. Aroma has light banana and spice. Flavor has nice clovey spice with touches of wheat and banana. Mouthfeel is full and lively with a dry slightly spicy finish.

Tan-gold, lightly hazy and with a silk cream top. Wheat nose with a nice mix of clove and banana. Well-developed body that strikes a perfect balance of wheat, clove, banana, and understated breadyness. Effervescent and crisp throughout. Sprightly and spicy on the tongue. Wonderful mouthfeel,
Hazy yellow pour with an aroma of grain, banana, and spice. Citrus flavor with banana, spice and grain finish. Lots of flavor with this one. Well done.
Draft. Strong clove aroma, light gold color, sweet taste, a little syrupy . Decent hefe but not one to run back to.
Sample at the brewpub. Light, bright ruddy orange, good lacing; citrusy, slightly nutty aroma...ringwood..more bitter than usual, not enough heft, ehhhh.
clear, copper-reddish color with a smooth light head that was slow to depart. Just a bit hoppy for a brown ale but that didn’t bother me at all.
Average, drinkable brown ale perfect for consuming in the warm weather months.
Light breadiness throughout. A bit watery. Lingering strong bitterness in swallow. Overly hoppy for a brown.

Slightly weak malty aroma with a hint of hops. Clear copper brown, with very little head. Light smooth carb in a medium-light body. Very hopped and bitter, almost like an IPA. Good nutty after. Very enjoyable beer, though I though a bit too bitter for the style.
a decent offering - light hops, slightly watery but refreshing. ............

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draught @ Barcade, Jersey City, New Jersey. Pours slight hazy brown with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, little caramel, light grainy, light grassy hops. Flavor is light sweet, malt, grain, hint of caramel, grassy hops. Medium body, average carbonation. A tad boring, but not infected. 230418

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: 22 ounce bottle. Hazy Amber orange color topped by a massive rocky beige head. Medicinal, caramel malt nose. Unusual, tart toasted malt flavor. A bit sour and funky. Not typical for the ESB style. Meh.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: [ Bottle ][ 2oz ][ Tasting ][ ][ Champagne Flute ][ 12.07.14 ] murky amber, fizzy white head laces well. Heavy chlorine nose, moderate sugar, lightly doughy. Ashy front palate, olive tomato through the end, oily with sugary balsamic. Am I eating a Greek salad? Off notes with sugar underneath and way overcarbonated.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Seems like this is old and not very well maintained. Pours orange with OK head and lacing. This is either off or not well brewed. Bottle from total wine.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Big thanks to Jecker aka Josh for this one. A - Pours out amber orange with a small one finger tall white head leaving light lace down the glass. S - Smells of doughy caramel malt, dulled grassy hops, toffee, and some faint citric fruit. T - Starts off with a big sweet caramel malt kiss slowly giving way to a mix of toffee and dulled out grassy hops. The malt really controls this one but it never really gets to the point of being overpowering. The finish is more sweet malt, lingering for some time. M - Medium-Light body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Very malty feel, lingering throughout consumption. O - I liked this one. It was very malt forward and it could have used a bit more hops to help even things out but it was still plenty enjoyable as is.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Unruly, bizarre aroma of latex paint, bubblegum, feet, cedar, and varnish. Clear amber, huge sticky off white head. Foam climbs out of the bottle from what was left behind from my pour. Vinegar and cedar, mold and moss. Ugh, something seems wrong here. It feels like an ambitious effort at greatness but fell short of mediocrity.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: (Bottle). My bottle must be a very bad batch. Even the slowest angled pour causes the foam to erupt and overflow the glass. The flavor is slightly sour and chalky mouthfeel. Drain pour. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Serving: Bottle from Total Wine Sterling. It pours a hazy amber color with a large, frothy, off white head. The nose is fruity and floral. It’s overcarbonated and prickly on the tongue. Sour vinegar flavors. Clearly infected. Drainpour.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Bottle. Pours amber gold with off white head. Nose and taste of sour grain, yeasty fruit, grapefruit peel, barley and baked bread. Slight infection. Light/medium body.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: 12oz bottle I picked up at Total Wine in Sterling. Pours a hazy, dark orange with some rocky, lacing, white head. Uh oh, aroma makes me nervous; stale cardboard, some dried lemon peel, rotting white grape. Whoa, flavor is definitely infected, strong grapefruit peel, cardboard, nettles. Trashy finish. Bad bottle maybe? Either way, drain pour. ***** Re-rate from December 2014. 12oz bottle pours a hazy orange with some foamy, white head. Nose of garbage, rotting tropical fruit, plastic, dust. Flavor has guava, mild pear, trashy though, hints of butyric acid, pixie sticks. Super carbonated, harsh finish. Worse than the first time I had this. 3-3-5-1-6.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: From a bomber. Pours a clear copper with a massive, long-lasting head. Weedy aroma. Flavors of grass and resin. Bitter finish.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: On tap while stuck in Newark. Diacetyl aroma apparent right away, in front of caramel malt, and lemon and strawberry accents. Almost clear amber under white wisps and collar. Sweet and moderate bitterness in the flavour leaves the balance towards sweet. Caramel and butterscotchy diacetyl dominate earthy, English hops. Medium body, moderate carbonation, smooth. Classic Ringwood beer that is likely to be misunderstood.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Cask at Uno’s Metuchen. Pours clear amber with a small, bubbly off-white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is toast, caramel, and cookie malt with earthy hops, dates and figs. Flavor is moderate hops and bitterness, light esters, cherry, and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: 12oz bottle. Pours a hazy burnt orange color with no head. Aroma of caramel, candied oranges, and slightly floral. Taste is caramel up front, followed by some sweet citrus fruit in the middle, and ends with a sharp piny bitterness.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Bottle. Nose biggest in caramel, sweet with fruit, hops, pours ruby-tinged golden with a large rocky beige head. Taste is very sweet with much lighter bitterness. Caramel and generic but very intense fruitiness, aggressive medium-full body. I can never tell with these homebrewish ales if they’re infected or just fermented weirdly, yeast is always out of control.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: For starters, I should have known better simply because the bottle cap is generic. If the brewery can’t afford to brand their bottle cap, how can they afford decent hops? Anyway, carefully pouring the beer into my mug resulted in half beer, half foam. I had to wait a good 10 minutes for the foam to settle before emptying the bottle. The beer itself has very little IPA flavor to it. Hardly a hint of hoppiness or bitterness. It reminds me more of a Blue Moon with the orange already squeezed into the bottle before it was even poured. This is the second time I’ve tried Climax IPA, six months from the first try, so it’s not a fluke. If you’re looking for a true microbrew IPA, don’t include Climax on your hit list.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draught at Rattle ´n Ham, NYC 120906. Amber a bit hazy beer wuth a offwhite head. Hoppy and herbal aroma and similar flavour.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: 12oz bottle. Explosive beige head atop hazy amber body. Aroma is medium sweet, spicy, some grapefruit/lemon, light bread, lemon/grapefruit rind. Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit/lemon, some orange, light bread. Effervescent medium body.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draught at Rattle&Hum, NYC. Cloudy golden/grey beer with a nice lasting offwhite head. Malty fruity hoppy aroma, grass, hay, floral, citrus, some pepper. Herbal citrus flavor, grassy, metal notes, fruity, grapefruit, banana notes. Decent without being special.

column2: Roselle Park, New Jersey, United States
column5: Bottle. I think my bottle must have been a bit too old -- foamed up pretty huge when I poured. Light brown to deep caramel color, tan frothy head. Taste is off -- a little astringent and coupled with high carbonation. I would try again just to see if this is an outlier.
Blossoming hop flowers behind a curtain of acid citrus fruit…Yeast and window cleaner whispering from afar…Still refreshing…
Belgian-style session ale, Chouinard is the same beer as Schoune Amber. A complex tartness is the signature, with peachy notes and a touch of bubblegum. A resample showed some spice as well.
Nice apple aroma and flavour. Not too strong. ............................

Had this beer on 8/1/2002. Color is a bright gold with good carbonation and nice head. Aroma is a light sweet malt scent. Taste is sweet and bitter. Starting with a light/medium body it goes down with a slightly rich feel and sweet flavor. It finished with an overly sweet malt flavor that is backed by a sudden bitterness. Its flavor is too heavy and rich for a summer brew.

Date: 12/07/2000 Mode: Bottle Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta yellow, light malt aroma, sligtly sweet malt flavor, no hops or bitterness, bland Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 2/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.2/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Cloudy orange with no head . flavor of sweet malt. aroma of malt. To sweet for me ..drainpour.

Slightly hazy golden yellow with a medium diminishing white head. Some floaties are present. Aroma of light bread, cereal, honey, creamed corn and a hint of lemon. Medium watery body with soft carbonation. Slightly musty flavor of honey, light bread, pepper, and adjunct related sweetness. Not good, not bad, I can see why it is now retired. Thanks to slikwily for this one!

A very, very, very small white head with fine sized bubbles that quickly diminished. The body was mostly transparent with soft carbonation and a pale yellow hue. The nose was lightly malty, sweet, citrus notes and fruity. The flavor was very flat, bland and boring with a sweet and light fruitiness. The mouthfeel was smooth, watery and thin making for a light textured beer with very sparse lacing. Not a beer that I will recommend.

This bottled brew poured a very small longlasting head of fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that left behind a carbonated slightly hazy yellow colored body and a good lace. The aroma ia a mild malt dough. The mouthfeel is smooth and tingly with a flavor of malty fruit like apricot.

Pours a light yellowy color with a thin white head. Aroma and flavor are lightly hoped and have a touch of citrus. Cute artwork on the label, but the beer is pretty bad. You can almost always tell when you pour a yellowy beer that it isn't going to be good.
8/1/03: bottle. light pils aroma. golden yellow body. very watery with a lemon-citrus flavor.

Light yellow body with a quickly dissipating white head. No lacing. Smells like corn and other adjuncts. A tiny bit of yeast is behind that corny nose. A little bit of that corny flavor with a hint of yeast in the flavor. Very thin and bland.. Smooth on the palate but had an odd mouthfeel.

Pale straw color,small white head that faded super fast.Wheat aroma maybe a mild malt presence,mild hops maybe a slight spice to it along with a mild fruit accent.Very mild taste,mild malt,mild wheat with a sweetness to it.the fruit doesn't really come through to well,the same with the hops.The after taste is mild at best with a definate sweet tone that is mostly malt and maybe citrusy the feel is like water.I don't know but this brew almost seems to try to be a lot of different styles but doesn't quite fit anything other then a wheat beer IMO.A nice brew to try once but not worth having any more then that.
(cask) clear, bright, dark orange brown colour with a small beige head; aroma of toffee; balanced flavour, bit weird and chemical, long light bitter finish

On tap at the brewpub, Andy Ricky PJ Andrew R. Dark pour and little/no head. Overall impression is that it’s a good scotch ale, but lacking a bit of the sticky tar-molasses-sugary quality that makes the style a treat to me. On the right track just a tad underdone and mellow. Still enjoyed much.

[6700-20140823] Tap. Toasted fig fruit and mild woody plastic aroma. Hazy, dark roan red brown body with a quick foamy tan head. Earthy mineral toasted grains flavour has a boozy fruity cherry overtone. Medium-full body. Good but my expectations were high. (7/3/7/3/16) 3.6 (Tap Takeover Event @ Volo, Toronto, ON)

[Draught at the brewpub, Sep.21] Pours a cloudy deep amber with no head. Aroma is smoky and malty along with dark fruit, some maple syrup and toffee. Nice flavour, malty, fruity and a bit smoky along with some hops in the finish. Medium bodied, almost oily mouthfeel. Love it!
sample at Festbiere in Quebec City, solid scotch ale. rich maltiness, earthy peat, wisp of smoke, caramel/toffee richness. very well made scotch
Smooth rich scotch on tap at bar volo. Reddish orange with some peat character. Smooth.

Pours a ripe copper color with gaseous eggshell foam. Lots of sweet maple, toffee flavors upfront that gain complexities of salted caramel, toasted malt, vanilla and a kiss of smoke. A touch flat making the body a little more sticky than Id like but still a delicious beer !
On tap at Dieu du Ciel. Very smooth. Pours a dark solid brown. Little on the nose. Nice ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @ DDC (Montréal). Reddish amber with no head and no lacing. Aroma is of butterscotch with light moked notes and light fruits. Taste is slightly sweet and about the same as aroma. Medium body. Low carbonation. Good Scotch Ale, but the lack of carbonation didn’t help and it as somewhat bland and boring.

Draft at Blind Tiger with Streets and the RB crew. Pours a deep hazy amber body with light lacing. Aroma is sweet caramel, spice and sweet booze. Mouthfeel is medium to syrupy with sweet notes of caramel, touches of vanilla and alcohol.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Rigor Mortis Tripel
column5: on tap on the premises - mtl location. hazy medium dark golden pour, light orange tint, with a creamy white head offering good retention and lacing. big doughy fruity maltiness, lots of phenols, overly tender peaches, floral honey sweetness - controlled level; citrus zest/skin, bitter grass, warming alcohol, woodsy vanilla traces, obvious very fruity trappist-like yeast. moderately high carbonation, medium body - oily; sweetish, warming and spicy-grassy finish. genuine tripel with an american hoppy angle. another one worthy in the rigor mortis series. enjoyed!

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Rigor Mortis Tripel
column5: Tap at DDC. Hazy amber-orange with good off-white head. Extremely well drinkable despite the 9.1%. Carbonation perfect. Caramelly, alcohol well disguised and luckily without any residual sweetness. Sweet, fruity, yeasty. So smooth. Excellent brew.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Rigor Mortis Tripel
column5: On tap at brewpub. A veiled orange golden with a short lived white head. Aroma is honey, grains, orchard fruits. Flavor is orchard fruit, sugar, honey, peach syrup. Finish is lemon, vanilla, peppery, minty. Very long-lasting lingering flavors. Medium to full body, average carbonation.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Rigor Mortis Tripel
column5: "this was a cool beer...very flavorful. complex spices and yeast. quite good, with a warming alcohol presence, although not overwhelming. i’d drink this often if more available."

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Solstice d'Été aux Framboises
column5: 0,341 l bottle from Malmö Systembolaget. Best Berliner Weisse what I ever tasted! Thnx to Canadian brewers!

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Solstice d'Été aux Framboises
column5: great juicy flavor that lasts a nice long time. carbonation is perfect. very enjoyable

If you expect something like a Guiness or Murphy’s you might be disappointed ... however this brew does stand a right on it’s own ... dark brown (not opaque though) pour with a not very firm head, a smell of chestnuts and herbs and taste of cooked peas mixed with dried fruits, only little bitterness in the palate .... interesting brew, albeight not a classic ...
Slightly passive stout. good color but lacks authority & true stout taste. Only slightly above average.
very dark brown colour, nice head, fine lace, coffee and herbal aroma, smooth, quite malty, long bitter aftertaste
Tap @ Heartland Empire State. Dark brown. Roasted malts, coffee, burnt coffee beans, not sure if I got the honey, but pretty ok.

Draught @ Heartland brewery and chophouse - 43rd street. Pours very dark brown with a creamy brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, light cocoa, honey. Flavor is light sweet, malty, caramel, chocolate, honey, little wood. Medium body, soft to average carbonation, light sweet finish. 210418

On tap at HB Burger, NYC on 09-Mar-2017. Dark brown colour with a creamy beige coloured head. Aroma is sweet with roasted malt and coffee. Medium body and carbonation. Taste is slightly sweet with chocolate, coffee and malt. Lightly hopped and sweet smooth milk chocolate finish.

Draught at Heartland Empire State Building, NYC. Black beer with a nice beige head. Roasted chocolate and coffee aroma, caramel, fruity, licorice, tobacco notes. Roasted coffee and dark chocolate flavor, licorice, raisins, soot, some cocoa powder. Nice coffee and roast finish.
Wenig süßer, angenehm schokoladiger Antrunk mit mild herbem Hintergrund. Mild nach Espresso, erdig, Vanille. Gelungen! 11/10/11/11//11

On tap. Heartland really knows its dark beers with the stout and this porter. Great chocolate, brown sugar and molasses taste. Had a nice medium creamy body. It finished off perfect with the honey sweetness. Probably one of my favourite porters.

Keg Pint at Heartland, Empire State Building, New York in March 2013 - Dark Reddish-Brown in colour. Malty; roasty malts, chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, coffee, nuts, some liquorice, hint of honey. Lightly spiced. Sweetish roast malty and fairly dry throughout. Very drinkable. Decent.
5oz sampler from the brewpub NYC. Pours black with a small creamy tan head. Aroma of black malt, licorice, and sweet honey. Taste of strong licorice, honey, black roasted malt, and dark chocolate.

On tap at the brewpub on 43rd Street. Pours dark brown with beige, long lasting head Aroma is of nutty, toasted malt, dark fruit, hints of coffee and chocolate Body is medium and smooth Taste is of nutty, toasted malt, dark fruit, brown sugar, chocolate hints of herbal hops and of coffee. Finish is medium and semi-dry. Nice porter.

Dark mahogany red, thick, pillowy head with good retention and lacing. Aromas of molasses, caramel, honey, and a bit of carmelized/burnt sugar. Honey is stronger in the taste than it was in the smell. Toffee and caramel flavors are also evident, but the sweetness from the honey wins out. Medium to full bodied, good carbonation and a lingering sweetness.
On tap at the scholars lounge. Not really bad but not my thing. I may drink it again if nothing else

On tap, half pint. Golden clear beer with a bubbly white head. Sparkling look, in fact this is a gassy one. Strange nose, not inviting. Aroma has some malts, corn and syrup, but lots of cork, chemical stuff and alcohol. Watery and carbonated body, poor stuff but and the booze came up incredibly quick.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Cuvée de l'Alchimiste 03
column5: Flowery hops and peaches in honey…Light and refreshing… .....

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Cuvée de l'Alchimiste 03
column5: Agree with Kaya, not a lot of hops here - just a touch of citric character and seems out of focus.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Cuvée de l'Alchimiste 03
column5: This is their interpretation on a Westcoast pale ale, but it is clearly not. Only mildly bitter with no real hop flavour.

Fruitiness and grassy citrus tones to the aroma. Clear golden body with low white head that recedes to ring. Fruity up front with some light bitterness and a metallic aftertaste. Light body with strong carbonation. Bottle. Entered from notes.

Mysteriously found this in a Montreal grocery store, must be a few years old. Cloudy (with lots of sediments)Brownish amber with an initially big off-white head that doesn't survive the chalice test. Light aroma of mild herbal hops and malty orange. Rather sweet malt with a notably short finish, dry and slightly bitter, but noticeably short-lived, with a hint at cardboard, a little overcarbonated for a belgian too. Not worth keeping up any longer.
Golden colour with a whitish head. Aroma of hop and malt. Hoppy sweet bitters.
Fruit with yeast aroma, cloudy peach colour, small head. Grapefruit flavour, nicely bitter, acidic. Good.
Nice fresh, fruity yeasty aroma. Quiet pleasant. Slightly parfumy , medicine . Strange mouthfeel and aftertaste . I think that this brew will not please everyone. (Spice).
Gold. White head. Caramel, apples, & peaches on the nose. Medium feel. Sweet caramel flavour w/ vanilla finish.

Clear golden colour with a thick dense off-white head. Sweet smell, a bit of malt and no hops. Medium-bodied; Subtle flavours, a bit of sweetness but not much else. Aftertaste sweet and shows a bit of depth with some malt. Overall, worth trying but don't expect too much. A decent Belgian single, and a great end to a nice evening! I sampled this beer at Joey_Capps' on 13-September-2003 in Hamilton, Ontario.
Hazy golden yellow wth tiny white head. Nice malt flavour, funny aftertaste. Need to re-rate, this was the last one of the evening.

hazy deep goldwn, white head. malt and caramel apples on the nose with a whiff of alcohol which seems strange for a beer of only 5.5%abv. sweet and malty with hints of apple and peach. finishes dry with a little burnt sugar in the finish.
Nice golden colour. Aroma of apples, caramel, citrus. Flavour of apples, slight malt, sweet. Finishes with a hoppy bitterness.
